GLADSTONE O n $ HW* EX.

PUBLISHED DAILY.

THUUSDAV, JUNE 4, 1874.

THE Government arc '? meeting Mr.

FITZGERALD'S constant reiteration of

northern grievances by publishing elabo- rate statistics, prepared with great skill, and proving incontestably to the unin- itiated reader that the northern portion

of the colony is being pampered with ! lavish expenditure. If certain returns

just laid before Parliament lie believed, | the public expenditure on ordinary

revenue account lo the northward of

Cape Palmerston was last year at the rate of £6 los. iod. per head of the

population, while to the southward of j that point it was only at the rate of £3

2s. 7<i. This, however, is exclusive of j interest and expenses of the department,

which items being taken into account ! leave the comparative expenditure as follows :-North of Cape Palmerston at the rate of 12s. 7d. per head; south,

jQ6 4s. yd. per head. These figures 1 appear sufficiently startling, and no doubt the hope is that they will effectually silence the northern members. But we i shall be much mistaken if this be the case, for a little examination of the TREASURER'S figures shows that in this

case they do not tell the whole truth, j

The total amount paid last year as

interest upon the public debt and, on account of sinking fund, is shown ! to have been ^248,173. Of this j however, only ¿JiSSG was for loan moneys actually spent in the north, while j .-£152,753 was on accountofloan moneys I

spent in the south. But no less than

¿93,498 was absorbed in interest upon j

loans of general account, and of this the north is charged with its full share, whereas nearly the whole of the amount should have been debited lo the south. For example, there was a loss of ,£209,977 incurred in negociating the

various loans of the colony, but, seeing I that thc north scarcely participated at all in the expenditure of those loans, it cannot bc fairly charged with a pro rata share in the interest upon the deficit. However, it must be admitted that lhere has been rather a large expenditure in the matter for the past year or two, and that lhere is much less reason for complaint on this head now than formerly. Thc late Government, although failing to pass

their Financial Separation Bil!, succeeded | in apportioning thc public expenditure with a kind of rough justice which ought to have secured for them the gratitude instead of the ill-will of the northern people, whose representatives have, strangely enough, since thrown in their lot with a party whose policy it has always been to deny justice to the north. Taking the TREASURER'S figures as they stand there is little ground for complaint,

but when it is recollected that the revenue contributed per head by the adult males of the north is largely in excess of the mixed population of the south the sub- ject wears a different aspect. The return, therefore, ts really not of much value, especially when it is remembered that the Wide Bay and Burnett and the Central Districts are thrown in with the south, and thus keep down the ratable expenditure per head for the whole of that part of the colony lying lo the southward of Cape Palmerston. There is nothing in the figures just published to disprove the fact that apart from the large expenditure on departmental account in the metropolitan districts, they also have managed to secure far more than their proportionate share of the moneys available for local purposes. The return prepared under Mr. PAI.MKR'S Financial Separation Bill is conclusive on this point, and we shall prefer those figures to the cleverly-prepared tables on which the TREASURER attempts to prove his case, and to make the public believe that thc sooner Separation at Cape Pal- merston is accomplished the better for the districts to the south of that point.

TiiKUK wiva an excellent house at the Theatre Royal last night, when the sensational drama of "East Ly imo " was repeated, Miss. Gougonhcim of course playing the characters of Litli/ Isabel Carlyle and Madams Vine. The artiste was as successful with her im- personation of tho difficult and arduous characters as she was on tho previous cvcuini;, and deep were thc expressions of applause that escaped from time to time from tho breasts of tho really affected specta- tors when souic expression of remorse and agony more intense than usual was forced from the woman whose jealousy the author liai linde tn rival even that ot Othello. Tho jealous but honorable Moor of Venice took human life, the Lndg Isabel Carlyle <li.I something more revolting, and was adequately punished. Mr. Dumar played the character <if .VIVI CarurHir Carlyle, owing to thc ¡Unos of Madame Laporto, and played it very well indeed-fur a mm Hut Mi-is Cornelia Carlyle, although stiff and exacting from thc inlirmities

of agc and her brother's indulgence, was .1 ¡ gentlewoman, and not a feminine buffoon. There eau be no question but that Mr. Dumar

played the character as well as his appearance ¡ and knowledge of ladies' ways permitted him. The drama was eminently successful, and will be performed this «venins hy special request, as a glance at our advertising columns will show. Thc evening's entertainment was

brought to a close hy thc amusing farce of j " Slasher aud Crasher. " |

WITH WHICH in iNCORmiiTrn THU

GLADSTONE OUSEUVKit.

PUBLISHED DA.ILY.

MONDAY, MARCH 2, 1874.

Junoixo hy thc grave complaints of tlis

franchisemenl that were heard in all

quarters during the late general election, the suffrage is much valued in Queens- land. Hut judging by the carelessness usually evinced when the new electoral rolls are in preparation, the grievance of

which so much is heard from election-

eering platforms, is little else than a sentimental one. livery year, as the time for revising the roll and for adding new names to it comes round, the Press takes up the cry, " Register! Register!" and most industriously impresses upon the public the necessity of a full and free exercise of their political privileges. Yet in very many cases the qualifiée! citizen deems the labour of regis- tration too great to be encountered, and prefers to remain amongst the numerous class of non-electors rather than devoto an hour or two to making good his qualification. For he it re- membered, the claim has lo be made and substantiated but once, and the elector's name is afterwards transferred to the new

roll year by year. Of course it is requisite tiiat he should keep a watch upon the preliminary lists each year, and par- ticularly so on an occasion like the last,

when the re-distribution of electorates

and the consequent splitting of rolls led to many great mistakes. Bul redistri- bution is a rare occurrence, and the elector usually finds that, once duly placed on a roll, his name permanently remains there. Looked at in this light, the trouble caused by our system of self-registration is a difficulty which no

man of common sense should rank

among political grievances. If, however, as »ve witnessed last year, impediments are thrown in the way of registration which were never contemplated by the Legislature, the disfranchised citizen bas cause for legitimate complaint, and it behoves all public-spirited colonists to insist, at the proper time, that the law shall hereafter be interpreted in an enlightened and liberal spirit. The Elections Act of 1872 was manifestly intended to be an enfranchising statute, and therefore in case of doubt as to its interpretation on technical points,

the scale should be turned in favour of

the applicant, lt is notorious that some of the Revision Cout ts in this part of the colony acted in a manner directly the opposite of this last year, and conse- quently that numbers of our most worthy colonists were improperly pre- vented from exercising their statutory rights.

To-day the quarter of the year begins during which applications for enrolment may be forwarded to the clerk of petty sessions. These must be sent, not as in former times lo the nearest clerk, but lo one whose office is within the boundary

of the electoral district in which

enrolment is desired. As is pretty well understood now, the application must be accompanied by a solemn declaration of correctness, made before some magis- trate of the territory, who in turn is required to certify that " to thc best of my knowledge and belief the same is correct." Having done so much, how- ever, the applicant must not rest satisfied that he mil be duly enrolled as an elector. He should either personally or by deputy examine the preliminary list hung up at the Police Office for public inspection during the first fortnight in July, and if his name be omitted, at once lodge a complaint in writing with the Clerk of Petty Sessions. And further, to prevent mistake, the elector should, if possible, appear either personally or by attorney at

thc revision court held under the statute

during the month of August. As is well known, some of the revision courts held last year were very incredulous, for not even a solemn declaration, with its correctness certified lo by a magistrate, was lield tobeasalisfactory proof of claim, in the absence of vivó, voce testimony. The slightest default in supplying " dates, places, areas, and values," was held to vitiate the application, and by at least

one revision court the Act was so mis- interpreted that thc personal attendance of the applicant was in all cases insisted upon. H was under such ruling that the applications of some twenty-two residents of Cowarral were rejected by the St lawrence revision court; and even in Rockhampton, under the presidency of a District Court judge, thc slightest omission of date, place, area, or value, was i held fatal to the application, unless the

defect »vere made good to the satisfaction of the Court by oral sworn testimony.

It may be hoped that Mr. MACALISTER, j profiling by thc experience of last year,

will endeavour to prevent such hair- J splitting on the next occasion. The ! intention of thc statute clearly is that

thc application, strengthened by a i solemn declaration certified to by a justice of the peace, should be, units» objected to, satisfactory proof of claim. The Act states that "thc declaration " attached to any notice of claim shall " be taken as prima facie evidence of thc qualification claimed." So (ar, thcefore, the Act is man- datory, and surely the court, having such evidence before it, cannot also reasonably demand oral sworn testimony, except perhaps in cases where there is some reasonable doubt as to the bona'fules of the applicant.

It may here be well to caution appli-

cants that much more care and cxacthess

is requisite in claiming under a property qualification, than under the " six months' residence." It has been held, for example, that in claiming under a leasehold, thc date and duration of thc lease must be particularly staled; and ¡tis not sufficient to describo thc property merely foridentificalion. Theprecisearea, it would appear, may and has been insisted upon ; and it may be presumed that without the saving words "more or less," the most exact applicant in this respect may find himself disfranchised. Jt is nothing to aver thal the statute never

intended such technical exactness. A

judge by habit is

» * » a great critic

Profoundly skilled in analytic ; He can distinguish alni divide

A hair 'twixt smith ami south-west

side."

And his decision in the revision court

must, so far as the applicant is concerned, bc accepted as final. In the interpreta- tion of a statute the united grasp of half-a dozen non-legal minds does not weigh a hair against the dictum of onctraincd one. Hence a whole posse of magistrates, sitting in a revision court with " His Honor," have practically no higher functions than to give local information .and twiddle their thumbs. Under these circumstances, the applicant is recom- mended to seek enrollment, whenever practicable, under the residential qualifi- cation, as the simplest and most certain method of attaining the status of an elector of the colony.

It is extremely doubtful whether the present or any other electoral law will work satisfactorily while administered with the technical exactness of a legal tribunal. The claimant under a property qualification, for example, can ordinarily only ensure success by either giving his personal attendance, or incurring the ex- pense of employing a legal gentleman to prepare his application. Not one lay- man in a hundred seems competent to carry out with technical strictness this provision in the Election Act, and few persons so value the suffrage as to wil- lingly pay a legal fee for the privilege. If, then, we would have all impediments to registration removed, it will perhaps be wise lo adopt the language put by

SnAKiiSPKKi; into the mouth of one of his characters

"Thc first thing we <lo, let's kill all thc lawyers "

metaphorically, of course. In other words, let legal strictness and formality be dispensed with. Let the revision court bc recommended to be satisfied with reason- able proof, and not absolute proof, that applicants possess the qualifications under which they claim. Were such a course adopted, we should hear no more of the complaint that the Elections Act of 1872 is a disfranchising statute. We believe thc grievance under notice might be easily remedied, by the Government. Were a circular letter addressed by the

COLONIAL SI-XRKTAUV to thc various benches of magistrates, pointing out thal (he design of the Legislature in requiring the declaration before a magistrate was to obviate the necessity of personal attendance, we believe the direction would be hailed as an opportune relief from embarrassment at the ensuing revision courts. Otherwise, in the face of a judge's decision, magistrates can hardly be expected lo give that liberal interpretation to the law which the legislature certainly intended it to bear.

There are other defects in the present electoral law, but most of them might be remedied without fresh legislation, livery clerk of petty sessions, for instance, might be required to give or send by post a receipt for each applica- tion, which receipt should empower a revision court to add thc omitted name to the electoral roll. The labour involved in this innovation would be small were printed receipt-books pro- vided, and il would silence the frequent complaint that applications are clandes- tinely disposed of. If the Government are really anxious to facilitate registra- tion, they may do so by treating the

unworkable details of the Act as the late Government thought lit lo treat the provision in regard to the numbering of electors' rights-as merely directory, not mandatory. They might thus deal with the objectionable foot-note to the application form, which has been held to give a restrictive interpretation to the text of the Act, quite foreign to its obvious scope and intention.

We had intended to discuss the ad- vantages and disadvantages of thc elec- tors' rights' system, but must reserve consideration of that subject for another opportunity.

Thu jurors and witnesses jiro rui|tiircil to give their attendance at thc < <mrt House to- day at thc usual time, hut in tito altseucc of Mr. District Judge Hirst thc Registrar, Mr. F. X. lieddek, wilt adjourn thc Court from day to «lay until His Houor arrives.

A OJIAIITRB-I'ASK of brandy was picked ii]) 011 Curtis Uland one day last week hy nonie <if thc men employed on Mr. Praed's .Station. It muid not have been long ill tho water, n» when found it was o,"itc free from barnacles or sca-wccil. Our informant docs not 6tate what bceamc of this w if and stray.

PUBLISHED DA.[L,Y. j

MONDAY, SEPTEMBKlt 7, ISlii \

1 THB Customs Revenue from tin Jst'totliti j

5tU September inclusive was £792 15s. od- |

Tm: people of Bundaberg aro somewhat j alarmed at tuc prospect of thc Queensland, «., I giving their port thc go-by, and being sen red ' by a diminutive craft which has just ani\ rcd at Maryborough, and is intended to i -uu between that port and Bundaberg. A ratl ter large trade in maize is carried on betwe cn bundaberg and ltockhainpton, ami under t he new arrangement the producers will have to «bip from Uundabcrg via Maryborough, tin >s increasing the cost of freight, and causii lg delay and uncertainty. It mayr bc hoped th st thc A. S. N. Company will take tho matt cr into consideration amt endeavour to give t' je Bundaberg people every possible facility f or shipping produce northward. The time is fast approaching when Bundaberg will bc . ut important port, and thc company will thci c fore lind its trade worth cultivating.

THE blacks aro making themselves troub1 c Bomc again, in the more settled districts, fia

I well as ou thc Palmer diggings. Oar telegva] ih I columns state that they have hilled three nu ai

on St. Anne's station, which is situated on tí ie Lower Ilulyaudo Uiver, near tile Cape, < hi

Saturday Captain Holman, who is now in j Rockhampton, received a telegram from «nie of his men, stating that thc blacks attacked tb ic miners at nine o'clock that morning, and r c »mesting him to send a message to the poli cc to order them off, or the men would not sto p.

JJy a new track just «pened, the distance to j

thc copper minc is twenty miles from t bo Westwood Kail way Station, and as the road . is good, thc item of carriage will bc a small ? DUO with the Company. Captain Hobnail info rms us that the danger from blacks is not by any means imaginary, as about 200 of them had

massed there before he ¡eft. I

GLADSTONE OBSKURER.

PUBLISHED DA-ILV.

FRIDAY, JULY 31, 1874.

AWKWARD problems frequently meet with unexpected solutions. On Thurs- day evening when the Rockhampton . Jockey Club committee finally deter-

mined that the races should conic off as

advertised, almost everyone, saving the

owners of certain horses, regretted the ; necessity. It was clearly apparent that even if the rain ceased immediately after the meeting, the racecourse must be quite in an unfit state for running upon, and that, barring accidents, thc strongest and not the fleetest horses

must win. Dut it was not a matter in which ardent sportsmen alone seemed doomed to disappointment. The public,

who subscribe to the funds of the | Jockey Club, and who look forward

to the race time as a general i holiday, would have found no enjoy- ¡ ment in seeing horses canter through < a sea of mud, while the course generally, \ and the vicinity of the stand and booths

particularly, were a complete bog. Mode- ' rately fmc weather and a sound turf are < essential to the enjoyment of race days ? by the general public, for in truth the ? majority of visitors go to see the happy i

and well-dressed crowd rather than to !

witness the triumphs of horses and ' jockeys. The races supply an object ' and pretext for a day's outing at the time of year when thc weather is usually

all that could be desired. To the , majority, however auspicious the sun might have shone out yesterday, the condition or the ground was such as to preclude all hope of pleasure,

cither at the racecourse or on picnic \ excursions elsewhere. While, there- , fore, the decision of the Stewards ] was accepted as in conformity with law, , it was felt to bc an unfortunate necessity , that the races could not be postponed. ¡ So that, when the flood rains set in < yesterday morning, and rendered thc ? . carrying out of the programme a physical :

impossibility, most people felt that all ¡ was for the best. Thc gloominess of the

.weather, and the steady deluging rain, ¡ were depressing, no doubt, but such a

state of affairs was better than a Scotch ' mist, or even than occasional heavy ' showers. The Stewards, with their usual 1 good judgment, took care that no exeep- ' lion should reasonably bc taken to their

proceedings, and a quorum was told off 1 lo bc in attendance at the grand stand al ' the advertised hour, and start any horses thal might put in an appearance. The

precaution was wise, bul the pouring rain, ' as it turned out, made allendince quite j unnecessary. Al lim appointed hour the . Stewards were punctually at their post, r but ¡¡ot a single racehorse pul in an ;. appearance, and therefore all chance of j litigation in consequence of postpone- t mein was quite swept away. The down- , pour was too heavy even fur those v

owners who, having powerful nags, believed they could win the slakes through a mile or two of bog, and, as already stated, the very awkward problem as to thcÄcpedicncy of a postponement has Jv> satisfactorily solved without the aow>f resolutions and lawyers.

The proceedings of the Committee at their subsequent meeting ought to give universal satisfaction. They postponed the races until Wednesday and Thursday next, by which time, it may be hoped, the heavens will have given forth their superfluous fatness, and the waters receded from this part of the earth. The resolution, too, which provides that I ages, weights, and entries shall stand as

already determined upon, cannot be objected to. Indeed, it is the only j possible arrangement without inflicting I great injustice. Whether it is in strict

accordance with racing law or not, we arc unable to determine, but it is certainly in strict accordance with equity. The cause of postponement was wholly beyond human control, and owners of horses ought not to suffer penalties in consequence. The choice of the Alexandra Park course, too, is wise. Tlie club's own course will be in a worse condition for running next Wednesday than it is to-day, and unless the Committee had agreed to a postponement of at least a fort- night, the races, if on their own course, would not have been a success. Alexandra l'ark, however, being near the river bank, and naturally well drained, will probably be in fair condition within a week, and it is obviously for the interest of all concerned to make the postponement as brief as possible.

On the whole, there is reason to hope that the meeting will, after all, be a success, and that thc non-racing public -a not insignificant minority-will be afforded the opportunity of spending a pleasant two days' holiday under a bright sky, and in such manner as they may think most agreeable. The greatest sufferers will be our visitors, especially those who have brought horses from distant places, and have other engage- ments-to fulfil. Hut there is always a glorious uncertainty about racing pur- suits, and those who follow them are generally well drilled to bear disappoint-

ment.

GLADS TO ¿ViP OBSERVES.

PUBLISHED DAILY-.

MONDAY, JULY G. 1874.

THE correspondence respecting the re- moval of Mr. H. C. STANLEY from the office of Chief Engineer of the Southern and Western Railways has now been published. It sheds some light upon the action taken by the Government in the matter, but it cannot be deemed entirely

satisfactory, either by the friends of Mr. ] STANLEY or the public at large.

The correspondence begins with a letterfrom Mr. A. O. HERBERT, Commis- sioner for Railways, dated 9th April, 1874, to Mr. STANLEY, informing him by desire of the Secretary for Public Works, that he (Mr. STANLEY) had been suspended from the position of Chief Engineer of the Southern and Western Railway, pending the decision of the Government as to his competency. In another letter of same date, Mr. J. ?THORNLOE SMITH, is addressed as Act- ing Chief Engineer, and requested to take charge of die department On the following day Mr. STANLEY writes to the head of his department expressing sur- prise, as during a period of eight years that he had been connected with the railway, he had never incurred censure or blame on any occasion. He also requests to be be informed of the specific grounds upon which the charge of in- competency is based, in order that an opportunity of self-defence may be afforded. On the 21st, Mr. STANLEY again wiles, reminding the COMMIS- SIONER FOR RAILWAYS that no reply had been received to his letter of the 10th instant, pointing out that the fact of sus- pension is likely to do him very serious injury in his profession as an engineer, and urging that an early reply may be accorded. This elicits a reply on the 27th April, inviting Mr. STANLEY'S attention to the fact that the letter of the 9th instant does not charge him with incompetency but intimates that his competence as Chief Engineer was questioned by the Government upon the following grounds :

Firstly.-That in such capacity you lcd thc Government to believe that a line of railwav

could bo constructed from Brisbane to Ipsnicl for thc sum of £8000 per mile, which bj estimates (BO called) subsequently prepared bj you, is computed to cost £319,000.

Secondly.-That although you did no1 probably suggest the system of small contracts still it was under your advice and approva that the Government had evidently acted ii carrying ont these works-a system which except under very extraordinary am exceptional circumstances, must bc vcr] expensive in the hands of the (Joven! ment, as, in fact, it bas actually proved in thi

present case.

Thirdly.-That having advised the Govern ment to carry on thc works by this systen of email contracts, you, in tho actual carryin] out of such system, have departed from you own propositions and the instructions of th Government in such a way as to destroy in 1 groat degree thc check thc Government migli have had upon tho cost of the works, and th proper expenditure of public money provide

for the same.

To this letter Mr. STANLEY replies 01 the 29th of April, averring that m estimate was ever prepared or furnishei by him showing thc probable cost of th whole line at £8ooo per mile, an* denying that he ever led the Goverr ment to suppose that it could b constructed for that sum. He also add that when the original loan vot of £192,000 was passed, no estimât whatever of the total cost of the line ha been furnished by him, and gives detail ; of his first estimate, submitted som months subsequently, showing thc tot: I cost of thc line, including i>35,y73 fi i thc Ipswich deviation, would t

£286,875 X4S. nd. To which he adds £32J54I for widening the Oxley Bridge, and for extra cost of steel rails, bringing : the total estimate up to £319,417. But a further increase became apparent after- wards on the detailed estimates, in consequence of the advance in iron and labour, bringing up the grand total to £349,000. Mr. STANLEY continues to point out that the system of small contracts having been adopted by the Government, it became his duty to carry out their views in the best way to make the system efficient He declares that tlie works carried out by him will

bear favourable comparison, both as to j character and cost, with similar works hitherto executed on any of Ute Queens- land railways. And he concludes by hoping that, under the circumstances, the SECRETARY FOR PUBLIC WORKS will be pleased to take such steps as may remove any stigma which the suspension may attach to his professional reputation as an engineer.

On the 5th May, Mr. HERBERT, in reply, addresses a letter, directing Mr. STANLEY'S attention to his report of 15th March, 1873, in which the estimated cost of a portion of the line is shown at " at £7796 lös. per mile, including " works, permanent way, materials, " and maintenance for twelve months, " but not engineering superintendence " or purchase of land." Mr. HERBERT next refers to the following passage in the same report :-" I must, however, " point out that this is hardly a fair i " criterion of the probable average cost

f " per mile of the line, as this section

" embraces universally heavy bridge " works, including two large viaducts " over the Bundanba and Six-mile " Creeks." He then goes on to say that the MINISTER FOR PUBLIC WORKS

presumes the late Government acted upon some professional advice in esti- mating the cost of the line at £8000 per mile in the Loan Estimates before Parliament in July, 1872, and it was improbable that in seeking such advice they would pass over their Chief Engineer. Another point adverted to by Mr. HERBERT in this letter is that Mr. STANLEY was instructed by the late Go- vernment to prepare and submit detailed estimates showing the cost of the works on the several sections before such works were gone on with. This, he says, was, in fact, the basis of the small contract system, and the only check which the I Government had on the Chief Engineer,

j But this was not done. In conclusion

Mr. HERBERT says :

I am further to observo that tho Secretary for Public Works has no intention of casting any stigma upon your professional reputation, so far as thc designs of the work on the Brisbane Railway arc concerned : on thc contraray, he has plcasuro in expressing again his cordial approval with respect thereto.

Finally, I am to add that tho Secretary for Public Works regrets that your identification with the present system of workiug has loft him no other course than to complete the works in progress through other hands.

Two days afterwards - Mr. STANLEY writes a long letter in self-justification, in which, we think, he but partially succeds. In concluding he expresses the hope " that, under the circumstances, the " Government may be pleased to take " into favourable consideration my being " placed in such other appointment as " they may be willing to transfer me to." The correspondence concludes with a letter to Mr. STANLEY, informing him that the Government have been pleased to transfer him to the position of " Engineer in charge of Railway Surveys, " at a salary of £600 per annnm."

In this manner, Mr. STANLEY'S grounds for complaint are removed, and the im- pression is that, although a good engi- neer, his estimates are scarcely trust- worthy, and his practical superintendence is inefficient. He is believed to be no match lor the small and swindling con- tractors who are the bane of the system under which our railways are carried out. And, as he -has obtained another appoint- ment at the salary of £600 a year, his case is not one over which much sympathy will be thrown away. With regard to the interests of the public, however, there is small room for con- gratulation. Instead of £349,000, Mr. STANLEY'S latest estimate, the Legislature are now asked to provide an additional £205,000, bringing the total cost of the twenty-four miles of line up to £397,000. And even this, be it re- membered, is only an estimate, as the line will not be finished for nearly two years, and there will be abundance of time for a still further multipli- cation of figures. Still, as the bulk of the work is now done, and the chief of the remaining outlay will be upon im- ported goods, and the bridge over the river at Oxley, it may be hoped that the ultimate cost of the work will not exceed £400,000, or at the rate of £16,666 per mile! We were under the impression that Mr. FITZGERALD had taught us a lesson in railway construction, but later experience teaches that our public men have still something to learn in that department of knowledge.

MAILS per s. Lady Bowon, for thc Austra- lian colonies, Gladstone, Maryborough, aud Brisbane, will close at thc Post Office thiB evening, for registered letters at six and for ordinary letters at eight o'clock.

THE Head Master of the Brisbane Grammar School, Mr. Thomas Harlin, announces ia our advertising columns that thc third school quarter of thc current year begins on Monday, July 20, aud cuds nu October 2. Thc fourth quarter begins on Monday, October 5, and ends Friday, December IS. School fees arc all pay-

able in advance, and may be paid to lt. Mac- j donnell, Esq., (Education Office, Edward street), the Treasurer of the Trustees, or to the credit of the Treasurer, at tho Union Bank,

Brisbane.

Bv an advertisement in our columns wc notice that thc Brands' 'Inspector for thc Leichhardt District, Mr. Thomas Middleton, draws thc attention of all concerned to tho necessity of rendering returns of stock, and payment of assessment iu advance annually to

thc nearest Clerk of Petty Sessions before the j 1st of January. He complains that many, either from neglect or design, have failed in this from its commencement, and unless nil such defaulters arc prompt in paying their arrears, thc penalty of £.*> will have to be

imposed as specified in the Brands Act i

WfTH vrHtCii ts iHCOiiroiiTF.n mr.

GLADSTONE O B S S It V IC fl.

PUBLISHED DA.ILY".

FRIDAY, MAY 1, 1874.

THE discussion raised by Mr. MACROSSAN on the Education vote on Tuesday week, will be productive of good. The Edu-

cational Board have heretofore been entrusted with the uncontrolled expendi- ture of the large sums animally voted for educational purposes ; at the same time there is much well grounded dissatis- faction with tlie proceedings of the Board, indications not having been wanting that, like all other irresponsible bodies, it is wont to be partial and despotic in administration. The imme- diate cause of Mr. MACROSSAN'* taking action was the refusal of the

Board to entertain a petition from teachers praying for an advance of salary because the signatures were nearly all in the same handwriting. And when the written authorisations to attach the sig- natures were handed in, the petitioners found themselves in no better position. This was extremely arbitrary on the part of the Board, who well knew that it would be almost impossible to obtain the signatures of teachers in all parts of the colony to the same document. The

demand that detailed estimates for the

educational department should be laid before the House is a reasonable one, and it is satisfactory to leam that on all future occasions the particulars will be supplied. Mr. MACROSSAN, however, in the course of his speech displayed an ill-concealed objection to governmental control of the schools, and complained of the unduly large number of inspectors appointed, as compared with the total number of schools in existence. But inspection is a vital part of the system of State educa- tion, for without it aggressive sectarians

will manage to smuggle in dogmatic | teaching on religious subjects for which the Government very properly refuses to pay. It is supposed by some persons that the action just taken in the House is in connection with some plan, yet in embryo, for deluding the public into the belief that non-vested schools are an

essential part of our educational system.1 But this we think an error, for if anything is calculated to seal the doom of sectarian schools, the dissemination of1 information respecting them may be supposed to have that effect. In a few days the second reading of Mr. GRIFFITH'S bill will come on, and we shall then see honorable members display their true colours. At present it is scarcely possible to distinguish nationalists from denomi nationalists, but Mr. GRIFFITH'S bill raises an issue which cannot be evaded. It is said that several secret denominationalists refuse to vote for the bill because it is not a Government measure. But these wolves in sheep's clothing-if there be such in the present : House-well know that thc religious

' element, introduced into our educational

system by an evasion of our statule law, is the true obstacle to any government dealing with the education question as a matter of public policy. It may be hoped that, despite the extreme diffi- culty of a private member forcing any measure through the House, the advo- cates of National Education will rally boldly and patriotically round Mr. GRIFFITH, and insist on his measure becoming law before the session closes.

THE revenue collectai at thc Custom House from the let to thc 30th April inclusive,

amounts to £Ô5!K) 13a. 2s.

THE dray approach to the Railway Wharf from Quay-street at the foot of Stanley-street, is sadly in want net so much of repair as of alteration. There are two tracks, mic of which is never «soil on account of its being eo deeply furrowed, combined with thc steepness

of the descent, while thc other is in just as I Iud a state as far as deep mts are concerned, j

although tho curve from thc river to the top of thc bank is of greater radius, rendering thc roadway less steep, and thorcforc less objec- tionable in that particular, lt is really dis- tressing to witness thc struggling efforts which both horse .iud driver are compelled to make while backing a load down or drawing one up, as the case may lie ; and many arc thc curses,

both loud and deep, that aro hurled liy thc j latter at thc lieut of tho llockhainpton Cor- poration. It would cost very little money tn cut au cutirely new approach in thc locality named, and a few loads of broken metal would

> render it complete. !

PUBLISHED DAILY.

WEDNESDAY, APRIL 22, 1874.

A HIM. introduced into thc Legislative Assembly by Mr. HUZACOIT, entitled, " A Hill to establish a Staline day for " Labour and regulate the employment " of Children and Young Persons," was read a first lime last week. The measure provides firstly that the standard day for skilled and unskilled labour in Queens- land " shall consist of eight working " hours, and no more, except in cases " where agreements for a longer working "day shall*be mutually entered into." The meaning of this we take lo bc that in the opinion of thc Legislature eight hours' work, comprises a fair working day for thc mechanic or labourer, just in the same way as according lo a Statute framed some years ago fifty-six pounds was considered a proper weight for a bushel of maize. Il must be observed, however, that the bill now before thc Assembly is not com- pulsory in this respect. Its effect will simply bc, in cases where no stipulation

for the hours, of labour is made, to fix j tlie day at eight hours. There is also a proviso in the bill that it shall not extend to domestic servants, persons employed by piece-work or on contract, and persons entrusted with thc care of any kind of live stock. Practically in the southern colonies and at Hrisbane the labour day now stands at eight hours, and we under- stand that our own MINISTER ron WOUKS has now under consideration

a proposal to fix eight hours as the standard day on all Government works. The bill under notice is therefore not by any means revolutionary in its cha- racter in (his respect, its author's expec- tation, we understand, being that thc moral effect of thc "statute day" will

be the chief benefit- to be derived in

the event of the measure becoming

law.

The public has an indirect interest in this eight hours' question which may not present itself at first sight. Kxperiencc

leaches thal in those trades where the

hours are wost oppressive lhere is the greatest preponderance of unsteady workmen. Over-work is an excess which carries other excesses in its train. The jaded workman naturally flies lo stimu- lants for relief until their use degenerates into abuse, and he soon becomes the mere wreck of a man. In our enervat- ing climate the danger from this source is very much increased, and il is clear thal if we would have steady work- men, good husbands and fathers, and happy homes for an industrial popula- tion, we must resist intemperance in work as well as that which is more generally dreaded in the shape of drunkenness. lt ought not to be for- gotten that our labourers and mechanics have their hom J duties as well as their duties on the road, tlx- wharf, and in tile work-shop ; and thal if we would have a thriving and contented population, the time must be afforded to men lo make their homes with their surroundings all radi ve. livery working man willi a family should have his flower plot, and his. bit of kitchen garden, and thus find healthful .ind profitable employment for his two or lince leisure hours a-day. Hui this cannot lie hoped for where protracted hours of labour exhaust all his energies.

The bill makes ii unlawful to employ children under twelve years of age in workshop, factory, or service, during the hours set apart for instruction in the primary schools of the colony, or during the hours of night-between S p.m. and 5 a.m. This taller provision also ex- tends to young persons of both sexes up to the age of sixteen years. The num- ber of young girls employed at sewing machines in factories al Hrisbane and elsewhere is now becoming very con- siderable. Their ordinary hours, we j understand, are from «S.30 a.m. to 1 o p.m., lo which there is mu

j much objection, but when a pressure ol

I business occurs-which in some esta

I blisluneiits is almost the normal condition

oí a/Tairs-these young girls (the future wives and mothers of the colony) arc kept at work till midnight or later, and dieu turned out upon the streets to go to their homes. This practice is very objectionable in two ways: long hours al the sewing machine or other seden- tary employment cannot fail to be very injurious, physically, to girls at a critical period of life, and may be expected to sow the seeds of future sickness, if not premature death ;-thc sending of young girls into the streets at late hours can hardly fail also to be morally injurious,

and is known to be the cause of much prostitution in lirisbaiie and thc other metropolitan cities of Australia. Thc rage amongst )'Oung girls for employment in factories is becoming a very serious matter. Domestic service is not to be thought of while from fifteen to twenty five shillings per week can bc earned at the sewing machine, and hence house- wives arc in despair at the impossibility of procuring help in their domestic duties. Thc claims of liberty and in- dependence attach to the life of the factory girl, and the night-work, in too many cases where there is no positive vice, alfords an excuse for an hour or two's promenade with "thc boys,"which leads too often to the worst results. Tile same remarks apply in many respects to young girls, whose constitutions are often permanently injured by the practice of turning day -nto night, and the irregular habits which it too often induces.

The prohibition against the employ- ment of children during school hours and at night is, we think, very desirable. Hoys in these limes receive such wages that many parents are quite willing lo take them from school at eight or nine years of age, and send them to "carn their living." Instances might bc cited of young children, entirely uneducated, being incessantly employed in workshops, factories, and mines, to their own detri- ment and to the serious future injury of society.

The bill imposes a penalty not ex- ceeding five pounds or fourteen days' imprisonment for every breach of its provisions, with the proviso that any information must bc laid within fourteen days after the date of thc alleged offence, ll is intended to come into force ott the ist January next.

Whether thc measure will pass or not is doubtful, as it is certain to encounter strong opposition from employers wlio are driving a prosperous and increasing

trade to the detriment of the moral and

physical health of the community. But as tile bil! deals willi acknowledged evils, and has a precedent in thc Imperial Factory Acts, il may be hoped that our Legislature will determine lo place it in the .statute book of the colony.

; or, 11) s v o y ¡i o n v ic RV i<: it. i

PUBLISHED DAJLY.

.rmnssuAY, xnuh .>, is;*.

[ i Ox thu re-assembling of Parliament, DU . Wednesday last, the new Ministry were

mel I))' a spirit of cordiality, in the popu lar brandi of the Legislature, which Í plainly showell that a strong majority of

the people's representatives were detcr ; mined lo give them al least u fair trial. 1 Mr. PALM KR, as the recognised leader t of '.he Opposition, seemed to fee! some > chagrin at lu's change of position - 0 nol so much because he no longer 1 held the seals of office as on ? account of the smallness of his fol \ lowing. The present relative position of

parties is, however, probably of an I ephemeral character, and may speedily 1 assume a totally difcrent aspect when

thc veal business of tile session comes on for deliberation,

b The particulars relating to the budget 1 brought forward last night by the ? Tur.Asuur.it are not yet before us, but I we are in possession of a full report (see i yesterday's Bulletin) of the Ministerial I explanation made by the PIU-'.MU.K in bis ' place in the Legislative Assembly. A i careful perusal of this "explanation" ; has led us lo the general conclusion ' thal there is mitch in il to ; which we can readily give our ', unqualified assent. The declarations of , the PUEMU-'.R on immigration and on 3 Public Works, including Railways, ' Roads and livitlges, Telegraphs, and [ Coast Lights, are for thc most part 1 excellent, and commend themselves to , thc judgment of reasonable men. Hut 1 on all these matters the present Govern [ ment have adopted the policy, pure and , simple, of their predecessors in office, . and as Mr. PMAI Kit humorously re ' marked, Mr. MACAU S I KH had stolen \ his clothes. Tn ere are, however, two 3 important points in which the ) policy of the new ministry differs

from thal of the former one-and these i relate to the Land question and the ivork , ing of the Electoral Act. lt must have 0 been with a special regard lo the mittis 3 tcrial intentions in these matters that Mr. v MACAMSTKK told his constituents at Ips r / wich the other day they had seen what J an obstructive Government had done, a but they should now see what a progres

1 sive Government could do.

, In dealing with the Public. Lands the 5 present Ministry stand cn a vantage

ground, from the fact thal a general L opinion prevails, and with some reason,

thal they are less hampered with vested ! interests, and therefore more able to j frame and administer the land laws 5 in the interest or the people as a i whole, than are their political oppo i nents, who represent the squatter and

I the large capitalist. There are flagrant

j abuses lo be corrected. The Land Act , of iS6S is liberal, both in spirit and

J intention. This is admitted on all hands.

Hui many of its salutary provisions, 1 designed lo secure honii fuie seulement, < have been shamefully set aside, and ¡ni

meuse areas of valuable land suitable foi I agricultural purposes have been secured ' by the gr.v.ier, ami thus kept in a com t paraltvely unproductive state, while the ! would-be cultivator is unceremoniously ; thrust aside. Now the Ministry have ', pronounced against these immoral prac-

tices, and declared war against the dum i mier. We only hope they will succeed

in this business, but títere is cause to fear thal they will find they

? have undertaken a herculean task, - A lillie investigation will soon cou.

vince Mr. St i'.mi-vxs, if he is not 1 already cognisant of the unpleasant fact, I llial the small selector is tarred with thc I same brush as his more wealthy neigh . hour, and goes into dummying right and 1 left whenever he linds the opportunity ol ' doing so. There are not a few selectors [ who unblushingly evade the residence ? and other stringent conditions of lhe

Act intended to ensure actual settlement and improvement, and do not hesitate, in order to sci ure a Deed of Grant. << ; have recourse tc) the most flimsy sublet' '? fuges, and to make, with certain mental

reservations, the required declaration i in the presence of a magistrate thal they ! have complied with the necessary con ' dilions. 'I'here are cases in which con

liguons selections ave 1aken up it: . several names-perhaps members of tin , same family -and held on pretexts thai I would not serve to establish an honest ; claim to one block of the group. Thi>

is the sort of thing thal calls for strong ? handed measures, and thal should bi : put a stop to without respet t of pvrsuiv ! or pail)-. The suppression of dummy , ing should be held superior to part j

considerations, as it is a species of im

morality, and all good citizens arc alik interested in discouraging it by all po! sihle means. If il be true, as Air. MAC AUSTER alleges, that the late Govern ment failed to usc measures al thei command lo put a stop to thc evil, w cnn only wish thal llie present Mintsti; «?ill lie more successful, and ive fcc confident thal al) honest men in lb House, whether seated on llie right c left of the SPKAKKK, will readily aid iii Minist./ in their praiseworthy undci taking.

Thc second pail of the minister!; programme relating lo the Land, is of totally different nature, and is not s easy of justification. The Govci/imei; propose lo throw open more land ft seulement, and in this they onl c ir./ out the policy which distinguishe the PAI.MKR Administration, who, uv asked, initiated and carried through th .ucccssai/ measures for resumptions o

the Dalling Downs, and never hesitate lo throw open land in any dislrie where there appeared to be any re.i demand for it. Some few weeks helor

the late Mim'sl.y left office lite Actim

Commissioner for the Port Curtí District was insti acted to report «po the extent of the demand for lan in (lie neighbourhood of Rockhall!) lon ; and a recommendation fror that oliiccr was accordingly made t ! the effect'thai the leased halves of nm

within anare.i of about thirty miles of th : town should be al once resumed atv 1 throw ii open to selection. Had th;: Ministry remained in power lhere can b no reasonable doubt thal resolution would have been .submitted to Parti;

: ment to give legal effect to ibis recoil

inondation, in accordance with llie terni , of the Land Act. Hut Mr. MACAI.ISTK

? and his colleagues are bound to shoi what a " progressive" Government ca do, and the course of procedure anthe rised by the Land Act ol' iSOS i not sufficiently startling and sensation,-! j The ten years' leases are lo be préservée

i but free selection is lo be establishei

I over them all, without exception or di:

linclion. This requires a speci;i enactment, and Mr. MACAMSTKK prc mises to bring in a bill for the purpose Tlie most remarkable part of lin: juc j posai is that it is done om of k'mdnes ; to the lessees ! Mr. MACAUSIKR, i: j effect, says thal lo resume certain lease*

halves thal happen lo be within read of a market to the exclusion ol' othe lands not so situated, " would have ? " tendency to inflict injury where it i " nol desirable to do so ; thal the lesse "whose inns and lands are not likely l< "be selected under any law might li " unnecessarily interfered with.1' Tb Government therefore propose in th. first place to give free selection over th whole of the leased halves of runs, will the condition thal the resumpiioi of these runs will depend entirely 01 and extend only lo the selections actuall; made. Mr. MACALISTER further says -" 1 think it will be found that whei '' the bill is presented, and taken in con " nection with the areas wc propose if " fis, that thal bill will actually be : " more liberal measure for lessees thai " than they al present possess under tin

" Act of i SOS." There is a vein o

irony Linning through ibis peculiar wai of putting the case which is positive!) amusing, and we hardly think that sucl a mode of reasoning will conceal fron the House or the outside public tin absurdity of the ministerial proposal Any man of common sense does no require to be told thal indiscriminaU free selection over a run depreciates thc market value of llie lessee's interest ir it, even if thc selector is bound to fence in his selection. Hut this is not all lt is well proved from experience in the southern colonies that runs utter!) unfit for cultivation or altogether beyond thc reach of a market are not safe where free selection prevails, for there will nol unfreqtiontly be found men who, from motives of spite or cupidity, will take u[: a selection ou a run for the mere object of levying blackmail on the lessee and compelling him al a heavy cost to bu;1 off the intruder. What is there in thc circumstances of ibis colony to justify a resort to indiscriminate free selection i There was some excuse for it?

adoption in the older colonies, whore ultra-squatting influences were strong ; but in Queensland we have in the Land Act of 180S, a law more liberal and pro- gressive than any other in operation on the Australian Continent, and its ma- chinery amply provides for llie growing wants of the people. The len years' leases were given on the understanding that the holder thereby obtained a vir- tually secure tenure of half his run, in place of an insecure one of the whole. And, in fact, no resumption could be made without the authority of a resolution passed by both Houses of Parliament. The leases are now more than half run out, and wo maintain thal lo proclaim free selection over these runs would inflict a wanton injury on many lessees, and would be a flagrant breach of faith on the part of the Government-not the less so, because authorised by a special act of Parliament. Let the Government proceed against all (hummers as they would against other evildoers, and we shall wish them God speed in their laudable work. And if lliey wish to throw open more land, Iel I them kee]) faith willi those men who

J have invested capital in the country, and

not resort to extreme measures that must

injure the squatter, while il -affords no guarantee that the cultivator would be hciiL-fiiicd. Should it be found, after a proper trial, (bat the conservatism of the Upper House is an effective block lo tho passage of wholesome measures, it will then be soon enough, but not before, for Mr. M.UMi.istr.u's hill for free selection.

The promised Kleclions Hill is also of questionable expediency. An amend- ment of the present Act, with a vie«- to carry out the views of ils framers, is all that is called for in the interest of the public at large.

The action initiated by the newMinislry aiming ai (he immediate reversal of legislation effected under the guidance [ of their |jrcdecessors, is not warranted

hy circumstances, and is totally opposed to the spirit and practice of Constitu- tional Government in the old country. We cannot believe that these hasty and revolutionary measures will receive the sanction of the House of Assembly. The course entered upon by the Govern- ment will certainly alienate many of their friends, and the small bul compact band under the leadership of Mr. I'AI.MF.K, will receive daily accessions to their ranks, until it becomes apparent thal the Ministiy no longer possess the

conldence of the House.

Ouit telegraphic column contains

some information relative to the Budget, j We learn that the TRUASUUER declared j

his intention of spending the surplus in ?> hand, amounting to a quarter of a j million sterling, on public works, immi-

gration, and telegraph extension. The i nd valorem duties are lo remain at ten

per cern lill July i, then lill ist October to be seven and a half per cent, and

from ist October to the end of the year ; five per cent. What is to be done after that dale, does not yet appear, but as the five per cent rate is then to terminate, thc necessary inferetire is thal lhere will be a further reduction, and probably the entire abolition of this obnoxious and iniquitous form of taxation. The

tenor of Mr. MACU.I.NIT.K'.S remarks on

this subject, last week, seemed to imply thal tho complete abolition of the dillies was not contemplated. ll will be observed thai there is no mention of a loan, and Mr. M'IIAVKAII n's intention to ask for a vote u(£i 20,000 to complete the Northern Kail way to the Daivson has evidently bei« abandoned for the Session. Reviewing the information to hand respecting the Kslimiles, we are forced to the conclusion that in the Works

Department they are most unsatisfactory lo this part of the colony, especially in the division of the surplus. The few sums set down in aid of our local insti- tutions .ire not of much account when it is considered that the revenue is in a

flourishing condition, and large sums are to be spent throughout the colony in works and improvements. The improve- ment of the Kilzroy is estimated at a value of one to thirteen as compared to that of Moleton Hay, and wc have to complain not only of the smallness of thc amount proposed lo be expended, bul the absence of any provision for a compre- hensive and thorough survey of the river by a competent engineer. And this, we contend, should be the preliminary step to the actual work of deepening the river. There is no reason to expect that the present Ministry, judging from their general conduct, will find it convenient lo push on our railway extension with greater rapidity than it is now being done. And il would appear thal MACAUSTKK'S and M'II.WRAITH'S pro- mises are equally worthless, and like pie-crust, only made to be broken. We shall suspend decisive- judgment until

the Estimates reach us and the inten- tions of the Government become intelli-

gible and clear. In the meantime we fear that Rockhampton and the Central Districts will gain but little from the return lo power of MACAMSTF.K and his party.

'i'm! proposed Oiolvct match hetweeii tho Westwood and ltoelvhauipton teams is likely to hecomc rta ftiil accompli judging from tho energy thrown into the iiiTaiigciiients hy thc Westwooil clot), which energy is the mon; coiHrticuoiis hy comp irison w'.t.h tho t.anlmcss cvineoil hy the mouther.- of our own elah. AT thc Lunatic licception House yesterday afternoon, before the I'olico Magistrate ami Mr. Fl ank N. r.c.ldck, .1.1'., Hither Mrookett Wiis eoiirnit.tcil to thc institution for tine mouth

upon tho cvitlcncc of Hr. Salmond. Thc accusal hail heirn lately discharged from tho Reception House to the care of lier husband, who stated timi he could do nothing with ber, as she had got into hov head that he lind .-motlier wife, and he was therefore compelled to bring her to tlie Kcccptinn House for

a labourer working at the Hawson lïridgc, aiul had two children to look after, and could not

nafe wife's malady. Ile was afraid, in fact, to leave lier at home with her children.

Tuc. weather appears to have broken, and bids fair lo ld-delightfully tine and cool for the Laster holid-iyit. Tlio^o persons who have made up their minds to c-icip.; from the lur lil'til of every day lift', and .-.purni a few days at ¡ '.mn I'.u k and oi lier places ne ir thc coast, wc trust will nut bc overtaken by anything t.o nen- their enjoyment. An ohnudni.'e of .?iinuseineiits are hilt-inlcd. There will be air excursion train on Killer Monday and tho Oi.-kot match 011 thc same «lay, together with the feto of thc Loyal troupe at rene's «tarden; which are sure to attract a great number <it spectators ; in fact, lhere Khoulil be no dearth of real fun in and about l'toelvhaiiipbtn. Saturday will be au todiuai-y business day, bul. wi- have m> doubt thal, Uko all such go in t«.ns, ¡twill bi voled a nuis-mec. lu miler to give nur <?«/>/?>,</<.' an opportunity nf observing«:.1 Friday, thc BulieUu will ' not bc published on that day.

PUBLISHED D.\IL,Y.

FRIDAY, AUGUST 7. 1874.

AT the Police Court yesterday morning before the Police Magistrate, ono peace dis- turber was fined 10s. or suffer forty-eight hours rn tho lockup, and Henry Obin was placed in the dock on remand, charged with unlawfully wounding one Bernard Ain well, in th: Alma Hotel, on the 4th instant. Dr. A. C. Robertson proved that about four o'clock io the afternoon of the day named he examined a man named Bernard AnuweU, in the Alma Hotel, and found him Buffering from a wound on the right temple, and one over the eyebrow on the same side of tho face ; there was also an abrasion of the skin on thc right aide of the cheek and nose: there is no danger to life, but the patient has been for some time suffering from chronic rheumatism, which prevents his attending thc Court. Thc wounds are all healthy. Tho police here applied for a farther remand until Monday next, «hieb, vas granted,¡

articleText:
The Rockhampton Bulletin,

WITH WHICH IS INCORPORATED THE

GLADSTONE OBSERVER.

PUBLISHED DAILY.

SATURDAY, JANUARY 24, 1874.

THE news of the wreck of the A.S.N. Company's steamship James Paterson, has scarcely taken the public by sur-

prise, for it was felt that any vessel at sea within range of the terrific gale which lasted through Wednesday night and the following day, must of necessity have been in great peril, even in open water with plenty of room to

tack or run before thc storm. But the

apprehensions of danger were intensified by the knowledge that the navigation

on our coast is restricted to a channel averaging for some distance not more than twenty miles in width.

The James Paterson, s.s., left Mary-

borough a few minutes after the Leich- hardt, on Tuesday morning last, and should have arrived here by Wednes- day's midday tide. The time required for ordinary steaming from wharf to wharf is not more than twenty five hours. In order, therefore, to account for her being off Masthead leland at the time when the disaster occurred, we must assume either that she lost two tides before clearing the Fairway buoy, or that she was disabled at sea and unable to maintain her ordinary speed before the bad weather came on. It is satis- factory, however, that no lives have been lost. The life boat, which reached the pilot station last night would not have left the wreck before yesterday morning,

as the distance traversed is not more

than from thirty to forty miles. Since yesterday morning the weather has continued calm, and as the Leichhardt will be alongside the wreck by eight o'clock this norning, it is tolerably certain that

the crew and passengers will be all taken safely off without difficulty.

Captain BIRRELL fears for the safety of the ship Landsborough. She weighed anchor on Wednesday morning, and

went out to sea. Towards midnight the wind arose, and shortly afterwards blew in gusts of great violence. There was no moon, and the weather was thick and dirty. The wind was ahead, and we hardly think the ship could have beat up against it. From the

waters being narrow, and currents strong, she could neither heave to nor run before the wind with

safety. Taking all the circumstances into consideration, it is not easy to imagine how she could have managed to ride through the storm. But we must hope for the best, not only for the sake

of the lives and property at stake, but for the reputation of the port. Had there been a coast pilot on board, he would probably have brought the ship back to her anchorage under Seaview Hill, or contrived to run into Port

Curtis ; but Captain THOMAS, being a

stranger to these waters, would deem it

his most prudent course to keep off the

land as much as possible. She had on board 464 tons of ballast, and not 250 tons, as we stated yesterday.

The Lord Ashley, steamer, was also at sea in the gale. She left Rockhampton on Tuesday night, but lost a tide in the river, and did not leave the bay until about five o'clock on Wednesday even- ing. It is asserted, so we are informed, by Mr. MITCHELL, of the Dunmore Arms, and Mr. BARTHOLOMEW, of Sebastopol, both of whom were at Emu Park on Thursday, that they saw the Ashley lying under the shelter of Keppel Island. It is just what Captain HARLEY would be likely to do when he found he could not proceed with safety, and we hope and believe the statement is true. There is

good shelter under South Keppel, and it is therefore pretty certain that the Ashley, with her crowd of passengers, has suffered no damage, and is now making good progress on her way to the

Endeavour.

A CORRESPONDENT from Emu Park states that the late storm began there a little before midnight on Wednesday last, and raged with great fury until Thursday night, when it moderated. Trees were snapped off and up- rooted in every direction, but the houses escaped with very little damage. The Lord Ashley was seen passing north late on Wed- nesday afternoon. All along the road to town lay the broken branches of large trees, thrown into all kinds of imaginable positions proving the destructive power and force of the wind.

AT the Police Court yesterday morning before the Police Magistrate, one drunkard was admonished and discharged. John Con- dron was then charged by Constable Matheson, with being drunk in Bolsover-street on Thursday afternoon, and with damaging his uniform to the amount of £2 ; a further

charge of wilful destruction of property to the amount of £1, preferred against the defendant by William Kearney, was struck out, there being no appearance of the complainant. Constable Mathewson deposed, that he

arrested the accused who was drunk at the time, at the instance ot Mr. Kearney, for

wilfully destroying property on his premises, in Bolsover-street. He did not come quietly to the lock-up but resisted and tore the trousers (produced) which were of the value of £2. They are of no service now ; fined £1, with £2 the value of the property damaged, in default of immediate payment one month's

imprisonment in Rockhampton jail.

articleText:
flDjje Jocíííjaiujílon bulletin,

WITH WHICH H INfJiJRHíEATKD Tlf.

GLADSTONE OnSKUl'KR.

PUBLISHED DAILY.

THlTliSDAY, MAKCJl 5, 1874.

Tino report of the meeting lately held nt lîrisbane, for the purpose of starlin"; a new steam navigation company, is now I before us. The proceedings were entirely of .1 preliminary nature. Thc object of the meeting is one that must enlist tile sympathy of everyone having the com- mercial prosperity of thc colony at heart. Thc CHAIRMAN, in his opening address, referred to the fact that the carriage of wool from Rockhampton to lîrisbane was the same as from Rockhampton lo Sydney, and the same remark applied to ]towen. This is a wrong of which the mercantile community throughout Queensland has always had to com- plain, and even thc A. S. N. Com ' pany themselves must admit thal il 1 is an anomaly which cannot he easily

accounted for on business principles, lt may he a simple and convenient arrange- ment of thc Company's tariff for the Company itself, but'it operates unequally and unjustly upon the transactions of the Company's pattons. In all business transactions there is a presumed recipro- city of advantage. Still the system pur- sued by the Company, by simplifying its scale of charges, and bringing all its vessels directly and completely under (he supervision of the directors, is, we presume, in some degree conducive to

lite interests of the shareholders, lt is really very important to tho Company that its business should, as far as possible radiate from its central point, and that point being Sydney, il becomes a desirable object to attract to Port Jack- son as much as possible of Ihe Austra- lian coasting trallie. There is another ground, too, on which a partial tariff may lie justified in dealing with tho northern pons. The farther the steamers gel from head quarters the farther from coal, which means an increased expense in working. A vessel running between Sydney and Townsville can fill up with

coal whenever the fluctuations of trade do not allow of her taking a full cargo, whereas a sicamor nianing between Rockhampton and Townsville musí have coal conveyed to her by other vessels. Another valid ground on which advanced charges might be made in the north is the want of back freight. lieyond lluwen lhere is no pastoral produce or copper for return loading, and hence the freights to those places" naturally range higher than to ports where wool, tallow, hides, pre- served meats, and copper, always furnish profitai ile rein ni cargoes. This, how- ever, does not justify the inequality of which Mr. Jinx complains, and which it is thc duty of all Queensland mer- chants to pmlest against and endeavour lo rectify.

Our readers will fully appreciate thc desire expressed by the several speakers at the lîrisbane meeting lo secure the co-operation of the northern ports. There is, we are sure, a general desire lo reciprócale these overtures, and lo join in a trading alliance thal can lie shown to be mutually advantageous lo ihe metropolis and ihe other ports of the colony. It would be a good thing to have a steam navigation company under the sole control of a Queensland directory, and worked with an exclusive regard to ihe exigencies of Queensland

trade. Union is strength, and if heany co-operation can ht! secured between Brisbane and the various Northern Ports, success is certain to attend the projected venture. Hut in dealing with a Dialler of this kind it is necessary for thc negotiating parlies to display can- dour, and let preliminary objections he

discussed without reservation. If there is to be hearty co-operation lhere must he strict mutuality, and in order to obtain this there must be no dashing of interests. Concessions to secure union may be made on both sides, so long as they do not involve sacrifices likely to outweigh the advantage to be derived from the compact. The question then arises whether, in the milter of the proposed Queensland Steam Navigation Company, the benefits to attend its operations will he universally distributed, for if not it will be hopeless to expect to establish the company by the co operative action of the metropolitan ami other mercantile communities of the

colony. There may exist among these communities the most hearty gonil-wi!l, and the most sincere desire to promote tile general benefit by means of a great joint effort, and yet difficulties may be in thc way which it will be found im- possible to overcome. Wc fear some

such difficulties will be encountered in

attempting lo establish the new Queens- land Steam Navigation Company.

Take the case of llrisbane and Rock-

hampton, for example. It may be admitted, if requisite, that between the merchants of the two ports lhere is sincere friendshipand mutual esteem. In a simple matter of precedence each may be willing to yield to the other,--the metropolitan because his undoubted strength and resources cannot be injured by any ex- tent of mere conventional self-abasement; the Rockhampton man because his com- mercial inferiority is loo marked to excite jealousy. Hui ihe two ate active rivals, nevertheless, and keenly compete for the lion's share of the northern trade. In matters of courtesy each is the "humille servant" of the other, but in business they are running a sharply

contesled race for valuable stakes. To

tell us that against llrisbane and Sydney Rockhampton has no chance of even a share of the prize, is beside the question.

Thc very remarks made by Mr. Hi ix

as to the treatment Jîrisb.me receives from Sydney, are equally .applicable by the Rockhampton merchant against

lîrisbane. Thc circumstance thal

Rockhampton and lîrisbane are politically united together, while they ave both severed from Sydney, must be allowed little weight. The merchant desirous of replenishing his stocks goes lo the best market, and whatever his political sympathies, he must discard them in making provision for the exig- encies of profit and loss. Otherwise his collapse is only a question of time. And so with the proposed steamship com- pany. The directors must of course work ihe business of the company from lîrisbane, and will be influenced by motives precisely similar to those which weigh willi the directors of the Sydney company, ll is as vitally important for

Brisbane lo become lite centre of

Queensland trade, as for Sydney to become the commercial metropolis of Australia. And il is unreasonable to

expect the merchants of lîrisbane to enter into any compact, by virtue of which they would impartially divide the

northern trade between themselves and the residents of Rockhampton.

ll is urged that the mere fart of placing opposition steamers on our coast must be advantageous, in a greater or less degree, to the traders of all the northern ports. So much maj' be admitted, and we have no doubt that wherever an opposition boat presented herself she would receive a warm welcome, and obtain a full share of the coasting trade of the colony. Hui in being asked to co-operate with lîrisbane in procuring steamers, our merchants are asked to provide a. portion of the necessaty capital, of which they have really none lo spare. That is, the capital at their command can be much more advantageously appropriated, and they cannot be induced lo invest money in a concern without gelling security for substantial indirect benefits, al least. Thc simple question then is, Can the projectors of the new company offer such security ?

lt is a well known aphorism that there is no friendship in business. In prac- tice, perhaps, the principle is not always observed. There is, actually, a good deal of friendship in business, and within certain limits it may subsist with mutual advantage. On the hypothesis that lîrisbane is our friend and Sydney our foe, a Rockhampton trade, may sin- cerely desire lo give the preference to the friend. Hut he is also bound to calculate how much that preference will cost -whether nothing, or five per cent on the amount of his year's transactions. If the latter, he must perforce discard friendship, and bestow substantial tokens of regard upon his enemy, lie may deeply regret this necessity, but in his case profits, peace of mind, and even solvency, are the real make-weights in the scale against friendship.

I'imlly, the question for our lîrisbane friends toconsider is, whether theproposed company can be so conducted as lo foster impartially ihe trade of all the Queensland ports. Were lîrisbane the geographical as well as the political centre of the colony. little diliicully would be experienced. lint as the geographical position «jf Rockhampton warrants her merchants in aspiring lo a profitable trade with the ports further north, she

is bound to use all available means lo

promote thal trade, liv means of direct shipments she hopes soon lo compele effectively with both lîrisbane and Sydney, and she cannot afford lo bend her energies in any direction not con- ducive lo that end. This way be deemed presumptuous ambition, but is il not justified in some measure by the design of lîrisbane upon the would-be "commercial metropolis of the southern hemisphere?"

articleText:
Cjjc|(oííi¡j¡imj)íoit bulletin,

«ITH WHICH I« ïnCOEfOUTKO TUC.

GLADSTONE OBSERVE ft.

PtJBLiíSMED DA.ELY.

SATURDAY, AUGUST 15, 1974.

THE determination of our Municipal Council to provide increased wharfage accommodation is one of the most satis- factory signs of the times. The exchequer of the Council is not at all in a flourish- ing condition, for, with the continued reduction of the endowment, the interest remittances on the government loan, and the necessary works to be done, a great deal of good management is requisite to make ends meet. It is now becoming pretty generally admitted that the dis- continuance of the government endow- ment is an injustice to municipalities, and that if the ratepayers consent to tax themselves to carry out public works, they are entitled to some assistance from the Treasury. Outside municipalities the roads, bridges, and waterworks are carried out entirely at the cost of the Central Government, and it is there- fore clearly inequitable to insist that within municipal boundaries, improve- ments shall be carried out by means of direct local taxation alone. Rockhamp- ton is no doubt exceptionally favoured by circumstances in regard to sources I of revenue. A considerable income is

derived from the Market Reserve, from I the punts and ferries, and from the

wharfage. The last item is one from which the Brisbane Corporation do not obtain a shilling, all the wharves there being in the ¡lands of the Government or of private persons. Our Municipal Council have, therefore, very properly recognised the peculiar claim which the shipping trade of the port has upon their attention. Increased business means not only increased revenue from assess- ments, but direct income from wharfage in addition, and it would be a suicidal policy to harass the trade of the port by a want of wharfage accommodation. It is this consideration, we presume, which has induced the Council to strain a point in order to construct two additional wharves now. The number of what may be termed necessary works is legion, and if some ;£izoo or £1300 be appropriated to new wharves it cannot be spent in drainage, in forming streets, or in metalling roads. As an isolated matter,

drainage is perhaps even more necessary than additional wharves. Considerations of health demand that better means of

clearing the town of stagnant and putrid water than now exist shall be quickly devised. In this matter the Corporation have a duty which they cannot shirk. But it must not be for- gotten that those who use the wharves are entitled to the proposed ex- penditure on account of past contri- butions to the municipal revenue. If the trade of the port demands it, there is surely nothing unreasonable in the claim that one year's revenue from the wharfage should be devoted to its extension. But for the utter impossi- bility of carrying on the municipal affairs without some impost upon trade, it would be sound policy to make the port free as far as wharfage dues are con- cerned. Our aim should bc to attract atid not repel shipping, and if circum- stances do not permit of wharf accom- modation being provided without charge, it is both our interest and duty to see that the dues are spent in the improve- ment and extension of our wharfage. It is fortunate for the trade of the port that we have several mercantile men in the Council, and that they perceive the necessity of removing all impediments in the way of the laking in and discharge

of cargo. It would be most shortsighted j policy to look upon the income from j wharves as money to be spent in im- j

proving the streets or beautifying the town. The very existence of Rock- hampton is dependent upon ils com- merce, and consequently the ratepayers of all classes are deeply interested in seeing that it is afforded every possible

accommodation.

I Bv way of Brisbane we have news from

f «Cooktown to the 29tU ultimo. The local

papers give very exciting accounts of the new rush, but the dates from thc Palmer appear « ?io be no later than the intelligence previously i received here. Perhaps thc fact that Cook 1 to wu is glutted with atores, has something to f do with the too brilliant reporta from thc

-palmer.
