articleText:
?jcf oclí|jtntj)toit bulletin,

WITH WtUCn fS lRCOXFOXiVMD SUR

GLADSTONE O BSE It VSU. j

PUBLISHED ,-pAILY.

WEDNESDAY, JULY 15, 1874.

ONE of the greatest obstacles to the in- troduction of a practicable measure of local government into Parliament is the j very partial success of municipal institu- ! lions throughout the colony, ? From the metropolis down to Drayton-Rock- hampton only cxceptcd-lhe various municipal councils appear to have fallen almost beneath contempt. This dis esteem is certainly not without justifica- tion, although possibly the more patriotic course would be to encourage and i counsel, rather than abuse and sneer at

the men who are attempting'to master thc principles and practice of local self government It is, indeed, an unfortu- nate thing for the metropolitan city of Queensland that ' her civic dignitaries have for years past been drawn from the ranks of third-rate men, and that in con- sequence the city has in «nany respects been allowed to go to the dogs. In all Brisbane there is not even one well-kept thoroughfare, while it is only in one or two of the principal streets that guttering and kcrbing has been even tried. Generally speaking the sanitory condi- tion of the city is simply execrable, although the site is one of more 'than common salubrity. The streets at night are filled with a poisonous effluvia, and judging by the decaying animal matter strewn about, such an official as thc Inspector of Nuisances does not exist. Such a state of affairs in the capital city of Queensland, where the assessments must show an astonishing annual increase, is. certainly discreditable, and supplies a powerful argument to that numerous ? body of our legislators who contend that centralisation is thc most economical and : efficient form of government

At Maryborough the condition o' affairs is even worse. That town is, in fact, just now in the throes of a civic revolution. Thc lawfully constituted authorities have abdicated under pressure of public opinion, and the functions o government are usurped by three alder men, who refuse to relinquish the shabb) robes of office in which they have beer clothed. The consequence is that thc ratepayers have formed themselves inte a committee to protect the public interest and arc endeavouring to scenrt the intervention of the Central Govern ment. But for this there is no authority or precedent, and the Police Magis trate has consequently been warnec not to interfere. Here, then, is ar actual revolution within the pcacefu colony of Queensland, and if there be n< barricades in the streets, and no riotoui demonstrations, it is simply because ii the breast of aU Englishmen there is ; respect for law and order, even whei law and order have been superseded b;

an unlooked-for accident.

The Government have given it a their opinion that the Municipality c Maryborough has utterly collapsed, aro that if its re-establishment be desiret the inhabitants must return and do the first works. In other words, the inuit get up a petition for incjrporatio i & .i "W", and for several monti

at least remain in their present chkottc j state. This is an uncomfortable . pro- spect, for however badly the raunicipa} institution may have worked, its 6iidde& collapse will bc attended by undesirable consequences. The principal creditor, who is interested to the extent of several thousands of pounds, is cheated out of every scrap of security, and is dependent. solely upon the honour and good faith' of the community. Then, with a defunct coqjoration, the collection of assess- ments, wharf dues, and tolls must be illegal, and in this manner thc town will lose a very large proportion of its revenue for the current year. Such dues and tolls, we ,are informed, are being still collected, by advice, and paid by the collectors into separate trust accounts at the National Bank ; but the irregularity of such proceedings must be apparent, and in the event of persons refusing to pay dues and tolls it would! be impossible to compel them.

Thc situation is further complicated by the persistence of the three aldermen who still hold their ground, and, despite protests, arc preparing to carry on an illegal election. That ultimately they must surrender, there can be no question, but holding for the present the key to the position, it may be in their power to indefinitely prolong the crisis.

It is fortunate for the inhabitants of Maryborough that they can discover a silver lining to their cloud in the circumstance that when their municipality 1 comes to be re-constituted they may

avoid tile mistakes of the past. One of these is thc inclusion of too large an area within the civic boundaries ; another, the division of the municipality into wards ; and a third, the selection of unfit men to the Council board. But persons who have watched the conduct of municipal institutions elsewhere, will be less hopeful of any great reform being effected by revolutionary means. The failure of self government at Maryborough cannot fairly be attributed to the excessive area of the municipality or its division into several wards, but to the pettiness and in- competency of the aldermen. . And that is an evil which will not be easily remedied. The spirit of the community at Maryborough is jealous~arid captious, and whatever changes be made in the constitution and personnel of the Council, that spirit will continue lo be evinced at the Board until there is a larger infusion of new blood into thc. town than has yet occurred. The miserable jealousy always displayed by Maryborough towards her neighbours, both North and South, is sufficiently notorious, and thc same spirit is constantly evinced by her leading

townsmen towards each other. Without

hearty co-operation for the public good no community can hope to succeed in the management bf its public institutions ; and unfortunately, in Maryborough, co- operation has hitherto been found imprac- ticable^ ' That the town continues to progress .satisfactorily is due to the varied resources of the district, and to the un- common development which has taken place in them through the introduction of outside capital.

The advocates of local self-government may well be discouraged at the present aspect of affairs in different parts of thc colony, but they may draw comfort from the thought that Dieir principles are founder! npnn the expetienee-of Anglo Saxon communities elsewhere, and can- not be overturned by . the blunders ol incapable men in our at present crude state of society.

I THE adjourned mooting of tue Philarmonic j Society will bo bold this evening, in the School

of Arts, Bolsover-Btreet, at eight o'clock. Members of thc society and all that arc inter- ested arc respectfully invited to attend.

ALTHOUGH tho official Post-office notice states that thc uoxt Torres Straits mail will be made up to-morrow, it is perfectly clear that a postponement must take place, os no steamer is in readiness to take the mail. Our telegram of last night from Sydney states that thc Flintshire is not likely to he in a seaworthy condition for a fortnight ; wo therefore con- clude that another steamer will be chartered

for thc purpose. Wo shall defer thc publica- tion of our monthly summary pending the rocoipt of definite information as to the date when thc mail will close at Rockhampton.

!TllK Queensland Church Neat. has a

characteristic article OD Education. It "thanks God we have an Upper House," and says :-"Wc were not quito prepared for thc resulta into which Mr. Griffith's Bill would launch us, where a majority ot one branch of the Legislatura of a Christian colony luis -publicly docidod that religion shall be banialied from thc schools altogether. Thc name of Cod or His existence must not he mentioned to thc rising generation. Heading, writing, arithmetic, and a smattering of a few other subjects aie to be taught them, and then they aro to bo turned loose upon society, with their wits sharpened just enough to qualify them for becoming sharpers, swindlers, thieves, liars, and murderers. Although wc have no State Church in tho colony, as we are every day by some mil wither of tho Church in some shape or other reminded, yet we do not cease during the sittings of our Colonial Parliament to offer np the prayer in our public services that 'God wopld bc pleased to direct and prosper all their consultations to thc advancoineut of His glory and the good of His Church, .iud that all thiugs may be so ordered and settled by their cudeavours upon thc best and surest foundations, that 1n\th and justice, religion and piety, may bc established muong us for all generations.' We may regard tho last action of tho Legisla- tive Council in throwing out this execrable bill as a reply to such prayer ; and the thanks of the community arc due to that right-minded body of senators for saving tho colony from a fearful calamity. In the faco of such a course os that of an infant colony committing itself to what was simply a repudiation, of the Great Architect of the Universe, nothing would have remained for us as a Church but to do what thc Church of Come has already done in several instances, to uphold our own schools in oppo- sition to and independent of those supported bythcStato." After this exhibition of clerical bigotiy and nsrrowmindedncss on tho part of our contemporary, thc reader will not bc sur-

prised to leam that tho Cftsrcft Aciesis in a. ' moribund condition. Thc majority of mem- bers of thc Church of Kngkuid in this colony aro not to bo f rightonod by the bugbear of godless education at thia time of day.

articleText:
?¡je otíiíjamptott §ttlletin,

WITH «míen is incoftroiiTBD Tar.

GLADSTONE OBSERVER.

PUBLISHED DA.ILY.

WEDNESDAY, JUNE 3, 1874.

THE PREMIER may be an astute poli- tician, but the impression is gaining ground that he is nevertheless thc mere creature of impulse. His notorious frailty as a promise-breaker is not due so much to want of good faith as to that rashness of disposition which leads him to make promises which a few moments consideration would convince him it would be difficult to perform. It is this impulsiveness also which leads the hon. gentleman into expressions which, how- ever sincere, are equally untrue and unbecoming. As PREMIER he of course professes an important regard for thc well-being of the whole colony, but against certain portions of it he has an unmistakeable and deep-rooted prejudice. He has a perfect horror of Rockhampton, for example, and can seldom resist the temptation of giving it a blow when opportunity offers. Yes- terday fortnight the hon. gentleman con- demned that section of the Immigration Act which provides that one-half thc vessels shall be despatched to thc northern ports. And in condemning the Act he found an illustration in Rock- hampton : " Had it not been," he said, " that a large number of the arrivals by " the last vessel at Rockhampton had " been employed on the Government " works going on there, they would have " become paupers." For this he was taken to task next day by our member, who moved the adjournment of the House to make an explanation on the subject. He said, as will be seen by the report, that the immigrants could not get employment, not because it was scarce, but because they were-nftt fit for any kind of work in the colony. To this, the PREMIER made no answer, but the MINISTER for WORKS replied that the hon. member had repeated exactly what the PREMIER originally said. Looking at the Courier's report, this answer is amusing, and it

seems odd that Mr. MACALISTER allowed

the misrepresentation to pass. As yet, Hansard has not reached us, but anyone who compares Mr. MACALISTER'S speech with the correction made by Mr. BUZACOTT must conclude that in this instance, impulse led the PREMIER into an unjustifiable attack upon Rockhampton. His object was palpable, and it was fortunate that a prompt contradiction was supplied. The present Government only want an excuse .for defrauding us of our share of immigration, as they havs already de- frauded us of our share of the public money and mail communication. It may be hoped, however, that alL the Ministers are not as implacable as the

PREMIER.

PERHAPS of all the present ministers, Mr. HEMMANT is the least oojectionable to the public in this part of the colony. Mr. M'ILWRAITH is, for the present at any rate, under a deep cloud, although sanguine persons amongst us are not without hope of his "turning up trumps" after all. But Mr. HEMMANT, as Treasurer.has perhaps given less cause for offence than his colleagues. The hon. gentleman is regarded as big wit .h promise, for has he not assured our triember that whatever sum may _ be necessary to improve the naviga'cion of thc Fitzroy shall be gre Med ? He ' is, moreover, reported ti j give prompl I attention to representa tions made b) 1 members of Parliament, and, if unable

always to give them effect, the permaneni I heads of departments are credited wit!

die chief blame. But Mr. HEMMANT if often amusingly illogical, and has no yet attained to that perfection in states mansbip which a larger experience wil . enable him to grasp. His tariff plungec

the reader into bathos after perusing tin budget speech, and it still remains ai awkward blot upon his reputation as : 1 financier. He also made another grea 1 mistake when, in the late debate upoi

' tile Suqilus Estimate, he expressed tin , belief that at no distant day a nev

colony would be established lo the nortl of Cape Palmerston, basin g that belie upon the circumstance tha t the Assembl had on the preceding evening prec pitately selected Bowen as the place c residence for the fourth 'Judge. It seem rather premature on the part of th TREASURER to assume that " thc vote < " last night, as far as the Legislativ " Assembly was conoeraed, settled th " boundary of the fu turc new colony This is no doubt Mr. HEMMANT'.? hone opinion, but it would have been bett« not officially expressed, as the hoi gentleman probably thought when h indiscretion was afterwards warmly coi demned by Mr. P'ALMER. Mr. KKMMAK ought to know th at in these days of clectr telegraphs and rapid steamships, ü

tendency is towards union and not division. There are already enough conflicting tariffs in Australia, and the Home Government have pretty distinctly

intimated their intention not to further

multiply them. The truth is that Separa- tion will never be granted to the North until the Queensland Legislature has pronounced in its favour, a proceeding which is not likely to be chronicled during the present decade. It is obviously desirable that the colony should be kept intact, and if it ever bc divided the cause will bc the short-

sightedness and narrow-mindedness of our politicians. Mr. HEMMANT has many good qualities as a Minister, and if he could be induced to shake off the Separation bugbear which dogs his steps, and assist in providing enlightened legislation and vigorous administration, he would render important service in preserving the unity of Queensland.

GLADSTONE OBSERVER.

PUBLISHED DAILY".

TUESDAY, JULY 14, 1874.

THE installation of the Hon. CHARLES LILLEY as one of the Puisne Judges was a ceremony not altogether devoid of public interest. The learned profession, in both branches, was very largely repre- sented, wc are told, and there was also a sprinkling of curious spectators drawn from that outside public which in former days it was Mr. LILLEV'S distinguished honour and unequivocal pleasure to represent in Parliament. The proceed- ings opened with reading the commis- sion, and would probably have ended in a most matter-of-fact way, but for the discovery made by the third Judge that the new Supreme Court Act, to which Mr. LILLEY himself owed his appoint- ment, threatened to interfere with the independer.ee of the Judicial Bench. The defect was thal thc Act which gave thc Cíovcrnmcnl power lo appoint, also empowered them to re- move a Judges to the Northern Districts,

or, to speak with more definiteness, to Bowen. Mr. LILLEY wished it distinctly understood that, iii accepting the ap-

pointment, he had stipulated that on no ' account should he be sent to Bowen, that, in short, he should be permanently stationed in the Southern District of the

colony. The very fact of such a stipu- lation being made at once aroused the CHIEF JUSTICE, who thought it due to himself to see that the independence of the Bench was not tampered with by the possibility of his being sent to Bowen. It is quite clear that His HONOR will be justified in a vigorous attempt at self-preservation in this matter, for it is not to be tolerated that the Chief Justice of the colony should hold hts seat on any less advantageous terms or less secure tenure than a newly ap- pointed judge. There is no doubt that the new Supreme Court Act must be amended, and that some better security for the independence of the Bench is required than the mere assurance of the ATTORNEV-GENERAL that the Govern- ment have no intention to interfere. The intentions of the Government arc not like the laws of the Medes and Persians, and were undue power permanently vested in them in this particular, there is no knowing how soon an obnoxious

judge might be relegated to that sana- torium of the tropics which most men in their vigour are desirous to avoid. Port Denison is no doubt a very fine habitat for invalids, but it is not by any means an attractive location to cultivated men who find intellectual society and the refinements of civilised life scarcely less essential to thc satisfactory performance of their official duties than to complete- ness of their personal comfort

It is, however, not the opinion of the Judges alone that the Supreme Court Act must be amended. It is believed

by many of those best able to judge that Bowen will be found wholly unsuited to be the headquarters of the Supreme Court in the north, and that when the fourth Judge is located, his place of

residence will not bc at Port Denison. But this is a matter which need not here

be further discussed, and our readers may rest assured that time will bring its

own revenges.

In replying to the felicitations of thc ATTORNEY-GENERAL, Mr. LILLEY con- gratulated himself on the circumstance that during a long career he had not made a single personal enemy in the profession. This perhaps is not equally true with regard to the honorable gentle- man's political career ; but, having regard to the extreme course taken by him on more than one occasion, and particularly during those discreditable deadlocks which proved so injurious to the country, it is a matter for satisfaction that Mr. LILLEY made so few personal enemies as he unquestionably did. This, however, is probably attributable to the fact that few antagonists of the learned gentleman in the parliamentary arena could get rid of the impression that he was acting the part of an advocate, or refuse to believe that his greatest displays of indignation were simply put on for the occasion. The smirk of insincerity accompanied the most sweeping tirade, and the deepest emotions were apparently at all times perfectly under

command. Yet with all this there was

not one of our public men who, in addressing a crowd, could assume so convincing a show of real earnestness, or play more effectually upon the sympathies of his audience.

There is every reason to believe that Mr. LILLEY will make a clever, careful, and impartial judge. His past career shows that his dislikes are the objects of impulse rather than vindictiveness. He is by nature a stranger to " hatred, malice, and all uncharitableness," and it is not to be wondered at, therefore, that he has few, if any, enemies. Enmity must be reciprocal or its vitality will soon dis- appear, and enmity is a sentiment that Mr. LILLEY never evinced any disposition

to cherish.

Nor is there much to be dreaded from

deep-seated political prejudice. Thc new Judge is now lifted far above the intrigues of politics and the tricks of legislation. Reposing on his well-won laurels and ermine, and placed by his stipend far beyond the reach of anxiety in pecuniary matters, Mr. Justice LILLEY will regard the past without acrimony. It is easy for him to laugh who wins, and a man whose career is one of unqualified success, can afford to look kindly on old opponents and competitors.

The time, however, is fast approaching when the single step from party politics straight to the judicial bench will be removed, and when a judgeship will be only attained after years of patient labour at the bar, and after a lengthened and unsullied career as a private citizen. It may bc hoped that ere long our Attor- ney-Generals will be non-political, and that a Minister of Justice will be en- trusted with the parliamentary duties now improperly imposed upon the Grand Juror of thc colony.

I TUE usual monthly mooting ot tho com-

mittee of tho Port Curtis and Leichhardt District Hospital Trill he hold in thc Court House this afternoon at four o'clock.

Tin: manner in which Shakespeare's fine comedy, " The Taming of thc Shrew," was put upon the stage last evening at thc Theatre Hoya! merited a mach better house thau was present. Miss Joey acted tho part of Katha- rine tho shrew so as to leave nothing to bo desired, throwing all thc feeling and passion into her part that is called for, and that she

eau so well command. Mr. Thomson also

enacted tho part of Pelruchio with his usual success, quite carrying thc hausa with him in some of thc scenes. Thc musical burlctta of " Gertrude's Lovers," with which thc evening's entertainment was concluded, was well pre- sented and enthusiastically received, Miss Joey and Mr. Thomson dividing tho honours by the performance of their respective parts. Wc were glad to notice tho return of Madame Laportc to thc stage in thc musical intcrludo, when she sang with piquancy sovoral favourite songs. Wo notice that thc samo programme will bo repeated Ulis evening by special request. Thursday will be a bcuolit night for Mr. A. Thomson, when "Lost iu London" will be

presented. J

GLADSTONE O HS S ar ER.

PUBLISHED DAILY. WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 5, 1874.

, THE approaching visit of His Excellency

thc GOVERNOR was a subject for dis- cussion in the Municipal Council yester- day afternoon. The MAYOR, reflecting no doubt the feelings of many persons in thc community, was prepared to show HER MAJESTY'S representative the customary loyal respect ; but the circum- stance that His EXCELLENCY would be accompanied by Mr. MACALISTER, he (the MAYOR) felt to be an obstacle to any public demonstration. He therefore wished to ascertain the opinion of the Council on thc matter. The aldermen ; appeared taken somewhat by surprise, for expressions were let fall which can be excused on no other ground. One gentleman not only objected to enter- taining an unpopular minister, but con- sidering a higher personage responsible for the scant justice meted out to the ' central districts, was opposed to any demonstration whatever. This was a mistake which so old a public man as Mr. FEEZ ought not to have fallen into. He has for many years been living under constitutional government, and must be well aware that " the king can do no wrong." If wrong be done, the fault lies with the advisers of the Crown, who are solely responsible to the people ; and if we as a community have to complain of injustice, the blame must be imputed to the Ministry, and to them alone. The question, therefore, as to entertaining His EXCELLENCY is entirely distinct from any consideration as to thc treatment the town and district has received from the Government, and it is rather unfortunate that this was not more clearly laid'down by the Mayor in his opening remarks. We are quite sure, however, that no mark of disrespect was intended to the GOVERNOR, and that thc Aldermen of Rockhampton would be amongst the first to resent any such proceeding. On the contrary, they arc well aware that the colony owes much to His EXCELLENCY, But for his firm-

ness in vindicating constitutional practice on his first arrival in the colony, irrepar- able mischief would have been done to our free institutions ; and, instead of the comparative general contentment which followed the impartial administration of the PALMER Government, we should have seen the residents of the various

districts of the colony split up into hostile factions, and have witnessed as near an approach to anarchy as was pos- sible in a community of Englishmen enjoying the privileges of self-government In thc Central Districts we have special reasonstobe grateful lo Hts EXCELLENCY, for his happy and distinct enunciation of constitutional principles ; for, however

much reason there may be for complaint at present, our case would liave been in- finitely worse had a weak-minded or popularity-seeking Governor been sta- tioned amongst us at that juncture. It is quite clear that if there are to be future dead-locks in the Assembly, it will not be the fault of thc noble lord who, fortu- nately, is the representative of HER MAJESTV in Quecnland at the present

time.

It is also, we believe, a mistake to suppose that the GOVERNOR desires any organised public demonstration of welcome on his arrival. The presump- tion is that he will but too gladly escape the reception of addresses from the Municipal Council and other public bodies. Such ceremonies must not be

too often repeated, or they become dis- tasteful and wearisome. In Rockhamp- ton we gave Hts EXCELLENCY an enthusiastic reception on his first arrival tn the colony, and although there is no reason to regretv that step, we know of

no special reason why it should be j repeated now. It has not yet been i

announced that the tour is an official

one. We shall all be glad to see our ; excellent GOVERNOR again amongst us, ; and if occasion offer, shall be prepared to testify our loyalty in no ambiguous manner; hut it seems no particular occasion for any great display, and pro- bably, tinder the circumstances, an exhibition of overflowing ' enthusiasm would only give rise to suspicion. At thc same time, some opportunity should he afforded the citizens of meeting the

GOVERNOR, and of suitably testifying j their loyalty to thc Crown, and their high appreciation of its distinguished representative in the colony. Judging from the result of the discussion yester- day afternoon, however, the Mayor and Aldermen may be trusted to do their duty in the matter at the proper time.

The public will, to some extent, sympathise with the unwillingness felt by certain members of the Council to join in any demonstration which would imply satisfaction with Mr. MACALISTER.

But wc have no hesitation in : saying that no such aversion must be betrayed if we desire to entertain the GOVERNOR. Mr. MACALISTER comes

to us not in the capacity of a personal friend, but as the first Minister of the Crown, and he is entitled to be treated with consideration and respect. We cannot dissociate him from his official position. By the action of constitutional government, the honorable gentleman has reached the summit of political power in the colony, and any disrespct shown towards him by the people of Rockhampton would be a reflection upon thc wisdom of the Legislature. That would be at least impolitic, for it could not possibly prove ol any local benefit. On the contrary, it would bring the community into contempt, and the consequences might be unpleasant. There are constitutional ways of express- ing disapproval of Mr. MACALISTER'S conduct, and those, however cordially we may receive him as Premier, will still be freely at our command. We may have a very decided opinion as to the honorable gentleman's personal and political worth, and be never slow to express it at the proper time ; but any public display of aversion or even apathy whim he visits us under guberna- torial tutelage would be an impropriety which might furnish matter for lasting regret. It may be hoped, therefore, that in considering whether any or what mark of respect shall bc paid to His EXCEL- LENCY, no stumbling-block will be found

in the circumstance that he is accom-

panied by a Minister of the Crown who is personally distasteful to Her Majesty's loyal subjects in Rockhampton.

--JJT--- -

PUBLISHED D A.ILY.

FRIDAY, JULY 21, 1874.

AMONGST the most useful provisions of the new Insolvency Act are those grouped under the heads, " Liquidation by Arrangement," and "Composition with

Creditors." - These will be found in

sections 202 to 205 inclusive, and are of sufficient length and importance to form an Act in themselves. Sub-section 1 of section 202 provides that a person unable to pay his debts may call a meeting of creditors, who may pass a " special

resolution " that the affairs of the debtor

are to be liquidated by arrangement and not in insolvency ; and at some subse- quent meeting held after an interval of not more than a week, the creditors may appoint a trustee, with or without a committee of inspection. In subsection 4 it is provided that on being satisfied after due inquiry that such " special resolution " was passed in due conformity with the Act, and that a trustee 'has been appointed, the district registrar "shall forthwith register the " resolution, iand the statement of the " the assets and debts of the debtor, " and such Resolution and statement " shall be open for inspection on the " prescribed conditions, and the liquida " tion by arrangement shall be deemed " to have commenced as from thc date " of the appointment of the trustee." It is ,thenjrApvided that the trustee shall have, so ur ^s is requisite, the status of a trustee in insolvency, and thc certificate of the principal registrar in respect of his appointment will have the same effect ' as a certificate of the court to the

lite effect in the case of an insolvency. The provisions of the Act with regard to the close of insolvency and discharge of the insolvent, however, will not apply in cases ofliquidation by arrangement, but thc close of the liquidation, discharge of the debtor, and release of the trustee, may be granted by a general meeting of creditors upon such terms and conditions as they may think fit. It is further pro- vided that the trustee shall report the discharge of the debtor to the principal registrar, whose certificate of discharge will have the same force and effect as a certificate in insolvency.

Sections 204 and 205 provide for com- positions. " The creditors of a debtor "unable to pay his debts may, " without any proceedings in insolvency, " by an extraordinary resolution resolve " that a composition shall be accepted in "satisfaction of the debts due to them " from the debtor." 31ut such resolution

. must be passed by a mtijorili/ in number

and f Jircc-fouvlhs in value of the creditors of the debtor assembled at a general meeting in the prescribed manner. The " extraordinary resolution " will then be registered as in the case of liquidation by arrangement, very strict directions being laid don n to the registrar as lo the lona fidrs of the proceedings. It is also provided that registration in such case

shall, in the absence of fraud, be con- clusive evidence that such resolution was duly passed, but it may nevertheless be afterwards set aside or discharged by the court on sufficient cause being shown.

The penal clauses of the Act are elaborately drawn, and sufficiently severe. An insolvent will be deemed guilty of a misdemeanour and become liable to three years' imprisonment for any of the following specific acts, unless the jury is satisfied that he had no intent

to defraud :

1. Failing to tho host of his knowledge and belief to discover to the trustee all IUB pro- perty, and how and to whom be has disposed

af it.

2. Failing to deliver up all such property as may bc in his custody.

3. Failing to deliver up booka and papers.

4. Concealing property or debts duo to or .

from him.

fi. Fraudulently removing property. ! fi. Omitting a material statement iu relation

to his affairs. |

7. Conniving at proof of a false ilebt. < 8. Preventing tho production of any book j

or document relating to his affairs.

9. Concaaling, destroying, mutilating, or falsifying any of bis books or documents.

10. Conniving nt a false entry.

11. Fraudulently.parting with any docu- , ments, altering, or making any omission in them, or being privy thereto.

12. Accounting for insolvency by alleging fictitious losses or expenses.

13. Obtaining property on credit by any false representation.

14. Obtaining property under the falso pre- tence of carrying on business and dealing in the ordinary way.

15. Pawuing, pledging, or disiiosing of pro ) porty otherwise than in tho ordinary way of

trade.

IC Obtaining consent of creditors to any agreement as to his affairs on false or fraudulent representations.

17. Omitting to keep proper books of

account.

It is perhaps sufficient for the honest debtor that lie will escape all penalties on satisfying thc jury that he had no intent to defraud or conceal the true state of his affairs. But it will be observed that the jury are required to give a verdict against him unless they are satisfiedofhisinnocence. Thisisvastly different from the ordinary procedure in our criminal courts, in which innocence must be assumed until guilt is proved. It is very unlikely, however, that in matters of insolvency juries will be difficult to satisfy, the prevailing tendency in such cases being to " give the poor fellow a " chance." Section 209 imposes a penalty of one year's imprisonment upon any creditor making a false claim. Sub- sequent sections render any person concealing an insolvent's property liable to six months'imprisonment; and impose a penalty of three years' imprisonment upon any person receiving or embezzling an insolvent's property with intent to

defraud his creditors.

The 2161h section empowers an insolvency court to summarily commit a fraudulent insolvent for trial, and in such case the expense of prosecution will be borne by thc Crown.

Sections 222 to 225 inclusive abolish the office of official assignee, and require that all books and papers now held by any official assignee be handed over to I the accountant in insolvency, to be clas-

sified and registered under the direction of a judge of the Supreme Court. It is also provided that after the expiration of two years all moneys then standing to the credit of the Unclaimed Dividend Fund created by the Act- of 1864, shall be paid to thc credit of the Consolidated

Revenue.

Our lengthened notice of this Act must be justified by the great importance of llic subject with which it deals. Its effect upon the system of credit, upon which nearly the whole of our business is conducted, may be expected to be great and beneficial. Credit is the outcome of confidence between seller and buyer, and the tendency of the new Act will bc, we think, to foster confidence by discountenancing and punishing dis- honesty. One feature of the Act may be referred to as unique. The fraudulent ' creditor, as well as the fraudulent debtor,

is brought within the scope of its penal clauses, a provision which probably sup-

plies a better guarantee against roguery j than any penalty yet devised. On the ] i whole, the new Act is certainly a good one,

and, although not perfect in all its details, ' its principles come to us from other

countries, where the brightest intellects of the age have been engaged in perfect- ing legislation upon the subject. Of course much -.viii depend upon the ad- ministration of the new law, but if our courts, legal practioners, and merchants combine to give it free scope, there need be little apprehension as to the eventual

result.

WE aro informed that it is contemplated to Btart Turkish Baths in Rockhampton, on tho premises lately occupied by Mr. M. L. Martin, East-street. Our informant could not supply the name of the gentleman about to atart thc project, but we can only say with reference to au intention proved to bc of such service in promoting health and cleanliness, that wo wish its enterprising promoter every

SUCCC6B.

A MAN named John Byrne was brought

before tho Police Court yesterday charged j with wife desertion. Michael Sheridan proved

thc arrest of thc prisoner at Westwood on the j evening of thc 21st instant, from, information received and from particulars giveu in the

Police Gazelle of New South Wales. At the | request of tho police the case was remanded ! for eight days to give time for the production

of the warrant from Sydney. On the oppli-. cation of tho prisoner bail was allowed, him- j self in £25, and one surety for £25.

Ocn telegram from Cooktowu, hy way of Cardwell, contains rather exciting news, but readers of Queensland journals have uow be- come so accustomed to startling intelligence from that part of the colony, that they will not be unduly agitated by tho announcement that Rome people at the now rush liave got twenty-tive pounds weight of gold in a few days, while others have procured even moro. There is un doubt, hov.-cvei', that, some rich groundhasl>ceinVnsC"Veruiltand it mayliubopcd th.it if there bc a second nish it will tum out lesa ilisastrounly tha.ii tho first. We ave in- debted to Messrs. ll. M. Hunter and Co., for inspection of a telegram received by them f rom Cooktown yesterday, hut it is for thu most part identical with our own message, and is evidently based upon thc same intelligence from thc iligj-iugi

n

articleText:
&[)enorthampton bulletin,

WITH WHICH I« INCORrOKtVTfa THC

GLADSTONE OH ¿SR UV 8 lt

PUBLISHED DA.IL1Y".

FBIDAY, FlïBKUAltV 27, 1874.

A ri:\v days ago, some correspondence appeared in our columns on the subject of Building Societies. About the same . time a pamphlet, hy Afr. li. !.. DIHDI.V,

was also issued to the' public. The pamphlet deals with the subject in a simple manner, and on the whole states fairly the advantages of such societies. Out correspondents, on the other hand, |K)int out how the needy borrower may find himself considerably victimised by attempting lo participate too freely in llie benefits a building society is intended to confer. Al a lime like thc present, when houses in Rockhampton are not lo he procured, and when many families are obliged to occupy buildings neither com- fortable norhcaliliful, the i|ueslion how to increase anil improve the dwellings of the people is one of much importance. Rock- hampton has long since passed through the mushroom stage of existence, bul its house accommodation has not ad- vanced with the times, and is, in fact,

inferior lo that provided in any town in : thc souillent part of the colony. At thc same time, climatic peculiarities render it very desirable that, in point of roominess and ventilation at least, our dwellings should he superior to those in use where less intense, or any rate, less prolonged heat of the weather has to be contended

against. But property owners tell us that j house-building in Rockhampton, except for business purposes, is an unre munerativc investment, and thai they

can use their limited means to much better advantage. They admit thal good rents may be obtained, but these, through the heavy cost of repairs and rapid depreciation of buildings, do not in the long run rctum the house owner bank interest. And as he is always subject lo the risk of having his houses tenantless, the investment is not by any means an attractive one.

One great «use of the landlord's troubles is the scarcity and costliness of good building materials. Wooden houses are preferred for dwellings, bul unless substantially built throughout of hardwood, they often prove bul very temporary structures, il is now pretty generally held thal, as a nile, wooden buildings, to be remunerative, must yield a rent which will return the principal in five years. On this calculation, a ¡louse costing ^300 should produce a rental of not less than £60 per annum an amount of return which under

no ordinary circumstances can be hoped for. There is a prejudice against brick dwellings, on the ground that they are usually close, frequently damp, and generally unwholesome. Rockhampton bricks .-ire at best bad, and therefore no one uses them for dwelling-houses unless under compulsion. In the blocks pro- claimed first-class, wooden buildings are not allowed, and hence dwelling-houses

are not erected within their limits. Until

belter clay or better brick-makers can be procured, therefore, houses tised for residence will he built of wood, and as a necessary consequence house-rents generally will be dear-too dear, in fact, lo admit of the hope that llie humbler classes of the population will lie either comfortably or healthfully boused for some years to come, unless some means can lie found of enabling every industrious and thrifty mau to provide his own house accommodation. Experience proves thal a wooden house which in the hands of shifting and care- less tenants does not rel urn five per cent upon its cost, would in the occupa-

tion of a careful owner be an excellent

investment. With the exercise of

ordinary care and judgment, a working man, by becoming his own landlord, may pretty confidently reckon on a handsome return upon his savings, beside ensuring lo his family far more comfortable (platters than would otherwise be pro-

curable.

The motto of liuilding Societies is, "livery man his own landlord," and there

can be no doubl that iinderfavourable «¡1

ciunslances Ibo practice of such societies , is ciptal to their professions. They

are based 011 a co-operative or mutual

principle, which returns to the members rateably all the net profits made by Ihe association. When therefore the ex- penses of management are small, the loans prudenlly effected, and (he profits equitably divided, thc benefits must be

considerable, ft is Inie that a borrower

may, hy going beyond his means, involve himself in difficulties, but in dealing n illi finance care and prudence are always indispensable conditions of success. A borrower may, in certain cases, pay a high rate of interest, but as without thc help of a building society he could not have been a borrower at all, exceptional circumstances may justify what would otherwise be excessive pay- ments for monetary accommodation

Huilding Societies aie primarily in- tended for thc man of small means, and for the fostering of thrifty and frugal habits amongst persons in receipt

of fixed incomes. It has been

argued with much force that if a man can live on one pound a-week, he may, by denying himself some small luxury, live upon nineteen shillings and

save the balance. An inducement to self-denial in such a case is needed, and that is supplied by the building society. I jet us suppose the case of a mechanic earning three pounds per week. Jf not burdened with a large family he might live comfortably on two-thirds of that sum, or. al any rate, pay a house rent of len shillings and save ten. He is in-possession of £100 cash, and, intending to build a cottage for himself, wishes to borrow ^200 for that purpose. "He takes four shares in a building society, the ultimate value of which, al

¿50 each, will be .£200. He then >

borrows the whole amount of his shares al the rate of fourteen per cent per anmmi. His payments to the society will then be-Subscriptions on four shares, £2 per month ; interest at

¿14 per cent, £1 6s. Sd.; total, ¿£4 ; ?5s. fA. per month, or just ,£52 per j annum. This is equal to £\ per

week, or exaelly the amount of ' his ordinary house-rent and savings. He is now rent free, and at thc end of five years and a-half thc society winds up, and our friend's property is clear of liability. He bxs liad the use of the society's money for thc whole term, and has paid back, in all, or ,£86 more than he origin- ally borrowed. His interest has thus been below the rate of eight per cent, per annum, and the money having been relumed in monthly instalments, he has never felt the payments burdensome. Such a man would have been unable to borrow .£200 from a money-lender, bul it will be interesting lo compare the cost of the loan in such a case. Thc interest on ¿£200, al io per cent per annum, would amount for the live years and a-half to ¿£110, after payment of

which the borrower must return the

whole of thc original loan. H is thus clearly shown that by borrowing from the building society, ni the high rate of fourteen per cent, he has gained just ,£24. There is no possible jugglery in these figures, and their correctness has been repeatedly demonstrated by practice. The truth is that the members of building societies mutually shale in thc profits, and thus thc borrower, while paying interest on the advance received, is also credited with interest paid by other shareholders on the money he returns to the society. The profits of building societies are also much enhanced by temporary advances from their bankers. For these they pay interest at the rate of (say) eight per cent, while they re-lend the money at rates varying from thirteen to fifteen per \ cent.

The illustration we have given proves (lie direel advantage to be derived from connection with a building society. The nun in humble circumstances is en- couraged to husband his means, and whether he remains a subscribing member or also becomes a borrower, he is insured a rate of interest on his savings which he cannot hope to obtain in any other way. Tile only precaution (0 be taken is, not to attempt too much. In no case should a man of fixed income so involve himself that his monthly payments, for both subscription anil interest, will exceed the amount of his ordinary rental and savings, lt is true that even such a man may build to let as well as to occupy, but if he do so, lie will enter upon a speculation which may or may not be successful, and he must accept the risk of the trans- action. Hut in erecting a house for his own occupancy with the aid of the building society, in the manner above described, it is clear that any man in steady employment is making a prudent use of the means at his disposal.

Of course thc success of building societies wholly depends upon their good management. (In this point, however, the intending shareholder need feel 110 apprehension here. The building societies of Rockhampton are, like most of thc institutions of thc town, well conducted, and are in the hands of men whohave proved themselves worthy of the

confidence of their fellow-townsmen.

Il is satisfactory to learn that the society last started gives promise of being the most successful yet established.

AK iillicial telegram received by Mr. I'eter sou yesterday fruin thc (louerai Post Office, lii-ishauc, states that thc Iv.M.S. JScittoiu « ill arrive at (Hailstone about Friday next, thc

«th March.

Turin-: is only one case set down for trial before thc District Ourt at (Hailstone., tobe held «it the I Uh proximo in its criminal juris- diction, and that is tho oise of William Finbcrsoii, for stealing a burse, the alleged properly of .lohn ,S. Kirby. As far as wc can remember lhere was 110 direct proof at thu preliminary examination that thu animal in question caine wrongfully into thc possession of thc accused, who alleged tlmt ho piireh ised her somewhere near the Calliope diggings. However thc burse or rather mare, is now dead and it is just possible that, none «if the witnesses can silllieicntly identify her, least, of all as being tho property of Mr. Kirby. Although the t'oiirl in thc prisent, installe" must meet in accordance with auciout custom, ii is a custom more honoured in the breach than the observance, because it entails un- necessary expense with no adequate result.

- _

PUBLISHED DA.ILY.

WEDNESDAY, MAV 20, 1874.

THE Commission appointed by His Excellency the GOVERNOR to inquire into and report upon the condition of the Queensland aborigines, has not succeeded in striking a new vein. Their report embodies facts which have long been patent, and which, however much to be deplored by all humane persons, will continue facts until the aboriginal race of Australia is extinct. When we are told that the aborigines are fast decreasing in numbers, that they are passionately fond of and easily procure intoxicating liquors, that disease com- municated by intercourse with Europeans is making fearful ravages among their young, that the whole race have an unconquerable aversion to persistent labour, and that little can be done towards ameliorating their condition, we can only say that similar conclusions have been arrived at on several previous occasions. And the subsequent recom- mendations of the Commission fall upon the ear with a similarly hackneyed sound. The appointment of protectors of aborigines, the setting apart of reserves for their exclusive use, thc building of huts on such reserves, the supply of implements for cultivating the soil, of rations, clothing, and medical aid,-ave all recommended. And, further, it is urged that special effort be made to improve, educate, and Christianise the young by the establishment of schools, and that more stringent legislation be enacted with a view to suppress the sale of intoxicating liquors to the aborigines. All this was recommended and tried in former years, and unhappily with but very slight suc- cess. Thc only result attained has been thc demonstration that the decay of the race may be temporarily arrested, but that with the most earnest and philan- thropic efforts ultimate extinction must

ensue. The fact seems to be that these children of nature cannot be civilised without damage to their physical health, and that they cannot even be civilised without restraint, which to them is intol- erable slavery. The natural habitat of the Australian native is thc bush, his only work is hunting for his daily food, and experience proves that if cooped up and kept at any steady occupation physical deterioration invariably ensues. It is a melancholy conclusion, but still a true one, that the aboriginal Australian can only exist and flourish in a savage state ; and that any attempt to raise his condition mentally or morally is inva- riably attended by a lowering of the vital force. Under such circumstances, thc efforts of good men to civilise the aborigines may be a labour of love, but it can scarcely be deemed an encouraging enterprise. And as, even in en- deavouring to spread Christianity it is usual to look for results, there is not much hope of missions to the aborigines being regarded with much enthusiasm by the Christian Church. Tile salvation of an aboriginal native is not of more importance than the sal- vation of a colonist of European extrac- tion, and therefore while so much remains to be done in Christianising our own countrymen, it can hardly be expected that labour will be uselessly expended upon a race whose extinction may be postponed but cannot be averted.

It is satisfactory to note that the Commissioner has found that, generally speaking, the aborigines are treated with kindness and forbearance by thc settlers of the colony, and that thc cruelty some- times practised upon them is ordinarily

the result of their own misdeeds. It has generally been found impracticable to punish thc aboriginal criminal through the ordinary courts of justice, and, consequently, the colonists have occa l sionally been compelled to lake thc law

into their own hands. In such cases the justice meted out lias no doubt been of a retributive character, and the punishment due to the individual lias been inflicted upon the tribe. This state of affairs, however, results from tile diffi- culty of dealing with a race of savages who respect no promise and can be bound by no treaty, and who, in fact, can only be kept from the perpetration of crime by the deterrent element of fear. In such case, the outraged settler cannot be blamed if lie regard the whole " myall " race as enemies, to be treated like other noxious animals of the forest, and kept at a safe distance by the dread of powder

and ball.

There is no doubt thal much maudlin sympathy is wasted upon our aboriginal neighbours. Necessity knows no law, and if the country is to be occupied by the colonists, the savages who formerly possessed it must be taught to respect both life and property by such rough and ready methods of instruction as the

settler can command. It would be a

work of years to impress upon the savage mind the principles contained in the ten commandments, however zealous the missionary engaged in that laudable work. In the meantime, the ferocious savage would remain the master of the situation, and find the thirst for blood cultivated by his exploits, a sufficient antidote to the benign principles of Christianity inculcated by his religious

teachers.

To us il appears that there is only one way of civilising and utilising our abori- ginal race. That is, by a policy of isolation and restraint, which would be, in fact, a species of mild slavery. On this point all English-speaking people are peculiarly sensitive, and the proba- bility is that, of the two methods of dealing with thc blacks, the existing one is really open to the least objection. So long as kindness is the rule and cruelty the exception, the policy of non-inter- ference is that most fitting for the Government to adopt. Unfortunately, this policy is not always practicable. Where the blacks are of the " myall " or untameable class it is necessary to bring the Native Police Force into re- quisition, and make the carbine the great instrument of civilisation. And unhappily the employment of this force entails upon the community some at least of the horrors of war. The officers

in command are not usually men of humane or otherwise irreproachable character. The work is at best repulsive to all right-minded persons, and there

lore, mose engagea in it can naraiy ue expected to temper mercy with justice. It is but just to admit, however, thal there ha ve been instances of good and humane men taking charge of Native Police troopers, and that under their control thc force has been no discredit to the colony. But such cases are ex- ceptional, and there can be no question that generally speaking the " dispersing" duties of the Native Police are per- formed willi blood-thirsty ferocity, and therefore we lake il that the employment of this force can only be justified on the ground of necessity. It is unquestion- ably the duty of the Government to dis- pense with native troopers at thc earliest possible time, and confine them entirely to those districts where life and property would be unsafe without their presence. It is doubtful we think, whether the re- commendations of the Commission will bc acted upon. On the whole it is perhaps better to trust lo the humanity and kindness of individual colonists, than to appoint protectors whose officiousness has in time past led to the commission of the very cruelties which they have righteously denounced. There is such a thing as sentimental humanity, the character of which is purely theoretical,

and which tends rather to embitter than

mollify thc antagonism subsisting between the colonists and their aboriginal neigh- bours. It must not be assumed, how- ever, thal, holding these views, we fail to appreciate the labours of thc Com- mission. Its appointment is a proof that the well-being of the native race is a subject of anxiety on the part of our rulers, and the publication of the report will tend to refute the slanderous aspersion that the colonists of Queens- land are pursuing towards the aborigines a policy of relentless extermination.

[ MAILS for Sydney and the Australian colo-

nies per Florence Irving will close at tho Post Office this (Wednesday) evening at 8 o'clock.

AT thc Polico Oourt yesterday morning, before Mr. Frank N. Bcddek, J. P., one drunkard-an old offender was lined 20s., or 24 hours in the cells.

A MEETIXII of thc Rockhampton Bread Association is advertised to take place this evening at thc Crusader's Hall, IW'iain-strcot, to receive the committee's report.

Tin; s.s. Tinonee brought six malo prisoners from the north yesterday afternoon. Three of these arc under sentence from To« ns\ Me, two are under committal from Cooktown to Towns\"e for forgery, and one from St. Law .-once to Rockhampton for larceny. They wi" be tried at thc next sittings of tho District Court, thc two former at Tow .isviltc, where they will have to he sent at thc public expense, and thc latter at Kockhamptoti.

INFOIIMATION reached thc local police station yesterday morniuj, a l'ttlo after nine o'clock, that Mr. Jacob Foster, who was in thc employ of Sir. W. Jagcr as superintendent ot his slaughtering estiV'sl' neut, and who was residing on thc promises at thc corner of Bolsover and Fit;.-oy stroets had been acci- dentally poisoned. Mr. Sub inspector Isley, with thc Health Officer, and Mr. F. N. Bcddek immediately went to the house and viewed the body, which was lying in lied in tho deceased's bedroom, ami from the utatc incnts of the f.-mily and servants it Appears that he had been ill a", thc previous night, and bail taken «onie medicino ; towards morn- ing bc had also partaken of a cup of tea, ami died from thc effects of poison between eight and nine o'clock. Mr. Bcddek gave thc necessary order for interment, and thc burial tonk place during thc afternoon. A magisterial inquiry into thc causo of death was eoinmencod before Mr. F. N. Bcddek, J.)'., at three o'clock, and lasted until dark, when it was adjourned for further evidence. Thc testimony of six witnesses was taken, which wc «hall publish when tbc inquiry is

concluded.

GLADSTONE O BS Bli VE ll

PUBLISHED DAILY.

TUESDAY, MARCH 17, 187-1.

THE question lins been long agitating New South Wales politicians as to whether an elective Upper House is de- sirable or not. The Assembly lias decided in the affirmative, but there seems little probability of the Legislative Council voting for its own extinction. More- over, some of the ablest members of the 1 ,ower House object to an elective Upper House, and rite the example of Victoria, where the Legislative Council, claiming to be representatives of the people, ob- structed all legislation for two years. Amongst die opponents of an elective chamber is Mr. WILLIAM FORSTER, the Colonial Secretary in Sir JAMES MAR- TIN'S late Administration, who holds that the number of members in the

existing Council should be considerably increased, and thc nominee system pre- served. It appears from a recent debate in the legislative Assembly, that although tile number of members in the Council is not restricted by the New South Wales Constitution Act, it was determined by a correspondence between the Secretary of State and a former Governor (Sir JOHN YOUNO) that twenty

seven members was a " convenient " number for the " House of Peers," and that unless in case of emergency that number should not be exceeded, il appeared also that about two years ago, a few days before Sir JAMES MARTIN'S administration fell, it recommended the appointment of two additional members to the Legislative Council. The GOVER- NOR declined to make thc appointments, on various grounds. Amongst these was the fact that, at the time, the " con- venient" number of twenty-seven had been slightly exceeded ; and the GOVER- NOR was also influenced by the consider- ation that, after an appeal to the country, the Ministry would in a few days en- counter a hostile majority in Parliament -a conclusion fully justified by subse- quent events. Mr. FORSTER, however, taking umbrage at His EXCELLENCY'S refusal to accept advice in the matter, resigned his portfolio, and after two years' reflection has introduced thc fol- lowing motion :

"1. That this House is of opinion that any attempt on thu part nf any (lovornor of thin colony, or of nny Secretary of State in Great IVitain, ivheUw.r hy despatches or instructions, or otherwise, to interfere with the appointment of members of thc Legislative (Council of this colrnij', or on the part of any Minister of tho Orowu in this colony to sanction such inter- férence so as in any way to limit or restrain thu power of thc líovcrmnciit of this colony in wich appointment, or to permanently limit thc immhcr of members of such f-onneu, or ti) con- fine such number to a fixed standard, is con- trary to law, and subversivo of tho rights and privileges of thc I ¡ovorimicut and legislature of this colony. 2. That the above resolution bc transmittal! hy aildvcss to his Excellency

the tïnvci'iior."

l'Ile hon. mover supported his resolu- tion in a laboured speech, which was followed hy an amendment from Mr. HUCUANAX, suggesting that "it would be advantageous to the " best interests of Great Hritain as well "as of New South Wales that the

" political connection existing between " them should cease, and that the people " of New South Wales*should be left in

" the full possession of their independent " right lo govern themselves without " interference of any kind from any " (juarter." Strange to say, the amend- ment found a seconder, but no one, except the mover, appeared to possess audacity enough to utter a word in its favour. After debate, Mr. PARKES, in an exhaustive speech, demonstrated the fallacies on which Mr. FORSTER had founded In's motion, and proved that there hadbeen noimproper interference on the part of the liritish Government with the rights and privileges of thc colonists

of New South Wales.

This is a very large question, and one in which the colonists of Queensland have a deep interest. The GOVERNOR, shortly before the late Ministry retired from office, made several appointments lo the Legislative Council, raising the number to twenty-seven. Hts KXCEI.I.E.VCV has since appointed another member, the Hon. GEHRCK THORN, Postmaster-Ge- neral, and thus lias passed the limit deemed in the mother colony to ¡ie tile " convenient" one. Accepting twenty seven as the convenient number, there does appear some trudi in thc accu- sation that the late Government had crammed the Upper House, in the hope of frustrating the Radical pro- jects of their opponents. Our Con- stitution Act, like that of New South Wales, fixes no limit to the number, but

authorises the GOVERNOR to summon in Her Majesty's name, " under die Great " Seal of tile said colony, from lime to " time, to the Î .egislative Council, such " person or persons as bc shall think " fit." ft therefore rests entirely xvidi the GOVERNOR, if we may judge by the language of the Act, to increase the num- ber of members as he shall think fit, and die Ministry for thc time being need not be consulted in the maller. Otherwise the words "by the advice of the Executive Council " would certainly have been ? inserted. Looked at in this light, thc late

Ministry are in noway responsible for the appointments recently made to the Legis- lative Council, although it is not impro- bable that His EXCKU.ENCV'S action has forwarded the interests of their party.

As yet the Upper House in Queens- land has rarely shown a disposition to obstruct salutary reforms, but that may have partly arisen from its numeri-

cal weakness. Its recent accession of strength may dcvclope a less accommo- dating spirit, and it is not impossible that the Assembly may find much of their labour lost through non-compati- bility with the upper branch of the Legis- lature. In this state of affairs, il is consoling to know that the GOVERNOR, in case of a deadlock, is entrusted with a constitutional key ; and although il would be in the highest degree mischievous for the prerogative of the Crown to be used in the interest of any particular parly, His EXCKIXKNCV might be relied upon to interpose did thc Legislative Council evince any disposition lo abuse the powers and privileges conferred upon them by the Constitution Act. Under these circumstances it is very unlikely that any measures will at present be taken for making thc Legislative Council of Queensland an elective chamber. We can, at any rate, well afford to await the issue of the experiments making in the two more advanced colonies of the group.

OUR Clermont contemporary of Wed- nesday last has a leading article on the shortcomings of the Telegraph Depart- ment since the era of shilling telegrams. Thc public have borne with the delays hitherto in a most commendable spirit, bul the question is now being asked, with some pertinacity, when the Tele- graph Department will be able lo cope effectively with the business (lowing in upon it ? So far the shilling telegrams have beena very questionable benefit, on account of the frequent delays in transmis- sion ; and, unless the department intends to increase its wires, its instruments, and its staff, the rales had better revert to the old figure. This, however, is one of those

cases in which retrogression is im- j practicable, and therefore Mr. CRACK-j NELL must be stirred up, and required either lo kee]) pace willi the times or

make room for a man who will. Even with continuous fine weather the existing wires are unable to carry the business thrust upon them, but when wet weather occurs the accumulation of business at the principal offices is enough to strike terror into the hearts of the operators. I5y hook or by crook, the department manages occasionally to get through its work, but if every case could be shown in which tardiness of transmission and interruptions had prevented the sending of messages, the necessity of greater facilities would at once be apparent. Were prompt replies the rule instead of the exception, il would be found that telegraphic business would increase beyond all present concep-

tions.

It may be hoped that the Ministry will show an intelligent appreciation of thc wants of the colony in this respect, and that they will ask the Legislative Assembly to make liberal provision for extending the telegraphic service, which al present is only in its infancy. The telegraph is of special advantage in a country like this, where distance forms

so serious an obstruction to business transactions. We have no doubt that the time will come when persons will meet by appointment al telegraph offices hundreds of miles apart, and transact business willi almost as much

facility as though they were within speaking distance of eacli other. In the article published in yesterday's Bulletin respecting the late attack upon Harrow's Creek telegraph station, we were told I )r. GOSSE, from the Adelaide telegraph office, gave full medical instructions up to near the wounded officer's end, and that, when the patient was getting worse, his wife was sent for by Mr. Tomi, and conversed with her fast-sinking husband by wire-a melancholy pleasure, no doubt, but still one whose value cannot be estimated in money. Thc one essential advantage of telegraphs over all other means of communication is, their instantaneous operation, and therefore the greater average celerity in the transmission of messages the greater advantage to thc public. This is a matter in which every colonist has a deep interest, and therefore the Govern- ment may propose a liberal expenditure upon it without laying themselves open to a charge of extravagance, or of favour- ing one part of thc colony at the expense of another, livery additional hundred miles of wire confers fresh benefit upon the whole colony, and indeed upon the whole of Australia, and therefore tele- graph construction may very properly lie regarded as a cosmopolitan work.

AT tho Police Court yesterday morning, before thc Police Magistrate, four drunkards were admonished and discharged.

WITH regard to thc imniiry into the circum- stances attending the late accident to the James Paterson, s.s., wc understand Hint tho evidence points to thc conclusion that neither tho intricacies of the channel nor the st:ite of the weather are chargeable with the respon- sibility of tli.it disaster. 1 f this be so, it may bc hoped that neither thc Marine Board nor thc A.S.N. Company will ho induced by false delicacy to refrain from meting out censure where censure is due. Persons in charge nf steamers are entrusted with really serious responsibilities, and carelessness nu their part should meet with exemplary punishment.

Tm; rapid spread of Bathurst burr and «'ula rfiiusa is creating some alarm amongst graziers in this part of thc colliny. We understand that thc I invcnuiicnt has been applied to in the hope that measures will be taken to extir- pate these pests from along main roads and waste lands, which being done, private land- owners will no doubt lie stirred up to action. Wc notice that in New South Wales thu »Ma rrttma is being collected for the Liverpool paper mills, it having been found to bc an ex-

cellent material for manufacturing paper. Wc ! sincerely hope that thu supply will minn bo j exhausted in tho sister colony, and that thu j weed will ore long become a marketable coin- : modity in Queensland.

WITH WHICH ffl INCO&rOKiTKIl TH ti

GLADSTONE ÖiSÄEFff».

PUBLISHED DAILY.

MONDAY, MARCH 23, 1874.

Ouu Brisbane telegram, notifying that in future the Tones Strait mail steamers will rim through from Hongkong to

Melbourne, is gratifying intelligence, as j

indicating thc future commercial success

of the line. A few days since we I

were told that an offer to allow the j steamers lo call at Port Darwin was ¡ in consideration by the South Aus- tralian Government, and it is even yet possible that the proposal will be accepted. Hut with thal we have comparatively small concern, for however desirable it may be to conned Port Darwin and the northern settlements of Queensland, the boats calling al Palmerston would involve some delay in thc usual service, which might much abridge its utility.... J)jlt."irJ}^ and Melbourne on the other, is a very different matter. Wc shall bc thus brought into direct communication with China, not only without the detention of our homeward-bound mails, but under circumstances which make il probable that their transmission will be accelerated. As we understand the telegram, Singa- pore will lie the Company's central port in the Haslem seas, the mails being conveyed thence, north-easterly to China on the one band, and south-easterly to Australia on the other. Starling from Melbourne, the calling-places of the steamers will probably be Port Jackson, Moreton Hay, Keppel Hay, Port Denison, Rockingham Hay, Cape York, Java, and Singapore. Thc homeward Australian mail will be there Iranshipped, and after taking on board the China outward mails, the Australian boat will continue her voyage to Hong Kong, reluming thence with the home- ward mail in lime to catch the next out- ward Australian mail at Singapore. The steamer will -then start for Melbourne via Java and Queensland.

There is already considerable trade: between Melbourne and China, and thc probability is that finding less encourage ment than was expected at Sydney, thc Company have determined to cater foi the Melbourne and China trade. And i it is not impossible that négociation! I have been privately going on with thc Victorian Government with the object o making Mclhournethc terininusof the mai' I service. If this bc thc case, Mr. FRANCK will have obtained another diplomatic I victory over Mr. PARKIÎS, who, if repor be credited, has behaved somewhat shabbily in the matter. Some month: since lhere was a half-promise given tc 1 thc Queensland Government by Mr

PARKKS, of an annual contribution ofter thousand pounds sterling towards the neu service. It was not contemplated tc retain that amount in the Queenslauc Treasury, but to band it over lo thc contractors, on condition that they sub stituted fi ten-knot service for thc existing nine-knot one. Hut Mr PARKIÎS hesitated to complete his <piasi undertaking, although by enlisting tl« co-operation of New Zealand he hat relieved his own colony of oni moiety of the Pacific mail subsidy It apparently suited Mr. PAKKKS book to have Port Jackson (Iv terminus of the Torres Straits servio without contributing anything toward the cost of its maintenance, lint he wil nciwdisioverlhalparsimonyand eronom are nol synonymous terms, and will hav a fresh grievance against Victoria fn stealing his clothes while he bathed. 1 this be the actual state of affairs, th Sydney Government have theniselve alone to thank for the loss of prcstiq sustained, while Queensland will luv learnt to expect more from the rivalr than thc liberality of thc two leadin

colonies.

This new development of the plan <if the Kastern and Australian Steal Shipping Company will do much 1 itconcilc tiie people of Queenslau

to thc irregularity and uncertainty which lias so far cliaractcrised their conduct of thc mail service. It is impos- sible to organisejan ocean mail serviccat a fewmonths'noticc,and therefore, solongas there are indications that die Directors arc working in the right groove, we may fairly be asked to exercise patience when thc mails do not arrive or depart with tlie desired regularity. The unfortunate loss of tlie fine steamship Sunfoo will .cause further delay in organising thc new service, but such disasters may be expected in opening up new ocean tracks. If tile Company possess thc necessary capital, and display a fair amount of administrative ability in its management, it will soon become a formidable rival to thc Peninsular and Oriental Company. Should that result be attained, the benefits to Queensland and, indeed, to the colonies generally, from thc far-seeing liberality of thc I'AI.MER Government will be greater than their most sanguine advocates could reasonably have anticipated. Had not Mr. PAI.MIÍR acted with a promptness, or "precipitancy" in making the Torres Strait contract, the probability is that many years would have elapsed before it

had been made available as a mail route.
