WITH WHICK tl «KCrtRrotUT»!D TUR

GL ADS TO U E O QSSRFE n. I

PUBLISHED DA.ILY". j

FRIDAY, MA.BOII 20, 1874.

THE Brisbane Corporation are at length making an effort to get rid of their white elephant-Hie bridge. It is now very near completion, and the city lins a liability of ¿142,000 on account of the structure. The cost of the work is

wholly beyond the means of the eily, and already some ,£20,000 of the ordi- nary revenue of the Council has been swallowed up in interest upon the out- lay. This amount the Corporation could ill afford lo lose, and the conse- quences ave but too apparent in ihe wretched condition of Ihe city streets. Beyond Queen-street, go where you will, there is not a street even in a passable stale of repair, nnJ probably in no town in the colony is so little «lone in comparison with thc amount annually extracted from the ratepayers. Tliis is anything but creditable to the metropolis of the colony, for if local self-government have a much better chance of success

in one place than in any other, that place should be at the seal of govern- ment. Bul it would seem that even metropolitan privileges are attended by sonic drawbacks, for when a seal in Ihe ' legislature- can he secured by ex-

perienced and able men, they appear to find no attractions in civic duties and responsibilities. At one lime, when the city finances were buoyant, thc periodical social gatherings, irreverently termed "quarterly feeds," possibly sustained Ihe patriotic spirit of the Corporation, but since pressure of interest was brought to bear these delec- tations were of necessity abandoned, and aspiring aldermen found their sphere limited to the more prosaic work offilling impassable ditches, cutting away imprac- ticable ridges, and so financing as to stave off the evil day until a. pitying Legislature should fly to their relief, lt was under these circumstances thal " Ichabod" was written on the Town Hall, and that the city was handed over to the tender mercies of men who, with some bright exceptions, were totally un- fit to bc entrusted with the transaction of public business.

It will be observed that our telegram gives no hint of the reception accorded to the aldermen when they repre- sented their case to thc Govern- ment. We arc not told whether the request was made by deputation or by letter, but it may be pretty safely inferred that no tangible result has been yet attained. The Government appear un- willing to incur thc responsibility of a general bridge scheme, awl will, in all probability, leave it an open «¡uestion. If introduced at al), Ihe subject will be myst likely brought forward by some privait; iiK-mbcr, in which case the Cabi- ns »nay i.-ilhcT be expected lo «livide on thc ipwiiti'in, tn to recommend its refer- ent fi a Seli;«;t ( :<nnmiltec. The latter, indeed, is apparently th«; moro feasible course, as llic 111.1 jori)y in the .Assembly arc very unlikely to assent 1« any general bridge project, without previously sub

jecting it to very rigid inquiry. Still less likely is it that .my proposal lo deal witli the Brisbane bridge alone will meet willi acceptance, even if it be backed up willi i all the strength of thc Jirisbanc and

Moreton district members.

As already slated in this column, wc think great works like these should either be made a charge upon thc districts benefiting hy them, ¡or a loll should be imposed for the security of Ute general revenue. They should not be under- taken unless pretty good evidence is pro- curable that, either directly or indirectly, the expenditure will be fully reproduc- tive. U'e cannot allow that any bridge yet erected or proposed in this colony is a national work, and therefore it should not be pennitled to burden thc national finances. At the same time, the national credit »ny fairly he sought in its behalf, just as in the case of loans (o municipalities such bodies arc enabled to carry out local works by giving security over the local revenues, j We know it is too common for muni

I cipal councils to repudiate their liabilities j to the General Government, hut the

laxity complained of is due to moral

I weakness in both parties to the transac-

tion. There is no doubt that if the

Executive in such cases insisted upon municipalities adhering strictly to their engagements, while evincing the dispo- sition to accord llieni all reasonable help, the public revenue would be amply pro I tecled, and the loan principle found of I much advantage lo local bodies,

ll is folly to contend that because the ( iovenuncnt do not choose to enforce payment of municipal loans, the ratepayers of the colony should he driven to accept the hard terms imposed by the private money-lender, or confine their jil ans of improvement strictly within thc limits of ordinary revenue.

lt must he admitted that the example set by lirisbanc in clamouring for a free bridge is not encouraging. That bridge is no more a national work than a bridge would he over any other river in the colony. And thc claim for exceptional treatment on the ground of surrendered bridge lands cannot be deemed valid, lirisbanc had no better right to a bridge land-grant than can bc shown by several other towns in ihe'colony, and therefore if a free bridge be granted to Brisbane, Maryborough, Rockli.ampton,and Mackay will be entitled to a similar concession. We cannot for a moment allow that Jlrjsbane is entitled lo consideration on the ground that it is the seat of Govern-

ment. That doctrine is now obsolete in ! Queensland, and, we arc persuaded, will i never he endorsed by Parliament, now j that redistribution has given lo all paris j of the colony their due share of influence

in the Legislature. j

it must be understood that wc have

no objection to free bridges, as such. Tolls of all kinds are an abomination, and might he wholly dispensed with were a statutory distinction drawn between local and general works. But so long as thc general revenue is held liable for purely local works, security for their cost must be exacted in the form of tolls. If our lirisbanc friends would submit to

this principle for the time being, and give their aid towards establishing a system of local government adapted to the peculiar circumstances of the colony, they might soon realise their ideal of a free bridge. The burden of ils cost is crushing to the city, but to thc whole Moreton district it would involve no appreciable increase of taxation, espe- cially when the Legislature had voted the compensation equitably due lo the municipal revenues for unwarrantable interference with the bridge contract in bygone years.

In conclusion, it must be remarked thal the country constituencies have no wish lo <piarrel with the metropolitans over the amount represented by the cost of the lirisbanc bridge. Their determina- tion, so far as we understand it, is simply lo insist that works conferring purely local advantages shall not bc carried on at the cost of the whole colony.

articleText:
Cjje ^ocíííjatujíton §ul(ctiti,

WITH WHICH tS TtTCOaPOKlTKU TH fl

GLADSTONE O ll SE TIVER.

PUBLISHED DA.rLV.

j .SATURDAY. MAUCIt 28, 1874.

i-i

Tm* manner in which thc session of Parliament lias begun inspires hope that some real work will be done (his year, j Whether Ministers can command a

steady majority or no, they will certainly, while Mr. I'AI.MKR remains in Hie Assembly, bc kept well in check by a strong Opposition. There is not like!)' to be any such obstruction as was con- stantly offered by the gentlemen now in power when they occupied the seal? on thc SPEAKER'S left hand, but the oppo- sition will be none thc less effective when iv is moderate and not ungenerous.

The very liest guarantee for beneficial i legislation is found in the existence of j well organised ranks on both sides. Il | is quite a mistake to suppose that a demoralised Opposition means a strong Government, or thal when a Ministry is nol met by systematic opposition it is likely to be more useful than when every movement is watched by opponents with a keen and careful eye. It is thus that Mr, MACAUSTKR'S movements will bc treated, and il is great good fortune for him that Iiis opponent is a man whose leadership will be unquestioned, and whose word, within reasonable limits, will bc a law lo bis followers.

Much surprise has been expressed at the similarity in the policies cnimn.Hcd by thc late and the present Ministries. The gentlemen who now control the affairs of the colony-or mosl of them were Libérais of such radical principles when aspiring to office, that the uninitiated were wont lo expect a programme c.ileulalud lo push the colony

j ahead with giant strides and forced

marches. lint politicians in opposition are like dogs on the vhain. Their patriotism is furious while their liberty is circumscribed ; but once give them carte blanclw, and, like the faithful mastiff who unexpectedly breaks the chain, they prove very harmless reformers indeed. Instead of finding the depart- ments so many Augean stables, recking willi corruption, every govern nient establishment is found swept anti gar nished, and the foaming patriot, once safely ensconced amidst paper; and red tape, quickly acquires thc bland and dignified demeanour of : Minister of the Crown. He finds him self by no means an autocrat in his nev sphere, and lo a greater extent thai bc had ever before suspected, he mus be guided by Iiis Under-Secrelary ant departmental usage.

It is thus that the MACAU srrci Ministry, who represent the Kadica reformers in thc House, have appcaro to so little advantage within the last tia or two. After two months' deliberador

it has been found that thc policy of thc gentlemen who were alleged to have unconstitutionally and violently held the reins of Government for a period of four years, is the policy required by the colony, and that it cannot be improved upon. Beyond the intimation that the ten years' leases arc lo be dealt with more liberally than the existing law allows, and that the Payment of Mem- bers Hill will be made a Government measure, there is no variation in Mr. MACALISTEK'S programme from that with which the session was opened by his opponent. This should be very gratifying lo Mr. PAI.MKK, and prove to the public thal whether the Minis- terial Benches be occupied by Conserva- tives or Liberals, under vigorous parliamentary government the policy of the Ministry must be in accordance with thc will of the people.

Wc are told that the Budget will be presented next Wednesday, and possibly in this the difference " 'Twixt Tweedle- dum and Tweedledee" will become manifest. The late Ministry's estimates provided for a general advance upon all salaries, and the new ones, we are told, will be prepared on the strictest princi- ples of economy. In the end, however, we apprehend the result will not be affected. The purchasing value of tile sovereign has been decreasing for years I past, and the expenditure of the colony will no doubt be proportionately in- creased. This is really a matter very much beyond thc control of Ministers, for, so far as the Civil Service is con- cerned, inadequate salaries aie the sure precursor of corruption and inefficiency.

In other matters the financial policy of of the Ministry is likely to differ but slightly from that of their predecessors.

There may bc an increased tendency to. cany on public works, and swell ihe debt of the colony, but that disposition even thc late Ministry would have been compelled lo show. The railways must be pushed on, and the progress of the country assisted in every practicable way. With the immensity of our known resources, and the ex- ample of other colonies before us, it cannot be argued thal we have reached the limit at which indebtedness is likely

to become unsafe or burdensome. In

judiciously constructed railways llie colony will have so valuable an asset for its loan expenditure, that there is still room for much expansion in this direc- tion. We shall, therefore, be quite pre- pared to leam that the Budget includes proposals for further extensive loans for necessary public works.

Mr. PALMER has just given a new pledge of his sincerity on the Education question, by introducing what our tele- graphic correspondent calls a " Com- pulsory Education Bill." His last bill contained a compulsory provision, and the probability is that it will prove to be the same as the one referred to. We can hardly believe that thc hon. gentleman intends to introduce a measure dealing with compulsory education alone, for other changes of even greater importance are necessary. Mr. PALMER stands on firm ground on this question, for he is very nearly

abreast with the most advanced re-

formers of thc day, while it is notorious that education is a weak point with Hie prescnl Ministry. Mr. MACALISTER has lost caste by courting the denomina tionalists, and Mr. M'DF.VITT'S associa- tions necessarily place him in the rear- guard amongst educational reformers. So that Mr. PALMER has a good oppor- tunity of proving that on one of thc most important questions of thc day, the

leader of the Government docs not re-

present the paramount opinion of the colony.

Until next week, when thc complete policy of the Government will be placed before the country, it is almost prema- ture to hazard an opinion upon thc prospects of thc Session. But so far as present indications go, there does seem ground lo hope that the new House will prove itself worthy of the respect and confidence of the colon}'.

KVKBVOKE who desires to sec the members

of thc legal profession enjoy tho respect and confidence of their clients and tho public, will rejoice to observe that at length thc Judges of the Supreme Court and tho hw Society at Brisbane, have marie au example of one prac- titioner wlii> has boen fourni guilty ">f unpm fcssiimal conduct. Thc oJTciioo was clearly brought home, anil their Honors tho judges ordered the offender tn bc Htruulc off tho

mil or attorneys. This example should have a salutary effect upon a number of legal gentlemen in Queensland who habitually tread the narrow margin betw een that which is dis dfsJioiiost and that which is illegal.

Hi'.vuHit ni is a book entitled " Handbook to thu Verna of Queensland, compiled from thc most recent works on ferns ; and au introduc- tion tn their study. " lt is thc work of Mr. Frederick M. Hailey, a gentleman well kuown in liolanii.'il circles, and is in every way a voy creditable production. Its contents have boen collected fruin a great many sources, tho names of fiirty-jiinc authorities being given for thc information it contains, and those authori- ties include all thc best living «mes of tho day. Thc Ilook is printed on good paper, and is neatly bound in cloth. Within its covers arc 72 closely printed pages of reading matter, and 22 plates, containing, over <>0 wood-cuts ¡Ilustrativo <>f thc genera and peculiarities ot this numerous ami ornamental family of plants. Botanical students iu this colony, and particu- larly those interested in thc extensive and beautiful family of ferns and lycoporis, should obtain a copy, to aid them in their rumblings juill researches in identifying their treasures.

A inore interesting class of plants duos not csist than this, and limiting for them in their native habito!ir, while contributing to thc plea- sure of tlie enthusiast, is at tho same time promotive "f health, ami may therefore 1» regarded as a profitable recreation. Thc compiler has aimed to clothe thc work in a less scientific dress of technical detail than is generally thc case, in order that it may serve thc student and amateur, rather than thc man ot science ; nevertheless, as a scientific M-orlc it is not contemptible. Not the least im iinrtant features of thc book arc the specified ocalilics where different ferns may be found, and thc illustrcvtions of rarietios jurd the peculiarities of the same. We have ranch Ï'icasurc in recommending the work to all

overs of these most graceful plants,

articleText:
WITH ffllICII IS IKCOITOUTKD TUR

QL Á D s TO y t¡ O BS E RJr R ft.

PUBLISHED D A.ILY".

WEDNESDAY, JULY 29. 1374.

THE Prorogation Speech, like the session which it closes, is unduly " protracted." It seeks to make the most of, so far as Government measures are concerned, an almost barren session. The writer-for Vice-regal speeches aro written before, instead of after, delivery-seems to have been sorely exercised to find staple for his product Ex nihilo nihil fit, says the proverb. But in these days an author is worth little who cannot make bricks without straw. We must, however, con- gratulate the ministerial speech-maker in this case. He has given the public, at least enough for its money.

The Government, through His EXCEL- LENCE begin by expressing pleasure at being able to give honorable members their dismissal, m which we credit-them with bein¿ perfectly ingenuous. The same may be said of the apology which follows for the crudeness of the bills introduced. Ministers " had but limited " time at their disposal for the preparation " of measures previous to placing them " before Parliament." The members of the Opposition, and of the Legislative Council, should really feel grateful for this practical confession that thc mis- carriage of Ministerial measures was due to their own inefficacy rather than to a blind spirit of resistance to judicious reform. And it is also refreshing to learn that the bills passed-upon which his EXCEL- LENCY'S advisers presumedly staked their existence-arc not of ,an unimportant character. We should be sorry to believe that Ministers would risk a crisis for the sake of passing an unimportant measure. Possibly the speech intends to convey no such doctrine-but who

knows ?

By thc Elections Bill, we are told, " self-government has been conceded to " the inhabitants of Queensland to the " fullest extent,"-a sentence wliich may be designated charmingly hyperbolic Thc Land Bill, and its collapse, is a tender subject, and it is gingerly treated. " My Government regrets that the " demand for land for settlement "has thus, for a time, not been " provided for," but it is " trusted " that Executive action under thc existing law will, to some extent, meet present requirements. And Ministers will not hesitate to use the legal means provided for recovering those portions of thc publicestate which have been fraudulently acquired. Just so. Had these legal means been tried before fresh legislation was attempted, the country would have been spared some agitation, and the land question would have been a year ncarei its settlement. Here is another conics sion thal in their patriotic eagerness to dc something great, (he Ministry began al thc wrong end. ll is refreshing to note this consent lo humbly cal the leek, and

return and do the first works.

The Gold-fields Hill, it is confident!) liOjM-d, will (end to remove obstructions and, we may add, not create mon serious evils than il removes. Tin Supreme Court Act confers upon th» Northern districts thc (dubious) advan tage of a brandi of thc Supreme Cour established in their midst. A rathe sanguine hope is that tho new tarif) while lcssemug the burden of taxation

will promote commerce. Thc power conferred upon the Government will enable them to carry out and extend their railway policy, and congratulations

are offered that a "more than usual

desire " has been evinced by the Parlia- ment to extend electric telegraphs.

The measures passed, which are cata- logued as deserving of special mention are,-Thc Audit Act, the Customs Act, the Law of Evidence Act, the Insolvency Act, the Navigation and Seamen's Acts, and the Land Order Act-a scanty list truly, but as the Speech observes, all these Acts are, in a greater or less degree of importance to the colony. The Payment of Members Bill is mentioned half apologetically, and it is confidently hoped that when again submitted to the Legislature, it may receive more favour-

able consideration.

Gentlemen of the Legislative Assembly are specially thanked for the liberality of their money grants, an acknowledg- ment which was possibly received not without a sentiment of compunction. And they arc further assured that by thc commencement forth- with of tlic public works provided for, " the various districts of thecolony will " practically experience the benefits of " that attention to their wants, which " has been one of the great objects of " your labours."

Thc appointment of a Royal Com- mission on Education is an assurance lo the initiated that the settlement

of this vexed question will be grappled with hy the Government next session. Mr. MACALISTER is herc taking another leaf out of his predecessor's book, we presume. When Mr. PALMER'S Govern- ment desired to retreat from their anti

railway policy, they appointed a Royal Commission; and now the present Government find it necessary to nail

their colours to the mast of national and secular education, they find it con- venient to work under similar cover. It is thus that experience teaches Ministers to adopt a course of action which was formerly denounced by themselves from the Opposition benches.

The Speech concludes with a laboured flourish of congratulation, amidst which the session of 1874, the shortcomings of Ministers, and thc mistakes of our legis- lators, are consigned to oblivion. Let us hope that the evil done during the session has now been decently interred, and

that the good, in the form of wholesome 1 measures passed and correct principles affirmed, may prove of lasting benefit to the community.

The Ministry, probably to their own surprise, have safely steered through the numerous dangers which beset their course. They had loyal assistance from friends, and, as a rule, generous treat- ment from their foes. The PREMIER'S

own folly on several occasions threw the Ministerial craft on her beam ends, but the Fates were merciful. The almost universal desire was that

the Government should have a fair trial _ at legislation" diking J«*»«*»---frJ' *V ? -na uusi a Minimi desire was manifested

that a fair trial in administration should

also be granted during the recess. In legislation, the failure, if not complete, has been something more than partial ; and unless the success be more marked in administration, the confidence of the majority will most likely be withdrawn at the re-assembling of Parliament. The Government, with a recess of eight months in prospect, are afforded an excellent opportunity of proving their administrative capacity, and they will unquestionably be held accountable for the proper use of that opportunity. The public will be agreeably surprised

if the blunders of the recess do not

prove far less pardonable than the

mistakes of thc session.

I AT a Uto hour laut evening, Bomo notes

roached us from our sporting contributor "Nimrod," but wc arc obliged to reserve them for to-morrow's piper.

TUB Agricultural Show at Gracemere of tho Central Queensland Graziers' Society, haa been unavoidably postponed until Tuesday next, ou account of tho inclemency of thc

weather.

MAILS for Broadsound, Mackay, and Bowon, per s.s. Tiuonce, will cloao at tho Post Oflico to morrow (Thursday) morning, for registered letters at G o'clock, and for ordinary letters and book packages at 8 o'clock.

TUB anniversary tea meeting of the Congre- gational Church, Bolsover-stroct, will tako place this eveniug at half-past six o'clock. After tea a public mooting will be held, when a number of addrcsBOS will bo delivered by

various ministers anil friends.

IN consequence of tho wet weather, a meeting of tho Committee of thc Boeing Club was held at thc Criterion Hotel yesterday evening to consider thc advisability ot post- poning thc races. After much discussion, it nppoaring that a majority of thc owners of horses were adverse to tho postponement, no decision waa arrived at, but it was resolved to convene a meeting by advertisement for eight o'clock this evening, to finally determine the question, lu addition to thc inconvenience of postponement, there is a still more serious difficulty to contend against. Thc A..I.C. rules, under which thc races have been alvcrtisod to run, provide that tho ages of all horses shall date from tho let of August. On tho minutes of the local club, however, is a resolution passed in tho year 1S7<>, substituting thc 1st of Ncritcinbcr for thc lat of August in counting ago of horuos runuing under the auspices of the club. But it is very doubtful whether such minute still retains force in the face of the printed A. .T. C. rules to the contrary ; and therefore, on thc whole, opinion seems to favour an adherence to tho days originally lived for thc running. From telegraphic intel- ligence wc leam that at ten o'clock last night thc raiu was general throughout thc north, lt was .also raining at Springsure, but at Ih-isliane it was a bright moonlight night, thc day having hocu linc .iud unusually warm. At lioak hainpton, almnt midnight, tliei-e was i^uni-; iippciraucc'of a clear-up, but the stillness of the :tir .iud mildness ni thc temperature were ratho,* unfavourable indications, lt may be hoped, however, th.it.lupitcr 1'luvius will now bid us adieu for t\ season.

A\' Oliio woman riding on thc cars with her boy said he »w only tis, and when Hilly spoke up and_ declared lie wis IO, tia-good woman drew bili! over her knee and had satisfaction fur thc half-fare she wa» ubligcd to pay.

mm willan ti incoRroiftTttn TUR

OCÍDSTOXS o B s s n rs n.

PCJBLtSHSD DAILY".

TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 8, 1874,

THE leading journal refers jocularly to the rumoured withdrawal of Mr. M'ILWRAITH from the Ministry, and remarks that it is generally thought " there is something in it." There is probably some real ground for this general conclusion. It has long been suspected that the MINISTER FOR WORKS has never worked harmoniously with all his colleagues, or, if he have, there has been often a divergence of opinion which must have proved destructive of sym- pathetic action. The Ministry have pulled together to keep the State coach m motion, simply because any other course would have immediately closed their career. Bat, if there were differ- ences of opinion on Legislative questions, there are, if rumour be credited, still more serious differences on matters oi administration. Mr. M'ILWRAITH is a shrewd, far-seeing, and experienced man, .with a strong tendency to stubbornness, and in the early days of the Ministry the public were shown that when thc MINISTER FOR WORKS "put his foot down," it was. useless for his chief to pro- test. In bis first effusive speech to the I pswichians, Mr. MACALISTER announced thiat he would have the Brisbane Railway Terminus brought into a more central position than had been selected by the late Ministry in" the Grammar School Reserve. Mr. M'ILWRAITH, however, declined to endorse this bid for popu laxity, and most distinctly said the tennînus site should not be changed. About the same time, it will be recol- lected, there were other differences ol opinion in which the PREMIER wai obliged to give way to his immovable colleague, and one, too, be it remembered whom he had detached from the part) supporting the late Ministry. At the time of the discussion of Mr. FITZ GERALD'S coolie labour motion, it wa; " well known that Mr. M'ILWRAITI

was favourable to coolie immigration and hence the electrical effect produced upon tile House when the PREMIER declared that if either of his colleague: voted for the motion he would not rcmair a Minister after the next morning. Wi believe Mr. M'ILWRAITH was not ii the chamber at the moment, or he would have scarcely sat like a " duml dog" under such an announcement and that he made no subsequent sign wa1 considered a matter of suqjrise. It probability however, is, that as the thr . was not reported, Mr. M'IIAVR* J-I thought it wise to pocket the aff for But such occurrences, though lempr ITar\ veiled, are not forgotten, but are tre asun up against the day of reckoning wh¡, must surely come. Since the pro ,x>gatio also, there have been fresh ind-' ,cations disagreement, and it can hardly 1 concluded that all the .'/ppointmen made have met Mr. "M'ILWRAITI approval, some of thr;Tri too sure smacking of nepotism « 0 satisfy so rig an economist as the MINISTER M WORKS. Again, thr; PREMIER durii his tour northwards seems to have bo particularly liberal hi promises relali; to matters within, the province of t Works Departui ent. At Bundaberg ai Mackay he s ^oke apparently as t mouth-piece of the whole cabinet

regard to Expenditure on public wor] The surveys of the projected rail or tn way frorr.t lUmdaberg to Mount Pei should bc al once commenced, and was surprised that they had not bc already started. He promised to reco

mend an additional ^4000 loan to the |

the Municipal Council at Mackay, and ' to provide for the erection of an immigra- 1 tion depot and a post office. The local 1 journal also states that before thc

lion, gentleman's departure he " caused 1 instructions to be sent to the department ' of public works to have plans for the

immigration depot and lock-up prepared." 1 These buildings are no doubt for the ( Colonial Secretary's own department, ' but they will involve a considerable ex- ' penditure which, it may be presumed, j

will need the consent of the Premier's colleagues. As to the Mount Perry tramway, we' can hardly suppose that Mr. M'ILWRAITH has any serious in tention of undertaking that work, for he is known to be an opponent of tram-

ways, and is not likely to change his , mind because the PREMIER has approved , of the tramway constructed by Mr. Tooth, at a cost of ¿£700 per mile.

Of course while Ministers are tra- , veiling about the country, we are not likely to hear of resignations, nor even when they all return to Brisbane is there likely to be any decided action for some months to come. The time to expect ? change will be when the next session

approaches, and when it becomes neces- sary to agree upon a policy for the i opening speech. It can scarcely be ex I pected that Mr. M'ILWRAITH will again I submit to the production of another

so-called Liberal Land Bill, but it is I difficult to understand how the Ministry

can propose "to go on without fresh legislation on that much agitated question.

C^egocíi^mptott §ttHeti«,

«TJTH wnioit ia iNcoRrottvrKD TH ic

OL ÁD S TONE O BSE RTE R.

PUBLISHED DAILY.

THURSDAY, JULY 1G, 1874.

THE work of the session is being brought to a close earlier than, three months since, appeared possible. When thc Parliament met on tile 25th March, there were two sets of Estimates to pass, and quite an array of measures on which we were assured that legislation was impe- ratively demanded. Since then the Assembly has sat scarcely more than three months when on Thursday week the business paper was almost cleared both of Government and private matters, and the representatives of the people were doing little more than awaiting the pleasure of the honourable gentlemen of tlie Upper House. The newspapers have told us repeatedly during the session that no work was being done, and that time was being constantly wasted in vapid discussion. There is unfortunately too too much truth in this remark, but it is not entirely true notwithstanding. Con- sidering that more than one-half of the representative chamber consisted of en- tirely new men, that a majority of Minis- ters had never previously held a portfolio, and that a great infusion of new blood had taken place into the Legislative Council, we think the quantity of busi- ness transacted has been considerable,

ana will compare favourably with most previous sessions. When we recollect how year after year all legislation was stopped by deadlocks, and how tile little work done went through with a run, the course of business this year has been

marked by a very perceptible change for

the better.

The country, however, is not so much 1 indebted to Ministers for this condition ! of aiTairs, the good sense and forbear- ance of the Opposition having been the real cause of improvement. Of party obstruction, such as the public were1 accustomed to when thc Great Liberals occupied Hie Opposition benches, there has been absolutely none, and for the little obstruction that has occurred the so-called independent members on both sides are solely responsible. On the one hand a few ultra conservatives have considered it their duty to talk against time, and on the other the radicals at the back of Ministers have occasionally resorted to this extreme ex- pedient of raising up a barrier against ^progress. But in every case these

proceedings have been resisted by the leaders of the House, and deplored by all moderate men, who desire to see every measure fairly and intelligently, but not tediously, discussed. It is well understood in this colony that honorable members will only devote a certain por- tion of their time to Parliamentary duties, and that if discussion on some subjects be unduly protracted it will be propor tionably curtailed in others. And this remark applies to all legislative bodies, for we find that the mischievous practice of rushing through business without dis- cussion is even more complained of in New South Wales than here. The Par- liament has just risen at Sydney, after an unconscionable session of ten months, and after interminable floods of talk, with thc major portion of its business still untransacted, no less titan thirty one orders of the day, we learn, remained on the business paper when Sir HERCULES ROMNSON thanked honorable

members and dispersed them to their homes. The result of such a stoppage of legislation must be deplorable. None of the actual business of the year has yet been done, and in consequence Parlia-

ment must re-assemble after a brief recess of scarcely two months. Whatever ground of complaint we may have in Queensland, therefore, our case is cer- tainly more satisfactory than that of the parent colony. Our Parliament will be prorogued in the course of two or three days, and the Government, rejoicing in twelve months' supply in advance, will have abundant time during the recess to attend to administrative duties, which are, in fact, of no less importance than legislation. Whatever laws we may be .endowed with, in the absence of vigorous administration, the public will reap no benefit It is there- fore matter for solid satisfaction that the state of the public business admits of so early a cessation of parliamemtary

labours.

It is scarcely less a subject for satis- faction that the country has been spared another political crisis this year. Thc new Ministry were entitled to a fair trial, and fortunately none were more ready to acknowledge this than their leading opponents in the Assembly. It is, perhaps, a matter of regret that the Opposition has been somewhat, disorganised, and that during a portion of the session no attempt was

made to lead them. But this was but a

natural result of the tacit understanding that Ministers should be allowed to play out their innings. And, after all, the Opposition has been tolerably steady and effective. Between the assaults of oppo- nents and the occasional defection of adherents, the Government have been kept well in check, and taught that there is a power even greater than themselves, namely, a constantly shifting majority in the Assembly. It may be hoped that this fact will not be lost sight of during the recess, and that the consciousness of

responsibility to Parliament will .be a constant incitement to vigilance and purity in administration. It must be admitted, however, that this hope, judging from past experience, is not one of a " sure and certain " character, and that outside pressure from supporters will possibly be too strong for the Spartan like fortitude of-tfnrhead of the Govern- ment. In such circumstances it is far more pleasant to yield than to resist, and we shall be considerably surprised if it transpire when Parliament re-assembles that no official act of the recess calls for parliamentary censure.

Ministers will now be afforded an excellent opportunity of displaying their ability in administration, and for the sake of the country we will hope that they will make good use of it In one way they might considerably increase their small stock of political capital, and that is by making themselves personally acquainted with the respective wants and I claims of the various towns and dis-

tricts to the northward of Dawes' Range. Tliey will, if wise, determine in certain matter-, offensive and unjust to the central districts retract their steps, and thus prove to the colony that the errors of the past in this respect have not been

wilful.

AT tho Police Court, yesterday morning, before thc Police Magistrate and Messrs. W. Pattison and A. Feez, J.sP., Septimus Nash Spong was charged by tho polioo with being of unsound mind. Dr. Robertson, who had examined tho accused in the absonoo of Dr. Salmond, gavo the necessary mcdioal testimony, and the prisoner was committed to thc Luuccic Reception House for ono mouth, to obtain,

medical care and treatment.

TUE Central Queensland Graziers' Society have decided to hold their first show on Weduesday the 29th instant. It will be held at Gracemere, and will comprise exhibits of cattle, horsos, &c. &c. ; also of farm, orchard, and garden produce. From thc short time allowed for preparation, it would bc too much to expect exhibits of a high order on this occasion. As a trial effort, bowevor, thc show may do good, by exciting a wholesome rivalry amongst our graziers in thc race for improvement.

THE Theatre Royal was not so well patron- ised last night as we could wish for, nor indeed BO well as thc excellence of the acting deserved. Shakespeare's meaning comedy of " Taming the Shrew" was repeated with Miss Joey Gougcnhcim as Katharine and Mr. Thomson as Petrttchio, and they went through their parts with a fair adhérence to the original text and wore groetcd with loud applause. A musical interlude followed, and the cveniug wound up with the " The Lady of Munster, as it is sometimes called, Miss Gougcnhcim enacting tho part of Gertrude. To-night Mr. Thomson will take a benefit, tho piece de resistance 4>cing the excellent play of "Lost in Loudon." It would bo superfluous for us to urge the claim of this gentleman upon the patronage of all true lovers of the drama, thc excellence of his acting and the care he evinces in the exercise of his diffi- cult and arduous profession, speaking with a louder and far more effective tongue than, wo can possibly command. No one who had. the advantage of witnessing his passionate but correct impersonation of thc honourable Round- head soldier, Sir Walter Aymall, can readily forget it, and we have roason to know that the character ho will appear in to-night is his chef Pauvre. We anticipate a bumper house.

WITH WHICH IS IKCORrOt&TKIl TH P.

O LAO STONE OB SE JIVE ll.

PUBLISHED DA.ILY.

TITI3SDA.Y, AVRIL 21, 1874.

WK i>uljl¡sli in another column, for thc j information of all persons concerned, the copy of a petition which is in course of signature, to thc Legislative Assembly, for a bridge over the Fitzroy. lt is ii ii fortúnale thal the memorial was n<jl drawn tip sooner, as there is now no pos- sibility of its being presented to lite House on the night set down in thc Parliamentary notice paper (Thursday next), for the discussion of Mr. HUZA corr's motion on the liridge question. However, better late than never, and the fiel of a petition being numerously signed in Rockhampton, in support of the motion before the House, so far as il relates lo bridging the Fitzroy, will assist the obj eel in view.

Il may be as well, hy way of reminder, briefly lo state that the motion referred to asks Parliament lo affirm the desirable- ness of placing upon the next I,oan Estimate the sum of £150,000 for pur- chasing thc lirisbane liridge and erecting three similar structures at Maryborough, Rockhampton, and Mackay respectively : the cost of all such bridges to he ulti j malely made a charge tt|)on the districts

benefiting by their construction. Tho petition in course of preparation sets forth the great advantages; a bridge over the Fitzroy River would confer upon this district, and that the work would certainly, in a few years hence, prove remunerative. It further adds, in support of this point, that the petitioners have "no desire lo gain an "advantage at the expense of their " fellow-colonists in other districts," but are " willing to bear their own burdens, "and to have this and other local works "made an ultimate charge upon thc "districts benefiting by their construc

lion."

The case is well pul in the memorial, and reijiiires no amplification. There can be no question that the bridge wool'I be a great boon to residents on both sides of the river. The present means of crossing are inadéquate to the wants of tile distric t, rind the people on the norlli side especially are subjected lo enlist.int annoyance and expense as a consequence. These hindrances to traffic are of necessity also hindrances to the seulement of population, and to thc increase of trade which thal settle- ment would ensure, ll winnot, there- fore, be disputed that a bridge is desirable, provided its cost would nert be too great lo admit of a remunerative return. Wc have no reliable data tt]>on which lo form an estimate of the cost of the work : hut we think £40,000 ts probably a safe figure. This would involve an interest charge-at five per cení - -of £2000 per annum ; and the annual revenue arising from the bridge should cover this amount, together with the cost of collection, wear and lear, and unforeseen expenses. The bridge

lolls could be collected for £150 per annum, and £350 would probably be a liberal provision for other expenses. This calculation would require an annual revenue of about £2500, or scarcely move iban double the income now derivable from tbe punt and ferries. No argument is necessary to shoiv that a bridge would greatly increase the traffic over lite river, and to a corresponding extent augment the income from lolls. Tlie bridge would not only serve industrial purposes and promote the prosperity of thc district, bul would greatly conduce to the health and recreation of the inhabitants of

Rockhampton by opening out pleasant walks and drives on the north side, and bringing Emu Park within easier reach

of tlie town. Considerations of this kind are not lo be overlooked even by hard- headed, practical men such as Mr. M'li.witAiTU, for they have a very direct heiring oil the question as to the

rc-productiveness of a bridge. Rut ] beyond the direct income arising j

from tolls, there would bc the indirect revenue resulting from an

increase of settlement and in the mini- j

ber of consumers of dutiable goods. There would also bc a corresponding increase in the value of Crown lands in the district and in the proceeds of land sales. These considerations, taken to- gether plainly demonstrate that the im- mediate construction of a bridge over thc Fitzroy might fairly be undertaken by the Government, seeing thal it would only make use of the public credit for a work of a safely remunerative character. lint should the re-

presentatives of the people, in Parliament assembled, hesitate to come to this conclusion, the petitioners at Rockhampton are perfectly satisfied and express their willingness to have the cost of the bridge made a charge upon the district benefited by it. There can be litlle doubt that were the whole of that district possessed of adequate corporate powers, it would not hesitate to under- take the construction of a bridge at its own cost, and if Parliament persists in withholding the powers of local taxation j and expenditure from the several districts of the colony, some other plan must be devised for carrying out necessary public works 011 fair and equitable principles. : The people of Rockhampton ask for a bridge over the Fitzroy on its own merits, and not because the Government propose lo construct bridges in other places, or because thc metropolitans are endeavouring lo bring pressure to bear upon tile Parliament to take the bridge off their hands, and make it free of lolls. Hut they protest most strongly against the muddling way in which the public revenues are kept and expended, which encourages a constant scramble for Parliamentary votes for local works without regard to equity. The contest, in fact, is one in which the weaker of the combatants is sure to go to the wall.

Tlie motion of which Mr. BUZACOTT has given notice in thc Assembly offers a rallying point to the members of the Central and Northern constituencies to resist the over-reaching schemes of the metropolitans, and we trust they will not fail to use the opportunity aright. In dealing with this question, it is important that the recognition of an intelligible and equitable principle of distributing the public moneys should be insisted on, and that the metropolitans should be treated no better and 110 worse than the residents of the other parts of the colony.

A srlici AI. meeting of thc suliscriliers to thc Port Curtin and Leichhardt District Hospital will he held in thc Court House, Bast-street, this (Tuesday) afternoon at 4 o'clock, to ap- point .% Treasurer in tho room of Mr. T. ri. J Lall, resigned.

THE yearly balance sheet of the Rockhamp- ton Volunteer Fire Brigade is published in another column. The document shows the amount of subscriptions for thc year .amount- ing in all to C">7 10s., thc whole nf which sum ia made up of donations from thc Corporation (£20) and tho foreign Insurance Company's agents-there is not a single shilling to thc credit of any of our merchants awl traders excepting such moiety as they indirectly sub- scribe a» ratepayers. The otherside of the shoot shows accounts for uniforms, and different sums for repairing thc engine, hose, and engine house, with a fow other expenses. Thc men complain that they are not supported by thc general public. This should, wc think, bc accorded, not only by those who are altogether uninsured, but also by those whose property is fairly covered by insurance policies, for wheu insurers iu a retail lousiness effect risks on their stock they rarely do so np to the handle, and nre therefore Hallie to actual loss in thc event of a fire, in addition to being deprived of their business. A well ordered fire brigado wrould, if on thc spot in time, prevent a fire which might otherwiso prove a disastrous one, and such a body of men with proper appliances connut he obtained without money.

Two men warned H. C. Melville alias C. Stanley alias CJ. West alias T. C. Morton, and W. Oreen alias Smith, were apprehended some weeks ngo at Ravenswood with a mob nf over thirty stolen horses in their possession, and whilo the police-two of whom were heavily lined for their remissness-were con- veying the delinquents to Clermont, one of them (Melville) managed to effect his escape. Those men hail travelled with way-bills got up in accordance with tho lïrands Act, and had disposed of a number nf the stolen horses as they rode along, and thc escapee was therefore anxiously looked for in all «lircclicms. ft appears that on Sunday evening last he arrived in l-ockhaiiiptoi- and put up at an inn in tin; suburbs under the name of T. C. Moreton, with tho intention nf getting away by ono of the southern steamers. Yes- terday morning he ventured into town, and about IO o'clock was seen and recognised in Denh.iiii-streot by detective Ila ny, who imme- diately arrested and conveyed liiiu to the lockup. I ¿atur in the tiny thc ofliccr pra

eecded to thc hotel and recovered two stolon horses and the prisoner's swag, which con- tained a ehei|ue-book nud a few loose cheipics, one of which was signed *' .1. Kelman, Meteor Downs," and was drawn for CIA 10s. ; and another was signed "J. 1*. lt. Ramsay," for .CS I0s. <id. There wore also several others, all looking like forgeries from thc close resemblance of the writing. The prisoner will be brnnght befnre thc Police Court this morning, and .111 application will bc made for a remand to Clermont on tho original charge nf horse stealing.

articleText:
Cije^ocïijjinttptou Bulletin,

mm Witten ta iitcotiro&tTKii TUR

GL AD sro y ff ort s KU nc n

PUBLISHED DA.ILT.

TUESDAY, jJDXY 28, 1S74.

Ova Maryborough neighbours having abolished their Municipal Council, and initiated an era of revolution in a corporate sense, seem ata loss for means of indulging in their customary recre- ation. So long as disputatious aldermen held periodical meetings, and entertained the public by hurling vituperation and slander broadcast, the town busybodies were never at a loss for a casus belli. lîut the aldermen having discreetly retired into private life, other methods of sustaining unhealthy and vicious excitement had to be sought for, and a most effective one has at length been found in connection with a recent Orange soiree. The customary annual festival of that institution was held on the 15th instant, and drew-thc papers inform us -an attendance of seven hundred i persons, including the clergymen of

i the various Protestant denominations

in thc town, two members of the Legislative Assembly, and the editor of one of the local jour- nals. Hie full accounts which anneared

in subsequent issues of thc Chronicle and j Nevts prove that the reporters were also | present, and that all possible means were adopted of making thc demonstration a bone of contention, the picking of which should afford exhilarating employment to mischief-makers for a considerable time to come. Such a chance of evoking the demon of discord was not likely to occur again in this year of grace, and recollecting die warlike proclivities of the Maryborough public, it is not sur- prising that the local Press determined to make the most of their opportunity. I How admirably they have succeeded is

shown by the mushroom crop of fulrai I natory articles and letters which has |i since choked out the usual miscellaneous

extracts, and by the evidence such com ? njunicavions supply that the dogs of war : have again been wantonly let slip.

I. The chief apple of discord seems to

have been thrown by the Rev. EDWARD TANNER, the Church of England , clergyman, whose speech at thc meeting .excited enthusiasm and merriment, but as reported in the public press became the subject of severe animadversion when circulated amongst the general public. As published by the Chronicle the remarks ol this divine were really indecent, but he has since publicly repudiated the report, and there is reason to suspect that his speech was subjected to a considerable amount of "toning up." Thc Ckroniclc always evinces bitter and contemptuous hostility towards the Orange institution, and thc reporter on the occasion appears to have been an enthusiastic interpreter of the wishes of his chief. Making allowance for exaggeration, however, and accepting Mr. TANNER'S disclaimer regarding the most offensive passages, thc speech was rather inflammatory, even from thc

mouth of a clerevman. lint it in! not

much more objectionable titan dozens of sermons recently delivered irani Pro- testant pulpits in a!) parts of the colon}', and would have soon passed from recol- lection but for the mischievous inter- meddling of thc Press. We have reason to believe that a desire was expressed by thc leaders of the soires thal thc speeches should not be published. But that desire was not respected by the leaders of public opinion, and thc most thoughtless o nd intolerant expressions have been pre- sented in print in all their naked de- formity. If we may credit Mr. TÄNNICH, several of his sentences have been mis- construed lo make them more ? jfit-.i lit, bul thc truth probably is that in the excitement of the moment-evoked by copious draughts of orange pel.-ie and

free discharges of Kentish ure-Üie |

reverend gentleman was betrayed into some extravagance of language. Allow- ance is commonly made for the fervour of pulpit denunciations, and, as a clergyman, Mr. TANNKK was perhaps entitled to equal consideration on the platform. His best friends well know that although a sound and acceptable preacher, he is a gentleman who should

never appear in print And he was ; perfectly justified in assuming that, when j addressing a Protestant audience at the j festival of a secret society, he would be j protected equally from the reporter's graphic pen and the editor's cutting criticism. Had Mr. TANNER spoken in

a similar strain from his own pulpit, thc : Press, according to usage, would have treated his remarks as privileged, and we think similar forbearance should have been shown when thc place of delivery was an Orange platform. Were every illiberal sermon, delivered both from Protestant and Roman Catholic pulpits, afterwards circulated in the public news- papers, the probability is that thc colony

would soon be afflicted with social and

political anarchy. But such utterances arc wisely allowed to pass unnoticed, and thus perfect freedom is secured to every man to worship GOD after his own fashion, and to choose his own language in condemning what he deems heresy or

sunerslition.

To many thoughtful persons it is difficult to account for the late great development of the Orange Institution in the Australian colonies. Such societies, in a free country untrammelled by a State Church, one would have sup- posed to be wholly unnecessary. Bur, on the principle that where there is smoke there must be fire, we may assume

that there must be a distinct cause of | the new vitality manifested by Orange ism. The determination of one parti- cular church to apply the public money to indoctrinating the young with its own particular theology, is probably the chief I rock of offence to the members of other

churches, and the real excuse for that powerful organization of enthusiasts who are enrolled under the Orange banner. It may be hoped, however, that the education question will soon be settled, and that all hope of promulgating sectarian dogma by the aid of public money will perisli with that settlement. In that case there is every reason to hope that the assumed necessity of a secret society for the protection of civil and religious liberty will be held to have ceased, and that the flaunting of party colours will no longer excite ill-will and

animadversion.

At present, we suppose, the Orange Society, if an evil, must be recognised as a necessary one. Hut it may be hoped that its leading members will continue to manifest less and less that spirit of into- lerance the existence of which must be

deplored by al) impartial colonists. There is really nothing more objectionable in the written creed of Orangeism than in thc creeds of the several religious denomina- tions, and so long as excesses are dis- countenanced by the leading members of the body, and the columns of the public press are not disfigured by thc extrava- gancies of intolerant speakers, the in- fluence of the society may, on the whole, be beneficial. So long as prelates and their clergy continue to dabble in politics and attempt lo exercise a sinister in- fluence upon public questions and public men,-so long, we fear, the Orange in- stitution will continue to thrive. But wc can only regard its existence as a blot upon our civilisation, and as a melan- choly proof that in the opinion of large sections of the community, the spirit of intolerance and persecution still slumbers in ecclesiastical breasts.

It maybe hoped that our Maryborough neighbours will soon outgrow their no- torious chronic tendency to squabbling. The town is becoming important as thc seat of commercial enterprise and manu- facturing industry, and its people should renounce those childish bickerings and village politics which have heretofore distinguished them and unquestionably retarded their progress. The resources of Maryborough are numerous and con- centrated, and no town in Queensland is warranted in indulging brighter antici- pations of rapid and solid progress. In making, these comments we may be accused of meddling with affairs which do not concent us, but knowing how contagious is thc spirit of strife, we claim thc right to protest against its thoughtless encouragement by reckless neighbours.

A GRAND race ball ia announced in our advertising columns to come off on Friday evening next, under thc direction of Miss Joey Oougouhcim.

MUCH dissatisfaction ha; been caused at Gladstone by the furtive removal of Ibo Tele- graph Office froto tho Customs buildings to a wooden cottage over tho hill in tho direction of Happy Valley, now become, through tho removal of the town towards the wharves, a valley of desolation. The inhabitants declare that the removal of tho telegraph instrument was affected under cover of the-night, and that the polos and wires were removed before anyone suspected thc intention of thc "authorities." Wc understand tho chango was modo because thc station master's quarters were at the cottage over the hill, and it was necessary also to have Ins offico on the promises. Tho arrangement is satisfactory to tho station master, hut it must he excessively inconvenient to the public.

A si'EctMEN of native industry was yester- day submitted to our inspection iii thc form of a liaudsomc chess-table, iuauufacturc>l hy Mr. ¡Cascli, of East-strcot, from tho ornamental woods of this district. Tho table has a circular top. Thc pedestal is of thc wood uf thc native plum, and from the claws sining four elegantly-carved supports of yellow hov. Thc edge nf the top is of cedar,-a graceful ogee moulding,-thc top itself boiug inlaid with various WOOIIH, comprising silky oak-, white heech, Mack box, Lcicluianlt wood, bocf-wood, yellow ho*, nativo apple, fount oak, hard pine, and rosewood, all highly polished. The general design is artistic, the workmanship excellent, and the table ¡ia a whole a very chaste .article of furniture, lt has been mauufactnrcil to thc order of Mr. lt. h. IWhdiii, for a friend iu England, and i? well worth inspection by everyone desirous of fieciug how our hcautful native woods may bc

utilised for cabinet wölk.

ÛLÂÙSTOWB O nSBRTK R.

PUBLISHED DAILY*.

TUESDAY, AUGUST 25, 1374.

THE finances of the Metropolitan Cor- poration arc in a very unsatisfactory state, and unless extraneous kelp be given repudiation, is inevitable. The total receipts in 1873 were about

¿13,000 and the expenditure ¿15,000,. increasing thc debt of the city by ¿2000. For the half-year ending 30th June last the receipts were ¿6247, and the ex- penditure ¿6509, stitt showing a.sinali deficiency. But on the 7th September next the Government endowment ceases

by effluxion of time,. and ' the bridge account shows a large monthly debit. It must also be remembered that rite city streets sadly need attention, and that the drainage question must ere long be dealt with. So that altogether the prospect is dreary enough, and the citizens may well be excused for looking about them" for means wherewith to increase their resources. Expenditure cannot possibly be reduced, and consequently revenue must be by some means provided.

The first idea is naturallvenojightp .

get rid of the bridg^atlîùsthërë^n indisposition)S éo, unless the Government we P'eggítíÜ to take it over and declare 'l Êeéfat a cost to the country of ¿7000 ^& ¡£8000 a-year. It is, however, now

hinted that if the tolls were reduced by one-half, it might be well to get rid of

the structure on such terms. Without1 such reduction in charges, we are told, the traffic across the bridge cannot be properly developed, and as "the people *' of Brisbane have contributed ¿20,000 ** a-ycar towards the interest on the " Ipswich and Darling Downs Railway," they may fairly ask such aid as is now required, and accept it as an acknowledgment that something is due to them. We are told that the city is the capital of Queensland, and that its case is one deserving of serious consideration from the Govern- ment. And by way of relief we are informed thal the Sydney Corporation

is in a still worse plight, no less a sum than a quarter of a million being required to place the finances of that city on a satis- factory footing.

It may be allowed that some readjust- ment of the affairs of the Brisbane Corporation is absolutely necessary. At the same time, Ute public of thc colony may well object to any special legislation giving endowments and privileges to the metropolitan city. We arc told that it is the capital of Queensland, which is true enough in a political sense, but thal h is only the capital partially and temporarily must be apparent to everyone. Were it in a central position, and naturally fitted to become the commercial as well as the political capital of the colony, it might, likê Sydney, claim special consideration, although we con- fess inability lo see thc reason why. The capital derives immense advantages in many ways. Its population is swelled by a whole army of civil servants, who are paid out of the revenues of the whole colony, but who spend their earnings in thc metropolis, thus increasing its trade, enhancing the value of its lands, and generally adding to its prosperity. Surely this aspect of thc case is worth considering, as well as the other, and it ts asking rather too much that the city

shall be beautified principally at the cost ; of thc people of the provincial districts, ¡ who are themselves at their wits' ends to | find money for essential public improve-

ments.

We are quite prepared to admit, how- ever, that something must be done for the metropolitanCorporation. But there is no need to deal with it specially, or to confer upon it privileges which must be withheld from Maryborough, Rock- hampton, or Townsville, lt may be true enough that none of the towns mentioned are in the desperate strait that Brisbane has fallen into. «But why? Not because they did not want good streets, bridges, and town halls, but because, not possessing the means, they did not plunge into debt regardless of consequences. They have made streets and built municipal chambers according to their means, and they have not attempted to build a bridge at all, whereas Brisbane many years since contemplated spending ;£i 00,000 on the town hall and bridge alone. Instead of that amount thc outlay has reached nearly twice that sum ; but even the originally contemplated expenditure was enormous for a city whose annual taxes taxes did not exceed .£3000 to ,£4000.

It is not our object, however, to dwell upon the mistakes of thc Brisbane people, who probably have done no more than the people of Maryborough or Rockhampton would have done if similarly placed. But it is incumbent upon us to see that when any municipal readjustment takes place it shall bc done on some well defined principle capable of application to the provincial municipalities as well as to thc metropolis. Thc fact appears to be that local government in Queensland has failed so frequently because of thc insufficiency of municipal revenues. In many cases incompetent officers have had to be employed, because the salaries requisite to _ secure good and trustworthy men could not be given. We owe much of the success of the Rockhampton muni- cipality to the fact that competent and fairly paid officers have as a rule been employed. At Brisbane the town clerks and town surveyors have been notoriousfy underpaid, and hence we

find the finances in a muddle and the

streets a disgrace In Maryborough i similar false economy has been practised,

and probably we in Rockhampton should have fallen into thc same mistake liad not an exceptionally large revenue been obtained from land endowment, punt and ferries, wharfage, and rents from the Market Reserve. Representative-govern- ment cannot bc successfully worked without revenue, and poverty is appa- rently even a greater temptation to ex- travagance than wealth. Aldermanic honours in connection with inadequate resources are not tempting to those who value their reputation, and hence a poor Corporation only attracts to its board unscrupulous and inferior men.

If therefore more effective municipal government be desired, provision must be made for raising larger revenues. This might b; done in two ways-firstly by raising the maximum rate by one-half, or eighteen pence in the pound instead of one shilling; and secondly by securing from the Treasury a' perpetual endow- ment at least equal to the amount raised by rates. In a year or two the munici- palities of Maryborough and Rockhamp- ton will, like Brisbane, be no longer in the position to claim endowments, and then, however efficiently the civic affairs may be managed, .financial difficulty must .occur. There will be no such embarrassment as the metropolis is now suffering from, but the fear is that crippled resources will tend to deteriorate the_ quality of the aldennen. Thus affairs will go from bad to worse until municipal government ultimately comes entirely to grief.

To avert thc threateneA-Cvii, therefore, legislation is^npr^ar^ an(j t]ic rcprc. scntahvjj- ¡or provincial constituencies JUto'st take cave that whenever thc wants of the metropolitan Corporation arc mel, thcwhole system of municipal government in the colony sliall als®, bc subjected to revision. As we staled in a recent article, it is unreasonable to expect the people

of municipalities to defray the whole cost j

of their roads and streets, while the con- struction of all public works outside the boundaries of municipalities is under- taken by the Government. The towns- man has to contribute just as largely as the country resident to* the Public Treasury, and it is unfair that the addi- tional burden of direct taxation should be imposed upon thc municipal ratepayer without compensating advantages.

I MAILS per Balclutha, s.s., for Sydney direct,

oloso this (Tuesday) evening, at eight o'clock.

Ti'P. annual meeting of subscribers in tho North rockhampton Primary School, is an \ Bounced to take pla^c thin evening, in thc

Schoolroom, when Mr. C. N. Birkbeck, J. P., I Will preside.

THE ROCKHAMPTON BULLETIN

GLADSTONE OBSERVER

PUBLISHED DAILY.

MONDAY, AUGUST 17, 1874.

A TELEGRAM has been received from Captain Maling by his Worship the Mayor, stating that His Excellency has been pleased to accept the Reception Committee's invitation to the proposed banquet and picnic. We understand that arrangements for the banquet are pro- ceeding satisfactorily, Mr. Cramp, of the Criterion Hotel, having been entrusted with its preparation. So mitch cannot bc said, however, of tho. picnic, there bciug no authority on thc spot to graut the use of the train for thc o ccasion. A telegram to the Minister for Wi jrks on tho subject has not yet elicited a reply, and wo may add that an unfavourable i »neis considered not improbable, owing to thc want of eugine power on the line. Should", present fears be realised, we undcrstaud that some champions of the fair seie on the Committee will renew their propo- sition for a, ball, which, under the circum- stances, viii probably be adopted by the majority, and acquiesced in by those members who nt thjo outset objected to that particular mode of entertaining His Excellency.

OUR advertising columns announce that thc Lingard. Combination Troupe will give one of their varied performances this (Monday) evening at tho School of Arts, in aid of thc Hospital funds. A lilreral programme is pro- vided, for tho occasion, aud seeing that thc company have n lade so literal an offer ou so short an ocquaiu tanco with thu Rockhampton public, they sha-did ho sure of a good house. Wc are inform« al that thc company intern! leaving by thc a ext boat for Mackay.

a r. .i i) sro y rc n nu K nm n.

PUBLTSÍ-I3D DAILY".

.SATURDAY, MAROU 21, 1874.

THU gravity of thc political situation in i Victoria, arising from the conflict of opinion between the two Houses of

Legislature, is indicated Ivy thc cxtva-1 ordinary expedient proposed by the CHIEF SIXRWARY of that colony lo ensure harmonious action. To bring in a measure for the reform of thc Upper House, would have been resented as an infringement upon the lights and privi- leges of that notable body, and would not have had the remotest chance of its sanction. Granted thal some reform which will prevent future deadlocks is necessary, it becomes a mool point willi which House reform shall begin. Thc Legislative Assembly may claim to represent thc whole (iconic, but the Legislative Council claims lo ile the chosen exponent of the wealthy and educated classes, and lo enjoy equal rights with the Lower House. There is a chronic quarrel between thc two chambers, but who shall decide which is in thc wrong? Any amend- ment of the Constitution intended to throw the balance of power into the hands of the Assembly or of the Government for the time being, if accepted by the Council, would bc a tacit admission that it was wrong, and an acknowledgment of responsibility for all the obstruction which has unhappily occurred in past years. This is one of the last things that the Victorian peers are disposed to do, and Mr. FRANCIS perfectly understands that it would be useless to ask them. He had before him the fact of the

rejection of Mr. 1'AUKF.S' bill for reconstructing the Legislative Council of NcwSouth Wales, in which reform it might have been anticipated thal a majority of the existing House would be but to glad to concur. A nominee chamber enjoys neither the influence nor respect that is commanded by an elective House, and hence it might be reasonably sup- posed that no strong objection would be raised to the proposed transformation. Hut experience has proved otherwise, and il is extremely doubtful whether any measure for making the Upper House in New South Wales elective, will ever be accepted by the existing mem- bers of the legislative Council. And therefore, unless the GOVKRNOR and his advisers can agree to adopt the violent expedient of " swamping " the Council, it will remain a nominee chamber to the end of thc chapter.

Mr. FRANCIS' proposal is unquestion- ably a leap in the dark. No precedent can be found for it in Great Britain or any of her dependencies, at any rate. Ils prospects of success are at least pro I blcmatical, and if the experiment Tail it

is difficult lo see how a proper remedy can bc applied without Imperial inler I vention. The proposal is, that in case of

a future deadlock upon any measure, the GOVERNOR shall prorogue Parliament, and convene a session of members of both Houses, who shall sit and vole togelhe- as members of a single chamlicr. But it is not intended to repeal or affect in any way the provisions of the Con- stitution which remire thal every measure shrill be passed by an absolute majority of members of both Houses. So that, il would appear, the decision of the temporarily amalgamated Chamber will only carry the weight of a recommen- dation, and the bill over which thc conflict has arisen must afterwards receive the concurrence of au absolute majority of both Houses of Parliament in the ordinary way. Any greater power given to the joint Chamber would be simply a pinn for over-riding the decisions of the Upper House, and would cer- tainly be negatived by that body. Tile remedy, however, becomes a cumber- some one, and its success is very doubt- ful. The only hope seems to rest in the assumption thal when both " Lords and Commons" assemble as one House, there will be a greater probability

of concord ihan when lhere is a

conllict of opinion between two rival chambers. I5ut as in Queensland we have proved the possibility of getting up a deadlock in a single House, the plan of Mr. FRANCIS supplies no sufficient guarantee thal it will meet thc exigencies

of the situation.

In adopting the elective system in this colony, if ever public opinion demands such a step, il might lie some safeguard against deadlock lo repose in the Go I VERNOR power, under certain circum

stances, to dissolve thc Upper House as well as the Ijjwcr. And it is somewhat strange Uiat Mr. FRANCIS does not suggest that course instead of a joint session of both Houses. Hts plan, no doubt, has thc merit of keeping political power strictly in Ute hands of the people's representa- tives, and limits to thc «tmost the prerogative of thc Crown. But whether fear of the prerogative is not a mere bugbear is open to question, for HO colonial GOVERNOR is likely to so exercise his powers as to infringe upon the political liberties or privileges of Her MAJKSTV'S Australian subjects.

On the whole, we think thc colonists of Queensland have cause for satisfaction thal they arc not governed by two elec- tive Chambers. With a nominee Council there is a safety-valve which precludes all dread of n deadlock, and places a wholesome limit upon thc power of the Conservative Chamber. The possibility of " swamping " lends to keep honorable gentlemen from running to extremes, and if they do occasionally postpone salutary reforms, they also sometimes place their veto upon hasty and ill-advised measures. Whenever public opinion pronounces distinctly upon any great question, and llie popular chamber endorses the ver din, the legislative Council cannot long withstand the pressure. Tile mere threat to swamp the refractory chamber is, in fact, found a sufficient guarantee against obstructive tactics. This subject may appear abstruse lo many readers, but il is neither desirable nor expedient lhat tlie cry for constitutional reform which now agitates the adjacent colonies, should he treated as a matter in which the people of Queensland have no interest.
