Cíjc^ocíiíjiuniílou §uUcti»,

WITH WHICH IS INCORrOllTf.]) TI1K

GLADSTONE O li S IC ß V ICR.

PUBLISHED DAILY.

SATKItDAY, MAIICH l-l, 1871.

A MUN'«; lite promised measures of the forthcoming session is ii liill for tile regu- lation of our gold-fields. This is a sul)jecl on which tile necessity of legisla- tion has long been admitted, and which has heretofore tidied the ingenuity of our most allie politicians. When tile Honorable RATCI.II I I: TKIXI:, Q.C., was some yeats ago appointed a " Rojal I Commission " lo visit the various gold-

fields and take evidence, and then prépaie such a lui! as his experience and legal knowledge might suggest, it was hoped the difficulty would soon be solved. The mining laws of other colonies being available to the Commission, and the peculiar cir- cumstances of each gold-field having been ascertained by personal inspection and information al first hand from actual miners on the spot, it was believed thal Mr. I'KINC'S bill, if not accepted in its entirety by the Legislature, would al least form the basis of future legislation. Hut the Commission bill was re- jected, several yearn have since passed, and up to the lime when Parliament lasl assembled no apparent progress had been made on this ipieslion. On the contrary, certain revised regulations, issued no earlier than October last, were termed impracticable and contradictory by Mr. MACROSSAN, a member returned by one of the chief gold-fields constitu- encies ; and it is believed that by his advice, supported by that of Mr. HODG- KINSON-, another gold-fields member, the new regulations were summarily abrogated, and the old ones temporarily

re-enacted. All this is not en- couraging lo those who desire lo see our mining industries fostered by judi- cious legislation, and were il not thal the new gold-fields members profess con- fidence in their ability to grapple with the subject, no one would feel very sanguine of much reform in this direction being effected by the present Ministry, no member of which even professes special knowledge of the requirements of our gold-fields.

One of the changes w hich il is under-

stood the new northern members have

insisted upon, and which the Ministry have promised to concede, is llie crea- tion of a new portfolio to be held bya Min- ister for Mines, who shall devote htsexcUi sive attention lo the administration of thc mining affairs of the colony. Whether the Assembly will assent to this change, however, is somewhat questionable, lt may be true that the evisting department of Works and Mines is overburdened, and that no one Minister can be ex- pected io bestow the needful attention

upon both brandies. But there may be other remedies for die evil complained of. There might be a permanent Under Secretary for Mines as well as for Works, and were the former official selected because of his intimate acquaintance with the affairs of the gold-fields, much of the labour and responsibility now cast upon die Minister would be avoided. It might even be possible to secure die

valuable services of Mr. HODGKINSON or Mr. MACROSSAN for the office ol Under-secretary for Mines, while, on the other band, there is considerable doubt whether either of them would at present be acceptable to Parliament as Responsible Minister for Mines.- Doth

are too new- to the House for .such a

post, and both too inexperienced in Par- liamentary duties to constitute them eligible candidates for a seat in the Cabinet. They are intelligent and ener- getic men, no doubt, but neither has yet won his parliamentary spurs. Without a practical man as Minister for Mines

it would be of little use to create a j special mining department, and therefore we think it will be held thal the wants of the gold-fields will be best met by a sub- division of the existing Works and Mines department, and by the appointment of a trained Under-secretary fo each brandi, i There is also another method in which

I the duties of the Minister for Works

might be simplified, and his attention given more fully to thc mining a (Ta i rs of the colony. Were a measure of financial separation and load government passed, the functions of the Works J leparlinent would devolve almost entirely upon local bodies. The Minister would then not lind it necessary to travel through the country to inspect roads, bridges, lock- ups, and court-houses, but would be free to explore the various gold-fields of the colony. This last, we are inclined to think, is the true remedy for the neglect of which the gold-lields members now com- plain, as it has the merit of redressing two grievances by one legislative effort.

Decentralisation is what the whole

colony most needs al the present time, and it would be a step in the wrong direction lo aim at giving Public Works greater importance by constituting for them a distinct department presided over by a Responsible Minister. It may be hoped, therefore, thal the clause of the new bill providing for a Mining Minister,

will either be withdrawn before the measure is laid before Parliament, or that it will be expunged by the majority

in Cummittee of the Whole.

lt is a matter worth consideration, whether the new gold-fields bill should not be a consolidating measure whether, in fad, il should not embrace mining enterprises of all descriptions. There is, for example, one very important point in which our regulations for mining

on other than aurifeiioits lands are

defective. Nro protection area is at present obtainable for copper, silver, kerosene shale, or oilier mineral deposits. A man who believes he has discovered a

copper lode cannot safely explore it until he lias applied for a mineral selection and paid the deposit of five shillings per acre. Now this is a direct discourage «.t rr,WM«, ir lu- .nat-- ?in-

application in due form, and the discovery turn out valueless, the applicant loses not only his labour bul also his 'deposit money. If lie explore without having first made the application, he is al the mercy of any speculator, who may possibly find the employment of "jumping" more profitable than prospecting or exploring. The remedy for this evil is easily suggested. Let the protection area be granted for any mineral lands; in order that every encouragement may be given lo the prospector, and reasonable protection afforded him in the prosecution of his arduous and generally ill-reipiitcd

labours.

It may be hoped that the promised Mining Dill will prove a comprehensive and well-digested measure, and that honorable members will give il ihe careful attention demanded by a subject of-so great importance to the colony.

M nib) per s.n. llolclutha fur Maryborough Alni Sydney will elmo nt 1 'HO p.in. tn-day.

I'm-: luring of tke immigrants at thc ilepôl is proceeding apaej. Of Hie 3041 statute a tulls that were takun from the vessel to thc depot only lilt arc left. Thc niiinlier of single girls at thc lirst was lil, sixteen of whom aro still waiting engagements. Tim principal portion of those yet in the ilepót ave the wives and families of men who have hoon engaged tn work on the railway, and have proceeded thither.

Wi: have hedi kindly supplied hy Captain lt. M. Phillips, of Hie Florence Irving, with the following items of news fruin Cooktown. The captain states that seven thousand ounces of gold bad been snipped at Cooktown per Wonga Wonga for Sydney, and that since her departure between four and live thousand ounces Mere deposited in the banks. A con- siderable quantity, however, reaches the town (Cooktown) dom the Palmer, and is retained in private hands. Thc riorenec Irving brings over ono hundred minces. The road is now open and thc weather line, but the rivers are still up, which seriously impedes Hie traffic. Husiness is improving, ami a large quantity of all kinds of goods arc being sent off til the diggings on pack horses, which is the only menus of transit at present. Provisions in thc town are plentiful and cheap, but there is a scarcity of butchers' moat, which realises ls.

per lb. Horses are in abundance, and have declined in value lately owing to the great number of arrivais -very few vessels anchoring in the port without as many as she can con- veniently carry, Large munbun; of diggers arc pouring in, and leave for the diggings at the rate of fruin four lo live hundred daily, and it is expected that when the rivers are down and thc road easy to travel with drays, there will bc very few people left in Cooktown. Thc murder «if a Victorian digger was reported a few days before thc Florence Irving left, lt appears that two men cain-J into town and stated that while travelling towards town ono nf their number had been killed by the blacks and that thc body had been buried. Suspicion of foul play sonn arose, and thediggers became very much excited and exhumed the corpse, when it was painfully evident that the unfor- tunate man had been killed by the whites. The two men were taken into custody, and lhe> people announced their intention of having thc murder thoroughly investigated.

articleText:
f (je|locííljftnii)tou bulletin,

WïTIl IV II IC« li Í NCO RrO UTK I) TIIK

QL.IDSTOVK OBSERVER.

PUBLISHED DAILY". WEDNESDAY, MAKCII 25, 1874.

Goi.n-i'itxns legislation is a subject on |

which all prudent miters and speakers will enunciate their sentiments with modesty. The differences of opinion among practical miners and their advo- cates are so important and essential, that people not engaged in unearthing the precious metal may well doubt their ability to suggest a practical solution for the many problems by which all attempts al reform are beset. It was on this ac- count that we were rejoiced to hear that thc three norther» gold-fields members had taken the subject in hand, and de- termined to produce a bill " not incon- sistent in itself," nor likely to be contradictory lo the regulations which might be afterwards based upon il. Those who drafted regulations under the existing Act were in a position of great difficulty. Thc law was not adapted to the circumstances of Ihc colony, and in the attempt to make il available, regulations inconsistent willi its provisions were put in force. In the absence of proper legislation, this was making the best of a bad business, especially as there was no immédiate prospect of Parliament passing an amended Act. Our legislators, in fact, confessed their incompetency, and, whether Conservatives or Liberals held the reins, the measures introduced on this question were equally doomed to

deserved oblivion.

Of late, however, the cry for gold-fields law reform has become vigorous. Some years since, when the Gympie gold-field assumed importance and permanence, il was hoped that all the ills that mining flesh was heir to would be «cured by the

constitution of a local court. Thal was

a slight improvement upon tile despotic Commissioner, but on the whole the success of the court was of a very qualified character. The gold discoveries \n the liorlb then followed, and a local court being deemed undesirable, the old demand for a new Gold-fields Act was resumed, and has resulted in the return to Parliament of two representative« intimately connected with the gold mining interest, .and also of a risinp barrister who, in bis newly acquired posi tion of ATTOKNKV-GENRRAI, was anxiotif to gain distinction by claiming thc pater nity of a measure specially suited to tht circumstances of the colony. The result

is seen in a new Gold fields bill, a. copy of which is now before us, with a polite request for editorial opinions and suggestions with reference to it. Appre- ciating the delicate compliment conveyed in the invitation, we have cursorily exa- mined the Bill without prejudice, and are free to confess that iv appears to he a much belter measure than could have been reasonably anticipated. And as lhere is every reason to believe that it will be treated by the Legislature strictly on its merits, the presumption is that, with sundry amendments, it will even- tually become Jaw. It would be impos- sible in a single article to deal exhaus- tively with a measure like that nowbefore us. We shall therefore at present be content with giving the reader a general survey of thc Hill, reserving extended comments until its provisions have been explained and illustrated by its hon. and learned author in moving the second reading in the Legislative Assembly.

The " Gold-fields Act of 1874 " con- tains one hundred and seven clauses, which extend over nineteen Gazette

pages of printed matter. For conveni- ence the clauses are grouped in several divisions, into which the subject natu- rally falls. Clauses 1 to 7 deal willi the name of the hill, and the definitions of various terms used in it,-repeal the ex- isting gold-fields laws and regulations, and abolish ihe Gympie local court. Clause 5 is thc first of gre.il importance.

It declares that

"lu onlor to remove existing doubts it is hereby declared that thc title conferred hy a minor's right existiii" at tho time of the pass- ing nf this Act Kli;ul he hchl only Ut include such auriferous deposits ns aro contained within the perpendicular of the pegs marking

tho surface boundaries of the laud held hy ! virtuo of such miner's right. I'rovidcd never-

theless that thc «hove provision shall not \ extend to tho rights of parties which may ho in litigation mid undetermined at thc timo of the passing of this Act."

Clause ö transfers all powers and duties concerning gold or oilier minerals from die Works and Lands departments lo a new department crea led by the bill, and presided over by a " Minister for Mines." With this pro- vision we at present totally disagree, believing thal the case would be met by a sub-division of the existing Works and Mines department, and the appointment of an UNIIICR-SJÍCRUTAKV FOR MINKS. Dui on this point' we are open to conviction, if it be shown by the author of the bill that the gold-fields of Ihe colony need the supervision of a Responsible Minister of ihe Crown, specially appointed for that purpose. Clause 7 empowers the GUVKKNUK-IX GouNCti, lo appoint all officers necessary to carry out thc provisions of the Act.

The second division of the measure

deals with " Miners' Rights " in five clauses. Clause S provides for the issue of such documents for any term not exceeding five years, on payment of a sum al the rate of ten shillings per annum, for every year that the right is in force. Clause 9 provides for Consoli- dated Miners' Rights, which will be issued to companies registered under the Act, on payment of a sum for each miner represented, at the same rate as if so many single rights were obtained. The Miners' Rights tuc all to terminate on 31st December, and after the 30th June they will be issued at the rate of five shillings each for the remaining portion of thc year. This provision, we should think, will give much satisfaction to the diggers, and will not seriously increase the clerical duties of the "Wardens," lo whom tile existing Commissioners are tb give place. Clause 12 specifies in detail thc privileges conferred by the Miners' Right, which, in addition to digging for gold, empowers the holder lo construct races and reservoirs, cut timber, etc., etc. Thc clause also empowers the holder of a claim lo assign or encumber the same.

The next division is headed " Mining Incases," for the issue of which it pro- vides. The term of years is left blank,

and the conditions are to be such as tile

CuvKKNOR-iN-CouNcii. shall think pro- per. The special condition, however, is provided by clause 15, that such leases

shall be voidable at thc will of the GO- VERNOR should the land referred to in

them not be used "honâ,fiâ-e. for the pur " pose for which it shall be demised." Thc WAUDEN is empowered to " Iwir, " receive, and examine evidence in rela " tion to the application for any such * lease, and the objections thereto." This seems a salutary provision, and one likely lo prevent subsequent disputes and litigation. Tile 17th and three following clauses provide thal the application for a lease, if refused, shall not affect land held under a Miner's Right ; thal actions for ejectment may be brought in the district court; that it shall not beobligatory on ihe part of the Warden to grant

leases, although the applicant must, in j such case, be informed of the reasons of j refusal ; and that any lease may be surrendered, and a new one obtained for

the whole or any portion of a leased 1 area. This provision, we presume, is j intended to provide for the division of interest in any leased land.

Clauses 21 to 24 relate to business licenses, which do not call for special

remark. Clauses 25 1032 provide for the j issue of publican's licenses on gold-fields, j which are lo be issued by the j " Warder in his discretion," on payment ! of an annual fee o( jQiO. Such licenses ! are not to be transferable, but may be j cancelled, and new licenses issued for the remainder of the tenn 011 payment of

a fee of ten shillings. j

Clauses 33 to 41 provide for the pro- clamation of gold-fields by the GOVER- NOR. All lands reserved for public purposes, or used liana fide as yards or gardens, or upon which any building

shall have been erected and be in actual use, are to be exempted from occupation for mining purposes. The Governor may also set apart any portion of a gold-field as a common, and Ihe holders of miners' rights or business licenses will bc at liberty to depasture cattle and encamp on any Crown lands not pro- claimed as a gold-field, while actually engaged in searching for gold, or in the pursuit of business. This is intended to protect the prospector, but the clause

appears liable to abuse, as under pre- tence of prospecting for gold, encamp- ments might bc formed on pastoral runs which would entail endless trouble and loss upon tile lessee. However, as the bond fide prospector must be protected, the clause is perhaps little open to objection.

The next division of the bill relates ta the " Administration of justice," but that we must reserve until to I morrow.

C|}e$focl¡j¡imj)tou §ttlletin,

WITH WttlCII 19 MOORrOiUTKI) THK

GLADS TONE OBSERVER.

PUBLISHED DAILY.

MONDAY, JULY 20, 1874.

OUR files bring details of the late dis- agreement between the Council and Assembly on that knotty, subject, the land question ; and as it is one of great interest in this part of the colony, we will en- deavour to give the reader the gist of the differences which threaten to provoke a serious quarrel between the two branches of the Legislature.

When the bill left the Assembly a fortnight ago, the general belief was, that it would meet with summary rejection from the Council. It was next asserted that the bill would be altered back to its state when first introduced into the Assembly, the opinion being that in such form it would conserve the interests of the pastoral tenants by obstructing settlement upon the lands. For a time this idea appeared to " take " amazingly, and it was held that a more effectual means of condemning a Liberal Ministry could not have been devised. But as time sped, other counsels prevailed, and, if report speak truly, a caucus meeting of i the " Lords" was held on the morning of I the day on which the bill was to be con-

sidered in committee. At that meeting, it is understood, the Hon. F.T. GREGORY, a brother of the Surveyor-General, sub-

mitted certain amendments with the view j

of making the measure of the Lower ; House a "good bill," as that term is understood amongst gentlemen who are,

rightly or wrongly, deemed ultra- j

conservatives in politics. The sug- gestions of Mr. GREGORY appear to have met with approval, for at the sitting of the Council that afternoon they were j submitted and nearly all adopted with scarcely a show of discussion. This proceeding was at least impolitic, and that in more ways than one. The ori- ginal bill was the product of Mr. A. C. GREGORY, the Surveyor-General, and it was considerably "improved upon," firstly, by the MINISTER FOR LANDS, and secondly by the Legislative Assem- bly. From thc prominent part taken by Mr. F. T. GREGORY in amending the bill, it naturally came to be whispered that he was in reality only the mouth-piece of the SURVEYOR-GENERAL, and that by this means that astute official had again effectually checkmated the responsible head of his department. But the mode in which the amendments were made was deemed objectionable on other grounds. It was held to be scarcely decent when some dozen honourable gentlemen, who were themselves pastoral tenants, sat around the Council table with the avowed determination to emas- culate a measure passed through another chamber by the people's representatives after prolonged discussion and delibera- tion. And it was contended that the proper course for thc Council to take was to reject the bill on the ninth clause, which was really tim obstacle to the measure becoming law. The Council held unnecessary resumption to be actual repudiation, and it »mst be confessed that cogent arguments have been adduced in support of that opinion. Thc ten years' leases were granted in good faith, and the lands included in them were only to be resumed when required for settlement. Thc bill, however, assumed that all the lands within the limits of the settled

districts wer« required,-notoriously an unsound assumption,-and had the Legis- lative Council rejected the measure on that ground, while expressing a desire to meet all reasonable demands for settle-

ment, they would have occupied a

position from which it would be unneces- sary to retreat. Such a stand-point might not have protected them from the assaults of rabid land law reformers, but it would have secured to them the

sympathy of every moderate man in the country. It is undeniable that thc Ministry could have easily ascertained where land was actually required, and that their throwing the onus of proof on the individual selector was an exhibition of moral cowardice which could only be tolerated in a professedly Liberal Ministry. It is quite certain that had the Government brought popular pressure to bear in favour of needful resumptions alone during the currency of the leases, the Legislative Council must have yielded to a demand the justice and expediency of which could not have been fairly questioned. And if the further stipulation had been made that at the termination of the leases four years he:ice there should be no renewals but absolute free selection throughout the country, the cry of repudiation could not have been raised with even a semblance of justice.

The Upper House, therefore, are greatly to blame for having neglected a golden opportunity of setting Ministers' on the right track. They believed the Land Bill essentially bad, and instead of taking their stand firmly on principle, thought fit to sacrifice everything to mere expediency. Their argument was " Let us not give the Government the " chance of taunting us with throwing " out their iniquitous measure, but let us " make it as innocuous as possible." And so honorable members cut and

patched the bill until it was impossible that either the Government or Assembly could accept it. The result is that every important amendment was rejected by the Lower House as summarily as it had been made by the Upper, and, so far as the land question is concerned, the Legislature of the colony has been brought to a deadlock.

But to come to Mr. GREGORY'S amend- : ments. He first dealt with the inter- ;

pretation clause, by giving a very | extended meaning to the term "improve- ments," and by providing that " fencing," in case of a selector holding several blocks, should mean a fence around the whole, and not around each block. The latter amendment, to use the words of Mr. STEPHENS, " would have proved a " neat arrangement for dummying," and both were consequently rejected. On clause 9-the resumption clause-being proposed, Mr. WILSON moved that it be expunged. Had the motion been agreed to, the bill would have been thrown out, but Mr. GREGORY came to the rescue with an amendment in the form of the

following appendage to the clause :

"In addition to tho right of pre-emption, which may be exercised under tue provisions of the Crown Lands Alienation Act of 1868, the lesseo may make further selection under pre-emption to the extent of one-tenth part of the area held under lease at the passing of this Act in compensation for such resumption, and such pre-emptive selection to bo in one block, except with the approval of the commissioner for the consolidation of previous selections, and in respect to the annual payments thereon, bc subject to tho same conditions as would apply to any other pre-emptive selection under thc Act of 1868."

This amendment was agreed to by the Council, but on being submitted to the Assembly was rejected, one speaker-a licensed surveyor-pointing out that if this clause passed [as amended the lessee would be empowered to make his pre-emptive selections in six separate

blocks. The amendment was con- sequently ¿tísented from on division by twenty-three ayes to six noes,-it being understood that

several of the majority, while anxious to , see the principle of compensation affirmed, could not vote for it in the shape it here assumed.

The next important amendment was in clause io, which was made to permit the lessee to remove improvements from lands in cases where pre-emption had been exercised elsewhere. This point

had been much contested in the

Assembly, Mr. WIENHOLT declaring that he would "remove every stick of irn " provements from his run in spite of any " Act to the contrary." Mr. STEPHENS, however, argued that where a lessee had exercised pre-emption nominally to se- cure improvements, and had not selected the lands on which they stood, he had forfeited all right and title to them. In this opinion the majority in the Assembly coincided, and their views were not changed when Mr. GREGORY'S amend- ment came down from the Upper

Chamber.

After a number of verbal amendments, all of which afterwards met the approval of the Assembly, Mr. GREGORY moved an important alteration in clause 2i. The clause originally provided that no decision of the land. commissioner should be final until approved of by the Secretary for Lands. At the instance of Mr. GREGORY, the Council added

"Who shall within six months notify his confirmation or disallowance thereof ; aud if such notification bc not given within such period, it shall bc taken that thc decision of the commissioner has been confirmed."

An amendment in clause 23, making

the decisions of the commissioners final in issuing certificates, was also made, but both the concessions having been stoutly contended for and refused previously in tlie Assembly, were unceremoniously dis- agreed to when inserted by the Council.

Mr. GRI:GORY*S next important amend- ment was a proviso to clause 25, enact- ing that lands should not be open to selection under this Act in thc unsettled districts, except ordered by a resolution of both Houses of Parliament. This had been a great subject of contention in the Assembly, and the Government having been defeated upon it, the Council should have known that their amendment would not be agreed to. It was, in fact, re- jected without discussion. An amend- ment in clause 31 intended to limit the area for selection to 2560 acres, shared the same fate ; and one in clause 33, con- fining the homestead areas to one-tenth the total area of a lease, was not more fortunate. Several other amendments in matters of detail were also disagreed to, as were some intended to prevent the

proclamation of commons in agricultural ]

districts.

The remaining amendments were what are known as two "quieting of titles clauses." They provided that in case of non-fulfilment of conditions the deed of grant might be obtained on payment of a penalty of five shillings per acre ; and in case

of selections held under the Act of 1866, that improvements might be sub- stituted for cultivation. Both these amendments were rejected without dis- cussion, although they would have been a great relief to hundreds of poor but bona fide selectors, who have found it impossible to fulfil the statutory con- ditions under which their selections were made. Politicians of all parties admit that sooner or later a "selectors' relief

bill" must be passed, but it does not suit the Government programme to grant this relief just now. Relief to the bona fide settler, it is alleged, would also involve immunity to the great dummier, and that it is not intended at present to concede. But persons who do not per- ceive the necessity of a Liberal Govern- ment conserving political capital, hold that if relief be inevitable the sooner it is afforded the better for the poor selector and the better for the whole colony. Nothing is more detrimental to progress than uncertainty in the tenure of the land, and that the present Government appear determined shall become the normal condition of affairs among con- ditional selectors as well as pastoral

lessees.

Our telegrams have informed us that the Land Bill has been finally got rid of by the Government carrying a motion for reading the Council's amendments " that day six months," which means that the bill be consigned to the waste paper basket-a thing not to be regretted. We

have since been informed that some

resolutions subsequently passed by the Assembly, for resuming certain runs for immediate settlement, have also been rejected by the Council-a circumstance to be deplored, as the demand for land is great in the neighbourhood of all thc principal towns in the colony. The blame for this state of affairs, however, must be divided between the Council and the Ministry ; for if the former be condemned for obstructing settlement, the latter must be also condemned for approaching the question of resumption in an offensive and unconstitutional manner. Had resolutions for resuming lands where actually required been sub- mitted in the first instance, instead of the wholesale resumption designed by the Government bill, the Council could not have rejected them without incurring very grave censure. As it is, they claim sympathy from very large classes in the community as the opponents of repu- diation, or, at least, of inexpedient tampering with Crown Lands held under

lease by the pastoral tenjiSl. x '

.-.-:

PUBLISHED DAILY.

FRIDAY, JULY 17, 1874.

THE election Li the Municipal Meeting yesterday, of an engineer for the Water Works, is deserving of study, more par- ticularly as it signally failed to express the wish of the majority of the Aldermen who took part in it. There were twelve candidates for the appointment ; one of those candidates, Mr. BURSTALL, had the votes of five out of the nine Aldermen and yet, strange to say, was not elected. A little examination will show how this untoward result was arrived at. And we may premise our analysis by explaining that the MAYOR has a vote as alderman, in addition to casting vote as chairman. As it turned out in this case, the casting vote was not called for; we have there- fore to deal with nine votes. The pro- ceedings commenced by the MAYOR reading out the list of candidates, and throwing aside those who had no supporters in the Council. The number was thus reduced to eight, which was further reduced by successive ballots, from eight to five, five to three, three to two, two to one-and the candi- date who in the last ballot polled the largest number of votes, viz., seven, was subsequently elected by formal resolu- tion. In the first ballot, ALLEY, ROBERTSON, and EDGAR each polled tight votes, BURSTALL seven, MELCHIOR five, and each of the others a less number. The five named were then submitted to ballot for the purpose of reducing the number to three, and the outcome was as follows :-ALLEY seven, EDGAR six, ROBERTSON six, BURSTALL five, MELCHIOR three. The two last were accordingly thrown aside. The next ballot was to further reduce the number to two, and resulted as follows : EDGAR seven, ALLEY six, ROBERTSON five. The choice then lay between

i /VI^LLÏ ana CDQAK, ana trie votes stood

respectively seven and two. It is a note I worthy circumstance that whilst ALLEY,

the successfulcandidate, polledse ven votes in the last ballot against two for EDGAR, the latter polled the highest number in the ballot immediately preceding. There is no reason to suppose that the aldermen had altered their opinions, and the relative change of position of the candidates is obviously attributable to the manner in v/hich thc ballots were . taken. In a siijiilar way we find that

BURSTALL, «ho hat? five aldermen on

his side, and in no instance polled less than that number of votes, was below three of the other candidates when the choice was made of three out of five.

The apparent anomaly is capable of easy explanation. In the ballot for three out of five, the aldermen in favour of i BURSTALL were required to vote for two

others also; and although they were decided as to their man, and gave him their vote, they were not so as to the candi- dates for second and third place ; and in selecting these, scattered their votes in such a capricious manner among the other four as to give a larger number to two of them than to their own favourite. This curious result, it will be clearly seen, was never contemplated by the majority, who were, in fact, defeated unintentionally by their own votes. The same mode of election has been adopted for some time past in the Council, and no suspicion ever appears to have crossed

the minds of aldermen that from the

very nature of things an election so con- ducted not only could not be depended upon, but might even so far go astray as to work in direct opposition to the wishes of the voters. In the particular instance before us, the successful candidate could not have had more than four aldermen in his favour, and the large number of votes polled by him was mainly due to votes that were indifferently thrown in by the several aldermen to make up the required numberin t!;eirrespectivc ballots. Each Alderman, we will suppose, had a preference for some particular candidate,

but was undecided as to the comparative . merits of the others. In this way the j

objectless votes overpowered those given

with definiteness of purpose. We are ; not canvassing the merits of the candi- dates. There were, doubtless, several of the candidates really capable and suit- able for the appointment ; and we make no charge against the winner, who is a perfect stranger to us, and, for aught we know, to the contrary, may be a good

man. It is nevertheless true that he has ; been chosen in error, and against the de- ¡ cided intention of a majority of j the Council. The proper course

would have been to submit all

the eligible candidates to the ballot j

at one time. Had that been done, Mr. BURSTALL would certainly have

polled five votes, whilst no other i candidate could possibly have obtained ; more than four, and it is not improbable

that the accidental votes would have I been so distributed as to allocate less than four to all the eleven unsuccessful candidates. However, as the matter stands, the Council wanted Mr. BURST- ALL, but against their own will and in-

tention elected Mr. AILEY. The rcso-1 lution by which the appointment was conferred on the last-named gentleman was purely of a formal character, and was agreed to without discussion, the aldermen, in a moment of surprise, being under the erroneous impression that they were simply giving effect to a deliberate decision intelligently arrived at by the majority.

As adjourned sitting of the Small Debts Court was held yesterday before the Police Magistrate and his worship the Mayor, when the case of Ash Sing e. J. H. Strobe, claim £2 18B. 6i. for wages, was called on. Mr. Melbourne for the plaintiff, Mr. Milford for the defendant. After hearing evidence on both aides, and the addresses of the attorneys engaged, the Court gave judgment for tho plaintiff for £1 17s. Cd., but without costs.

The R.M.S. Legislator, with ¡the incoming English mail, lçft 'Bowen yesterday at 10'30 a.m., for Keppel Bay, where she will arrive to-day, about 5 p.m. The s. Mary will leave Rockhampton this morning, as soon after IO o'clock as possible, with a mail for Brisbane to pnt on board the Legislator, and will return to town early to-morrow morning with the English mau. An official telegram waa received from thc General l'oat Office, Brisbane, yesterday, by Mr. Peterson, notify- ing that the A..S.N. Company's steamship Alexandra will leave Brisbane on Wednesday next, at 4 o.m., with thc outgoiug English mails via Torres Strait, and should arrive in Keppel Bay on Thursday night. The incom- ing mail, should the Legislator reach Keppel Bay this evening as anticipated, will be nearly five days before her contract time : whilst tho outgoing mail, owing to the accident to the R.M.S. Flintshire, viii bo dispatched a week Ute. One advantage will however be gained by the irregularity, as it will give Queensland correspondents an opportunity of sending quick replies to letters arriving by the Legislator. In Rockhampton, for instance, thc incoming mail will be delivered to-morrow morning, and the outgoing mail will close on Wednesday night or Thursday morning.

AT the Police Court, yesterday morning, before the Police Magistrate and his Worship the Mayor, three persons were punished as drunkards, and two others were fined 5s. and £2 respectively for being drunk and disorderly the previous night. William Henry Heggarty was charged with stealing the sum of £5, on the 9th instant, the property of Elisabeth Hoey. Mr. Melbourne for the prosecution, Mr. Brown for the defence. Detective Barry proved that he arrested the accused on Wed- nesday, thc 15th instant, about 1 o'clock, at tho Dunmore Arms, by virtue of a warrant (produced), and he replied "Ideny the charge completely," and after- wards said, " I gave five £1-notes in a letter to give to some one." At this stage of thc case a remand was applied for by the detective officer, which was granted for three days, hail being allowed the accused in £40 and two sure- ties of £20 each. This was immediately pro- cured, and the defendaut left the Court. John Bailey, on remand, was charged with obtain- ing £7 10s. from Edwin Macaree hy means of a false pretence. The prosecutor deposed that ou the 2nd January last, he cashed an advance note of the prisoner's for £9, giving him £7 10s. for it. The note was addressed to Messrs. W. and M. C. Thomson as agents {or the Landsborough and was endorsed by thc firm, subject to the usual conditions, one being that the prisoner sailed in the vessel ; this is thc note (produced), and this is the receipt (produced) the prisoner gave for the money. Tho prisoner promised to go in the ship, and it was upon this statement that the note was cashed. The Bench here asked the police if they were prepared to show, by evidence, that there was a false pretence of an existing fact by thc prisoner. Mr. Isley replied in the negative, and the accused was discharged.

articleText:
®|e|Jo(it(|am|}tou bulletin,

trim ff ri icu is iBcoaroUTiîD TH*.

G&J.DSVOX8 O BS S UV SR.

PUBLISHED DA.ILY. THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 3, 1874.

HOWEVER plaintively some persons now living may regret the good old times which thc world can never see again, there are, probably, material compensa- tions to be discovered even in this age of steam and electricity. The restless anxiety manifested by progressive com- munities to grow rich, or in some other way to attain the summit of human felicity, is perhaps after all more defensible than the life of mere vegeta- tion in which out respected ancestors delighted to exist, as a set-off against occasional privations and sanguinary ex- ploits, lt may be true that the intellectual activity and assumed physical deterioration of the present day are not without their disadvantages, and that, wliile the average duration of human life has been lengthened, insanity has in- creased, and the proportion of aged people to the whole population has somewhat diminished. Yet modern

existence is not without its own liorations. If the term of life half teen in cases shortened, the capacity for «?»?enjoyment has been enlarged, ana it!

opportunities have been increased; and although death is not robbed of its terrors science and skill have done something to mitigate the suffering attendant upor disease, especially when it afflicts the mind. One of our poets tell us

Th ero ia pleasure, sore, in being mad, Which none but madmen know.

But that pleasure must have been of ¡ very melancholy kind in the lunatic asylums of a hundred years ago, when chains, manacles, and brutal treatmen drove incipient madmen to despair, and converted hopeless lunatics into fiends.

In no way is there humanism; instincts of the present age mon pleasingly developed than in the

treatment of the insane. Bru

tality and violence have been re placed by sympathy and gentleness Chains, manacles, and strait jackets have been banished in favour of kindness and careful attention, with the happiest results and the friends of persons afflicted with mental disorders enjoy the consolation that in the public asylums everything possible is done to promote recovery, not where reason is hopelessly gone, be soothe and mitigate the wretchedness of the maniac's condition.

In Queenslandi until a very short time ago, our treatment of the insane was cruel. We had an asylum at Woogaroo but it was conducted on, the old coerciv system. Refractory' lunatics: were treated in the most approved' methods of re pression. Even women were caged. Chained to rings in the floor, handcuffed and leg-ironed, and cruelly beaten into docility, or rather exhaustion. They entered the asylum through the gaol' and generally speaking were treated like furious wild beasts, instead of human beings afflicted with mental disorders. No doubt the cruelty was not intentional, an the repression was no more than media men deemed necessary for the protection both of the lunatic and his keepers But that such violence was really unnecessary is proven by the succèss which attends the present humane treat ment, and by the immunity with which two or three warders move about amongst dozens of confirmed maniacs.

The lunatic asylum at Woogaroo is becoming an institution of some magnitude. It is, in fact, a collection < some 270 mad people, who with the warders in charge out number the population of many a bush township. With its convalescent and refractory wards cells, dormitories and hospitals, for both male and female patients, Woogaroo is a

place which the visitor requires consid able time lo inspect In thc surgery he discovers a tolerably complete chemist

shop. Tossing into the male refractory wards, he finds himself suddenly in the company of some fifty or sixty men in all stages of lunacy, but perfectly free from implements of restraint or torture, and each pursuing the vagaries of his own perverted fancy. Here is a perfect bedlam of noise. One howls, another sings, a third preaches, a fourth pro- menades with thc regularity of a sentry, a fifth runs or jumps, a sixth plays childishly with rags or bones, while others sit or repose at full length on the ground, looking about with dreamy vacuity. The first idea of thc visitor is

that some four or five warders must be insufficient for the proper control of so large a number of dangerous madmen, but the business appears to be conducted without fear or difficulty. livery patient is an isolated wreck of humanity-a practically solitary individual although actually in a crowd-perfectly indifferent to and apparently unconscious of the doings of his companions. A concerted attack is therefore impossible, and the ¡ warders are always able to concentrate their strength upon a patient when the violent paroxysm comes on. ^ The keepers are calm and systematic in their movements, and exercise full control over the incoherent mass of human beings by whom they arc surrounded. The sight of these unhappy people is, however, most melancholy and depressing to the un- seasoned visitor, and he gladly passes on to inspect other portions of the institu- tion. Adjacent to the refractory ward he notices some dark cells, where other- wise unmanageable patients are "occa- sionally placed, it being found that darkness soothes the diseased mind as well as the diseased eye. In the con valescent ward everything is in marked contrast to that just left. Here every- thing is quiet, orderly, and conducive to the patients' recovery. The dormitories are a picture of neatness, and, so far as the space available admits, thc inmates are provided with all requisites for health and comfort. The hospital ward is fairly adapted for the purpose, and although here the visitor is sickened by meeting patients shattered both in body and mind, there is some comfort in the thought that the poor creatures receive all the care which their deplorable condition demands. The female wards require more fortitude for proper inspection than the usual run of visitors can command. It is revolting enough to pass through the male refrac- tory ward, but recollections of the violent ravings of lunatics of the " gen- tler sex " would be too disagreeable a reminiscence in the visitor's mind to make . the inspection of the female wards a matter

of choice. It may be deemed some satisfaction, however, when we state that the female lunatics, both refractory and convalescent, are attended upon solely by women, and that no degree of violence on the part of an inmate is held to warrant the calling in of a male warder.

The institution is in charge of Dr. JAAP, who is not only an experienced surgeon, but also an enthusiast in his work. He resides with his family on the grounds, and is always within call, by day or night. His responsibilities are very great, and his duties have proved so severe and unremitting that it has just been found necessary to appoint an assis- tant-surgeon. Ufortunately, the number of patients Ls steadily increasing, and in consequence new and improved buildings , have been for some time in progress. In a few months, it is hoped that these will have been completed, and the insititution placed in a thoroughly effective state. The question, however, arises whether Woogaroo, with some three hundred lunatics within its grounds, is not large enough for a single establishment of that nature, and whether a second asylum, either on the Darling Downs or at some place in the northern districts, should not as soon as practicable be commenced.

Another question arises in regard to the treatment of the insane, on which the "authorities" differ. Dr. JAAP, for example, is sceptical of the benefit derived from the several lunatic recep- tion houses, and strongly disapproves oí the discretionary power given to magis- trates to re-commit patients for a second or third month's treatment to those institutions. He argues that at Woogaroo are incomparably the best appliances for the treatment of dementia, which is a diSorderdemanding prompt and energetic treatment. He contends therefore that dipsomaniacs alone should be retained in the reception houses, and that all other patients should be forwarded at once to Woogaroo. The percentage of cures effected at that institution has been steadily declining for years past, until it now stands at some 22 or 23 per cent of the numbers admitted. Years ago the percentage of recoveries was very much greater, and as Surgeon-superintendent, Dr. JAAP naturally looks upon his un- favourable returns with anxiety. The buildings, appliances, and mode of treat- ment have of late years been greatly improved, and to the casual observer it may seem remarkable that thc percentage of cures has so greatly declined. Woogaroo is, in fact, rapidly becoming an institution for incurables, and almost all the medical staff and warders can hope for is some amelioration of the state of unfortunates as dead to society and the world as though they were in their graves. This is less satisfactory in some respects titan a higher percentage of cures would be; but there is another side to the question. At the lunatic reception house in Rockhampton, for example, the accommodation, in propor- tion to the number of patients, is not inferior to Woogaroo, and it possesses the advantage of not being regarded as a public madhouse. A person of unsound mind, when committed to the

I lunatic reception house knows-if he have any glimmering of reason left that it is a place of temporary detention only, and that he goes there as an invalid for medical treatment rather than as a patient to a lunatic asylum. Dr. J AIM- makes tallier hght of this aspect of the matter, but, some of his professional brctliren

hold a contrary opinion, and maintain it with all die firmness usually displayed by j doctors who disagree. At Brisbane, Dr. Houns, who has charge of the lunatic reception house there, sends a patient to Woogaroo only as a last resource when convinced that the case is incurable. Dr. SALMOND here, also takes up much the same ground, and he is scarcely less an enthusiast in the matter titan Dr. J AAP himself. What- ever might be the correct practice at Brisbane, which is within a few miles of Woogaroo, it seems obviously desirable to retain patients in the lunatic reception house here so long as there is hope of cure and the institution is not over- crowded. The costof transit to Brisbane

is considerable, and the roughing it in charge of a constable on board steamer canscarcelybe conducive to apaticnt's re- covery. This argument applies with still greater force at Townsville, and if the result of establishing lunatic reception houses at all the chief centres of popula- tion in the colony, tends to still further

1 reduce the nercentace of cures at Woo

garoo, compensation must be found in the probability that, by timely measures on the spot, incipient mania is often checked and mental health restored where delay would be attended by un- favourable symptoms. Anyone who has visited both Woogaroo and the lunatic reception house at Rockhampton, would certainly not hesitate as to which he pre- ferred for an afflicted friend of whose recovery there was some ground for hope. Despite the many advantages of treatment at Woogaroo, wc think our medical men are quite justified in keeping patients out of that institution as long as possible. A sick man who would not suffer depression on entering that place must be very far gone indeed, and not even Dr. JAAP will argue that mental depression in cases of lunacy is conducive to convalescence. ?,<

Óf|e1|ocíi5»inj)toii bulletin,

WITH WltlCn IB INCORPOft&TP.U TUF.

GLADSTONE O BSRUlrf£ R

PUB LIS H: ED DAILY".

TUESDAY, JULY 7, 1874.

THE report from the Superintendent of Electric Telegraphs for the year 1873, lias just been laid before Parliament. It is dated 13th June, 1874, and there- fore appears at a considerably later date than thc uninitiated may conceive to be desirable. It is, however, on the whole, a satisfactory record of progress in electric telegraphy in this colony, and contains a variety of information of general interest.

The work of extension is still going on in this department as is shown by the list of new lines and additional wires erected since the date of Mr. CRACK NEU.'S last report They are as follows: -From Maryborough to Teningering, new line, 48 miles; Maryborough to Gayndah, additional wire, 25 miles ; Gin Gin toGladstone.newline, i04miles ; Too- woomba to Dalby (railway line of three wires), 52 miles ; Gin Gin to Bundaberg, new line, 30 v£ miles ; Springsure to Tambo, 144J/¿ miles; and Brisbane to Maryborough, second wire, 177y2 miles. In the colony there are altogether 3203 miles of line, and 3931 miles of wire, which are worked by 181 officers at 74 stations. Ten years ago we had only 298 miles of wire, 25 officers, and 11 stations. The comparative number of messages and receipts were'-in 1863, messages, 19,219, and cash receipts, £4152 is. íod. ; in 1873, messages, 156,268, and cash receipts, £20,759 is. 3d. This is exclusive of O.H.M.S. business, which is equal to about one third of the cash business. The popu- lation of the colony in 1863 was 61,640, and in 1873, 146,690, so that the tele- graphic business is extending far more rapidly than the population is increasing.

The lines at present in course of con- traction are,-from Roma to Charleville, 180 miles, where 150 miles of poles have been erected, and the work is generally in a forward state ; and from Roma to St George, 120 miles, to bc completed al the end of the year Arrangements have also been entercc into for erecting a second wire on tin

line between Rockhampton and the Burdekin, 493 miles, the single wire between tírese points being much over crowded, and business being greatly obstructed by the stoppages which some- times occur. Tenders have also been invited for the construction of lines from Brisbane to Nerang Creek, near the Border ; from Brisbane to Ipswich, within the railway fences; and from

Ravenswood to Millchester. In addition to these we are told that

Provision is made for the erection of lines from Charleville to Cunnamulla ; from Bunda- berg to the Pilot Station, Burnett Hoads ; from the Pilot Station, Keppel Bay, to Capo Capricorn ; from Charleville to Tambo ; and sufficient money is available for surveying linos from Junction Creek Telegraph Station to thc Palmer River Gold-lields, and from the Palmer River to Cooktown, It is also proposed to extend tho lines from Waterview to the Lower Herbert, from thc Burdekin Telegraph Station to Cape Bowling Oreen, from Mackay to Flat- top Island, from Gladstone to Bustard Head, from Woody Island to Sandy Cape, from Tiaro to Inskip Point, from Gyinpio to Tewantin, from Ipswich to Nanango, from Cunnamulla to New South Wales boundary, and from Spring- sure to Blackall, at an early date.

On the subject of shipping telegrams, the SUPERINTENDENT says that they are "transmitted as regularly as the large " business will permit," but that too much

time is taken up by the transmission of j free messages, to the injury of legitimate traffic. Meteorological observations also continue to be taken at Cape Moreton, Toowoomba, and Warwick, and for- warded daily to Brisbane. But why such

observations are not taken in other j parts of the colony, and transmitted daily to Brisbane, with the rainfall, Dr. CRACKNELL does not explain. To relieve the pressure from this free business, he suggests that shipping should be forwarded at Press rates, but he does not say who is to pay for them, as the public expect such intelligence to be posted daily on receipt, and could not be satisfied to await the issue of the next local paper.

In referring to the " working of lines," the report reminds us that serious damage was done to the lines between Hawkwood and Camboon, and between Mary- borough and Gayndah, by heavy storms and bush fires in November last ; and that the cyclone in January injured many miles of the line between St Lawrence arid Nebo. On the whole, however, we are assured that the lines worked well

throughout the year-an assurance which

we cannot accept without some qualifica- j

tion. It would have been of course unrea- sonable to expect Mr. CRACKNELUO admit that owing to his own want of foresight, or obstinacy, telegraphic communication was nearly brought to a deadlock for months after the reduction in charges last November. Messages were re- ceived, it is true, at the different stations, but so inadequate was the staff to trans- act the increased business, that their transmission ordinarily occupied days, instead of minutes or hours. It is well known that until October the Superin- tendent took no measures to prepare for the flood of business which he ought to have anticipated and prepared for. We now are told that for the sue months preceding the réduction), the number of messages transmitted was 58,542, while for the succeeding six months the number was 96,130 or an increase of 65 per cent. The former brought in £10,700, and the latter £9692, so that the loss of revenue, notwithstanding the reduced charges and the continual delays in transmission, shows a loss of only £2000 a-year. A better justification for the reduction, in spite of Mr. CRACK NELL'S protests, could hardly be supplied. It will no doubt be found that the receipts for the current year will largely exceed any previous one ; and although the expenditure will be considerably increased, the public will have gained a large indirect return by the reduced charges.

After referring to various matters of minor interest, the report explains what has been done in regard to the cable proposed to be laid between Normanton and Singapore, the construction of which was agreed upon at the Intercolonial Conference held in February last year. The proposal has since been assented to by the Legislatures of New South Wales, New Zealand, and Queensland, and we are glad to be informed that steps will be

taken to commence the work without

delay. We may remind the reader that the project includes the laying of a cable between Sydney and New Zealand, and that the enterprise will be carried out at the joint expense of the three colonies.

There are several appendices to the report, supplying details on various, matters connected with the department. A map showing the telegraph lines con- structed or proposed between Europe and Australia is also attached, and gives the reader valuable information with respect to the extension of international telegraphy.

Tile revenue collected at the Customs, Rockhampton, during thc month of June, amounted to £5G4I fis. 2d. The receipts for the quarter ending on tho 30th ultimo, shewed a total sum of £17,791 tis. 3d., and for the

half year terminating same date, 4533,863 2s.., The total receipts for 1873 were £63,555, a moderate increase is therefore perceptible dur the past six months os compared with the ration previously maintained,

i TUE house at the Theatre Royal last evening I was smaU, and tho first part of thc programme,

the lecture by Mr. Emile Arglos, was not very well received. Thc lecturer, according to promise, gavo a number of short readings from American authors of comic or humorous celebrity-Artemus Ward, Bailey's Danbury Newt, and Mark Twain-and brought it to on early termination by a reading from thc last named author, when he gracefully retired. The comedy of "The Jealous Wife," however, in which Miss Joey took the part of Mistress Oakley, played os it was in her usual style of excellence, soon put thc audience into a better humour. Mr. Thomson, who acted tho part

j of Afr. Oakley, sustained the character weU, j

and was duly appreciated. Mr. Dumar, os I Major, acquitted himself in good style. The

same programme, we observe, ta announced I for this evening, and on Wednesday evening ' thc touching play ot " Thc Wifo's Secret" will ! be performed on the occasion of Miss <Jongcn I hoim's complimentary benefit, when" we expect

' she will have a bumper house. 1

PUBLISHED DAILY.

SATURDAY. MAY 9, 1874.

WE understand that the members of Parliament in this colony are much dis- satisfied at the very curt manner in which their speeches have been lately reported -often distorted-in the public Press. The leading journal limits its Parlia- mentary reports to four or five columns per diem, a space quite adequate on some days, but utterly insufficient when any important question is under considera- tion. It is quite certain that public opinion has heretofore been formed mainly upon the Parliamentary debates published in the daily Press, but with such reports as are now supplied, it is prac- tically the editors of newspapers, rather than the members of the Legislature, who form public opinion in this colony. This state of affairs no doubt exalts the func- tion of journalism, but in a colony like ours, whose immense geographical ex tent necessarily involves a great diversity of opinions and interests, it is impossible for any individual journal to satisfactorily reflect public opinion in ¡ts various forms. The editor of thc Courier is actuated by thc most honourable inten- tions, but he finds it will not pay to report the debates in full, and Üierefbre exercises discretion as to what shall be

published and what suppressed. The I consequence is that some discussions of the greatest possible interest to the central and northern districts are not published at all, while matters of su- preme but purely local interest to the southern, districts are accorded a liberal quantity of space. Hansard is intended, as an historical record merely, and therefore reports in Committee of the- Whole, where some of the best speeches, on current topics are made, are not in any way preserved. On reference to the number of Hansard just to hand, however, we find that portion 'of the debate in Committee of Supply 'which refers to Mr. Stanley is preserved, while no notice is taken of the remon- strances of the members for the central district on thc road and postal votes, or of the discussion which took place on the roads department at Rockhampton. So that the only account of these matters that has been preserved, is the meagre notice and bald comment which appeared in the so-called report of the Brisbane Courier. It is not unnatural, therefore, that a change in the method of preparing Ratuard is under consideration, and that failing the dissemination of reasonably correct and full reports by private enter- prise, arrangements will probably bc made for the publication of authenti- cated reports by the Legislature itself. The project has, in fact, been mooted of publishing a Morning Mamari, contain-

ing not more than fourteen newspaper ; columns of authentic reports prepared by thc Parliamentary staff. This sheet, it is further suggested, should be issued at a nominal price per hundred or thousand to all newspaper pro- prietors for thc purpose of cir- culating with their ordinary issues. Were this proposal adopted, the electors of all parts of the colony would bc placed in a position to judge of the opinions and capability of their repre I sentatives, and a means of education

provided which must tend to dissipate! ' thc too prevailing ignorance on political I

subjects. As now published, Hansard is useless in forming public opinion,

^ but if issued contemporaneously willi the.

daily Press, its value would be greatly increased. There would be no necessity to preserve all the speeches in permanent form of Hansard, as all matters of merely temporary interest might bc elimi- nated after circulation in tho daily form. Another suggestion is that tenders be called for publication of the Parliamentary debates in connection with one of the public journals. This plan would result in a large saving of expense, and it is said to have been already adopted with marked success in South Australia. The objection to it in this colony seems to be that the pro- prietors of the Brisbane Courier would be the only tenderers for such work, and that they would in consequence secure a practical monopoly at their own price. A third method suggested is that the Parliamentary reporting staff should be increased so as to furnish thc proprietors of the Cottrttfr with a given number of columns of " ropy " each night. Hy this arrangement the Courier would be able to dispense with its Parliamentary staff,

and be able to furnish more extended

reports than is found practicable at present. But this, too, would give the Charier a monopoly, and would bc more expensive than the existing method.

The best plan, therefore, would evidently ¡ be to employ a competent and inde-j pendent Parliamentary reporting staff, and j have Kantard issued every morning from theGovcrnmcnt.priiiting office, which lias all the appliances requisite for the work. We should think newspaper proprietors would only bc too glad to purchase such sheets by wholesale as suggested, and so give their readers the benefit of authorised and full reports. To say that the plan has never been adopted elsewhere, is no good argument against it, for elsewhere private enter- prise supplies the public with full and accurate reports of the parliamentary debates. It is not to be endured that, because thc Brisbane journal chooses to suppress the parliamentary reports, the public should bc deprived of the mass of useful information contained in them.

They contain much chaff, no doubt, but they have also too much grain in them to be thrown aside as so much rubbish.

GTJADSTOSR o ns IS ara n

PUBLISHED DA-ILV.

WEDNESDAY, MAY 13, 1874.

SOMK weeks ago we gave a resume of the New Land Sales Hill produced by Mr. STEPHENS as one of the first-fruits of tile délibérations of an avowedly Liberal Ministry. Beyond a. passing remark disapproving of some ol" ils pro- visions, however, we did not pronounce upon llie measure, preferring that thc

reader should be allowed to form his own conclusions. Tho Press elsewhere seems to have been actuated by a similar intention, but this course has not proved of assistance to thc author of the bill. The measure is, in fact, condemned on every side, and it seems to be without a single friend beyond two or three thick and-thin supporters of the Government who happen to be identified with the small farmers of East Moreton and of tlie environs of Toowoomba. So universal a condemnation of an impor- tant Government measure has seldom

been witnessed, and therefore we are j

bound to tender to its author our heartfelt i commiseration. So far as the Ministry i is concerned, however, thc fate of the bill is not of much consequence. They have not, it is declared, the remotest intention of standing by it, and conse- quently no apprehension need be enter- tained of their possible fall. Mr.

STEPHENS was ever a sturdy opponent of Mr. LAMH, the unhappy Secretary for Lands when the Act of 1868 was passed, and no one professed to feel a more patriotic contempt for thc incapacity of

that unfortunate Minister than did the

gentleman who now wears his long dis-

carded mantle. But Mr. STEPHENS finds that Mr. LAMB did one wisc thing at least during his tenn of office. He made a precedent for throw- ing a land bill upon thc table of the House, and leaving it there for hon. members to worry to their hearts' con- tent. Mr. STEPHENS therefore, although a thorough-going radical, has determined to take advantage of this useful prece- dent, and, we arc assured, will not stake his reputation, much less the existence of his government, upon a single prin- ciple contained in hts precious bill. This, on the whole, is perhaps fortunate for thc country, as one at least of Mr. STEPHENS' colleagues is somewhat tainted with squaltocratic prejudices and even disinclined to go as far in thc direction of " Liberality " as several gentlemen who occupy the Opposition benches, and who, by courtesy are termed Conservative politicians. The PREMIER, too, although a popu- larity seeker, is not by any means a land reformer of the cabbage garden stamp, and it is believed will not support the new bill further titan decorum compels him to do so. Thus the measure will have lo be abandoned to its fate, and if il ever find a place in our statute book, will be so disfigured as to be scarcely recognisable as thc offspring of the present SECRETARY FOR LANDS. It will, in fact, be a measure of which thc parentage might as consistently bc claimed by Mr. STEPHENS or Mr. RAMSAV, by Mr. GROOM or Mr.

WEINHOI.T.

In all directions ominous murmurings nie lo be heard, and as time passes on, thc sound of them in- creases in volume. The most distinct popular demand for land reform, foi example, has been in connection with thc homestead arcas. Of these thc maximum fixed by the Act of 1872 was a block of not more than 120 acres agricultural and 200 acres pastoral. Thc general demand, however, was for an extension to 640 acres agricultural, Instead of Mr. STEPHENS noting thc signs of the times in (his respect, he has perversely turned his eyes in thc othei direction, and proposes to restrict the

j homestead to 160 acres. And his bil

provided that any further selection undei the conditional clauses, must be con terminous ; but this was too flagrant s blunder, and a Ministerial amendment providing that such selections must bi within three miles of each other, wa; printed before thc dale fixed for tilt second reading. It is perfectly certain ilia' if the bill ever gets into committee stil more important amendments will bc carried. An attempt will be made, a' any rate, to fix the maximum homeslcac area at ¿40 acres, tm thc very sufficieni grounds thal with our uncertain climate our partial acquaintance willi the possi bilitics of agriculture, and our knowledgt that under existing circumstances ai least a square mile of country is ncedec to support a family in most parts of th< colony-a smaller maximum will no suffice to plant a class of prosperou; settlers upon thc soil. Then it will alsc bc sought to extend thc maximum arc: of conditional selections from 1280 acre: lo 5120 acres, or from two to eight squari miles. And lhere will bc a determiner.

> attempt to aller thal clause which ruakci

residence compulsory, on account of the discouragement it would offer to our most useful classes of settlers. Under the new bill, for instance, carriers would he unable to plant their families on the land, because their avocation would disqualify them irom holding a selection. This is a fatal objection to the simple but stringent residence clause, and it is clear that if dummying can only be prevented by such a restriction, the remedy is

worse than the disease. Mr. STEPHENS' clause will, if passed, exclude all but capitalists from forming grazing farms, and lend to leave thc country in the hands of thc great squatter and thc poverty-stricken small agricultural settler. The consequences of such legislation would be disastrous, unless as in cases of most restrictions of a like character, arrangements could be made to successfully evade them. It is simply childish to force thc cultivation of the soil by such expedients as these. At the present time grazing is the mainstay of thc settler in nearly all the districts of the colony, and the introduction of another industry-that of cultivation must take place by a gradual process. The homestead or conditional selector had heller al the outset devote his limited means to the enclosure of Iiis

land and to procuring the nucleus of a ¡ good flock of sheep or herd of cattle. ¡ His holding tims slocked, he will be free lo turn In's attention lo the growth of

maize, hay, and other fodder, and thus . not only increase his income by entering t a fresh market, but also prepare himself J to contend against those frequently i recurring dry, cold winters which ordi- narily destroy the natural grasses and cause great mortality amongst the set- tler's live stock. Thus, while gaining experience of the seasons and generally developing the resources of his estate, he

will be treading the road to affluence, i and with ordinary prudence will surely reach the goal.

Unfortunately, experience teaches that in alienating Crown lands, a maximum area must bc fixed, or, at the low price at which they are offered, all the good

lands would be at once secured by great j speculators, who would speedily grow rich at the expense of the industrial and thrifty classes. But would it not be

desirable in this matter to resort to a sliding scale, and regulate tile maximum area of selections by the time which had expired before they were thought worth taking up ? Suppose, for example, that for the first year after a district had been proclaimed open to

free selection the maximum area was fixed at 1280 acres ; for thc second year at 2560 acres ; for the third year 5120 acres ; and so 011 until the ultimate

maximum had been readied. The con-

sequence of sucli a system would be the selection of all the best lands first, and the non-alienation of inferior lands until

contiguous settlement and the extended arcas procurable had made them wortli taking up. The system of classifica- tion by Commissioners has proved a failure ; but the plan above suggested would be practically classification bi/ time, and would certainly not be open to the imputation of partiality.

The most gratifying feature of Mr. STEPHENS' bill, and the one on which there seems to be no difference of

opinion, is thc fixing of one shilling per annum as the uniform rent per acre of all conditional selections, without regard to situation or quality.

MAILS per lady Bowen, for brisbane direct, will close this evening-for registered letters at six, and for ordinary letters at eight o'clock.

IN our notice yesterday morning of pure- bred stock by tho Balclutha it was not stated, owing to a tyyographical omission, that threo of thc bulls, viz., Littlejohn, Barrister, and Adrian, were imported to thc order of Messrs. ii. and J. Living, for their Weroona Station. And wc may add, that besides stock already noticed, throe bulls and six heifers arrived by thc Balclutha, s.s., in charge of Mr. Sullivan, who purchased thurn at thc Exhibition in Sydney for lus Peak Vale Station. Ono of the bulls took a prize, another an honourable mention ; also one of thc heifers au honour- able mention.

A MKKTINC of the Licensing Hench was held yesterday, at the (Joint House, East-street, before thc Police Magistrate and Mr. V. N. Beddek, .1.1». Thc following applications were granted: - General Licenses-Janet McGregor, Union Hotel, Rockhampton ; Joseph Baldwin, Kentish Anns, Rock- hampton ; David Tierney, Tho Star Hotel, Lake's Creek ; .lames Roberts, Prince of Wales Hotel, Rockhampton ; Isabelle Hill, Railway Hotel, Rockhampton ; William Kearney, Hibernian Hotel, Rockhampton ; Maurice Harris, Commercial Hotel, Rock- hampton. Country Licenses :-Fanny Clarke, Fleetwood Hotel, Fleetwood ; William Sheehy, Railway Hoto), Dawson Bridge ; Moses Wafer, Charlyvue Hotel, Charloyvuc.

Transfers :-Mr. J. O'Brien to Maurice Fitz- gerald, Commercial Hotel, Fleetwood, adjourned for seven days, in order that thc police may make inquiries ; William Joseph Murphy, Railway Lino Hotel, from Oakey Creek to Herbert Crock-adjourned for four- teen days for inquiry.

Till: ordinary monthly meeting nf tho com- mittee of tho Port Curtis and Leichhardt Dis- trict Hospital, was held in the Court-house yesterday afternoon at four o'clock. Pre- sent : Messrs. Hunter [President), lleadrick, Russell, Macfarlane,'Smith, Beddek, Pattison, Livermore, and Dr. Macau. Thc minutes of last meeting were read anil confirmed. A lot- ter was road from thcColonial Sccrctary'solllco) stating that the Pauper Fund money woidd bc in future handed direct to thc liencvolent Society. The lutter was ordered to bo acknowledged with thanks. Accounts for thc mouth, amounting in all to £172 14s. 3d., were passed and ordered to bc paid. On thc motion of Mr. A. W. S. Smith, seconded by Mr. Macfarlane, it was resolved "That members of Committee bc requested, iu consequence of tho .crowded state of tho hospital, to refer all applicants for admittance to tho President or a member of thc Visiting Comimttcc for thc timo being, who will countersign the ticket of admission." This

closed thc businoss. Wc would call thc attention of members of committee who were absent from the meeting to this last, resolution, as it is necessary tn impose a temporary check upon thc admission of patients into thc hospital
