V"?")" " ,!,T»"»»TKD mr

OLADSTC&E OBSERVES.

PUBLISHED DAILY.

FRIDAY, JANUARY 2.1, 1874.

ONLY wait a little longer, and the wailing err that " Agriculture will not pay" will be heard no more in Northern and Central Queensland. The cultiva- tion of the soil is certainly exciting more attraction here than formerly, and in nil probability this tendency will still further develop itself in the future. It may possibly not be advisable to tread in the footsteps of tbe Southern Colonists by depending upon the cultivation of cerials, but there are specialities which may be grown lier« with profitable tesuHs. Many people are beginning to loam that the dry-belt theory is falla-

cious, and common sense combined with ' the prospect of a good future for the agriculturist is urgingHbem to secure some of tho fertile and well-watered hinds of the colony with the expectation of good returns therefrom, by the growth of crops adapted lo the country.

At this particular juncture, when " rich fields and pastures new " are being reclaimed from nature by BODIO of our colonists, a few hints and warnings with reference to agriculture may not be ill-timed. The cultivation of the soil in Queensland has not advanced beyond what may be termed the experimental stage. It is known that sugar-cane, cotton, maize, arrowroot, and possibly potatoes can be successfully grown here. Aa for cereals generally, besides many specialities which might bo enumerated, they have not as yet received the trial necessary either for their condemnation or approval. Some things that will luxuriate here may not pay, because the cost of labour runs too high to leave any margin for profit. Coffee, ten, flore plants, and many of the spices aro of this class, and until further expcriiner>* trials have boen made, it would -

wise to attempt their cul»*", "ot uo tensively. The day mny nr J'<otion *s" however, when theso t> 'l uo distant, with the specialities " ""S»» together may Form the chief' ' oefore mentioned, exports. Wher dtaples of this colony's entered the ' > agriculture has fairly land, we - practical stage in Queens succer may reasonably anticipate the pr*' j, usually attending such entor

jiei. Untold wealth lies biddon in the fertile soil of this country, and the successful farmer with tho wealthy grazier will yet represent no inconsider- able portion of Queensland's prosperity. Before this is attained, however, much of hard work, hard pay, and bardet disappointment will bo experienced ; and, indeed, it would be unreasonable to ex- pect otherwise.

Success in agriculture depends Inrgelj upon taking advantage of tho propel seasons for different crops. Even cereals generally regarded as unprofitable should prove remunerative if thc propel season of tho year be clioson for theil culture: especially when taking int« account the fact that such produci invariably commands a high price. Ii an ordinary winter here, oaten hay, oats and potatoes would yield good returns provided the soil were broken np to ¡ sufficient depth. And upon considera tion, we find it difficult to draw th lino of demarcation at all sharnl between the profitable and tho unprofil able in theso malters. Heretofore it hs been fashionable to deny the possibilit of successful farming in norther Queensland, but this, together wit the dry-belt theory, has well nig exploded.

One thing must be kept in view i dealing with thiB part of our subject

the rapid growth of all kinds of vogotation ; for thia will to a very great extent compensate for the brief duration of tho wet and growing season. If, in view of this, judicious' selections were made of early maturing varieties of groin, potatoes, and general farming produce, there would practically be no limit to the agricultural capabilities of Queensland.

But it is not to cereals or tho spe- cialities of temperate climes that Queens- land farmors will have to look for profit- able returns. Sugar «rill always holdjfiret placo, ns it is well suited to the colony, and will always cotónjapad a ready market. Colton- has not as yet onmanded much attention. Experi- ments already made in the matter of its production Imvenot boen found profitable on account of (lie expenso entailed ¡in harvesting it, but we may nevertheless venture to predict that al nodiBtantdato it will be one of the staples of Queens laud's wealth.

Maize, again, is a crop that should

receive a full share of the farmer's attention, as it is well suited to the colony, and may bo used largely as a substitute for other cereals. Two crops of Indian corn may be garnered in tho I yean if proper judgment be exercised

in Inking advantage of the season and selecting tho seed. Ita-extensive use as horeo fcod, and tho good price it in- variably commands, are sufficient induce

rain' to promote its cultivation to any . reasonable extent. Not only will there be a forge local demand for maize, but tho new country opening up for settle- ment, and tho new gold-fields to the north, will stand in need of large quantities of this valuable grain.

Arrowroot ¡B also« suitable and profit- able crop for the agriculturist of Queensland. It is easy of cultivation, yields well, and is in good demand both in tho colonies and elsewhere. The arrowroot already grown and manufac- tured in this colony compares favourably with any other country's production, and il leaves a fair margin of profit to tho grower.

Coffee hue not come much into notice

yet. There are difficulties in the way of

itB extensive cultivation which have not been surmounted hitherto, bat, as they cannot be regarded aa insuperable, we may look forward at no distant date to aeo the billy elopes of Queensland pro- duce tho coffee berry in abundance and perfection. Care, attention, and skill are necessary to raise the plant from seed nnd bring it on to strength sufficient for handling and putting out. This would properly fall into the hands of the nurseryman, as it would be much better for thc codee-planter to have the young trees ready to his hand, than run the risks attendant upon their propagation.

Tue cultivation of tea cannot be expected to receive attention here until wages fall considerably below their present rate. At the same time it would

bc well fur persons engaged in agricul- ture to make experiments witn this plant, as the heavy duty upon it should, we think, make its cultivation remunera- tive. If cheap labour could be had for gathering tho leaves, all the rest is com- paratively easy. Coolies could easily be procured, and would probably serve the purpoeo better than labour lit any stber ¡ description. - 1

Fibre plants deserve attention, as they may be grown hore in great variety, and I fibres form an article of commerce in request. The sida retina claims atten- tion as a good fibre-producing plant, indigenous to this country, and should

occupy a position in Queensland similar I to that DOW held by the phormwm tenaç

in New Zealand.

Then there are the many varieties of spices which would thrive well in our poor and stony ridges, where other crops would languish.

May we not say, then, that the agri- cultural prospects of this colony are promising ? There is an abundance of rich land in the country fitted ad- mirably for thc growth of all we have mentioned, and a great variety besides, and surely there is scope enough in theBe for agricultural enterprise.

But agriculture is carried on. at a great disadvautage unless >**ock-raising accompanies it. In ¿¿her" countries these two pursuit* m not usuaUy kept distinct, aud -iV0 ioc!ine t0 the opinion that tue - ltompt t0 do B0 m Queensland 'ms voen a prolific cause of failure, both

"o the small grazier and farmer.

And now, before quitting the Buhject, a word with reference to the con- servation of moisture. The thing to be studied is, bow to ensure a crop in an unfavourable season. Quceuslaud is not at all singular in having exceptional seasons of drought is no reason why such should be feared here any more than in other tropical countries. The first and best safeguard against drought is deep tillage, always supposing that it is accompanied with proper drainage. The next thing to help to conserve moisture is the frequent stirring of the surface amongst growing crops, as it tends to check evaporation aud promote absorption. Much may be done, however, by enterprise and ek.il!, either privately or by the assistance of tho Government, to aid this important interest by means of efficient irrigation. Tho rainy season furnishes a full supply for all our needs in this respect, provided it could bo conserved by dams and wells, and such machiuery furnished as would cheaply and effectively raise it to the required level. The advancement of agriculture is an essential element in securing the progress and prosperity of Ibo country, and the important matter of irrigation, therefore, well deserves legislativo attention.

AT tho I'olicc Court, yesterday morning, before the Police Magistrate, one teníalo inebriate was tined forty shillings, or forty eight hours in thc cells. This woman hail forfeited hail {(3) the previous day for a similar offence. Alfred Donnelly was charged with hoing drunk ami disorderly in East-street on Wednesday evening. Thc police proved the offence, and defendant was lined ton

^ shillings, or forty-eight hours' unprisonmest,

There

, PUBLISHED DAILY. |

THUIWDAY, MAROU 1ft, 1874. |

i r has transpired that a Dil! to provide i for Payment of Members will be intro- j duced as a Government measure during the forthcoming session of Parliament, i Nearly two years ago, in deference to j the wish of a majority in the Assembly, Mr. I'A'.MKK introduced A Bill to par- tially reimburse the expenses of hon. members ; but he could not deal with the Hill as a Government measure, and although it passed the ordeal of three readings in the Lower House, it was "summarily rejected by the Upper Cham- ber. Last session the attempt to pass a similar Bill was repeated, but without suc- cess, for the measure was rejected in pass- ing through committee in the legislative Assembly. The causes of rejection did not appear in the reported debates, but it is understood that the certainly of the bill being thrown out by thc Upper House, and the then moribund con- dition of the Lower, precluded all hope of its becoming law, and very properly, we think, the measure was relegated to the constituencies al the General Election. '1'he fact that the new Govern- ment have promptly nailed their colours to the mast on this question, induces the belief that lite predominant feeling of the Legislature and the country is sup- posed to be in favour of reimbursing hon. members in the amount of their actual expenses, at least, while engaged in legislative duties.

Tile question is therefore now fairly before the colony, and demands from the thinking portion of the public calm and earnest consideration. It is perhaps nol a subject of transcendent importance, and therefore was not made a test point at the late election. Still, in all tlie populous constituencies the public voice, where it was heard at all, spoke in favour of payment, and hence, we presume, the firm stand taken bj' the Ministry on the subject. There, is however, an impor- tant minority of the better educated electors who view the proposed change with grave apprehension, and who regard payment of members as the in- evitable precursor of a deteriorated Le- gislature. This opinion is entitled to respect, even by those who differ from it, and we may hope that hon. mem- bers «ill not come to a decision on the question until it has been thoroughly examined and fully debated. The very fact that it is pro- posed to devote some twelve thousand pounds a-year to such a purpose, should induce our legislators to exhibit scrupu- lous care and delicacy in recording their opinions and voles in reference to it.

. A glance at the position of the question elsewhere may assist the reader in coming to a satisfactory conclusion, ll may be hardly necessary to observe that, down lo a comparatively recent period, members of the House of Commons were paid by theirconsritueiits, and that the custom lias probably fallen into desuetude through circumstances peculiar to the mother countiy. The United Kingdom is fortunate in the possession of a numerous leisure class, drawn from almost every grade of the community. The country is small and compact, and the facilities for tra- velling are great. These circumstances are a guarantee of real representation lo the remotest constituency, and no didi cully is experienced in procuring the willing sen-ices of local men whenever desirable. lt therefore follows thal while payment t»f members may be wholly unnecessary in Kngland, il may be absolute!)' indispensable in coun- tries less fortunately situated. As a matter of fact, the representilives oflht people are paid in almost ever) Kuropean country. In the Uniut' States and in Canada a similar prac lice obtains. And although it maj be. ; signed that on the continent ó Ktirone*>ep!'ese!tU!tive- government ii scarcely out of its swaddling clothes, anc that in the United Slates it is attendei hy a deplorable amount of corruption thc Canadian Dominion may be pointée to tnth pride as among the most ad

vanced of all countries in the art of self' government. Unless it can be shown that payment ol' members impairs the efficiency of European Governments, or corrupts thc institutions of the United States, no fair argument unla.voura.blc to the practice can be drawn (rom their experience,- for by the same process the efficiency of government in Canada might bc credited to thc payment system. It is, however, reasonable to presume that, had not payment of members been found necessary, it would not have been so generally adopted, and thal the exceptional position taken by British legislators in this respect is due to some .insular peculiarity rather than to the superior excellence, as "a general rule, of honorary representation.

Dut we have examples of the working of paid representation in the Southern Hemisphere, which may be esteemed more valuable as precedents than any illustrations taken from Kurope or Ame- rica. In New Zealand the members of

both general and provincial Legislatures have been always (laid for their services, and despite the cumbersomeness of the constitution, we have yet to leant that representative Government has been a failure in that colony. The over legislation by the provincial councils is by no means due to paid representation, but ! lo the excessive powers conferred upon

these ambitious bodies. At any rate, thc payment system has been on trial in New Zealand for many years, and among the catalogue of desired political reforms honorary representation has never yet found a place, lu Victoria also, after years of debate, and the exposure of almost unparalleled parliamentary pro- fligacy, the system of payment was adopted for three years. The experi- ment, we are told, has not been success- ful, and, in the face of the forthcoming elections, the Government have inti- mated their intention not to propose the renewal of the Payment of Members Act. The leading journals of Victoria disapprove of the practice, the Aryn* because of its democratic tendencies, thc Age because of its costliness, and alleged non-success in improving the personnel of thc Legislature. At first sight it may be assumed that thc united testimony of Conservatives and Liberals, of Freetraders and Protectionists, should be conclusive. Hut not so. The experi- ment is only in its third year, and no

one seems to assert that the character of the Legislature has deteriorated under ils influence. Only a few days ago we read a congratulatory article in the Australasian upon the improved lone of political morality in Victoria of late years. There was a time, said our able contemporary, when twelve or thirteen needy members of the Legis- lative Assembly levied black mai) upon the public through the Lands Depart-

ment, These adventurers hired rooms

in Melbourne, and professedly carried on business as "commission agents, but, as a matter of fact, formed a parlia- mentary "ring," whose influence was powerful in the Assembly and omnipo-

tent at the Land Office. In those times departmental justice could only bc ob- tained by subsidising one or more mem- bers of this gang. Hut matters have changed now, and the Legislature of Victoria has been purged of its most discreditable elements. We do not argue that payment of members has done this, but in the face of the gratifying change we confess to some doubt as to the genuineness of the alleged reaction in favour of honorary representation.

But even were paid representation unnecessary in Victoria, that fact would be no sufficient argument against il here. Queensland is an infantile, sparsely populated colony, and it has been proved by thirteen years' experience that proper representation is impossible without pay- ment. With us, therefore, payment is not a question of mere expediency, for our constitution is unworkable without it. In its absence we may have représentation in name, but not in reality. If therefore we wish parlia- mentary government in Queensland to be conducted willi success, we must be prepared to pay the men whose time

and talents are devoted to the attain-

ment of that object. Al thc same time, we admit that faithful honorary represen- tation, if not unprocurable, would be attended by some advantage to the

public, lint this is a case itt which it ,

having been found impossible to adapl

circumstances to our mind, il becomes 1 our duty lo bring our mind to circwm- \

stances.

Our conclusion therefore is that thc Payment of Members Hill ought to pass, and lo have at least three years'trial in this

colony, '{'he Legislative Council has ; already recorded its disapprobation of the principle, but if, as we anticipate, j the new Hill bc passed by a large majority i in thc Assembly, it may be hoped that the Upper House will gracefully waive

ils theoretical objections, and permit an i experiment to bc made which cannot do j serious harm, and may possibly be the means of preserving the unity of Queens-

land.

tioi.il on FIRE.-Khaftdowu a ipiartcr of a j milo ! Tin's is thc latest from the Magdala j minc, in thc cheerfully named district of Plea- sant Creek. Thc enterprising shareholders iue.au finking till they strike gold -fir (ire. This faith entitles them to a rich reward. Of course they have had th« encouragement of

vcsnU*'. iu other deep mines in the district, j

Thurs arc, however, other places where indi- cations are gool!, and whore lin »haft has ever been put dow n to eut a mai» lude. Wouldn't it be .IR desirable to encourage a valuable dis- covery at depths as to reward thc finer of a new Miirface gold-field ? Ï am told that at .Stock- yard freck there ave most favourable iudica tionu of a main lode nt depth, but that the peoiilc can't afford tho cost «if sinking a deep shaft speculatively. If Oovcmmcnt would aid, hy paying lmlf thc cost of nu experi- mental shaft, thc result would probably bc the establishment of a great |ieniianent gold-field. An intelligent cm-respondent asks mc if it is lint the «Inly of a Oovcrmnciil (especially in default of immigration) to endeavour tu keep hi thc country thc able-bodied men we have Íjot 1 Yet numbers leave our shores for distant mids, whilst the gold is under our feet, and

I only waits fetching u]>.

PUBLISHED D.ULY.

SATURDAY, WML 18, 1874.

Tm-. Financial Separation Hill of Mr. I'AI.MF.K, although not yet thc law of Ibo land, is proving of much value as having furnished the basis for a record of expenditure in (lie various districts.

An Executive minnie of the late Government required lli.it the accounts should be so kepi as lo distinguish between general and local expenditure, and to allocate il lo the respective dis- tricts. In conformity with the minute referred lo, a return has just been laid before Parliament showing the "Revenue and Expenditure for the year 1873, ap- portioned in accordance with the pro- posed Financial Separation Hill of 1S72." As the information contained in this document is of great interest to the central and northern districts, we repro- duce it in another column, and take the opportunity ol nuking a few remarks which are suggested by its publication.

ll will be seen that the general revenue for the year amounted to ,£622,109, of which amount nearly ,£502,000 was produced by customs mid excise. The remaining ,£120,000 was received on account of slam]) duty, postage and commission, fees of office, pilotage, light dues, civil service super- annuation fund, electric telegraphs, and miscellaneous ; the last item amounting to the rather large sum of ,£20,000. The total expenditure under the head General was £488,000, exclusive of interest on loans incurred for general purposes, and amounting to £62,378. It would be interesting lo leam what the items of this huge proportion of the loan expenditure really are, for the probability is thal some of them al least ought to be debited to loan account. The single item of immigration, however, must amount to a considerable sum, and perhaps, aller all, the amount charged to general revenue is not excessive. The total local revenue is given al .£502,000, yielded by fluid, Land, Licenses, kent, exclu- sive of I.md, and Railways. 'Che total local expenditure was .£404,1179, of which ,£185.71;'/ was .111 account of interest upon Lo ins. ( ti iii is last amount no le->s lb.in ,£155,000 is charged lo the Southern Division, while the Wide liny .ind ihimcil is < barged with .£302}, th'.- fenlr.il with

and the Northern with ,£27^5. f »11 thc whole, the return '.!i'i .. . a lota! surplus revenue of ,£i'i

When the Hon. lin- Mivivi 1 1:

WOKKS was in Um ^bampton lalcly. ne stated that the expeiidiluie in the Central District last year had been dispro- portionately large. lt «-ill therefore l>c interesting to ascertain the facts from the return before us. The Southern Division yielded a lota! of ,£334,000, or about 30 per cent., or less dian one-third of the total revenue of the colony; while the expenditure for the same district was ,£203,240, also about 30 per cent, or 1 under one-third Ihe lotal expenditure of

liie colony. The Wide Bay and Kurnell Division contributed £45,000, just 4 per cent, or one twenty-fifth of the total revenue. The expenditure for the same district was ß 18,000, less than 2 per «nt of the total expenditure, and less than one-half of its ow« revenue. The Central District yielded £75,000, just 67Í per cent, or one-fifteenth part of the total revenue. The expenditure for the same district was £55,000, less than 6 per cent, or one seventeenth part of the total expenditure. The Northern district contributed ¿£50,000, about 4j¿ per cent, or a twenty-second part of the total revenue. The expenditure for the same district was ,¡£38,000, about 4 per cent, or one twenty-fourth part of the total expenditure.

These figures show that the Southern Division obtained far more than its pro- portionate share of expenditure last year, while the Wide Hay and Burnett Divi-

sion obtained far less. The Central Division received a smaller proportion than the .Southern, and smaller even than tlie Northern, although the greater proportionate contribution to the general revenue by the last-named division, owing to the preponderance of adult m iles, must not be forgotten. The con- sumption of dutiable goods per head of the population is very much grenier in the north than in the south ; and as Customs and Kxcise revenue approaches nearly to one-half the total, il is clear

(hat the North must be in fairness cre-

dited with a larger contribution than is

shown under the head of local revenue.

h would be found (on examination) that the expenditure under the head of General Government and Loans is al a much larger rate per head in the South than in the North, which further throws the balance of expenditure in favour of the metropolitan districts. No doubt the excess arises chiefly from the payments on account of Southern Railway loans which, will) the working expenses, swallow up _>£S.),ooo annually in interest, over andabove the total receipts. The Northern Railway shows still less favourably, as absorbing .£25,000 annually more titan the revenue it yields, it amounis, in fact, to nearly one-half of the total expenditure in thc Central Division on local account, and yet the surplus balance is proportionately larger in that division than in any of the others except Wide Hay. So much for the allegation of the

Miyisn.it rou WORKS that ihe Central

districts have been pampered by over expenditure. Omitting consideration of railways and loans, (he Central Division would show a surplus of receipts amount- ing lo over ,¿30,000, while the surplus from Wide Hay with a similar omission would be only .£29.000.

In their Intimates the Government have treated the Central Division very scantily on the additional pretext that where a large expenditure is taking place

un loan account there should be a cur-

tailment of outlay on account of ordinary revenue. It may be admitted that there is some force in this argument if applied impartially. Hut, as a matter of fact, it has never been applied in the Southern Division of the colony, and therefore the public may well object to its application

in the Central and Northern districts. On the whole, the return under notice shows that lhere has been continued

over-expenditure in the Southern Division and persistent denial of justice lo the Wide Hay and llumell. Hut il does nol show that there has been excessive outlay in the Central District, or justify the shabby treatment it receives in the

Ministerial Intimates.

PUBLISHED DAILY.,

SATURDAY, JANUARY 31, 1874.

Tm: concert advertised to bo held at the School of Arts last »light, for thc benefit ot thc boat's crow ot thc James Paterson, was postponed in conscnnciicc of tho severity of

the weather.

AT the Police Court yesterday morning before tho Police Magistrate, Enr'y Wright charged Margaret Tighe with assaulting ha- in Arckcv-strcet, on tho 2Ctli iustaut, ami prayed for sureties of tho peace. Mr. Milford for the complainant. Mr. Bogers (Ufr. Mol bourne's clerk, with thc permission of thc Bench) appeared for tho accusal, aud pleaded guilty. Thc l'ulicu Ma¡,'.8trate would prefer I having evidence, which disclosed that thc

defendant had. assaulted the complainant as

¡ alleged, and had called her very bad names,

nuil lia'l als« threatened to kill her. Ordered j to lind sureties iii tho sum of £5 to koop thc

peace for two months.

ALTHOUGH Hie thermometer has not shown a remarkably High rango during tho past few days, tho heat, owing to the humidity of thc atmosphère, has boen extremely oppressive, nml lalmnr of any kind lias libon attended with great ditliculty, Last evening a thunder «binn bullee over thc tow« shortly before fiii o'clock, ruitl gave temporary rd'ef (rom tin heat. The Htorm roso "i thc south-west, th« centra of it appearing to pass within a feu miles of I leckhampton, first travcllinj westerly, awl afterwards in a north easterly course. Thc rain was varj heavy a I»U ot two and a bal inches having been registered by thc rail guage nt tho Telegraph Office during thc hon the storm lasted. Tho weather is «till close anil more rain, i's probably at hand. Thc Fitz roy is considerably Rwollcn, covering th wharves .at high water. Tho current is vcr rapid, and smne difficulty ia experienced ii working the jerries. Thc punt is laid up alte gctber for the time being. Yesterday morniii, thc punt chain broke, one of thc links, wilie] luv I a previous /law in it, having given way Should tho freshet abate somewhat, it wi] again bo practicable to work the pun for a short time daily during tin slack water cangai by thc full tides. Th force nf the wind hist week for n tim completely suspended both telegraphic mu portal communication, and even now th northern linc is only open to* 8t. Lawrence, s that all thc colony northward of that point awl westward, to thc Peak Downs, am Springsure districts is cut off by tho destine tion of miles of telegraph wire. Immediate! north of St. Lawrence the Une is niue injured, thc country there presenting quite desolate aspect from the fury of the cyclo« which passed over it, amt it. is not cKpeeto that the line will be repaired for some tirnt News, however, caine by jiost on Wedneeda evening, froi* thc Mackenzie and Pea Downs districts, showing that thc storm wa ns violent (hero as at Koekiaampton, and t particular localities from which advices hav been received, as, for instance, Oakey Cree and Tulagi Stations, tho «lainage to houses un fences wa» great indeed. On one mn sue was thc destruction of trees, that scarcely on is left standing within sight of the head st« tin;i, although there vero many before th cyclone devastated thc country. By way < Copperfield we learn that the storm roache Springsure, destroying th« Telegraph OHice ,1 that township. Kew* came from .motin Stanage Bay, evidencing that thc centre i tho cyclone passed over those loealitie Particulars oí the tlestroutinn caused there a furnished tu another part of our colima; At Mackay, pidgin;; from Captain Hirst's ¡' port, there appears to have been jiuthii-g r uiarkable beyond a Unod in the river. K intelligence has come in fi-om the country wc. of Springsure. Wc hear that thc ÎUreoo ai even thc lVak Downs were wanting rain n longer than a fortnight hack. Tlievo was abu (lance of gnus, but thc watcr-holvn M ere go ting low. The Peak Downs hat« no- lung »ny complaint «ni that score, mid it isprobali that there has been abundant iniii iii- thc f wost. Thc Southern telegraph wires we working very badly last lúglit, which pt vented the receipt of our usual, messages.

Kr.iTK of thc hospital for tim week cmlii January 30 : - Admitted, daring thc wed 7 males and 2 females :, discharged, "> mal and I female -, remain'jig in Hospital, 35 ma! and 5 females; feral, 33} Il patient» «pedal ward.

OHK of the unfortunate inmates of the Lunatio Reception House, a Polynesian named Ben. Ratumah, managed to make bia escapo a few days since, hut was captured yesterday. morning.hy mounted constable Welsli, about eight milos from town on the road to Laurel Bank. Tho poor fellow peiïistod in declaring that he ivas not sick, and that there was no necessity at all to. loclchim up. All he wanted waa to go away and work. Ho was again lodged in tho institution', where every caro

will no doubt be taken of him.

HUMOUR lias it that thc new Ministry have decided on appointing two additional Judges of thc Supremo Court. Mr. Lilley is to bc elevated to the Bench, and to reside at Bris- bane ; Judge Sheppard of tho Southern District Court, is to bc thc fourth Judge of thc Higher Court, and to reside at Rockhampton ; and Mr. Paul is to bo mada District Court Jndgc of the for North. We give the story as an on Hil. Nothing has publicly transpired os to tho appointment of a Crown Prosecutor in thc room of Mr. J. K. Handy iloceasod, but it is whispered lhat thc choice will not in this instance bc .«stricted to gentlemen of tho long robe. An Attorney, distinguished for his fidelity to thc Macalister party, and of moro than, five years standing in Rockhampton, is spoken of as thc coming man.

COMF1..! iNTs of postal irregularities have alarmingly increased in number dining thc past six months. We have had frequent occasions of late to call attention to thc non- delivery of the Bulletin with proper regularity, on tho now portion of thc railway line espe- cially ; but from information to hand, there Wiis undoubtedly something or somebody greatly at fault on thc lino between Copper- field and Springsure. Cue gentleman on that road writes that ont of twenty numbers of thc Australasia^ only five reached their destination, and n similar ir- regularity characterised thc conveyance of tho newspapers, and even letters were not much better cared for, several important ones having miscarried. It is clear that thc whole district wants thorough inspection and investi- gation, so as to place its postal arrangements in a satisfactory degree of efficiency. Wc aro not censuring our new Postmaster, Mr. Fetor son, os he is not accountable for all thc mis- management at thc inland post offices, and lias not been long enough at Rockhampton to bc responsible for all tho existing faulty arrange- ments in connection with his own office ¡ but we feel assured that he »;H usc his best endeavours to establish regularity and cer- tainly in postal conveyance. We suspect tliat tho fault lies very much in thc acceptance of low tenders for mail contracts from incom- petent men.

A MKKTINIJ of thc Rockhampton Chamber of Commerce was held yesterday afternoon in the Municipal Council Chambers for thc purpose of electing a committee of management for,thc enauingyoar. Present : Messrs. E. P. Liver- more (in tho chair), A. W. S. Smith, T. S. Holl, W. Pattison, H. L. Dibdin, W. C. Caporn, J. Macfarlane, A. 1. Bell, W. Thom- son, II. Schmidt, W. K. D'Arcy, \V. (f. Jackson (.Secretary), »nd several others.

After a few remarks from the Chairman, Messrs. W. fi. Caporn and W. I,. Dihdia were admitted taoiubers of thc chamber. The chairman then said that tho meeting had been called for tho purpose of electing a Committee of Management, nud hail huon called ofi requisition in accordance with

the rules. It would bo now tor tho members present to choose a committee of niue mem- bers to manage tlt^i affairs of tho Institution. A ballot .then took place resulting in thc election of Messrs. E. P. Livermore, R.M. Hunter, C. h. Shaw, W. Pattison, J. Mac- farlane, lt. L. TMbdin, A. W. S. Smith, T. S. Hall, and W. Thomson. H was nest decided that the newly elected committee shall hold their ("list mooting on Thursday next at tho same time and place, and thc proceedings terminated.

A LKTTBH was received in town yesterday morning hy Messrs. Pu M. Hunter and Co., per special messenger, from Stannagc Bay, stating that »the well-kuowu cutter, Florence, the property of tho firm, had been totally wrecked and " smashed up" at No. 8 Island, Northumberland Croup, during thc late storm. Tho letter further stated that thc wind swept over the islands and across thc peninsula, which suffered serious damage, but the full strength of tho galo was experienced at thc north end of Stannagc Bay. lt commenced at nine o'clock on tho morning of thc 22nd and blew with groat violence from the south-east for a few hoars; the barometer falling considerably. At the end of that time the wind abated-in fact nearly ceased, for about twenty minutos ; and just as it was thought the galo had spent itself altogether, tho barometer remaining ! stationary, it shifted suddenly to thc N.W.,

and blew with terrific violence, accompanied by Winding rain, levelling buildings aud fences, tearing up trees by the roots, and sweeping everything before it. Huge branches of trees were rent oil, and smashed and torc and ground against each other like furious monsters bent upon mutual destruction, under thc maddening inllitcncc of desperate malice. At the head station (Torilla) tho buildings were all levelled with thc ground at tho first blast, «iud thc materials of which they were com- posed were whirled away in a ni'jmoiit. Fur- niture, clothing, books, and properly of every description wore blown in all directions in one general confusion, some of it for miles, in fact Bcvcral things were afterwards found fully a mile «.way from where tho houses had stood. The people were all lying on the ground in throe and four inches of water, not daring to stand up and face the storm, and while in this position were every moment in danger of being maimed or struck doad by thc falling timber and debris of tho houses. Fortunately no lives ?were lost although there were several narrow .escapes. The station appears like a ruin, and three thousand pounds would not cover thc .damage done to the head station alone. It is really wonderful, considering the fury of thu wind and rain the falling houses and large In-Michcsof trees hurtling through the air in :such uuinbcrs and with such terrific force, that thc people escaped with their lives. The houses and property on the islands are nil ?entirely destroyed, and the Florence, as wc 'have already said, ' was swept away hy the gale and completely smithed up.

'The master and rrcw nf tho r.utti'i- cum over

in the lifeboat from Xn. 8 Island to the Hay, but went back again to take tho other people uway, and go on to Broadsound, with tho hope joining station of wcvercly, tho bouse and buildings at the head s tatum having liccu^blown down, anil the coun t ry in seriously ¡ni)icdcd by the fallen timber ITo may add that Messrs. Hunter ¡iud Cu., arc also heavy losers by the storm, for in addition t o tl ie loss of the futter, a windier of building*, and si large quantity of stores, with the punt und boats on No. 8 Island, have been destroyed.

WE have ticen requested by Alderman Leigh, to state that tho Inspector of Nuisances called on him a few days ago, and desired to be informed whore the five loads of manure luvd boon deposited which had been spoken-ot in thc Council as a public nuisance. / Merman Leigh explained the exact locality (Archer street), and said it was still lying there un- touched, and not only so, but that tho heap Iud been increased with a quantity of broken bottles, kerosino tins, and other matters, which rendered it a still further offonco to public decency.

KIM.IOT most WRESTI-ISII.-About half past 2 o'clock, mi Saturday morning lost, John Tibo, a Chinese, tho keeper of a restaurant at 161, .Sussex-street, met with injuries at his residence which eventuated in his death. It seems that at the hour named a lodger named Ferry commenced wrestling with Tilro, in fun, it is said-giving thc Chinaman a heavy fall backwards, which resulted in his death, about 7 o'clock on Saturday evening last. Ho was attended before death by Dr. Lunhnrb. l'erry was arrested about II o'clock on Saturday night, by sergeant Larkins and senior-constable Mulquccney, when abont to depart for New- castle per steamer. He is now in thc lockup, on suspicion of having caused Tihn's death,

Deceased has left a wife and child.-S. M. Herald.

X CiiEU' KII.TP.II.-The Sj/incj/ fiait states that Mr. Lavers has lately drought under tho notice of thc phillie a ehoap and simple method of Altering water, which may bc useful to travellers and other residents in the bush who aro forced to slake their thirst at muddy ponds. This is nothing less than to take some cotton or woollen threads, andleitingoneend into tho water cause th? other to pass nv jr thc edge of the receptacle, tho water will pass up the capil- lary tubes and discharge after the manner of a syphon into thc receiving vessels, and passing through the minute tubes, thc suspended matter in tin: water is removed. Thc idea is not new though it may have been rediscovered. Wo understand that in Calton'* " Art of

Travel" it is roconi-ncndral to travellers to. dip their stock'ngs into thc water when it is dirty and let it Titer «long tho Vne ot tho threads, lt is a very simple nad inexpensive arrangement, ami thc knowledge of contriv- ances of this kind cannot be too widely spread.

ExPLOliATios or Ai-.sniAUA.-llefcrring to tho endeavours of Mr. Gosse to penetrate from South Australia into Western Australia by a hitherto unexplored rout», thc Melbourne ,4ro/ws makes the following judicious remarks on Australian exploration ns ft whole:-"No doubt our enterprising neighbours will soon luve another expedition on foot, and will never rest until they have accomplished their purpose. Tlio perseverance they exhibited in supporting poor Stuart's offorts, until at last they were crowned with success, give us a good assurance that neither di'h'cultics nor temporary defeat will dishearten them, nor turn them from their pnrposc. Hut we do not think that thc exploration of that portion of Austivdia which remains unknown should be conducted hi a haphazard fashion; nor dowe think it fair that one colony should be left to bear thc whole expense. Tho only part of this continent which at present remains entirely a tfrra iarogmla is situated between thc transcontinental telegraph lino and thc settled districts of Western Australia. Thc latter colony cannot afford to do much in tho way of exploring, as its means are small ; and altliiniçli South Australia seems reidy enough to undertake the ditty, we 'should not work a willing horse to death.' -There can be no doubt that if those provinces were united in a federal bond tho cost of examining tho territory contained within thc union would be a charge on the general exchequer, and although, unhappily, we have not yet boen able sn to adjust our potty diffei-ciiccs as to admit of our forming ono vast dominion, there is nothing to prevent out undertaking this national un ty mintly. A small amount contributed by each eoloiiiy yearly-an amount which wonld never

bo missed-would soon alter the face of thc Australian map, and fill up with natural fea- tures what is now ono vast blank. If anyone asks for n reason why wc should spend money in examining a country which there is every reason to believe consists for thc most part ot arid wastes, there are plenty of answers ready. In thc first'place, we hare no certainty that thc land is valueless. Vast traces of country which now form thc grazing grounds of thousands upon thousands of cattle and sheep, wore at one time thought to be as sterile as thc desert of Sahara. .Secondly, it is s reflec-

tion nu our enterprise to sit down contented

while au interesting problem awaits solution. Furthermore, wo arc bound to lill up those blanks upon thc map of Australia as our con- tribution to geographical science. Our countrymen have always boen foremost in thc work of exploration, now seeking an entrance through the eternal barriers nf icc which sur- round tho poles, and now struggling after knowledge through tropical heat aitd pestilence. Shall we, then, refuse to under- take a work which lies at our very door ?"

CnUISTV.VN 1 £Riuits.K. -F mn thcS. 31. Herald

of tho 10th instant, we extract tho following : -" In ait account written by tho Kev. A. W. Murray (the pioneer missionary of the London Missionary .Society) of his visit during last year to Torres Straits aud New (¡uinca--pub- lished, in tho Herald of November 20 last mention was made of au act of Christian heroism performed by a native ot Miaré, in the Lifu Islands, or jjoyalty Croup. On August 18 last a large fishing boat left Somerset, in thc north of this continent, for some place in tho Straits. In this boat was Mr. Charles Jardine, accompanied by another white man, an aboriginal native, and 'Milly'-alad from Mani, whose native name is Wacania. Thc boat was unfortunately capsized at sonic distance out at ssa, and four men were for a long time tossed about, clinging on to tho heat without cither water or provisions. At length, when off Woody Island, 'Billy,' or Wacania (who is a Christian), bravely swam between three and four miles away to thc land, against a'.li knot tide, and was enabled to make thc beach-thcrehy saving not only his own iifo, but tho lives of his three companions. Besides a liberal pecuniary reward presented to bimby thc Messrs. .lani i nc, a handsome medal has been presented by a gentleman iu this city to Wacania, in recognition of bis heroic conduct. .This medal is of silver burnished, from thc atelier of Mr. Mac Donnell, of (îeorge-stroet. On the obverse are those words --' A token of admiration for tho noble and Christian couduct of Wacania, of Marc, for swimming miles of ocean and obtaining help, which rescued Mr. Charles Jardine .md others from Woody Island, 18th August, 1873.' this inscription :-' To Wacania, a native of Marc-, from Mr. Hcnjamiii Cocks, nf Sydney, .launiiry, SST*.' "

WITT os AI .SIK.ILIA* WINES.-A meeting of gentlemen interested in tho Australian wine trade was held at tho Australian

Moat Agency's Oilice, on November 21, Mr.

Tallcrinnn in thc chair. There were als«

present Mr. Olarson, of Molbournc ; "M r. D. liamUU, ot South Australia : Mr. MctliLy, of the firm of Apps, Smith, and Co. ; Mr. Devlin, of New South Wales: Mr. Barton, of the Auldana Vineyard ; Mr. J. P. Bear, of Tabilk ; Mr. E. C. Booth, Mr. J. R. Stebbing, and others. Mr. Tallerman explained that the fact of many of the Australian wines exceeding 25 per cent of alcoholic strength, such were now excluded to a great extent in consequence of their being subject to the half crown duty. Messrs. F.-mtm, Vrindall, llcar, and others spoke to the strength of thc ii.-i.tur.il wines of Australia exceeding those of thc continent, and after sonic conversation, it was determined that, after thc rcûdinç nf Mr. l'allon's paper-referred to in our Ia-;t issue - it ho read before thc Society »T Arl.«, to biku steps t i urge upon thc tîovenimcnt the de sirahitity of placing thc wines of Australia on

c same footing with regard to duties as

of thc continent.

PUBLISHED DA.ÏLY. mí' {MONDAY, APRIL 20, 1874.

AT tlio Police Court on Saturday morning, before Mr. V. N. Bedilck, J.P., ono male drunkard waa admonished ami discharged. This was thc only business.

TIMI following lotter showing the state of the marketa in Cooktown will bo read with interest. H was received per Florence Irving by it well-known merchant in town, ami has boon kindly handed to us for publication : Dear Sir,-1 beg to advise you ns follows as to thc state of thc market hero for most descriptions of goods and stock. During thc lost three weeks mnj<y vessels have arrived and prices have fallen considerably. Bulk ale i« overdone, bat small lots of tho best brands still leave a fair margin. Bottled ale anil porter, quarts scarce, but pints unsaleable. Brandy* Rcmicssy's fiSs., scarce, good demaud for spirits just now ns thc consumption is large. Galvanized iron, retails £50. General ironmongery does not afford much profit, some parcels being aold very little over cost price. Flour sold to-day £20 10s. the lowest price for two months, and 1 can confidently say it will uot go lower for snmo time as there is very little in Btock. Best Hobart Town jams Os. to 10s., and Victorian janis ouly saleable when others arc scarce Dried apples 10d. to lld. scarce. Good bacon ls. Sil. tn ls. Cd., plentiful. Potatoes?15. OoriiSs.tol0ä.,butwill go up. Cheese lld. Timber and Hobart Town palings coiniug iu too fast aud faUiug rapidly. Cattle nominally £20 per head, but there are sovcral vessels laid on from Brisbane and Townsville, and some stock coming overland prices are sure to fall. Sheep have fallen to 22s. ful. for good, and will fall lower if they come in at the sanio i-utc as latterly. Horses are nuw below a paying price, having fallon £15 per head this last three weeks. In ship- ping hore you will have to notice tho ship- ments from other ports to n great extent, as I anticipate most things being overdone, but

the priées ijuohal must bc taken at thc lowest, : and at thc time of a great rush of vessels.

Flour, for instance, will go up directly the ' steamer leaves. Sheep also will go up, ns the prices ruling will deter many from shipping, and they will probably lie scarce again in two Weeks. I am, sir, yours faithfully, F. .1. \V.

BEAKUMOKE, Cooktown, April 8, 1874. I

PUBLISHED DAILY. WEDNESDAY, JANUARY 28, 1874.

TUE telegraph, wires .on. tho New South !

Wales siilc wore down throughout thc day I yesterday, but communication was restored

last night.

AT the Police Court yesterday morning, before thu l'olieo Magistrate, one drunkard was admonished and discharged, and another for a second offence was lined fire shillings or suffer twenty-four hours imprisonment. Thc Inspector of Nuisances charged J. T. Jones, of liockhauipton, witb a breach of tho Muni- cipal Bye-laws by unlawfully using, on thc 5th January lost, a fire-place iu his house on Wcinholt-atroet, the said fire-place "not being properly constructed with a ilue or chimney, and the walls or sides of stone or blick or any admixture thereof." Mr. W. J. Brown appeared for thc Corporation. The defendant who, pleaded guilty, boped tho Bench would be lenient with bim ; be had a large family to sup}>ort, and at thc tune that the fu'o-plaec was used was quite ignorant of the existence of the bye-law under which thc information had been laid. Mr. Brown said that bc did not prcsss for a heavy penally, and under the circumstances would waive his claim to professional costs. The Bench ordered thc defendant to pay a fine of Ss. (id., cud in default -of sulficient levy and distress, seven days' imprisonment. Fourteen days were allowed thc defendant to pay the money. Another information against Mrs. O'Donnell, for a similar offence, was then ealleil on. Thc defendant did not appear, and tho case was ^ultimately withdrawn.

articleText:
WITH WHICH IS INCOarOllTKD TIIK

CHADSTONE OBSERVER. PUBLISHED DAILY.

TUESDAY, MARCH 24, 1874.

Tm; Marjflorotigh Chvuiclehas a leading '

anide on tho bridge question, in which much laudable anxiety is expressed to throw over Rockhampton with lite " log- rolling scheme" tonnangefbrtheconstriic tion of bridges across the several tidal riversoflhceolony. Wecannotsufficiently admire tho diplomacy of our contem- porary, and of those extremely scrupulous people of whom he is the mouthpiece. The so-called " log-rolling " scheme, which among others was intended to provide bridges for thc' Alary and Fitzroy Rivers, was substantially that the money lie obtained by the Government on loan,

and that the districts and not thc immki

paliltcs be held ultimately responsible (or the debi, tolls being in the meantime imposed for Ute protection of the public revenue. The Maryborough people, or that section of them whom the Ohrtmiclc represents, believe now that by bringing pressure to bear upon I the Government they can gel .1 free

bridge, and that the Minister for Works is unwilling to respect the offer of the PKKMIUK to provide a portion of the cost of thc Fitzroy Illidge out of the surplus of the current year, lt is assumed at once that the general scheme will not bc adopted, and that the most profitable course for Maryborough to pursue is to stand alone, on the principle of " Every one for himself and Go» for ns .7!!." Of course no one will feel much surprised al this proceeding, while most people would have been considerably astonished had Maryborough betrayed acquaintance j with thc axiom that " Union is strength."

From its very foundation that town has laboured under the disadvantage of being divided against itsejC Any object intended for the cotÄon benefit can never be started with a reasonable hope of attainment by concerted action. The Municipal Council has been a scandal I ever since its establishment, the useful-

ness of the School of Arts has been

crippled by incompatibility amongst its Committee, and the Chamber of Com- merce within one short year of ils birth has degenerated lo such an extent that an attendance of three appears to be the average al its meetings. Thc attempts at establishing copper mining companies have proveí 1 eanally unfortunate, their promoters having so far fallen foul of each other ns not only lo publish their shame in the public prints, but also to disseminate libellous circulars-which we presume the newspapers had pre- viously declined-throughout the colony by means of the Post Oftice. Had thc people of Maryborough, therefore, agreed to unite with Rockhampton in resisting the "southern greed" of which the Chronicle has always so bitterly com- plained, thc general ¡niblic of the colony

might well have wondered hy ,what pro- cess the Ethiopian had been induced to change his skin. ¡

In the second paragraph of his article, our contemporary makes statements which, coming from any other source, might elicit from the reader a pungent expletive. But people who read the Chronicle are so accustomed lo find in its most earnest deliverances a supercili- ous sneer, that they will notice the re- marks in question without much irritation. The writer infers that the receipts from the Rockhampton ferries are "about on a par" with those received at Maryborough, and that the Rockhampton deputation were mistaken in rating them at .£1500. Now, the records prove that the revenue at tile Maryborough ferries is liol on a par willi thal received from those nf Rock- hampton ; and the deputation did not rate their receipts at ¿£1500. They produced documentary evidence, the correctness of which was certified lo by the TOWN CLKKK, that the receipts for thc year 1S73 exceeded .£1107, and on that evidence they not unjustifiably rated their receipts at ^1200. Our contem- porary, however, when floored hy facts, goes on ti} prove thal they cannot exist. The trade between Rockhampton and the scanty population on the north side, he declares, cannot produce anything like thal sum. Such a method of debating a question is unanswerable. If the facts are against ns, practically says tile Chronicle,

so much the worse for the facts.

Our contemporary is positively amusing

when he teiis us thru the traffic from Rock-

hampton "trends naturally south-eastward "-towards Gladstone," and that "a " jv'eat ninny years niusl elapse before " these natural tendencies undergo any " material alteration." In matters of this kind experienced people have less faith than our contemporary in natural tendencies, or we should have seen the northern railway started from Gladstone, and Rockhampton transplanted to the semi-marine township of Herbert-the paper city at Broadmount. Another edifying remark is that the .Mary bridge would be a " link in the high-road between Mai /borough and the Capital " -in which direction we suppose the traffic from Maryborough " south-east- ward, naturally trends," but lias been diverted through lack of a bridge. This circumstance, coupled with the fact that " our river could be bridged at half the " cost lhat the l'ilzroy could be," make it " at once apparent how unjust, nay " impertinent, it would be to lump " the two enterprises together in one " log-rolling enterprise." This iast

is . a conclusion with which few will be

disposed to ijiiarrel, if by log-rolling our contemporary implies conaption in any shape. But if he means that thc two towns should not cordially help each other to secure legitimate mutual advantages, thc doctrine laid down will be stigmatized as petty and selfish.

Of tile " double-banking scheme be- tween the Iwo towns," referred to by our contemporary in his closing para- graph, we confess entire ignorance. The only scheine we have heard of was one lo provide for bridging all the tidal rivers of the colony, on a principle fair to the inhabitants of every portion of it. But if Maryborough refuse participation in su ch a sch em e, an d ch oose to isolate her- self, the worst we wish is tliat she will suc- ceed. The bridge across the Mary is un- questionably a district want, and whatever small-minded selfishness may be dis- played by thc, people more immediately concerned, their claim lo the work will remain unaffected. It may be hoped

thal both northern and .southern mem-

bers will vole for the Mary River bridge, even if any general bridge scheme be found for the present impracticable. Hut if the condition be imposed that the money shall be g anted only in the form of a district loan, to be saddled upon the Wide Bay district in the event of future sub-division for local govern- ment purposes, our Maryborough friends

must not consider themselves ill-used.

Mails per Lidy Unwell, s., for (Hailstone, Maryborough, and Brisbane, will close this morning at 11 o'clock.

AirnnwNi: to aunoiiiieeinciit the L1y.1l troupe maile a considerable change in their evening's entertainment last night before one of thc largest auilieiiecs that ever sat within the walls of tho Theatre lloyal. As nsnal, the hall was opened hy Mr. Lloyd in one of his eoinic songs, followed hy Miss Shapler anil Mr. M'Lenn in a Polish dance. The ell'orts of these members of tho company were frequently encored and loin'ty applauded throughout the evening, lint the interest of the spectators was evidently centred in tho performances of the " ctherial sisters" and Mr. Loyal, and their appearance was looked for with thc most lively interest. Their lirst exhi- bition of thc gymnastic art was an elegant and chaste display of skill «11 tho *' Flying Rings." In this exercise Mr. J/iyal's wonder- ful evolutions eclipsed anything of the kind we have ever witnessed cither in Kugland or elsewhere, while the feat of holding Miss Zuila suspended hy a leathern belt in his teeth, although daring in itself, is more an evidence of strength of jaw than sfciil. How- ever it was well received, and served as an adjunct to the more graceful part of the per- formance. Mr. boyal's balancing himsc'f on one foot on a trapeze while he played a solo on the diam, was a wonderful exhibition of cipii lihrmm, and furioshes another evidence of what may he accomplished by patience- and perseverance, lint the erovcirjig feat of the evening was thc "leap for life 011 thc ladder in the air" by Miss Zuila and Mr. Loyal liefere describing this really extraordinary performance wc may remind our readers tint everything is gone through with ease and tinish, which removes that natuval fear of an accident which invariably necinipanies the mind tif the sjiectat.nr al such exhibitions. Thc ladder, which is about ten feet long, is suspended horizontally near thc coiling of thc theatre, and whilo Mr. l/vyal is hanging by his legs, head downwards, at one cud of it, Zuils, from thc other, takes a leap, turns a complete somersault in the air, and is caught while falling hy thc male performer, and before thc audience can recover breath they have deftly regained their seats 011 thc ladder. The effect is indescribable, and all unpleasant feeling is lost in admiration at the skill of tho artists. A comic ballet, concluding with thc maypole dance, finished the evening's amuse-

ment about 13 o'clock.

GLADSTONE OBSJSJtVSR.

PUBLISHED DA-ÏLiY. SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 2S, 1874.

THF. new Government of Queensland, true to the traditions of its party, and pursuant to the desire of the colonists generally, have instructed Mr. DAINTRIÎI: to increase the stream of immigration to our shores. During the last year, our AKF.NT-GF.NKUM, succeeded tn dispatch- ing some seven thousand persons, and these, instead of causing a glut in the I labour market, appear lo have stimulated

the demand by opening new avenues for employment. Mr. DAIKTKKK telegraphs that for the next twelve months ito will be able to dispatch one thousand immigrants per month. This will be a numerical increase of about seventy-five per cent upn last year's arrivals, and if concurrently with increase in number there be also a corresponding improve- ment in quality, thc very best results may be anticipated. The greatest impediment lo the progress of the colony is want of population, and it is therefore true policy in our Legislature to supply that want by liberal votes for immigration pur- poses. The cost of the new arrivals last year was about fourteen pounds per head, yet despite the provision made for immigration al that rate, and the pay- ment of interest on ottr large public debt, a considerable surplus of revenue still remained. Another surplus ts expected at the close of the current year, and the Government have very properly resolved lo appropriate a portion of it to increasing the volume of immigration.

Taking a retrospect of our immigra- tion arrangements for the year i S73, two striking features present themselves. In the first place, the immigrants have been belter distributed amongst the various ports than during any previous year-a change which has given much satisfac- tion in the north. In the second place, there has been, both on the passage out and after landing here, a serious development of that fatal disease known as ship fever. On the whole number of the new arrivals, perhaps, the percentage of mortality from this cause lias been small, but in certain vessels it has been undoubted)' large. This under any circumstances would lie a matter for regret, but it becomes especially so in the knowledge that thc ravages of ship fever may be greatly mitigated-in fact, may be fairly classed amongst prevon tibie evils. With the exercise of

intelligent precaution, the disease may almost be warded oft altogether, and if our immigration authorities fail in this respect, they will incur a grave respon- sibility. And not them alone. Thc people of llie whole colony, as the fountain of power, have an ultimate liability which they cannot get rid of; and if the Government fail to recognise the gravity of the evil, public opinion

should make itself heard in a manner which admits of no misunderstanding. When from a single shipload of people fifteen or twenty persons in the prime of their strength arc sometimes cut off by fever, it is surely time that energetic steps were taken by the authorities to

abate the virulence of the disorder.

We ave glad to see that this matter has at length been reported upon by Dr. SALMOND, the Sub-immigration Agent and Health Officer at Rockhampton. That gentleman has officially recom- mended that all immigrant vessels be quarantined for a period of seven days .after arrival, thal the people be landed al the quarantine station, and that Ihc

lime be occupied in cleansing their clothes and persons. Dr. SAI.MONII believes that the daily ablutions, the use of fresh provisions, and thc pureness of the atmosphere, would have a most favourable effect upon the health of the immigrants, and nip the germs of fever which might be dormant in thc constitu- tion. At worst, time would be allowed for latent sickness to develope itself, and we should have less of fatal cases of ship fever among immigrants who had a few days previously landed apparently in perfect health. The suggestion is a good one, for it is undeniable that the persons and garments of immigrants are often in need of a thorough cleansing before coming ashore. Everybody who has been brought into contact with new arrivals from Europe, must be aware that the " ship smell " often hangs about them for weeks after they have landed and mixed indiscriminately with the colonial population ; and during the last

six months lhere has been undoubted proof also that they sometimes

carry with them into the far in- terior the latent germs of mortal sick- ness. Fatal cases are known to have occurred among the Landsborough's immigrants a few months ago after they had reached Copperfield, while at the Rockhampton hospital there was a large accession of patients from the same vessel, although on arrival she had no

sickness on hoard to warrant the HHAI.TII OrncüR in refusing pratique. In con- nection with this matter one satisfactory circumstance may he mentioned. Up to the present lime, there is no known instance of ship fever being communi- cated by immigrants to the shore popula- tion ; and this notwithstanding the fact that several cases are known of persons, who had landed in apparent health, succumbing lo attacks of the disease so long as two months after their debarka- tion. While therefore, we cordially

endorse Dr. SAI.MOND'S recommenda-

tion in this matter, wc cannot regard it quite as a preventive of thc evil under consideration. The cleansing and purifying process is requisite on sanitary grounds, and it may in certain cases mp the germs of the disease, but alone it will not be an effectual antidote to ship fever. The mischief is usually done before the immigrant vessels reach our harbour, and the causes are manifold.

To begin with,-the wrong class of people arc often selected-persons with debilitated constitutions arising from constitutional taint, vicious indulgences, semi-starvation, or unclean habits. Thrust into a crowded emigrant ship, fed with provisions to which they have never been accustomed, deprived of all healthy exercise, moving and sleeping in

the midst of foul air and unwholesome

smells, neglecting their daily ablutions, and often falling into a condition of morbid wretchedness,-it is no wonder that the immigrant becomes thc victim of fell disease. Thc preventive measures, to be effectual, must therefore be taken at home and on board ship.

Tin» im mirv into nrevious habits anil

character should he more searching, the medical examination more thorough, the ventilation on board ship more effective, and the discipline more strict. Persona! cleanliness should be rigidly insisted upon, and exemplary punishment meted out for disobedience in this respect. An immigrant should be required to sur- render his liberty for the term of the passage, and to live strictly according to the niles adopted for sanitary purposes. With regard lo ventilation, it is much to be regretted that the 'tween decks plan of the Imperial Emigration Com- missioners is not adopted in our vessels. The opinion ofexperienccd medical men is that " Allen's Patent Uerths," are hot- beds of disease. The domestic privacy for which that system is so much praised, is found an impediment to proper venti- lation, and to be subversive of strict discipline, ft is also the nursery of accumulated fillh,the scat of foul odours, and the generator of fever and other diseases. Privacy on board ship is very desirable, no doubt, but it may be pur- chased at too great a cost. That it has been so purchased in several of our immigrant vessels cannot be truthfully denied, and were the actual mortality known, the necessity of sacrificing domestic privacy and personal freedom

to considerations of health would no

longer be questioned.

lt may be hoped that Dr. S.M.MDNMI'S report will be the means of drawing the

attention of the (¡nverninenl lo this subject, and that henceforward the pre-

cautions taken will make the dreaded

fever ship a rare phenomenon.

A *JI:NT).KM w whit ha* paúl considerable

attention to the stock-markets of Australia

lins kindly furnished ns with a tallie compiled from authentic sources, showing tile total nmuhcr of cattle iii Australia to bc nu .'10th .lune last, 4,l!)S,'iS2, and of sheep 3!l,83!I,<i(iS. In cattle there «'.as a small decrease, and in sheep a slight increase during thc preceding year. The t<«\al population of thc Australian colonies on 31st Keceinlier last was I ,<¡3t,<!!l.'t. We have not space to reproduce the table tn-day, but will do so ou thc first oppor- tunity.

GLADSTONE O BSE UVE ll.

PUBLISHED DA.ILV.

THURSDAY, JULY 9, 1874.

IN our Police column, we have reported at some length a. summons case, in which Mrs. CONNOI.LV, the head teacher in the Girls' National School, in William-street, was charged with-assaulting and beating a scholar named'ADA PRICE. Our object in giving extended publicity to the evi- dence is not so much because of any intrinsic» importance wc attach to the case, as from a desire to put a check on exaggerated reports as to the nature oí the assault which caused proceedings to be taken. It would appear that the girl, when called upon for an exercise which had been given her two or three days previously, said she had not finished it, but would try to do so in a couple of days. This answer did not satisfy Mrs. CONNOLLY, who, in order to test thc girl's veracity, sent for the exer-

cise book. The book came in due, course, and nothing of the exercise was written in it. Mrs. CONNOLLY thereupon concluded, whether rightly or wrongly, that Miss PRICE was guilty of thc double offence of idly neglecting her school duties and endeavouring by falsehood to hide her faults, and gave her a severe beating. Whether the girl was really

so much to blame as the schoolmis- tress supposed we cannot tell, for the evidence taken was all on one side, as the defendant failed lo put in an appearance. Without, however, im- puting intentional misrepresentation to thc complainant and her two school- mates, who gave evidence in the witness box, wc may fairly assume that another side could have been presented, and that the defendant might have adduced such evidence as would have explained away or greatly modified the testimony niven in the Court yesterday. The beating, judging from Dr. ROBERTSON'S evidence, must have been unduly severe, and with the facts before them the Bench could not do other than order a verdict to be recorded against the defendant Hut there is undoubtedly much to be said in defence of Mrs. CONNOLLY. It is not by any means an easy task to maintain proper discipline in a large school, even of girls. Colonial children are precocious and impatient of restraint,

and in too many instances their . parents fail to a lamentable degree ¡ to keep them in proper subjection

at home. We are perfectly certain that ! Rockhampton is no favourable exception j in this respect, and that a public school ! made up of 200 or 300 girls from all classes of the community must contain

not a few troublesome scholars. With

regard to thc case of ADA PRICE, it is far fFom our intention to make her conduct appear worse than it really was in order to

find an excuse for MRS. CONNOLLY. The

girl possibly did not on that particular occasion deserve a beating at al!. But Mrs. CONNOLLY was evidently of a con- trary opinion, and believed that the vigorous use of the cane was necessary in order to maintain proper discipline in the school. Unfortunately she went too far, and thc danger now is that, through excess of punishment, the offender will be commonly regarded as a martyr. Parents are apt unwittingly to encourage this feeling, and thereby to weaken in the minds of the children that feeling of respect for their teachers which is abso- lutely essential to enable the latter to perform their duties with efficiency and

success.

We have little sympathy with the popular aversion to corporeal punish- ments in schools, believing that they are frequently far more salutary than other favourite modes of punishment. And even with girls, in a public school, we are dis- posed to think that the cane may be used with great efficacy. But. moderation is a virtue, and school chastisements should not be inflicted in a brutal or savage manner. It would be better in extreme cases, after having called in parental aid without effect, to resort to expulsion. Incorrigibles should not, under any circumstances, be permitted to remain in a school. If, however, the rod will save children from reaching that unenviable degree of degradation, let it be used by all means, and used without restraint from any maudlin feeling of delicacy.

THE annual mooting af the members of thc School of Arts is to take place this evening, in the hall of thc same, at eight o'clock.

THE meeting of tho Rockhampton Phil- harmonic Society, convened to take place in tho School of Arts last evening, was postponed until next Wednesday at thc same time and place, thc Committee having met iii thc after- noon, and so arranged, as many of tho mem- bers were desirous of attending Miss Joey Gougenhcim's benefit at tho Theatre Royal

A CASE oamo beforo tho Police Court yester- day, in which a man, named Thomas Halan, was charged with being drunk at tho railway- station, and destroying property belonging to thc railway guard. Tho bye-laws under tho Railway Act próvido that in audi a case, tho guard may take tho offender in charge and bring him before a Bench of Magistrates. They also authorise thc infliction of a fine for such offence not exceeding £5. The railway guard in this particular instance took tho man in charge, and afterwards handed him over, while within thc railway enclosure, to a constable, who convoyed him to tho lock-up. A technical objection upset tho case, and caused thc pri- soner to bo discharged, although he admitted tho drunkenness. It seems that the bye laws posted up at the Railway-station are not thc most recent, and although in thc particular matter of dealing with drunkenness and disorderly conduct thoy arc word for word the same as those last promul- gated, and are goneroUyto the same effect, but they boar a different date. The bye-laws at prenont in uso by tho railway officials are contained in a small book ; and there was no evidence before the Court that they had ever been legally brought into operation. Tho objection was deemed fatal, and thc Bench had no alternative but to discharge the prisoner. But had this point not' boen raisod, it is possible that objection would have been -successfully taken to thc manner in which the defendant was handed over to tho police. If we under- stand the law rightly, the guard should him- self have taken tho man to thc lock-up. Or another course was open. The guard might have removed the inobriatc outside the railway enclosure, and then have allowed a constable to take him to tho lock-up for the ordinary offence of drunkenness ina public place. How- ever, the failure of this case should cause such steps to bo taken os to prevent thc ends of justice being again defeated in a similar

manner.

MACKAV Correa MIKES. - Tho accounts

from thc copper mines arc, we [il. Mercury) understand, most encouraging, thc lode which was originally struck having now been followed for a considerable distance and shewing signs of improvement all the way. There is no doubt that a valuable and permanent lade hos been found, and all that is wanting is tho ex- penditure of capital in order to dcvclope it thoroughly, and to erect tho necessary smelting work«. Wc believe that some of those interested intend visiting and inspecting thc minc shortly, and ehauld tho lode lie then considered as satisfactory, immediate steps will probably be taken to carry out the necessary works. Wc hope before many months arc passed to sec teams loaded with copper coming regularly into Mackay, aa nothing would hotter contribute to advance thc prosperity of this district than the addition of a good copper-producing mine to our present

industries.

Lojir IN THE Btrsn.-A labouring mau (says thc ¡1. Mercun/ol June 7) named Patrick Gaynor recently had thc good fortune to escape from a miserable death as a consequence of being lost in the bush for three days without food, lt appears that while on Iiis way from Bowen to Mackay he found himself, on Friday morning, 19th inst., somewhere in thc vicinity nf Era merson's station, with no rations, and suppos- ing that thc station was situated up thc river or creek which he carno to, he turned off thc road and proceeded along thc hank of thc stream in that direction in search of thc sta- tion where he proposed to purchase a supply of provisions. After walking about twelve miles and meeting no signs of tho station, thc fact became evident that he had lost himself, and not having had any food for several hours, ho was forced to camp early, too exhausted, depressed, and hungry to proceed further. Next morning (Satur- day) he pursued, wearily enough, his distressing journey, taking an easterly course which lcd him to thc head of a large creek, which he followed down for many miles. It was most fortunate he kept the creek, as thc next day he made the glad discovery that it

crossed the road not far from what he after

wants found to 1» Messrs. Macartney, Am- hurst, and Murray's cattle station, Jolimount, whore bc arrived on Monday morning last, with just sufficient remaining strength to relate his sufferings during the three days in which fae accomplished his painful walk of about sixty miles through the bnsh, with nothing to sustain him except water. It is needless to say that he received kindly trcat I ment at tho station, and is nnw nearly re I covered from thc effects of thc hardships he

I experienced.
