GLADSTONE OBSBBl'KR.

PUBLISHED DAILY. SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 19, 1874.

ALTHOUGH the new Electoral Lists have been prepared by thc collectors, it would be a great mistake to assume that the names of all qualified persons will appear on ¿ie next year's electoral roll without

further trouble. The collectors have probably done their work well, but it is quite certain that in all the electorates some qualified persons have been missed, particularly when the qualification is a property one. In the Kennedy electorate one camp of twenty-five miners is said to have been altogether passed by, and there is no doubt that similar omissions have been made in some of the electorates of the central districts. At any rate, we strongly advise everyone tc examine the lists now posted for inspec- tion, or, if unable to do so, to send in a written claim before the loth October, in accordance willi the provisions of the new Election; Act. In* the Rockhampton electorate there is special reason for this, as it ii pretty certain that an election will tak< place before Parliament re-assembles At all former elections great complaint; have been made by disfranchised person; on the polling days, and not withou reason, for there is no doubt that lh< Revision Courts threw obstacles in tin way of enrolment which were neve contemplated by the old Act. If, how ever, similar complaints are lodged it future, those making them will be placee beyond, the pale of sympathy, am will have no one but themselves to blame The Government not only have gone tc i the expense of scouring the wholt country for electors, but thc further pro ' vision, of thc written appl ication is made b;

.the new Act. No magisterial declaralioi

is now requisite, and the applicant merci; sends in his claim in a form .statin; (i) his Christian and surname ; {2) hi place of residence, specifying if in a tom the name of thc street ; (3) his qualifi cation ; and (4) where his property i situated or how his claim arises. Ii making his claim, the applicant is'rc quired to solemnly declare that he i possessed of such qualification. Th form is supplied by the Act, but th application need not be exactly as pr« scribed, so long as it is to the s am effect, and contains all necessary pa ticulars. There are only 675 names o the new electoral list for Rockhauiptor whereas there should be at least Boo. 3 is therefore desirable that persons inte ested in seeing a complete electoral ro should bestir themselves. But it is nc in Rockhampton alone that vigilance i requisite in this matter. The state < parties just now leads to the conclusio that a dissolution next year is more tha probable. The Education question and til action being taken to extirpate th dummicr, are sure to stir our society t its very depths. New combinations at certain to take place in the Assembl; and it is impossible to predict what wi be the effect of the late reconstructioi Should Mr. M'DEVITT and In's frienc secede to the Opposition cross-benche the Ministerial majority would be vet much reduced, and if met by anythiri like an organised Opposition, M MACALISTER would find progress wil the business of the country impossibl That would soon lead to a vote of 11 confidence, which in time would I: succeeded by an appeal to the countr Care should therefore be taken to mali the registration of electors universa It is not only the individu who suffers by disfranchisement, fi when the electoral rolls are kilo« to be incomplete, the membe returned upon them must occupy

equivocal position, and have the co sciousness that had the voice of thi constituents been taken on a complc electoral roll thc cast at the ballot bi > might have been different. The existen

of the present Assembly, for example, will certainly be curtailed through the general belief tliat the electoral rolls of 1873 were extremely imperfect, and that the House never did fairly represent the choice of the country. That belief may be well or ill-founded, but that it exists and exercises an undesirable influence upon the political situation, is too plain to be questioned. There never was a time when the voice of the constituencies should be heard more distinctly than now, and there never was so good an opportunity of making the electoral rolls so nearly complete as is offered under the new Elections Act. We have at length universal suffrage in fact as well as in name, and the elector's right having been abolished, the next appeal to the ballot-box ought to reflect the opinion of the country with a fidelity which has never on any previous occa- sion been attainable. If with the facili- ties now offered for enrolment this result be not arrived at, our public men may welt despair of ever securing any volun- tary expression of the aggregate will of the great body of the people.

GL .i O S TO y IC OBSERVER.

PUBLISHED DAILY.

TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 10, 1874.

THE ratepayers aro called upon to-day to elect two members of tho Municipal Council in tho room of those aldermen who haye retired by rotation. For the two vacant seats there are four candi- dates, all of whom have claims to the suffrages of the ratepayers. But ali have not equal claims, and it will be for Ibo electors to-day to give their votes to those candidates «rho possess tho highest qualifications, and whoso return will best promote the true interests of tho town. Rockhampton has, of lato years at least, been fortunate in the character of its city fathers. The Municipal Council has not only beon a credit tb tho town, but also to tho colony at large. When Mr. PALM icu spoke of the Municipal Council of Rockhampton as tho best iu the colonies, his eulogy was deemed somewhat extravagant. Butin point of fact we do thiuk our Council may chal- lenge comparison with any otlier municipal body in the colonies. Whether we regard tho character and abilities of the aldermen, the mode in which business is conducted, or the results as shown in the respect- able appearance of our main streets, we cannot claim for our Corporation anything less tban the front rank among civic institutions. And when we write thus, tho reader must not suspect us of flattery. We give praise to whom praire is duo, in the belief that by so doing we contribute to perpetuating the good character of our Council. It is very unfortunate when tho action of cor-

porate bodies brings them under the

deserved censure of the Press. The evil

does not cease with the annoyance caused to individuals. When sensitive men perceive that acceptance of civic respon- sibilities places them in imminent danger of adverse criticism, thoy naturally prefer the walks ofprivate life, and leave to less scrupulous and less intelligent men the obligations and dubious honours of public life. Give a dog a bad name, and you may as well hang him, is a trite saying which applies equally to Cor- porations, and thereforowhen a Municipal Council falls into public disrepute, it might as well at once be abolished. No good men will be indnced to accept a seat in it, and under such circumstances local government can only descend from bad to worse, until it becomes a curse rather than a blessing to the commu- nity.

We therofore ofter our congratulations on tho high character of our corporation with hearty pleasure, and only hope that the result of tn.day's election will bo to perpetuate tho good namo and fumo which our Council at present enjoys. And this hope moy be iudulgcd with some confidence. The Municipal Council is not tho only ono of our institutions which has won credit for itself and the town. Our School of Arts, our Hospital, our Benevolent Society, and our Orphanage are all exceptionally well conducted, and if not quite abovecriticism are, on tho whole,

entitled to commendation rather than reproof. This, in a colony whore local institutions arc so generally ill-managed, is indeed high praise, and gives to Rock- hampton a position of which ber citizens may well be proud.

It is an unequivocal honour to any citizen to win a seat at our Council Board, and hence when vacancies occur eligible candidates are always forthcom- ing. This ÍB a state of affairs which we heartily desire to perpetuate, and there- fore we counsel all the voters to go to the poll to-day, and C3Bt their voteB for tho two candidates who will make the most useful and creditable aldermen. It is not our duty to make the selec- tion, and whatever tho result we shall cheerfully defer to the preponderance of public opinion, in tho full confidence that tho ratepayers aro really tho beBt judgos in the matter.

THE presentation of an address and a copy of Hogarth's Works to His Worship tho MATOO, yesterday, supplies an opportunity for a few remarks on tho subject of tho mayoralty. We shall take leave to regard this tribute from the officers of tho Council as indicative, not only of their regard and esteem for Mr. LIVEEMOBE, but also as a testimony of the efficiency and succoaa with which ho has for three consecutive years administered tho affairs of the town. Wo have not always agreod with 'Mr. 1/iVEB.uonE, and it is possible that

fae at times boa laboured under a sense of injury at tho severity of our criticism, He is uot faultless by any means, yet he must be classed ns among the most excellent of Mayors. Always attentive to his duties, always accessible on an emergency, and always ready to throw his whole energy into his official duties, he bas fairly won the highest honours that caa be con- ferred upon a good citizen-the universal esteem and gratitude of his fellow citizens. There are mayors and mayors -men who, once io possession of mayoral honours, seek repose under thom, and men who regard the civic chair as a mere Btep towards tho highest distinction of good citizenship-the reputation of tho most useful member of I the community. We think it will be I admitted that Mr. LrrcttMOiiE must be

classed in tho latter category, and that he ißnow fully just i dod in retiring upon

his laurels. .

His successor will bo placed in cir- cumstances of no mean difficulty. Upon

bim chiefly will rest tho responsibility of,

maintaining the prestige of the j

mayoralty and tho credit of tho Council. He will have to contend with many adverse influences, and will bc fortunato if at first ho do not make some grave mistakes. But eotno such, at least, must bo cipected, and if there be manifested a moderate degree of ability, and an enrnost desire to perform tho duties efficiently, the public will look kindly upon involuntary errors at the outset. In a community like ours it cannot safely be admitted that any man is inevitable, and if an apprenticeship be necessary to fit tho Coming Man for the chair, we must submit to a temporary evil in the hope of securing a permanent good.

articleText:
The Rockhampton Bulletin

with which is incorporated with

Gladstone Observer.

PUBLISHED DAILY

SATURDAY, MARCH 7, 1874.

The safety of the good ship Southern Belle is more due to good luck than good management. After the storm in

which the vessel was dismasted she was

"in dangers oft," and her escape during the gusty weather that has lately pre- vailed upon our coast is a subject for special congratulation. Landsmen must speak with diffidence on nautical sub- jects, and be always ready to accept cor- rection, but in cases where valuable human life is jeopardised, they are entitled to ask for information when due care appears not to have been exercised

or mistakes avoided. It does seem to

have been an error of judgment, for example, when the CAPTAIN of the Southern Belle - fearing in her crippled state to attempt Capricorn Channel, resolved to brave the dangers farther north, and ultimately to cast anchor in an exposed place within three miles of a lee shore. But this apparent error is possibly capable of explanation, and as no casualty has resulted, the Marine Board of Queensland will most likely pass it by unnoticed. Recollecting the treatment meted out to Captains Sea- ward and Mowatt, however, we can

only conclude that Captain CARPENTER will be particularly fortunate if he escapes

the official censure of our great nautical authorities.

But it is to the arrangements of these very authorities that we now purpose to direct attention. The news of the

arrival of the Southern Belle off the coast, and of her casting anchor on Sunday in an exposed place off Water- park Creek, was promptly reported by special messenger from Mr. ROBERT

ROSS to the SUB-COLLECTOR OF

CUSTOMS at Rockhampton. The news

reached town on Sunday afternoon, about half-an-hour after the Mary, the only steamer that day in port, had started

for Gladstone with the English Mail. Mr. KILNER at once reported the intelligence to Harbour-master RUNDLE,

who lives some two miles out of town. Captain RUNDLE concluded that nothing could be done that afternoon, and seems not to have thought it worth while to come into town until the follow- ing day, when he reported the matter to Captain HEATH, at Brisbane, and calmly

awaited instructions. In the meantime the SUB-COLLECTOR and the HEALTH

OFFICER, impressed with the necessity

of doing something, determined to dispatch the ketch Violet to the relief of the ship, and arranged with her owner to call for them off Mr. Ross' house, at Bald Hills, on the following evening, and take them to the dismasted vessel. Pursuant to this arrangement, Mr.

KILNER and Dr. SALMOND started over-

land for the coast next day. On Mon- day Mr. Ross reached town with additional particulars, which excited free comments upon the inaction of the HARBOUR-MASTER'S department.

Representations were then made to Captain RUNDLE, in consequence of which he telegraphed on his own

responsibility to Pilot HAINES, at Glad stone, instructing him to proceed with the Mary at once to the ship, and if unable to tow her into port, to return to Keppel Bay by Wednesday, in

time to meet the Queensland steamer, whose mails and passengers were to be then transhipped to allow of her proceeding at once to the vessel. It

is understood that Pilot HAINES also received instructions of similar purport from Brisbane. At any rate, he left

Gladstone for the coast on the same

evening, and at an early hour next day was seen by Mr. KILVER cruising off Mr. Ross' house, and inside the Keppel Islands. The dismasted ship and the steamer were both at the time visible to Mr. KILNER with the naked eye, although probably neither vessel could distinguish

the other from the deck level. About nine o'clock, to Mr. KILNER'S astonish- ment, the Mary turned southward, and apparently steamed for Keppel Bay. But it has since transpired that she cast anchor inside South Keppel Island, and

remained there for the day, spending part of the time in getting fuel from the

shore. Here she met with the 'Violet'

and here Pilot HAINES first learnt the

actual position of the vessel. If ever there was an illustration of "How

not to do it," this is one. Mr. Ross' first letter to the Sub-Collector speci- fically described where the ship lay, - "twelve miles north-east of the house." Everyone in Rockhampton and Brisbane knew, and the officials of the harbours and rivers department must also have been well aware of the exact position of the vessel. And yet the Mary was sent on a wild goose chase after the dismasted ship! Whoever is responsible for this mistake should certainly pay the

penalty. It is no excuse to urge that no harm accrued. It is sufficient for

the public to know that a large vessel, with five hundred souls on board, was kept twenty-fours hours in peril through an official blunder. If no lives were lost, five hundred persons were needlessly allowed to remain in painful anxiety ; for we learn that on the appear- ance of the steamer five guns were fired by the ship, and that on the 'Mary' coming alongside. Many of the pas- sengers yelled with delight, while others wept, laughed, and embraced each other. So that, if the delay was not destructive to life or property, the mental agony it caused must count for something, at any rate. In these cir- cumstances it is needless to present a catalogue of hypothetical honors result- ing from the mistake, it is true that on Tuesday the "heavy squalls and thick

weather " were unfavourable to the

'Mary' proceeding beyond the lee of Keppel Islands, but we know that there was a smooth sea at the time, even where the ship lay, and there is no doubt

that had Pilot HAINES known her position, he would have carried out to the letter his instructions to go with the 'Mary' to the ship and report.

It is in no fault-finding spirit that we make these comments. Humanity re- quires that in such cases every official concerned should display promptitude, zeal, and intelligence. The laudable activity shown by Mr. KILNER came on in striking contrast against the waiting upon. Providence spirit of his colleague of the harbour department, in a case where moments are precious, it is folly to lose hours in awaiting instructions from Brisbane, and any official who will not attempt to save life without first seeking instructions to do so, has but a poor conception of the duties and re- sponsibilities of public officers in British

communities.

The table appended to this article supplies some information which must have a peculiar interest to the Queens- land stoekowner. The figures have been collated from the latest official documents, and may therefore be con- sidered at least approximately accurate. As will be perceived, they show a small decrease in cattle for the year ending 30th June, 1873, and a small increase in sheep during the same period. And as there is a marked increase in the popu- lation, it is not to be wondered al that the value of live stock generally rose throughout the year, especially as a number of meat-]»reserving establish- ments had to be supplied in addition lo the demand for ordinary home consump- tion. The partial cessation of meal preserving has already eased ihe market, and the presumption is thal without this outlet for surplus ^ock existing values cannot be long maintained.

Without ¡»lacing much reliance on the calculation, it may not be uninteresting to make, a rough estimate of the probable available surplus of stock for the current year. Taking the yearly cast of market- able horned stock at ten per cent, of lite whole, and of sheep at seventeen per cent ; and allowing six hundred pounds for each bullock and forty pounds for each slice]), the gross number and weight

available for the market will be

Nnmlrr. TIVqhl, Ihn.

Catt!« . 42l»,O00 2ô2,bOU,Oufl Sheep . (i,(iö(),000 2(¡(i,4011,000

Total weight .rilS,4O0,O00 Taking tho total population of

thc four colonies at ],<¡:U,(¡!I3 - souls, au«l allowing tin: annual consumption of hoteliers' meat to lie :lll0 Ihs. per hcail, the total quantity required for

home use will lie . 4'.M),407,ftOO

Surplus for export 27,!»!»2,10(1 This estimate, however, is probably bul a very distant approximation to facts, the only figures at all trustworthy being those in thc table. The percentage of marketable surplus will be <|uestioncd by many good judges, as will also be the average weight per animal. In a still greater degree is the consumption probl .'inaiical, the probability being thal in Queensland, with her preponderance of adults, thc allowance for consumption per head of the population is much under-estimated at three hundred pounds; while for the southern colonies il is possibly over-stated. A Queensland bushman consumes about twenty pounds of animal food per week, or at the rate of over one thousand pounds pur annum, whereas thousands of children in Vic- toria will not use an eighth of that quantity. The conclusion, however, appears to be that there is not a very large surplus of cattle and sheep avail- able for export, and that at present meat-preserving can only be conducted

on a limited scale. j

wini WHICH i* ixconrortiTKu TUK

QlADSTONiï O H S Ä ß V ff ß.

PUBLISHED DAILY:.

SATURDAY. AP1UL 25, 1871.

LAST Thursday week's sitting of Parlia- ment was almost entirely devoted to thc Insolvency Bill just introduced by Mr. GRIFFITH. This is perhaps the most difficult and important of the measures before Parliament,' and consequently the bulk of honorable members were con-

spicuous by their absence during the second reading. There is some fun in badgering a public officer by threatening lo cul ¿50 off his salary, but little

amusement can bc extracted from an

attempt to reform laws which are a dis- grace to our Statute Book. Amongst these must be classed the Insolvency Act of 1864, which, while giving a dishonest person every opportunity to cheat his creditors, affords but slight protection to the honest man who, through accident or indiscretion, is plunged into financial difficulty. The evils of thc system are numerous, bul one may be referred to by way of illus- tration. An insolvent is required to give up to the Official Assignee every shilling he has in the world, and to make oath that he has done so. Vet, if residing in a remote part of the colony, he is required to make two or three expeditions to Brisbane, or bc dragged there in charge of a policeman and spend tile interim between each meeting in gaol. Such an alternative is simply a disgrace to our civilisation, and the country is entitled to expect from its representatives an immediate measure of amelioration. But this is only one evil out of dozens almost equally patent, and which need not here be referred to.

Mr. GRIFFITH'S b'll contains consider-

ably over two hundred clauses, some of them such as few laymen can compre- hend. Hut as a whole the measure is a

really excellent one, and it has been pre- pared with great skill and care. Mainly it is based upon thc new insolvency law of England, but Mr. GRIFFITH has not scrupled (to use his own expression) to avail himself of useful clauses from the Scotch, Irish, and Victorian Acts. The last-named statute is an adaptation from thc English Act, and contains some improvements upon it ; while Mr. GRIFFITH'S bill takes note of all the mosi recent English decisions in insolvency, and remedies all the defects which the courts have discovered in the practical application of the new Act. Taken as a whole, the system to be inaugurated by (lie new measure will be a great stride (in advance of tile existing law :-" The main prin " ciple in the Hill is that when a man " is unable to pay, his property shall be " given up to his creditors to be divided " amongst them, on the ground that they " being the persons most interested, " should be entrusted with thc manage " ment of the realisation and dis " tribnlioti of thc properly." This prin- ciple is now recognised by all the most recent legislation in British communities, and there can be no question but that it

is a sound one.

We are unable lo-day to give even an abstract of the leading principles of the new measure, but are glad lo leam thal its passage through Parliament is almost certain. Practically il has so far met willi no opposition. Its author hus thc cordial support of the An'oiîNT.v-GiîNF.RAi. and the Govcni ni.nt, while Mr. TiiuMrsour, the only legal member on the Opposition ! side of the House, is scarcely less I anxious than its author thal the bill

should pass. Moreover, Mr. GRIFFITH is well backed up by the members for

Brisbane and the other mercantile con- stituencies, while the majority of country members are content lo lei the bill go I with the most cursory examination.

I Really, after all, there is little beneficial

.alteration to bi suggested in the details of the bill ; and, therefore, the less honorable members meddle with it the belter. It does not pretend to be original, but a compilation of the labours

of the most acute intellects of the

age. The only fe.tr is that in some cases the peculiar circumstances of the colony will be forgotten in transferring the clauses bodily from the Jinglish Act ; but we understand that a pretty sharp look-out is being kept in this particular. Tile tardiness and difficulty of communi- cation would interfere with thc operation of many of the most useful sections ; but this obstacle is met by the provision that legal documents in insolvency may be transmitted by telegraph. To facilitate this the necessary forms are abbreviated to the utmost possible extent.

We must reserve for another oppor tunityfurther explanation of the principles of this measure, merely observing that the best possible provision appears to bc made for placing the winding-tip of insolvent estates in the local courts, and for giving lo creditors on the spot the

control of their debtors' estates. The

official assignees are fortunately to be

abolished.

Cje^otïifjamjiion $nUelin,

WITH vii icu is ^coiiroi*Tr:i THY.

GLADSTONE O B S Jil fl r K R.

PUBLISHED 'DA.'IL7.

THUliSDAV. KEUJIUAÜV 1!), 1374.

IT is «jiiilc unnecessary for ns lo prove how much (he sipiallers of Australia .ne indebted lo thc Meat-preserving indus try. Tile direct benefits flowing from it

are seen in the enhanced value of slock from one end of the continent to the other. Since the utilisation of unmar- ketable Hocks and herds was found prac- ticable by means of boiling-down estab- lishments, nothing has so much contri- buted to increase the stability of grazing pursuits as the commercial success of the meal-tinning process. From the manufacturers' point of view the enter- prise has perhaps on the whole barely proved remunerative, especially hy com- parison with thc results of boiling down. The product of the tallow pots found an already established market. There was no difficulty about the process, the percentage of loss on shipments was trilling, and with the use of ordinarily good judgment there was but a slight element of speculation in the conversion of flocks and herds into cash. Vet even boiling down was spasmodically carried on, and being a merely temporary expe- dient for controlling the fluctuations in the stock market, was attended by a great amount of waste. The fal, hide, and horns were turned to account ; the flesh of the animal was lost. The <mes tion of questions therefore became, How to utilise the whole carcase, and secure to the glazier the full value of his product ?

For many years the problem remained insoluble. Experiment after experiment ended in failure. Hut the object was kept steadily in view, and at length the tinning process presented a glimmering of success. The difficulties, however, were still serious. The preserved meat was unpalatable, thc percentage of bad tins more than absorbed the profit of the manufacture, and thc supply had to create the demand. At length, after long-continued experiments and enor- mous losses, a fair margin of profit gra- dually became discernible. The influ- ence of the discovery was at once felt, and, strange to say, the meat-preserv- ing industry most rapidly developed where the most vigorous demand for home consumption existed. The butcher and thc meal-preserver competed side by side for the fattest beeves and thc heavi- est wethers. Naturally prices advanced as the demand increased. In (lie mean- while the new industry steadily pro- gressed, and the quality of the manufac- ture advanced ste]) by step. Improve- ment was stimulated by constant com- plaints of over-cooking from the Euro- pean consumer. The meat, though origi nally good, was done to rags, and no one who could get fresh-killed joints would

eat the Australian manufacture. The problem was the most difficult yet en- countered, bul ultimately il too was solved. Preserved meals rose in public estimation, and slightly also in price. Hut the price of fat stock rose still fitster, the limit of profitable manufacture was passed, the meat-preserving companied had to confess to a loss, and suspension became the order of the day. Not, however, until thc reserves of fal stock had sensibly diminished, or until indis pulable evidence was forthcoming thal the demand had been out-running thc supply. The very success of the nevi industry, in fad, necessitated its own suspension.

For a lime the slackened demand hail slight effect upon prices, and the move- ment was still upward despite a succès sion of favourable seasons. Hut thc

limit of the advance had now evidentl) been past ; the downward movement ha> begun in the south, and is so marked ai as to warrant the re-opening of some ol the meat-preserving establishments there. Al (¡«elong, we are told, "thc works arc " again in full swing, and some fom "thousand five hundred tins of pre " served meal are turned out weekly.' This intimation is explained by another fact, namely, that a large mob 'nf shee): from one of our western fattening sta- tions has just been sold in Melbourne for a price considerably below lli.il cur- rent in this district last year. The mob refelled to fetched only six shillings and ninepence at Melbourne, although sold with over twelve months' wool on, Thc price given for sheep last sea

son at Laurel Hank, was ten sin!

lings and sixpence per guaranteed fifty pounds weight, with eight months growth of wool. Il is but fair to slate thal in the former case thc net price ii named, while in the latter the i/rosi amount paid by thc meat-preserver i.' «luotcd. However, these facts indicate nôt that Melbourne is become a cheapei market than Rockhampton, but thai there has] been of late a decrease ir

in the value of fat stock in the colonies. The reason is obvious. The advance

was due to a vigorous prosecution of the meat-preserving industry ; lite decline is thc effect of its suspension. The fluctu- ation resulted from a rush of competition

between the bulcher arid the meat

preserver, and the sudden disappearance of one competitor from the market. The impetus of the new industry sent prices above the level of the future, and now the retrogression will possibly be equally marked. A renewal of the pre- serving process will soon induce another reaction ; but the oscillation will con- tinually lessen, and soon we may expect to see prices attain their normal level, and be subject only to such fluctuations as may be caused by bad or good seasons, and the varying condition of the Jiuropean demand for our meat

manufactures.

'l'he closing of the largest meat preserving establishment on the Fitzroy is due, we believe, to exceptional causes. It is no new thing for public companies managet) in England to fail in Australia, and il" the Central Queensland Meat Preserving Company do not prove a commercial success, fen/ experienced colonists will feel much surprise. The declining ¡trice of fat stock and tile approach of thc cool season, may possibly induce a resumption of the works by the

Company. If not, it may be hoped thal 1

lite establishment will soon pass into

other hands. It is known that lije tinning process at Lake's Creek is a success, that the Company's manufac- tures find a good market, and that (he works have all the appliances rctjttisilc for thc business. It is not for us lo scrutinise loo narrowly the proceedings of thc Company, but its prosperity is so bound up with the well-being of the dis- trict, that we cannot regard its suspension without deep regret and anxiety. And in these circumstances we are justified in adverting to the prevalent opinion that the expenses of management are excessive. locally the business may be well conducted, but Queensland shareholders exhibit great distrust in the management of thc London office. Thc Lake's Creek works do not stand alone, and many persons amongst ns can approximately estimate what the expen- diture and receipts of such an establishment should be. It must lie distinctly understood that we make no charge of mismanagement against the Company, or any of its officers. We merely record the very general belief that, now all preliminary expenses have been paid, and the price of fat stock is likely to decline, the Company ought to be able to carry on its works with a remunerative margin. It is not now a question whether the concern mil pay a fair percentage on the capital invested, but whether the season's operations would show a reasonable percentage of profit. Some detailed and guaranteed

returns from another establishment are

now before us, and they show a good percentage of profit on last year's opera lions. We find also thal the season

extended over two months only, thal

the establishment was worked to bul

one-h?lf its capacity, and that the prices paid for stock were extreme. What was possible in one case, should be found practicable in another, and hence the dissatisfaction to which we have already

adverted.

We observe that a project is on fool for placing the Laurel Hank works in the hands of a local company. A prospectus giving the leading features of the proposal is already in circulation, and we shall take an early opportunity of discussing its merits.

close hero on 1st March.

Thc latter gciitlema-u took exception to the plaint on tin; grouml that under the publicans aot not more tli.v i I'll could lie legally claimed. Mr. Milford triplied arguing that thc money was due, ami. th at the particular section of the act referred to 'ny Mr. Brown did not apply in thc present ;i-.t.mce. Thc ( 'onrt non-suited thc plaintiff with, il 10s. costs. Neville r. A. M'Donald, thura il\ His. tub, being tho defendant's half «if Ct-, 13s. for goods sold and delivered to two Jiarijot -.. Mr. Milford, for tho defendant, took esees» tion tr» thc form of action, and after ar^ imo ut the Court uou-suitod thu plaiutiff wi"i ll )s. Cd.

IN another part of the paper wo pub- j lish the Courier's repon of the late 1 interview between tho HOD. A. MAC- , AUSTER and a deputation of citizens on the subject of the llrisbane bridge, lt will be .seen thal tho MAVOK, on the])art of the Corporation, offered lo hand over to the Government the bridge and bridge lands, for ihe amount of the Council's liability-jCi2,>25°i'-lnt' Corporation foregoing the sum of ,£20,000 paid out of the city revenue upon the work. MIÓ WOKSIIII' did not make the condi- tion that ii should bu a free bridge, and, in reply to Mr. MAU.U.ISTKH, Alderman GKAVSON said that the tolls received at the temporary bridge, some years since erected by M v. HOVKM-., the contracto]-, amounted to ,/~Sooo per annum. He also estimated the value

of Otc bridge lands al ,£50,000, bul Mr. M .M AU STU! preferred the Surveyor General's estimate, ,£10,000. At this puhu Mr. Si l AV.Mt r, the member for brisbane, tool; mi die question, and urged that the bridge being "a main " outlet to die whole southern part of " the colony from Ihe metropolis." and a free bridge having been granted to Ipswich and promised to Maryborough and Rockhampton ; and remembering the loss occasioned bj- Government interference, - he thought thal the llrisbane bridge should bo" Iahen o\er as it. stnod, and made a five bridge. Mr. KIIMOMI-IONI-: lull.lived in snppuii, and he wis suc- ceeded by Mr. DICK* IN, who said the tInvi'i'iniieiil musí nu'*e llie bridge flee, ot lhere would be in great inducement to hanii i; mer. Mr. I'UYAK. aiiothc! member ol" ihe linus.', ivis j in-sent, am! by his siletv e sanctioned the representa lions of his colleagues. The conclu sion therefore is. thal if Ihe Governnieii conclude to lake o\er tile bridge un tin te, ms suggested, tin- proposal ',\viU obtaii

no insignificant amount of support ii

Parliament.

Mr. M MAI i-iv.i;'-; replies, uhhougl ambiguous, nia-il he deemed on th whole favourable lo the request of th deputation. He refelled to aa offe

made by him some years ago on the part of the Government, lo build tile bridge at a cost of ,£20,000, but the Corporation then refused thc proffered aid. That was undoubtedly a mistake 011 the part of the Council, for although no practical man could have expected the bridge to be erected for any such amount, if the Government had begun the work, they must have carried it out, at whatever cost, and the Corporation would have escaped a burden which has botli crippled and demoralised il.

One obstacle to the taking over of Ute bridge was suggested by Mr. HEMMANT, the Colonial Treasurer. The Coqiora tion debentures bear five per cent, interest, whereas thc Government can borrow at four-and-a-half. Were the

Council's liability taken over as it stands, j tlierefore, it would practically exceed by

some thousands the nominal amount, lint Mr. STF.WART suggested that the holders would gladly exchange their Cor- poration debentures for Government ones, which is not al all improbable, con- sidering the embarrassed condition of the Corporation finances.

The difficulty in the way of (he Go- vernment appears lo be the demand made for a free bridge. The condition, be it observed, is not made by the MAYOR, or either of the Aldermen, who joined in the deputation. The pre- sumption is that the Corporation would be glad lo get rid of the bridge on any terms. When once out of their hands, il will be no business of theirs whether lolls be levied or not. The Govern- ment, therefore, would probably be able lo close will) the Council al once, knowing thal Parliament would not refuse to take over a work which must soon reimburse its cost. Hut that course does not meei the views of the Brisbane

members, who apparently consider them- selves strong enough, with the aid of the Ministry, to carry a loan for a free bridge. In tin's we believe they are mistaken, for a free bridge at Brisbane would necessitate provision for free bridges elsewhere. No case for excep- tional treatment can be made ont in favour of Brisbane in this matter. Thal it is the metropolis of the colony,-that the Corporation hold a Crown Giant of certain bridge lands,-and that it was originally supposed the railway terminus would be on the south side,-are no justification for laking the bridge over at a cost of j£i 20,000, and throwing it open lo the public. If the Govern- ment were prepared to admit that a huge blunder had been made in interfering willi the bridge, and that owing lo thal blunder the Corpora- tion had suffered lo such an extent that the public revenue was fairly chargeable with the whole cost of the structure, the way to accept Mr. STEWART'S proposal would he clear. But as malters stand, we think it would be more prudent lo consent to the imposition of a loll, if it be really desired to relieve thc Corpora- tion revenues of the liabilities which burden them.

lt is worth noticing that the MINISTER for Woutis, who was present, and into whose department Ihc bridge would fall, made no sign, lt would have been in- teresting to leam whether thc hon. gentleman would apply to a metropoli- tan deputation the arguments he lately used at Rockhampton. But Mr. M'lt.

WRA1TH knows lite virtue of silence. He will give no -departmental sanction to any general bridge scheme at present, and if such be adopted a majority of lite Legislature must take the respon- sibility.

MAILS ncr s.a. Leichhardt, for Sydney, and per H.S. (.Jnvcrnor Blackall, for Brisbane (bulli direct), close this (Priday) evening ut eight

o'clock. Tho (iovcriior Blackall would havo sailed this morning, hut for thc heavy «howers yesterday interfering with the discharge of

cargo.

Titi: first number of tho Cooktown Herald,

a modest newspaper-as to «izo-reached us last evening by the Leichhardt, lt has evi- dently been got out in great baste, and therefore must not he too critically examined, As a first number, thc Herald is creditable to its iirojcctor, and tho show of advertisements indicates that it will not bc a losing specula- tion. Judging by tho leading article, tho editor has a keen eye to business, and politi. cally ho is prepared to support either Mr. Palmor or Mr Macalister-especially M aealister. The politician who docs most for Cooktown and tho Palmer will bu thc tuan for thc Herahl, Our young eoutemporary's he-id is manifestly put on thc right way, ami bc is not likely to be found crying out for thu very dubious advantage of Separation at Cape

Palmerston, while there is a chance of Ministers " making thc people of Cooktown, what they are bouud to be, a prosperous community."

AT tho Police Court, yesterday morning, be- fore tho Police Magistrate and Prank JJ. Bcildek, J,P., Mary tiuidra, Poler Lahhc, and A. C. Clarke, were ooimiiittoil to thc Lunatic lic ooptiuii Houseful' iiuu mouth upon thc evidence of l)r. Salmuii.L Mr. Bcddek hore left thc Bench, and a mau named J. li. Young was placed at the bar and fined Ss. or twenty-four hours 'imprisonment, for disorderly conduct in a public place, llobeit Perkins the quarter-master belonging to the ship ^southern Belle, was brought up on rcmaml, charged with doscrliou. W. A. Carpenter, captain of the ship, proved tho authenticity of the defendant's signature to the ship's articles, and also to his being absent without leave. Ju reply to tho Bench tho witness .slated that ho had only that morning arrived from Brishaiic, aud could not therefore pro- duce Un- otlieial log. The ease was ultimately ad journed until to-morrow (this) muming for the production of the log book.

l\ commenting 011 the otl'uvls madeto pro- hibit the ¡iule of liquors by law, the Huston Aihoeatv nays ; -"After nearly twenty years' experience nf a prohibitory law, and seven or eight yw¿ of a istate police, especially ap- pointed to enforce il, there are at this time Ul Boston 3000 places where liquors arc illegally »obi There are also IC constables in the city to close those places, and what, it is asked, eau those i(i men do with such au army of ollcinl ers, each one of whom. Iiis his own clientele to sustain him, and to set bini up in business again if any accident befall hiui ? The public aud open violation of the law increases every year, and the constables cannot «ítiforoe it justly and impartially, if they would. If their force wore increased tenfold they would stiU bo unable to enforce it, for the diflicultice arc i «piito beyond their control."

articleText:
%\t|focí,íj:imp(<M Çulletin,

WITH WHICH ls INCOBPOUTKU TIIK

GCADSTONG OBSRRrER,

PUBLISHED DA.ILY. WEDNESDAY, MARCH ll, 1874.

AI,THOUI:H there may be some doubt as to whether the " Northern Memoran- dum" will ever be discussed in Parlia-

ment or not, there is every reason to j believe that the twin subjects of finan- , cial separation and local government will receive some consideration. That any change in the law in these respects will be made during the impending session is improbable. Indeed it may be apprehended that the session will not be fruitful in legislation of any kind. Honorable members know too little of each other's opinions and capacities lo warrant the belief that any attempt to settle great constitutional problems will be successful. The probability ts that the passing of some patch- work measures, the two sets of Estimates, and some abstract resolutions, will absorb so much of the time of the House, that measures involving organic changes will be thrown over till the following session. In politics, however, there is so little ground on which to base prediction, thal the best informed writer must feel that in venturing to ex- press an opinion lie lakes an almost unwarrantable leap in the dark. There- fore should the pertinacity of Mr. Ftfz CURAM), or the eloquence of his northern colleagues, induce Parliament lo pass a financial separation bill, the public would only be treated to one of those surprises which may be constantly looked for in the working of responsible government in thc colonies.

As stated in a former article, we do not' believe either House of Legislature will entertain a measure granting financial or territorial separation dt Cape Palmer- ston. The only possible kind of legis I lation at the present time, we think, would have a precisely opposite tendency. Thc desire of most politicians now-a-days is to unite and not to divide. Mr. FII'Z<;I:HAI.I>, even professes to treat separation as an undesirable alternative, and would prefer union on some perfectly fair and equitable basis. It is, he avers, only because such union is impracticable' that he would dissolve the existing connection between north and south, lt therefore becomes

a question which all public men should earnestly consider, whether permanent and satisfactory union is attain- able or not. If it be, we think the overwhelming' balance of legislative opinion will pronounce in favour of a lasting connection, bul if that be deemed not attainable, the advisability of a friendly separation will hardly be ques-

tioned.

We venture to hazard the opinion that by judicious measures the colony of Queensland may be kept intact, and such a national spirit created amongst the people that north, south, east, and west may be induced with complacency to regard themselves as but parts of a great whole. All the advantages derivable from separation may be obtained by sub- division. The people under a wise local government law might bc allowed to manage their om» affairs, to spend their own money, and to enjoy as much real liberty as they could obtain by dividing north from south, or by splitting up the colony into three or four distinct and semi-hostile provinces. AH that appears to us necessary to this happy result is a willingness on the part oí Ministers to relinquish the patronage and functions which properly appertain to local bodies, and an earnest desire on the part of the Legislature to enfranchise each district with full statutory powers to administer its own affairs.

But simple as this process may appear, it is practically one surrounded by great difficulty. At thc very outset,

it would be necessary in attempt-1

ing legislation, to agree to a de- finition of terms. lt having been affirmed that a severance should be made between local and general expen- diture, there would be a wide difference of opinion as to what were general and what «'ero merely local works. The present Ministry, for example, call rail- ways, main roads, and costly bridges national works, while Mr. FITZGERALD and his political associates denominate them all local works. The present Ministry, wc fear, would never consent to relinquish die directcontrol of such under- takings, and therefore, so long as they retain power, railways, main roads, and expensive bridges will be dealt with as national works, and made a charge upon the Consolidated Revenue of the colony. Bul the present Government is not unchangeable or inevitable, and circumstances may induce a modification of its views on this point, or Ministers ceasing to represent the majority in the House may be required to give way to other men. There is reason to believe, however, that even the PKKMIF.K is ready to admit thc advisableness of decentral- isation of some kind, while some of his colleagues are prepared to go a long way towards meeting the demands of the warme it advocates of local government.

Although, in a certain sense, railways and main roads arc national works, inasmuch as their construction tends to

foster the progress of the colony, they do not benefit all parts of the colony alike. A railway from Brisbane to the Darling Downs benefits the Kennedy district about as much as Victoria, and if the people of the Kennedy arc taxed to pay for such a railway, they have a legitimate cause of grievance. In Queensland, therefore, railways must be treated as district, not as national works, if ever the whole colony is to be dealt justly by. And as the several districts are marked by distinct geographi- cal features, their boundaries might be easily defined. Were this preliminary basis of action agreed upon, one great obstacle to a satisfactory settlement of the local government question would be

removed. We shall return to this sub-

ject on an early day.

Wir« WHI'tTH IS inoOAPOliTKD TIU

&LAD8TOWE OBSERVER,

PUBLISHED DA.ILY.

SATURDAY, JULY ll, 1874.

AN able article on the subject of Aus- tralian Free Trade, bearing the signature of " Wabash," appeared in a late issue of tue Courier, and was reproduced, mini is its concluding paragraph, in the Bulletin of last Wednesday- The por- tion referred to was omitted because it contained a statement to the effect that the Australian Colonies Duties Act of 1873 throws an obstacle in the way of I any mutual agreement between two or more colonies. " If Victoria," says the I writer, " should agree to receive Queens-

land sugar duty free, she would be com- pelled to make the same arrangement . with regard to sugar arriving from every other part of the world." This assertion was quite startling, as we had always been under the impression that the Imperial Act in question did nothing of the kind. We therefore took an early opportunity of looking it up and reading it through. The Act is very short, and

is as follows :

AN ACT TO AMEND THE JJAW WITH RESPECT

TO COSTOMS DUTIES rs THE AUSTSAÍIÍK COLONIES.

[26th May, 1873.

Whereas it is expédient to amend the law with respect to Customs Duties in thc Austra- lian colonies: Be it enacted by the Queen's Most Excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consout of the Loria Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Par- liament assembled, and by tho authority of the same, as follows :

Short Tille.

1. This Act may be cited os " Tho Austra- lian Colonies Duties Act 1873."

Interpretation Clause:

2. In this Act the tenn " Au stralinn Colo- nies" sholl mean the colonies of New South Wales, Victoria, South Australia, QueensUvud, Western Australia, and Tasmani a.

The term "country"shall mes ji any country or place except Australian col onies and thc colony of New Zealand.

Poster to Colonial Ltjjislatut 'es to regulate

duties.

3. Thc Legislature of any one of tho Aus- tralian Colonies shall, for the purpose of carry- ing into effect any agreement between any two or more of the said colonies, or between any one or more of the said -colonies and New Zealand, have foll power fi em time to time tc make laws with respect to the remission or imposition of duties upon tho importation into Buch -colony of any arti ele the produce 01

manufacturo of or imported from any other of j

tho said colonies, or thc produco or manu- facture of or imported from Kew Zealand.

Provided always, that for the purpose afore- said no now duty shall be imposed upou, and no existing duty shall bo remitted as to the importation into any of thc Australian colo- nies of any article, the produco or manu- facturo of any particular country, which Bhall net bo equally imposed upon, or remitted as to, tho importation into such colony of thc like article the produce or manufacture of any other country. Provided further, that no duties shall be levied upon articles imported into any of thc Australian colonies for the supply of Her Majesty's land or sea forces, nor shall any duty be levied or remitted con- trary to or at variance with any treaty or treaties for the time being subsisting between Her Majesty and any Foreign Power.

The circular of Earl KIMBERLEY, transmitting copies of the Act to the Governors of the Australian colonies, says it will be perceived that the Act gives full power to each of the Australian colonies to make laws imposing or re- mitting duties, for the purpose of giving effect to an agreement in respect of any article imported into it from any other colony to which the Act applies. It has been thought expedient that, subject to the proviso against differential duties, the powers given to the Colonial Legis-

latures should be extended to articles not the growth, produce, and manufacture of Australia or New Zealand, in order to remove all doubts as to such arrange- ments as have already been made as to border duties between Victoria and New South Wales, and also to enable a Cus- toms Union to be established between

any two or more of the colonies to which the Act applies. A careful perusal of the third section must, we think, con- vince the reader that full power is given to the colonies to mutually agree to intercolonial free trade, or to establish any form of tariff they may think proper as between themselves, provided only that they must not impose differential duties on articles imported from other countries. The term " country," section 2 says, " shall mean any country or place except Australian Colonies, and the Colony of New Zealand." The colonies named may therefore .establish any tariff they please, or none at all, on articles passing from one to another of these colonies, but importations from places beyond, whether foreign countries or British possessions, must be treated with perfect equality. In short, the Act enables the colonies of Australia and New Zealand to regard themselves for fiscal purposes as one country, so that each colony shall occupy a similar position in relation to other colonies included in the group as one state in America occupies with regard to the

other states of the Union. Canada has j

attained this boon by federation; Australasia1 may ' attain it without wait- ing for federation. An. Australasian Customs Union would 7be a great

boon, and would give a great fillip to ' the progress of these colonies, both indi- vidually and collectively. This is generally admitted, and it therefore seems strange that the colonies have yet made no serious attempt to tum to account the Act which they were formerly so urgent in seeking from the Imperial Parliament. Wc are convinced that great difficulties willbe experienced inanyattemptto single out particular articles passing from one colony to another for exemption from duty, and that the wisest plan is to estab lishcompleteandunrestricted intercolonial

free trade. Doubtless it will be an arduous task in the - absence of a Federal Government, as agreements ar- rived at by Intercolonial Conferences are of no force until ratified by the several Legislatures of the Colonies re- presented-and the chances are greatly against such ratification being obtained in all cases. However, it is worth a strong effort, and we should be glad to see a Conference called for the purpose on an early day. The object can only be accomplished by the aid of earnest and persistent discussion.

A SERMON will be preached at the Presby- terian Church by tho Kev. Dr. Nelson, to- morrow morning, at cloven o'clock. In thc evening the Kev. James Carson will preach on " The Future Education of Queensland."

STATE of the Hospital for the week ending July IO, 1874:-Admitted during tho week - ¡ 3 malos and 1 female ; discharged-6 males and 1 female ; died-1 male (Morris Lillis) ; remaining in Hospital-35 males and 2 females ; total, 37 ; 4 patients in special ward.

TUB performance at the Theatre Boyal last evening was quite equal to former occasions, butas tho same piece was presented as on the two nights previous, we noed not par- ticularise, as the acting of "Thc Wife's Secret" has boen exceedingly good oach timo on the part of all the characters. To-night a change of performance is advertised, when Shakspeare's famous play " Thc Taming of the Shrew" will bo presented. Miss Jooy Oougen heim to appear as Katharine, in which part her talents will have good scope for display, so that she cannot fail to appear to advantage,

A Bi'EOiii, meeting of the committee of the Benevolent Society was held yesterday after- noon in the ladies' reading-room of the School of Arts. Present-Mrs. Hunter (the Lady President), Mrs. Beddok (Vice-Presidout), Mrs. lieadrick (Secretary), Mesdames Hartley, Leigh, Macpherson, Dr. Salmond, Mr. Mac- arthur (Polico Magistrate), Dean Murlay, and Rev. R. Hartley. The chief object of the meeting was to consider an offer made by Mr. Harden in a lotter forwarded to Mr. Liver- more, and by him handed to tho Lady Secretary expressing his willingness to let the Benevolent Society continue to occupy for another year the building now used ne a temporary Benevolent Asylum at tho present rate, viz., 10s. per wock. After some conversation on the subject it was moved by the Rev. K. Hartley, seconded by Mr. Macarthur, and carried unauimonsly that Mr. Warden's kind offer bo accepted It was moved by Mrs. Bcddek and seconded by Mrs. Leigh, " That a vote of thanks be givcu to Mr. Hanlcu for Iiis kindness in extending thc term of occupation of tho build- ing used as a temporary Benevolent Asylum." -Carried unanimously. It was thea moved by Dr. Salmond and seconded by thc Rov. R. Hartley, "That tho Lady President, vice President, Treasurer, and Secretary be requested to draw up a code of rules to be submitted for approval at tho next monthly meeting, for the government of the temporary Benevolent Asylum."

GL.iDSTOXB 0 ii S f£ RV K ft

PUBLISHED DALLY.

MONDAY, MAY 25, 1874.

THE meeting on Friday night was marked by earnestness and unanimity, and must ii ave answered the most san- guine expectations of its promoters.

Although the series of resolutions submitted had regard lo the general -7*--i."r J he. present Government, the

main Hung treateanpoii was ine'acuun-1 of the Legislative Assembly in fixing the residence of the fourth Judge, proposed to be appointed under the new Supreme Court Dill, at Bowen instead of at Rock- hampton. The meeting laboured under a great disadvantage from the want of information as to the nature of the debate in. the House on this question, the views expressed by hon. members, and the sides taken by them re- spectively in the division. The only intelligence at that lime to hand was furnished by two or three brief telegrams, which beyond stating the bare faci that Bowen had been fixed as the place of residence, only told us that on the following night, when the motion for a re-cast bf the Surplus Estimate was under discussion, the COLONIAL TTEASURF.R took occasion to remark, in the course of his defence of the Government allocation of the public Expenditure, that the vote fixing the residence of the Northern Judge had settled the question that Separation would be at Cape Palmerston, and not at Dawes Range ; and that the Central Districts should therefore make up their minds to cast in their lot with Queensland. We are further told in reference to this matter, that Mr. PALMER expressed surprise at the honorable MINISTER mentioning Separation as he thought it was a great mistake ; but he warned the Government that if the Central Districts were not properly treated, Separation would not alone be at Cape Palmerston. It was but natural, therefore, that the speakers at the meeting the other night attributed this décision to Government influence and connected it with the

I general policy of the present ministers in I regard to the Central Districts of the I colony. To understand the situation

fairly, it is necessary to bear in mind that scarcely had the Ministry entered office when an intimation was given to the member for Rockhampton that the Government intended to distribute their favours upon the assumption that the Central Districts had of late years been dealt with too liberally and should now stand aside whilst other districts were bountifully cared for. And although subsequent ministerial promises and expressions of kindly regard towards this part of the colony encouraged us momentarily to indulge the hope that ministers liad thought better of it and abandoned their evil intentions, thc publi- cation of the Estimates showed that our early fears were only too well founded. In tile proposed expenditure on roads and bridges and other improvements, the Estimates in chief displayed a determi- nation to mark out the Central Division as the object of their undisguised dislike. And this antagonistic feeling was further shown in the terms of the coastwise mail contract entered into by the Govern- ment without parliamentary sanction being asked for, and by which the A.S.N. Company, in consideration of the postal subsidy, were required lo discontinue their practice of making Rockhampton a port of call. The Government had evidently felt the pulse of the new Parliament, and made such overtures to the members representing the extreme nortli as would enable them to carry out their views. Tile Central Division had deeply wounded the feel- ings of the leaders of the southern party : having succeeded, after a hard struggle, in putting a stop on southern schemes of aggrandisement, and secured thc extension of the Northern Railway and the introduction of a system of fair dealing towards all parts of tho country. Hut the head and front of thc offending appears to be that the Palmer Ministry were instrumental in bringing about thc change. The extreme north, having taken an almost passive stand during thc conflict, owing mainly to the circumstance that the residents of those distant parts were

too much absorbed in the work of

pioneer settlement to interest them- selves deeply in public questions, did not excite the resentment of the Southern party and their leaders. It is foi these reasons that the members re- presenting the territory north of Cape Palmerston are treated tenderly by the present Ministry, and their co-operation secured at all hazards. Rockhampton and the Central Districts generally must bc punished for their contumacy in the past towards the south, and their grateful adhesion to the Palmer Ministry; and so it happens that a policy of retaliation against thc Central Districts is being successfully pursued, and that "Her MAJESTY'S Opposition" is at the present time almost exclusively made up of the representatives of the part of the colony against which Ulis hostility is directed.

The division of parties in the House i can no longer be said to represent pro- i gressive Liberalism on one side, and i

humdrum Conservatism on the other, i For, as a matter of fact, the conserva- ! lives, or squatters, as a party have no organised existence, and the leader of the present Opposition has proved him- self really more liberal and progressive than the leaders of the so-called Liberal

party. Mr. PALMER signalised his term of power by fair dealing and honesty of ?purpose ; and, with the aid of able :colleagues, connived to do what perhaps no other mah in the colony could have done. The course of extravagance was

stayed ; the annually recuning deficits j

were made to give place to annually ; recurring surpluses ; and the improved financial position of the colony was

availed of to give to the central and out- 1 lying districts a more equitable participa- tion in the public expenditure than had hitherto been accorded them. " Dis- appointed Southern politicians called the Palmer Government "humdrum" and retrogressive ; but acts speaks louder than words, and the people of the Central Dis- tricts know how to appreciate real worth,

and they regard the ex-Premier as not only ; a statesman of liberal and progressive , principles but as their true friend. |

It has been said that an unholy . alliance has been made by the present

Government with the members of the I extreme north. Whether this be literally true or not, we are not concerned to . i-iimv;_ we are, however, thoroughly

satisfied that tne action uf iiic enveni-

ment and the members of the new1 Assembly gives at least a colour of reasonableness to the report, for the Estimates have been carried in spite of their flagrant partiality and un-

fairness, and upon every question affect-^ ing the relative claims of the three principal divisions of the colony respec- tively, the action of the House, the Government party has represented south and north in opposition to the Central

Division. The Estimates were mani-

festly unfair as to the distribution of Expenditure for public works, and they

were shown to be so. Mr. M'ILWKAI'J'H

assumed great ignorance as ¡o the manner in which the public moneys had hitherto been spent mainly for tile advan- tage of the Southern Division, and made the assertion that, as far as his nun department was concerned, whatever might have taken place in previous years, he could say that in 1873 people of this part of the colony received an expen- diture double the amount per head of the population in other districts in that particular year. But even this statement, applying as it did only to the Depart- ment of Public Works during the period when the Central Districts were

undeniably liberally treated as compared with the conduct of the Brisbane Govern- ment towards them in previous years, was incontestibly disproved by an official statement of revenue and expenditure of the respective dis- tricts laid upon the table of the House. Notwithstanding the stern logic oriacts thus brought prominently under notice, the Estimates arc allowed to pass. How

hon. members satisfied their consciences we cannot tell. The MINISTER FOR

WORKS, however, gave the cue to wavering minds by pointing out that although the Central Division had less than its fair share of expenditure from the Consolidated Revenue, it was receiv- ing the benefit of the half-million loan money in the extension of the railway in progress. This consideration might, however, be entitled to weight, if it were made equally applicable to the South, where lhere has been a much larger expenditure on railways. But the argument is unfortunately one-sided, and reminds one forcibly of the " Lion in

the Fable."

So much for the estimates. Tile same style of conduct characterised the House in dealing with the question ot a Judge for the North, and his place of residence. We form our opinion from the abstract of the debate furnished by the Courier, which is published in another column of the Bulletin to-day. This report, we suppose, professes to give the leading remark of each speaker. If so, it is passing strange how the question was treated. It seems to us that the very essence of the necessity for a " resident " Judge, implies that the judge is not merely to travel periodically and hold circuit courts in different parts of his district, but to preside over a branch of the Supreme Court esta- blished in some centre of population having a considerable amount of legal business. And it was the want fell at Rockhampton lhat gave rise to thc demand for a resident Judge. This town has for some years past been the only assize town in connecliou with the Supreme Court for the whole of the colony from Dawes Range northwards.

lt was made an assize town because it

had a considerable population itself and represented a very extensive inland district besides. But hall-yearly visita- tions by one of thc Brisbane Judges do not adequately meet the growing wants of the

i town and district. In civil business es-

pecially, great loss and expense are en- tailed upon the community, owing to the

[ system by which all legal business that

cannot be done during the sittings of the

Circuit Court has to be transacted in Brisbane, tims involving expense in employment of agents and in other ways, which often amounts to a practical denial

of justice. A branch of the Supreme | Court in Rockhampton and a Resident j Judge would therefore be a great boon, and the districts further northward might

still have their Circuit Courts, and in j reality have all the advantage from the | appointment of a Northern Judge which they could enjoy were he resident at Bowen. But at the latter place there is no local business worth mentioning, and the Judge, if stationed

there would literally have nothing to do ' during the time he was not actually on !

circuit. We fail to see what benefit is : likely to accrue from the residence of i the Judge at such a place, for thc local j advantage is nothing, and a Judge for ; 1 circuit business only might just as well \

reside in Brisbane as in Bowen, and

much better, for he would there be of j some service. The possible contingency of future separation at Cape Palmerston has^ really" nothing to do with the question, and the action of thc House in fixing the residencelat Bowen is simply a political job. ,%

It would have been all the better had more time been afforded to the people chiefly interested iridis measure to make themselves heard. with regard to new

provisions inserted^ committee. The

petition now in course of signature for presentation to the: legislative Council Jias particular refetence to the clause fixing the Nortbi&i Judge's place of residence. ft istjefng got up hastily as the bill lias passedjfnrough all its stages in fjie Lower HouB^, and will soon be dealt willi in tí)é Upper. There is thevelure no!* time to wait

ibr reports of ^bates from Bris

brno, and the \' only chance of stopping its progrejsi is by petitioning the Council. We shoad not like to see the bill rejected altogether, for Mr. GRIFFITH'S clausesfciabling attorneys to practise; as bam»(Jre, and barristers as j attorneys would feen great improvement , on the existing lay ; and something is \ undeniably wanted to facilitate the : administration of justice in the Central I and Northern Districts, though not what I is ]lroposed in this bill. The suggestion

of the member for Rockhampton

contained in -"thc telegram read! at''the public kneeling is deserving of j consideration, jlt.is.to the effect that

»there shall be oBy three judges, one to jreStíe at jRockhXmpton, and make half yearly circuits ter ^Townsville and Bris-

bane-the latter tp meet the objection at present existing with regard to the jAgueaipourt. Thisplan would fully meet tliewînts of the country, and the expense of a fourth Judge is therefore unneces- sary. Thc suggestion came too late to be embodied in the memorial to the Council, but there is yet a chance that the bill will be referred back to the Assembly, and an opportunity be thus afforded of nákihg it in all respects a

really useful ineasuve. I -U_

articleText:
Wltn WHICH 19 IHCOKPOKATRD Til«

GLADSTONE OBSERVER.

PUBLISHED DAILY".

WEDNESDAY, JULY 8, 1874.

-._I

AMONGST the numerous claims which Select Committees of the Legislature

have this year been appointed to ex-1 amine are those of Mr. T. F. MERRY and ¡ Mr. JOHN BUHOT. The former seeks

compensation for an error in the Real I Property Office, and has so far esta- blished his claim in the judgment of the Select Committee that they have recom- mended a vote of £1500 to recoup the petitioner for his losses. In the matter of Mr. BUHOT'S petition, the Com- mittee recommend a grant of 500 acres ol' land as a reward for his effort in in-

troducing sugar cultivation into the j

colony.

The particulars of Mr. MERRY'S losses are briefly these :-Some years ago the petitioner bought from the Australian Mutual Provident Society a piece of laud situated at Toowoomba, receiving from the Society a transfer dated 29th April, 1870, in which it was stated that t)ie land formed a portion of the pro- perty comprised in certificate of title No. 16,864 issued to the Society. The petitioner lodged the transfer in the Real Property Office, and on their side the Society deposited a plan showing the Yal ii i t subdivisions of which that sold lt Mr. MERRY was one. On the 7th November following, a certificate of title was issued by the REGISTRAR GI A'F.RAI. to the petitioner, who naturally supposed bis title to be indefeasible. But on the 22nd March, 1872, he was ejected from the land by the Sheriff of Queens and, at thc suit of another person, who, as representative of the mortgagee, claimed thc property as included in a certificate of title issued in thc year 1866, to GEORGE M'CULTJOCH REED. " It appears to yourCommittee," says the report, "that the petitioner was so ejected

" because the land transferred to him " was not included in, and did not form " part of the land comprised in the cer " lificate of lille held by the society." It seems further that in issuing the certifi- cate to MERRY in error, the REGISTRAR {Jr.NKKAi. was misled by a plan prepared by a licensed surveyor named SWANN ;

but it is also held that had the plan been compared with, and checked by the plans in the Real Properly Act Office, the error would not liave occurred. But a very serious errorit proved for Mr. MERRY, and his creditors. Relying on the validity of his title he had erected on the land a store and other improvements to the value of ^1000, which were lost to him on his ejectment; as, although he re- covered thc original purchase-money of

the land from the Mutual Provident

Society, the loss of his premises brought about a crisis in his affairs, and his stock and property were sacrificed to meet the claims of his creditors. The Committee ascertained that the petitioner, at the time of his ejection, was in a solvent condition, his assets being valued at £9100, and his liabilities being £7684. The personal loss to Mr. MERRV was therefore £1416, but the loss to his creditors, through compulsory realisation, was £3298. With the latter amount, however, the Committee seem not lo have concerned themselves, their recommendation only covering the actual loss sustained by the petitioner

himself.

In this case the petitioner, unlike Mr.

P. F. MACDONALD, was not possessed of the means to bring an action against thc Government. But the probability is, that had he done so, the result would

have been thc same. The cases are j analagous in the respect that the losses j arose through official errors, and there j can be no room for doubt that both these j

claimants are entitled to substantial compensation. That the recommen-

dation in each case will be adopted there j is every reason to hope, and thus two grave public scandals will be removed from public notice.

The claim of Mr. BUHOT IS, however, a different matter altogether. He asks a reward from thc Legislature, as being the first person who actually made granula'ed sugar in Queensland, and as having by letters to the newspapers excited interest in sugar cultivation,

which would not otherwise have attached to it. He also claims consideration for

having rendered practical assistance by advice to many inexperienced sugar planters, both in the Moreton and Wide Bay districts. The Committee, after inquiry, find that Mr. BUHOT greatly contributed to the permanent and speedy establishment of the industry of sugar growing in this colony, and they recom- mend that a free grant of 500 acres of land should bc given to him as a reward for his services. Seeing that sonic years ago the Legislature granted 2000 acres of land to Captain HOPE, as the first colonist who had embarked capital in sugar-groiving, it may be hoped that the

smaller reward will not be refused to Mr. BUHOT, whose previous successful ex- periments in sugar manufacture mainly induced Captain HOPE to embark in his enterprise.
