articleText:
GDjje Soríibampíón bulletin,

WITH w:ncii i*» iflironroii4Trr) TUR

GLAD sro x ff o ns renns n.

PUBLISI-ÍSD DAILY.

MOXIIAV, FF.MUWUY l«, IS74.

QL'I:I;N".S].AM) may well he proud of her attempt to establish a special Kuropean Mail Service, liven if only partial suc- cess be realised for a time, il is not an insignificant matter lo win a character for boldness and enterprise, and that she has certainly liol failed to do. It is quite true thal at the outset no one sup- posed the young colony would be left to grapple with the difficulty and expense unaided. While the preliminaries wore being arranged, lhere was an under- standing among the colonies that the "three routes should be kept open at their joint expense, '('here was to be a rateable contribution in proportion lo the weight of mails from cadi, and all were to participate as equally as practicable in the benefits of the several services.

The project was an excellent one, and if afterwards found impracticable as a joint transaction, it has been virtually carried out through the enterprise or rivalry of three of the colonies. Queensland was the weakest of the trio, and the service she has established through Tories Strait is consequently the least efficient of all. Still, considering that she has undertaken to develope a practically new mail route,

and that she has aimed to accommodate all the chief ports on her extended coast- line, the prospects of the service are not by any means discouraging. .Al present il is only in the initial stage, being chiefly carried on by chartered steamers. Hut when the fine vessels now building for thc contractors are completed, we may look forward to the new line proving of substantial benefit to the colony, and to its conferring increased postal facilities upon thc Australia* generally.

Some information with respect lo the new service has reached us, which will assist the reader in forming an estimate of its prospective advantages. The contrata time at present is fifty-five days, the average speed required being nine knots, with five ports of call on the Queensland coast-line. In these days a nine-knot speed-is but slow, and the time is further prolonged by the intricacies of the Inner Passage, which compel the boals to anchor during three successive nights, thus involv- ing a detention of thirty-six hours. This might be remedied by tile erection of additional light-houses, the expense of which should be jointly home hy all the colonies, pursuant to a decision of the late Intercolonial Conference. There has also been unnecessary detention al the several ports of call, bul this will, no doubl, soon be obviated. As the com- manders of the steamers become more

familiar with our coasts and harbours, they will become more independent of our ineliicient pilot service. And we are told thal arrangements are already contemplated for changing the ports of call. When the telegraph wire is ex-

tended lo the Kndeavour River-which it must bc within a few months-Cook- town will be substituted for Cardwell.

Already the agents are reported to have recommended the substitution of Cleve- land Hay for Port Denison, and Keppel Hay for Port Curtis. The reasons assigned are, that although the existing ports of call boast ofmagnilicent harbours, the approaches to them are intricate, and can hardly be deemed safe at night for vessels drawing nineteen or twenty feet of water. To ensure expedition it i is essential that the calling places he

easily approachable al any hour, and this desideratum, il is alleged, is found at Magnetic Island in Cleveland Hay, and Sea Hill in Keppel Hay. Besides, it is staled thal fully two hours will be economised at each of these ports through the reduction of distance, and we need hardly remark thal a saving of even four hours, ¡san important object in a mail service. We understand also that a further modification has been suggested by the Company, it is that instead of the mail steamers calling at Port Denison or Cleveland Hay, thc contractors should pul ona small but swift despatch boat to convey the mails between Keppel Hay and Cardwell. The suggestion appears lo be a good one, and is also worthy of attention as likely

to afford increased facilities for the con- veyance ol our ordinary mails coast-

wise.

With thc necessary lighthouses supplied in the Strait, and the proposed modifica- tion in the ports of call, il would there- fore be possible to deliver the mails, with a nine-knot speed, in fifty-three days at Brisbane, and in fifty one days at Keppel Hay. Hut this to the southern parts of the colony would be bul a trilling advantage, and the route would attract no Kuropean letters from the southern colonies, ll is true that the northern pulls would be belier served (han formerly, bul on the whole the advantages conferred by service would bc comparatively small. Our

object, then, should be so to shorten thc contract time as not only lo make thc service valuable to Queensland, bul also to thc southern colonies. In fact, to so increase the1 speed of (lie mail boats, as to make the service allómate either with that viâ California, or that by way of Melbourne

and (¡alic.

The correspondence shows that thc contractors for the Torres Strait line are fully prepared to increase their speed if required. They have already offered, in consideration of an additional ten thou- sand pounds a-year-making a lotal subsidy of thirty thousand-to run their boats at a speed of ten knots, and to deliver thc mails at Brisbane within

forty-eight days. And they are further prepared, for a corresponding increase, to adopt a twelve-knot speed, and land their mails in forty-two days ! Their «cw vessels now building ave of thc best and most modern construction, and thc

company arc prepared to fit them with

such boiler power as will ensure an j average speed in all weathers of al least twelve knots. Were this arranged for, (be Torres Strait line would compete effectively with any other, and our (¡overmnent might reckon upon toking toll at thc rate of nineteen pence per ounce upon one-half the total European correspondence of Australia. The postal revenue thus yielded would materially reduce the burden of the subsidy, and if ratable contributions were

forthcoming from the southern colonies, ! Queensland would enjoy tile advantage of a first-class mail service without any addition to the expense already incurred.

Thc question then arises-Can this very desirable object be attained ? First, as to the amount of subsidy. There appears to be yet hope of extracting a contribution of ten thousand a-year from New South Wales, on condition of the

speed being increased to ten knots. A , half-promise was some time since given by the PARKES Government to this effect, and in consideration of Sydney being made the postal as well as the commercial terminus of thc line, it is highly probable that thc contribution will yet be forthcoming. Hut if so, a still, larger amount might be expected for a twelve-knot service, especially

now that New Zealand has taken

a moiety of the burden of the Californian

contract. New South Wales would

certainly appreciate the advantage of j an alternating fortnightly service, which ! would render her independent of the

P. and O. Co.'s linc, and interpose a j check to the immoderate pretensions of j

Victoria. "

The increase of speed from len lo j twelve knots would involve an enor- I mons additional expense in the conduct

of thc service. To the uninitiated an j extra knot or two an hour may seem but a small maller, but marine engineers and owners of steamboats know that in coals and wear-and-lear of machinery the expense of high speeds multiplies rather than increases in geometrical ratio. It is probable that the contractors would

undertake a twelve-knot service for a

subsidy of sixty thousand pounds per annum, but for a less amount they certainly would not venture upon it. Indeed, it is understood that even sixty thousand pounds would not be an inducement but for the belief that a first-class mail service via Torres Strait

would attract the bulk of passenger

traffic to that route. What then would

be the probable cost to this colony of such a service ? At present we are paying twenty thousand pounds a-year.

If we could induce New South Wales to

offer a yearly contribution of an equal amount, and New Zealand to provide (say) one-fourth of thal sum, the Queensland contribution to the subsidy would be increased by fifteen thousand a year-or raised to thirly-five thousand pounds. Hui as a set-off against this increase lhere would be the tolls collec- ted on all southern letters sent viá Queensland, and an additional toll on telegrams despatched to catch the mail boat at our northernmost port of call. These collections would very nearly, if not quite, cover thc increased cost of the service. If this be so, North Queens- land might be brought considerably

within six weeks' reach of London

without any additional charge upon the public revenue.

These facts appear to present an excel- lent opening for diplomatic négociation, and Mr. THORN bas now a grand oppor- tunity of immortalising himself. A Con- ference is at present out of the question,

but if a brace of our astutest Ministers

could be induced to undertake an expe- dition to Sydney, and lay a feasible

scheme before the cabinet of Mr. PARKI»

the results might he important. At any rate, we should have the satisfaction of knowing that no possible modification, with the object of securing united action, would be likely to impose more costly advantages upon Queensland than she enjoys under the existing postal con-

tract.

Turc revenue collected .it tho Customs fur

tho week ending Saturday last amounts to C.Y29 Ifls. lld.

'ivsi ISrisbane telcgrjun states that Mr. Alexander Fyfe has been appointed Assistaut <!ohl Commissioner to Mr. St. tJcorgc at the I'almer Uiver, Mr. Fyfu's experieuee iu Viulona and Queensland should go far to qualify him for tilling the appointment with credit to himself and satisfaetion to thc public.

Ar thc polioe Court on Saturday morning before Mr. V. K lîeddck, J.l\, «ne drunkard was admonished and discharged. .lannis Marcham, on remand, was then placed in tho dock, and on the application nf the Sub- inspector of Police was further remanded until this (Monday) morning at ten o'clock.

Tun Theatre Royal his been engaged hythe agent in advance of "lïobson's World renowned Variety Troupe," who, we ari; informed, will shortly appear, certainly not later than Saturday next. Messrs. Stephens and ïicwis, memhers of the Troupe, have visited I'ukhampton before while under engagement with Mr. .Tames Ashton, thc last named gentleman being the bold and dashing rider nf Hie Chvtis ring. The remainder nf the Company ar.: now to a Knukhamploii

audience, but report speaks highly in their ! favour. j

I WITH WÏ1ÏCU i* IKC0MOliiTV.il TM»*.

0 LA D sro SE OBS f£ fl V K ll.

PUBLISHED DAILY. WKNDESDAY, FBIIRUARY 18, 1874.

WHAT is known as the " J.ison kidnap- j ¡lili!,' case " bas excited nindi interest j throughout the colony during the past ! two years. It arose out of a trial on the 2nd December, 1871, in the Criminal

Court at brisbane, in which John WI-1

liam COA TH, master of theschoonerjason,

was found guilty of kidnapping, before j His Honor Mr. Justice LUI WVCHK, and , sentenced to imprisonment for five years, and to pay a tine of fifty pounds. COATH was primarily committed for trial on the information of Mr. JOHN MEIKLEJOHN, who accompanied the Jason as Govern-

ment agent when the alleged kidnap- ; ping was committed. lt transpired, I however, that MEIKLEJOHN'S oral testi- mony was contradicted by Iiis own entries in his diary, and that in other respects his statements induced the belief that his mind was affected. His case against COATH therefore broke down, . and the doubt which his testimony ex-

cited was afterwards justified by marked proofs of his insanity. He subsequently destroyed lu's own house by fire, and lias since been an inmate of the Talban

Creek lunatic asylum in New South Wales. According to the statement of Dr. MANNING, the Superintendent of that asylum, MEIKLEJOHN has "an " attack of violent and dangerous mania " about once in three months, an<i in " the intervals he is calm, plausible, rea " soiling, and displays considerable " powers of memory and intellect ; bm is " cunningly suspicious, and prone to " make the most malignant accusations " against everyone about him with an air " of thc utmost truthfulness." As already stated, il was on the evidence of this unfortunate gentleman thal COATH was first committed for trial. Another in- formation, similar in character, was after- wards laid against him by JAMES HAR- PUR, one of the seamen, and it was 011 his evidence, with that of two oilier sailors, that the conviction look place. At the lime of the trial many persons were of opinion thal the story was a con- coction, and thal impression was strengthened by the well known profli- gate character, of the witness-in-chief for die prosecution. So strong was our con- viction on this matter two years ago, that we expressed in these columns the belief that thc man had been wrongly

condemned. Our information cune from

anvissionary source, where, hailtheve been valid grounds for the conviction, no sympathy whatever would have been

shown with the criminal. Native testi-

mony on the islands was the basis of belief in COATH'S innocence, but that testimony was unfortunately not avail- able in his defence. Circumstances, however, afterwards occurred which stimulated inquiry, and caused the release of the prisoner as a man who had been wrongly convicted and unjustly incar-

cerated.

Immediately after the trial, 390 in- habitants of .Maryborough petitioned for the prisoner's release, on the ground that native testimony in that district and at the islands unanimously pointed to his innocence of the crime. Inconsequence, Mr. A. W. MANNINI; was sent up to Maryborough to make inquiries. He visited unexpectedly the several planta- tions on which Polynesians were em- ployed, and among others examined " seven Malicolo and two 'lanna " islanders, whose assumed abduction "occasioned the prosecution of Captain " COATH, and his consequent punish " melli." Their unvarying replies were, " Me want to come ;" " Captain COATH very good." Thc ATIORNKY GENERAL, however, in commenting upon Mr. MANNING'S report, pointed out that these seven Malicolo and two Tanna men

were not those for the stealing of whom COATH was convicted. The real victims ! were nine Api or Tanna men, and he (Mr. HRAMSTON) was not satisfied thal Mr. MANNINI : had seen them amongst I the men examined. He therefore

thought the prisoner could not bc safely released upon these statements, but suggested further inquiry. The next step was the forwarding of a petition by COATH to the GOVERNOR, thc allegation's in which were supported by solemn declarations made hy several of the "kidnapped" Polynesians, and by the chief officer and one seaman who were on board the Jason when the alleged outrage tool; place. All these documents tended to establish the innocence of the prisoner.

After perusing the petition, the ATTORNEV-GENEIIAL resolved personally lo question the Polynesians alleged to have been kidnapped, and he accordingly proceeded to . .Maryborough fur thal purpose. He examined nine islanders, arid their testimony was all corroborative of that previously obtained by Afr. MANNINI;. In subsequently reporting the proceedings lo the GOVERNOR, Mr.

IJRAMSTIIN wrote :

"The islauders were not examine.! at either of the previous inquiries as to the agree- ment raailc over-night, or as to the disposal of the pigs ami finit, so that they could not anticipate my questions, and they had no opportunity of concerting the story after 1

bogan tbo examination. The coincidence of their fctatouiouts, their demeanour, and the fact that sonto of them answered iu English thc questions which, the interpretar translated to thom, convinced me that they were telling thc truth ; and, as the statements they mode arc incompatible with the alleged kidnapping, I can only come to tho conclusion that Captain <Joath was wrongly cauvicted. I, therefore, beg to recommend him for a pardon in Her Majesty's name,"

Tlie above particulars have been chiefly gleaned from a paper laid before Parliament last month. Strangely enough, it contains no intimation of the steps subsequently taken beyond the bare in- timation by Mr. BRAMSTON thal a free pardon had been granted upon his re-

commendation. The matter does not appear to have been submitted to the Executive Council at all, and the pri- soner, it may be presumed, was released ¡ by a simple-exercise of the royal preroga-

tive. Tl) is method of procedure wnsatleast peculiar, the custom in such cases being to refer the new evidence to the Judge who tried the case. Possibly that)was done, lint it would have been more satis- factory had die paper laid before Parlia- ment contained some information upon thal point. It does bear the look of a stretch of thc prerogative lo reverse the verdict of a jury without the Judge's recommendation, and we can but hope such recommendation was first obtained.

.There cnn be no reasonable doubt of

th ; prisoner's innocence, but there is a natural apprehension in the public mind lest an injurious precedent should have been set by the procedure in this

matter.

This case is also calculated to awaken anxiety on other grounds. If, willi our cumbersome system of trial by jury, it is possible for an innocent man to be convicted of felony, to be de- prived of his good name and fame, and to be kept in prison for two whole years, where are the boasted safeguards which arc supposed to protect the mdt vidual in British communities? It

floes appear odd that not one of the islanders alleged to have been kidnapped

was examined at the trial, and that the in- ! criminatory evidence of sailors, who had quarrelled with the prisoner, should have been accepted without qualification hy the corni. It seems hard to get rid of the suspicion that the anti-slavery mania then prevalent al Brisbane gave an unconscious bias to the decision of the jury. The undeserved punishment was an outrage upon Captain COATH, and

his case cannot fail to secure the

sympathy of all impartial persons. But still greater mischief resulted from thc conviction. It gave consistency to the imputations of those over-zealous phil- anthropists who charged the colonists of Queensland with being the aiders and

abettors of men-slealers. It is some consolation to find, even at this late period, that the reproach has at length been removed, and that up lo the present lime there is no valid reason to believe that employers of labour in this colony h u e ever soiled their hands by trafficking in the bodies and souls of their fellow^

men. Bul the whole circumstances ol the trial, the conviction, and the release, do not supply grounds for an agreeable retrospect.

Oirii Coloration lias been making praise- worthy efforts to improve tho sanitary con- dition of tho town, but there is scope for

further administrative reform in thc same direction. Thc closet-cleansing business must,

at best, ho a disagreeable ono, but it nomi not ' bc so conducted as to hscotnc a public

nuisance. The pinching shoe makes one speak j

feelingly, and sojwith the mittel- under notice. Wc do not think it at all necessary tint on one or two eveniugs in each week our « hole staff, from editor to devil, should ho routed by tho unsavoury nightman, anil compelled to rush to the river bank for a breath of pure air. Sixpence worth of carbolic oil would remove all diHieultios.

lr will be recollected that sonic months ago we commented strongly upon the apprehension of a person mimed Hugh Willis, at Tambo, nuder thc prutext that he was an escaped pri- soner finin Ravenswood. Ito was brought down to Rockhampton in irons, placed in thc dock at tile l'olicc Court, and immediately dis- charged as nut thc mm wanted. Naturally enough he was very angry, hut the injury hciug done by a constable he had no rodross without proving malice, a rather difficult matter. Mr. Willis, however, has again got into trouble, and certiinly supplies a striking illustration of what may happen to a man iu thc bush, lt appears that on being discharged hera last November he proceeded to Brisbane, where he remained a short time, and then went overland to thc Barcoo to adjust some business ho left in an unsettled state, when dragged away to Rock- hampton by thc Ipolice. From thc Barcoo, he started for Brisbane, going round by way of Clermont, determined on reach- ing thc metropolis to demand au iuvestigation into tho circumstances attending his previous arrest. Wlieu near Clcruiout he met a m ui uamed William Hlntoll,, rilling a horse which it afterward anpoarcd was the property of ono Peter Cunningham. Cunningham took out :i summons against Bint til for " illegally using," and subpnuiacil Willis to prove his ease in the Clermont Court. On the day set down for tho hearing, thc complainant did not appear, and thc ease was nut even called upon. But after- wards Willi? rcciivcl another subpoena, re pin ing his attendance on the iltli Kebrnary.

lfe remained at Olcriuiuit three days, and then finding there was no likeli- hood of lilntoll hoing apprehended, there loins other clurges against him, Ii; (Willis) told th: complain mt aol the sergent of police that he. e>uld not identify the hor.se, and that as it was useless his remaining in Clermont ho should leave. Since leaving lie has learnt that lî i ut il I was apprehended hut not till after the Sith instant. .Vs .alipou ..'I from our report of .Monday's pdicj ciurt,

Detective Bury npni-obciidi-.l Willis on that day, on tho charge of refusing to obey a subji'cna of tho < 'lerui mt bou;h, hut thc police not having reçoive I the warrant, Willis was dischargcA. The warrant, however, is known to he on tile way fraoi dorm nit, and Willis expects t i bu re-arrested to day or to-morrow, ti bc conveyed back to 1'eak Downs at thc public expense, and til bc called on to givo evidence in :i iiiitt.ir upon which he can state nothing material til the issue. Mr. Willis considers himself an ill-use 1 person, and wc think thc reader will confess that he is at least singularly unfortunate.

WITH WHICH is irtcoRfOKLTP.D TMR

GLADSTONE OBSKRVKR.

PUBLISHED DAILY".

FRIDAY, MARCH G, 1874.

SOME surprise was felt a few days ago at the rejection or Mr. W. E. MURPHY by the Fortitude Valley electors, in

favour of Mr. Alderman BEATTIE. Mr. MURPHV is a solicitor in large practice, while Mr. BEATTIE enjoys the unenviable distinction of being a member of the City Council. Our files just to hand contain reports of both candidates' speeches, and after perusing them we confess to thc conviction that the Valley electors have chosen the better man. Mr. MURPHY, alluding to the demand from the north for a change in the seat of government, proposed to meet it by diffuse public ex- penditure on Brisbane, and by pushing on tile construction of a net-work of railways in the back country of which Brisbane is the port, " so that Brisbane would lake " such a position that the North could " no longer cry out for such a change."

We do not wonder that this kind of ] statesmanship was too audaciously corrupt even for a metropolitan audi- ence. Such a mode of procedure would raise up a compact parliamentary phalanx with the determined object of preventing the aggrandisement of Bris- bane, in which case Mr. MURPHV would liave found thc last state of the city worse than the first. Oismissing all

consideration of thc claims of

justice, therefore, the proposition was a highly imprudent one, and Mr. MURPHV richly deserved the snubbing afterwards given him at thc poll. On the education question, too, this candidate was equivocal in his utterances, and evaded the question whether he would continue state aid to non-vested schools. This alone, lo a constituency educated by Mr. LILLEY, should have been fatal to the candidate's prospects, and possibly

was the real cause of Mr. MURPHY'S rejection.

With regard to the successful candi- date, it is satisfactory to find that his speecli had the genuine ring of true metal, and that although addressing a metropolitan audience ho had thc honesty and manliness to say, " He believed " their representatives should pay most " particular attention to the improve " ment of the harbours and rivers along " the whole coast of Queensland, and " for his part he said at once thal if " elected he did not mean to go into thc " House for the purpose of making " Brisbane the greatest of ports, but to " do justice also to the various Northern " ports - Maryborough, Rockhampton, " etc." Mr. BEATTIE adopts thc principles of Mr. LILLEY'S education bill, but takes exception to some of its details. In one part of his address lie gave the legal profession a hard knock by observing that hail business men instead of lawyers had thc drafting of our land laws there would be fewer loop-holes for the dimi- nuer. This probably told against his opponent, for whether founded in truth or not, there can be no doubt of the prevalence of the belief that thc special pleading of the legal members of the late parliament was not conducive to beneficial legislation. In the new Assembly there are but four lawyers, so that the public will soon have

an opportunity of judging whether their j lessened influence will be advantageous ; or not. In concluding, Mr. Beattie had ! the modesty to remark that " He might, , "if elected, make failures; but, if such " should lie the case, they would not " arise from any want of will on his part " that fair and even justice should be " done to this constituency as well as lo " the whole colony." It may be hoped that the new member's usefulness in

parliament be will such as to imite fill up llic gap created by the resignation of his learned predecessor.

Tmtoticu tho courtesy of Mr. D. Peterson.' Post master, wo have been furnished with thc " Hough Time Tables " showing the times ot arrival at, anil departure from tho Queensland ports of call, as fnllous :- 15.M.S S. Rentan loaves Ih islianc with thc nut-going mail, March 211 ; arrives ot Keppel Ray on the morning of the ."Kith instant at 7 o'clock, and leaves again at IO p.m. same day ; arriving at Singapore April 21st. The 15.M.S.S. Tom Morton, lewes Singapore on April 7 ; aiTives at Kcppol Hay, April 2<>, at 4 a.m.; leaves three hours later, arriving in Urishane at 8 p.m. of April 27th. Tho 15. M. S. S. Flintshire on her next outward voyage will leave Moreton Ray at 4 a.in., April 10th ; arrive at Keppel Hay at 7 p.m., April lilli; leave again three hours later same evening, and arri ve at Singapore on May I. Tho date of thc Flintshire's arrival herc from Singapore is lint stated. It may be alsn observed that there is ouly an interval of twelve day» between thc departures of thc ]3cutaii ¡md thc

Flintslure,

VriXVL WHICH IS INCOBFOtUTMl TUR

ai A D sro y ff o ns fen rta R.

PUBLISHED DAILY.

SATURDAY, JUNE 6, 1874.

THE most important debate of the session, thus far, has evidently been that on the Land Bill. That discussion lias apparently been reported by thc leading journal at much greater length than usual, and we regret our inability to reproduce the whole report in our

columns. The debate was conducted

with good temper and moderation which does the Assembly great credit ; and if sonic members indulged in long and dreary orations, the greatest sinners in this respect have had a kindly veil thromiovertheirindiscrctionsbythePress. The best speech of the debate was de- livered, in our opinion, by Mr. GRAHAM, who reviewed the land laws of thc colony from its foundation, and after completely

emolishing the new bill, sketched out .vhat, in the opinion of the speaker,

should bc the character of the future

legislation on this subject. Mr. GRAHAM'S speech on the occasion was marked by a liberality, comprehensiveness, and inde- pendence of thought which did both him and his constituents the utmost credit, and completely vanquished several of the

rabid Liberals of the southern districts.

It is extremely fortunate for the inember for Clermont that he has taken advantage of this opportunity, as heretofore the impression has been that he had left office without making his mark. That, however, ¡snow shown to be a mistaken conception, and he is complimented equally by friends and opponents. No one now doubts that in acquiring valuable infor- mation, and mastering the land question,

Mr. GRAHAM has turned his brief and

eventless term of office to good account ; j and the conviction seems to have become j general that, so far as the personw I of the Lands Department is concerned, the colony is not benefitted by thc change of Ministry. Whether the almost entire elimination of squatting influence from the Cabinet will prove advantageous is of course quite another matter.

In moving the second reading of his bill, Mr. STEPHENS make a very long, and from an exclusively southern stand- point, perhaps an able speech. It was moderate in tone, and very fairly attempted to grapple with the scandals alleged to exist in the southern districts. But it exhibited a poor compréhension of the real wants of the colony, and provoked an amount of hostile though moderate criticism which must have taught the new MINISTER FOR LANDS a useful lesson. Mr. PALMER'S attack

consisted chiefly of ridicule, and, in its way, was very effectual. Mr. THOMPSON made a successful defence of his ad-

ministration, and pointed out that the chief of thc dummying scandals occurred under the administration of his prede- cessors, and under the Leasing Act of

iBúú. This was one of the most valid arguments used against die new bill, and considerably dismayed those blatant Toowoomba men who colloquially are the victims of " dummy on thc brain." Mr. THOMPSON had a great advantage over other members in having been for several years .it the head of the Lands Department, and in exhibiting a prac- tical acquaintance with the question to which no one-Mv. GRAHAM excepted -could make any pretension. In a de- bate on thc land question it is evidently no mean advantage to be an ex-Minister for Lands. Bul, perhaps, after Mr. GRAHAM'S, the most effective speech of the debate was th.it delivered by Mr.

Gun i ini, who. although a staunch'parly . man on the Ministerial side, sealed the condemnation of the bill. He saw many

defects in it, and only one good principle, namely, the proposed resumption of the leased halves of all rims in the settled districts. He twitted the Ministry, and also their predecessors, with want of the moral courage necessary lo the adminis- tration of the present law, and pointed out that it was (mite equal to the suppression of dummyism. He also con tended that it was the duty of the Government to clear the -colony of this scandal without creating any new-fangled tribunal, and he con- cluded by warmly deprecating unneces- sary alterations in the land laws of the colony. Taken altogether, Mr. GRIF- FITH'S was a most merciless onslaught on the Ministerial land policy.

Thc members for the Central Districts were unanimous in their condemnation of the bill. Mr. MACDONALD started

carly in the debate with the declaration that, as it stood, the bill was only suited to a portion of the southern districts, and that unless it was greatly altered in com- mittee he must vote against it. Mr. BUZACOTT - asked for proof that the alleged scandals had occurred in the ad- ministration of the Act of 1868 tn the Central and Northern Districts.

He generally condemned the prin- ciples of the bill, and protested against their being forced upon thc people of the Central Districts. Mr. JOHN SCOTT maintained that the Act of 1868 was equal lo the wants of the colony, that the residence clause was an infringement upon the liberty of the subject, and that the wholesale resump-

tion of leases was a breach of faith. Mr. DK S.VTOE objected to the bill from a purely squatters' point of view, and, although there was much truth in his observations, their judiciousness at the present time is rather questionable. On the whole, however, the people of the Central

Districts luve niucii cause tor satisiac

tiou that their representatives, entirely without party action, and from different stand-points, united in condemning a measure which, whatever its merits as a scheme for dealing with Crown Lands on thc Darling Downs, would inaugurate a retrograde and injurious policy if applied to this part of the colony.

it is quite problematical whether the bill will go through Committee or not. Mr. MACALISTER has announced that the Government are not wedded to any of its principles beyond that of resuming the leases, and therefore the probability is that the measure will pass through the Assembly. But if so, it will come out in a greatly altered shape, in which case its rejection by the Upper House is certain. This will not be a matter for regret under the circumstances, for the balance of opinion, even in the Assembly, appears to be that the new bill has not been demanded by the colony.

articleText:
i;|eJocii|aittj}ton §ulletin,

WITH WltlCt! IS IKCOirOKlTKIl IHK

GL AD S TO XE O fl S12 RV ER.

?PUBLISHED DA-ILV.

FRIDAY, JANUARY "30, 1874.

PAWING to the disturbed state of tho

ttnoephore, our telegraphic despatches of 'uesday and Wednesday only came to and yesterday.

The English telegrams contain one or two lines of moro than ordinary inte- rest.- ¡The Imperial Parliament faaB As ' sembled and been dissolved. The mar-

riage of the DÜKE OF EDisimnon with

the GEAND DUCHESS ALEJCANDEOVNA

of Bussia, is an accomplished -fact. DB. " îirviNG6roNE is dead.

' From hints that have fallen from Mr.

"GIJABSTONE on several rccout occasions,

^fehn impression has widely prevailed that

-Poe was becoming weary of office and

Anxious.,for rest. Ile has for many years taken a prominent part, with occasional intermissions of brief duration, Íin the Councils of the Nation, and his

present administration has far outlived the average time allotted to ministries in the mother country,it having been formed in December, 18GS. It is essential to constitutional government that the .seals of office should not remain unin- terruptedly in the hands of ono party ; and the overwhelming majority of the liberals, both In tho Commons and tho constituencies, ts not potent enough to prevent tho Conservatives from securing sn occasional term of power. Indeed, it has not unfrequently been found that a protracted tonuru of successful rule will of itself eventually bring about the disintegration of aMinistry. Its members crow careless, and their policy in time lacks tho vigour of novelty and freshnoss. As a natural cnuscqucaco, tho party 7 grows weary of its leaders and desires a

- «bange, even at the risk of a change for

the worse.

This we believe lo bo tho true ex- planation of tho position of tho Liberal

Interest in tho United Kingdom. The J present Administration havo done wo!I for the party. They have carried through the most important measures of modern times. Tho diseBtablishmentof thc Irish Ï Church, the reform of th» Irish Land V Laws, the extension of the Franchise and

tho introduction of Vote by Ballot, are all tho work of tho GLADSTONE Ministry. lu addition to thoeo a vast '- reform'has been oflbctcd in tho system

of taxation, and tho remarkable nbility Mr« GLADSTONE lias displayed in the capacity of Chancellor of the Exchequer has caused him to. be regarded as tho Prince of Financiers. The prppout PUUMTEB and his colleagues, wo may safely say, have accomplished moro real work in tho interest of liberal legislation than was effected in the thirty years immediately preceding their advont to power. But thero are still disabilities to bo removed, and reforms to bo effected. Mr. GLADSTONE readily acknowledges that the British Constitution is yet capable of improvement, and that

there is still work lo do of this nature OB important as any that bas been done. But ho doubts if the country is ripe for further pro- gress, and hesitates not lo say, that however necessary a policy of aggression may be, bis desire is to be content with the laurels he has already won, and " rest and be thankful." Ile bas there- fore caused a wide spread spirit of disaffection among the extreme radicals, I and throughout the country the feeling

1 has of late been rapidly growing, that I

there is not mach use in having a j

Liberal Government unlesB it show a I

liberal and progressive spirit. Thon ! the Education Act has giron great dis I satisfaction, and justly so, for it is in

soma respocls of a positively retrogressive character, notably in tho way in which it gives ubdue preponderónos to tho

Established Church in tho constitution of tim School Boards and the manage- ments of the schools. There are ia the

old country as in the colonies, ndvocatos of purely secular education by the State, as tho only kind of education which the State can rightly undertake; and there is a powerful minority in the Liberal party determined to use every legitimate means to abolish State-Aid to religion in every form. At present tho energies of these wen arc chiefly devoted to an effort to excludo tho clerical element .from thc Public School«, and to esta- blish ;i thoroughly efficient system ol' secular education. They demand that their leviers shall bis true to themselves mid to thoir principles, and they refuse to submit to any com- promis» on this question. Mr. Fonsi'Eit, who may bo regarded as the ministerial champion of tho present Act, refuses to

to yield tho position ho has assumed, J and a breach in tho party has thoreforo become imminent. Tho roturn of Mr. Buta HT to the cabinet gave a ray of hopo tn tho sebularists-that distin- guished statesman having publicly admitted thal the Education Act must ba ainouded. His colleagues, however, repudiated his setitiiuonta, nud denied

! \ that ho was speaking with their full

! consent and approbation.

' From thc causes wo havo indicated, ; tho influences ofthe Gr.vnsroNuMiniBtry , ban boon steadily on tho decline, and for ? some months past nearly every electiou

has resulted in the return of a Conaer7a

! tivo. On tho assembling of Parliament, . therefore, a resignation or a dissolution

became inevitable. A resignation was rcsortod lo some time ago, which > proved that Mr. GT,A.DSTONF. was still in ' a sense master of the situation, and he ! retarnod to office. His position, how-

ever, has never since been satisfactory to himself or his supporters, who, are not by any moans in a good humour with the ' government.* Hence tbe expedient of

an appeal to the country. It remains to be soou whether tho programme indicated in our English telegrams will turn the tide in favour of the Ministry. The abolition of the Income Tax, the revision of local taxation, tbe assimilation of tho borough and county franchise, and othor measures promised, aro very good in their way, but the Education Act will still remain ft bono of conten tion ; and, if wo mistake not, Mr. . DisBAELt will bo ready to abolish the

Income Tax and to make up a pro- gramme that in the present mood of tbe : nation will be equally, if not more

acceptable than that put forward by the preaout PREMIES.

Our space has already been exceeded, > and we must reserve our remarks on the f Royal marriage and the death of Dr. . LIVINGSTONE for another opportunity.

ONE of the seamen belonging to the ship I

Pacific was brought up in custody before the ! Police Magistrate yesterday morning charged under warrant with deserting (ram that vessel iu thc month ot March last. No prosecutor appearing the accused was discharged.

IN reference to thc arrival in Rockhampton a few weeks since of two French strangers, who represented themselves to bc turtle ashers in distress from Noumea, New Calodonia (where there are no turtles, by-thc bye), we may state that there is an island which forms ono aide of the harbour of that port, and on that island exists a well-guarded convict out-station; It is customary for a number of those men, accompanied by a euflicicut guard, to row themselves over to Noumea ovcry morning, a distance of some wiles. Thc boats used, oro very large ones, and tho men arc taken over to perform a certain amount of labour in thc way of assist- ing to construct Borne harbour works for the Government. The party arc in the habit of returning at fivo o'clock in tho evening, when ofter Buppcr thc prisoners arc safely locked up in suitable buildings for tho night. Ono evening in the middle of the month of December last, thc boats (two) had arrived at the island as usual, one of them containing a quantity of provisions, in addi- tion to the convicts and a portion of tho guard. The former, who it is to bc prosumod " left their country for their country's good," then stepped ou shore with their escort, thc ollicer in cliwge ordering two of the convicts to romain in thc boat and take nor to another binding close by for tho purposo of landing thc provisions mid water with greater case and safety. Ono of these men was an old sea cap taiu. There waa a flue strong breeze blowiug at the time, right fair out of the harbour, and instead of obeying orders, tho suddenly hoisted thc Hails .nuil made thc best of their way out to sea. As soon as it was comprehended on «höre that they were escaping, thoru was a great commotion, ami tho other large boat was speedily manned by thc guards, who could do very little in thc way of pursuit, as most of thc sails, oars, and gear, had been placed in the other anil now rapidly departing boat, and thc few oars and an old Bail that hail been loft behind had disappeared by some means between thc time thc boats had lauded their living freight and the time the one was wanted to start in pursuit. A small boat was ultimately sent to Noumea, but in the face of «Btnmg breeze andimperfoct rowing apparatus, could make but little headway. She reached one of the men of war. however, and reportée thc escape, but nothing could be done as it was now growing dark, ami tho island of Nc« Cilcdnnia is surrounded by dangerous reefs, ami again it was generally lwlicvcl that thc escaped boat must conic to grief on one of tba many dangers with which the entrance to thc liarlxiur is bristling. The vessel got Hilder weigh at ilaylight the following morning and proceeded to sea, searching thc coast well all round, lint returned thc next day and reported that nothiug could be seen of thc boat or thc missing mon, and it wa« universally credited that they had struck on a roof, and thal thu men had perished. She is de scribed as a lar-;e t«|uavc sterned boal piintcd black, fitted for rowing witt double b&nkod oars, two abort masts, carryinj lattecn sails, iron tiller, and large and heavy iron ringbolts ; she is also coppered well up 01 the outside. How far this description agrees with thc boat now lying on the bank of tl» Fitzroy in thc custody and care of thc Col lector of Customs, can be easily seen, \m whero the two turtle fishers are at present located is not so easy of determining.

QLAD8T0NJ2 OBSERVER

PUBLISHED DAJLY.

SATURDAY, FKBRUAUY 7, 1874.

A Í.A.TH lelogr.i.-ii from lirisliano brought na iiitoiligotico that tho Urisbano diam bor ol' Commerce intend reviving tho agitation for Ihr formation of a Harbour mid River Trust for that port. It will bo in th« recollection of many of our render» (lint this question porno td reo or lotir years ago was pusbod tn an advanced stage. Thc Chamber referred to collected information on the subject, and invited and readily obtained (ho eo operation of some ol' I lie principal incrcdantBin Mary- borough and Rockhampton. If our me- mory serves us, they wenl so fur ns to draft n bill for tho constitution of Trusta for tho principal harbours of (¡io colony. At all events, they brought tho subject under the notice of Mr. T. H. STEPHENS, the Colonial Treasurer of that time, who, whilst admit!ino that thc wbolequostion was surrounded with difficulties, pro- mised to give it his best considérait in, and, if possible, submit to Parliament a bill to carry into effect tho object in view. Tho unsettled state of polities, however, en II sod lilia question, ni il han many others nf equally preening impor- tance, to bo postponed indefinitely.

Tho formation of efficient local Trusts armed with ¡implo powers and re- sources, we hnvo lon; deemed absolutely essential to tho proper management and improvement of onr harbours and rivers. AVo do not think that these trustK should bo expected to be onttroly self supporting for many years tn come. For that could not be tho caro without imposing undue burdens on thc shipping trade of the novoral ports. But tho trust rovcnuci from dues, pilotage, and other so irees, might be mipploinctil'.Ml by Parliamentary grants in much the same way os at present, excepting that tho dÍ8b'.irfiementof'lho fundsand lliccar

rying out of improvement s would b.'tinder I

theconlrolofthe locnl Roaid*. The funds

no handed over should not he nlloivc il to ¡ pans out of sight in tho general ox pom! i lure of tho colony, ns it would bo fairly

chargeable to the severa! districts'

directly benefittod by it, and in tho event of a system of beal government being initiated nt a future time, the sume spent on tho various harbours

might be transferred from tho Général. Government to tho account of tho roapoclivo districts.

Wo may safely say that no port in the colony has suffered moro front ibo absence of local control in relation to

harbour management and improve, mont than Rockhampton. The loeM harbour master at this port is

merely the servant, and that in a very ! subordinate sense indeed, of Lieutenant, ITEITII, R N., Portmaster at Brisbane. That last mentioned ofG-.'ial may bo an able engineer, aud competent for the position he hold«, although engineers of the Royal Navy are not always tho bast men to look after harbour improvements >n tho interests of commerce. But what-

ever his abilities may be, their oxoruiso is almost exclusively confined to tho port of Brisbane. When anything wants doing thorc, he is aware of tho fact, and probably gives it his ¡inmediato atten- tion; or should it for a timo escapo his notice, tho morell an 13 and shippers nt that port (alto very good care to set him on tho right track. Not so in Rockhampton. Tho Fitzroy hus boon

buoyed and beaconed, but Jim work ol' ! 'deepening the river channel has yet to j bo commenced. Truc, a little drodging |

liashci-u done, but lim benefit obtained has been only nf a temporary nut uro ; nul no ono pretending lo practical knowledge in such undertaking», over ventured to hope that it would bc otherwise than tempo- rary. Were tho channel nt tho Flats first dyked, so to givo direction to tho current, dredging w >uld probably bo nf lusting ad- vantage, flic fact is, thai the divdgo was scut up from Brisbane hy Mr. MaC.YMS TEtt and set to work on tho Upper Flats in our river, mainly for tho purpose ol' silencing tho clamour raised in Rock- hampton in consequence of thc «encrai neglect of tho district then exhi- bited by tho Government Tho roa! businers of improving tho river navigation in tho most effective and economical manner, was quito n secondary consideration, nnd almost lost sight of altogether. The consequence is seen in tho present state of the cutting at tho Flats, which is not a whit better than tho original channel. Tho dredge- bas now been laid up iu ordinary for some years, and has just beeu put in a slate of repair, but for what purpose has not transpired. Rumour says that the money voled for harbour improvements has nil beon exhausted upon works in tho Brisbane River; and if this be true, thoro is no immediate danger of moro mouey being wasted in dredging the Fitzroy. Bot something must be done, mid that soon, or tho trado of Rockhampton will suffer great and last- ing injury. As tho coasting trade increases northward, it becomes moro and moro a matter of importance to this port that passing steamers should be able to call without thc danger of stick ing on tho Flats and loeing a tide. Rockhampton has also a direct trade with Europe, struggling lo establish itself on a permanent footing; but the charges in the form of lighterage, towage, and other cxpeuses arising from the neglected state of the river, nud the absence of ordinary facilities for shipping, fall with almost crushing weight on our infantile trade, and if nothing is done to remove some of the existing drawbacks, the port will get a bad name, which is far easier ncquirod than got rid of.

To provide tho requisite facilities for shipping, a project has been mooted to construct a tramway from Rockhatnp ton to a point in tho river frontago at tho Town Common, where, it is alleged, vessels of eighteen feet draught could come up in ordinary spring ti dos, and experience no difficulty in the river navigation. The length of tramway would be about fifteen miles, and it is

urged that the Corporation should take the scheme in hand, and they would not only benefit th? town, but make good dividends by tb", receipts from tho tramway. The advo- cate!) of this scheme mustbesanguino ina to suppose that it would oitbor provo « financial success or benefit trado, Wo do not look coldly on tho proposal from any fear that it would bring into

existence a rival town, for that is quito | nut of tim question. But wo bold the opinion that for many years to come the principal part of tho trade will bc carrie I on by coasters, in Ilia same way

as at thc present time ; and I vessels of Ibis class would never j uso the deep water wharfage or the

tramway. They would prefer coining np | to Rockhampton, in spito of tho risk of grounding on the Vint*. Tho most reasonable thing, therefore, is to reider judicious aid to the trade as it actually exists, and not to launch out tn theo rctical projects, afterwards to find that wo ha>l hoon taking a leap in the d'irk. Wo would apply to trade a principio that has boen found to hold good in improving rivera-attempt no violent changos, but aim lo improve the natural channels. And in tho matter under consideration, this principle commends itself ns won by of adoption. Th.i river navigation must, in any caso, bj improved ns far u;i a* Rockhampton, and wo believe the most elfie! u<i! and

cheapest plan of providing tho requisite j facilities for tho trado of tho pori is to ' deepen the river channel as funds un- procurable, with tho view of enabling such vessels as tho Alexandrina to lie

alongside the wharves at Rockhampton, without lightering in tho river. This could be accomplished at a moderate cost, provided tho work iver.! undertaken in a systematic and sensible manne-. Tho first thing lo be dono ia to gel a thorough survey of tho river,

and elaborate an effectivo sc'iomc

for deepening thc channel. The, plans and specifications having bcjii prepared, the work should be carried out in accordance willi them, as opportunity ottered. This method would tend ti proinolo economy, and bj thc most satisfactory in I ho long run. Until the channel at the Upper Finis was Buffi cionty deepened, a steam lighter plying in thc river would bo as serviceable as 1

tlie proposed tramway, and would bs more profitable to ita owners.

It is useless, however, to discuss plans

unless meaus arc taken lo reach a practical rnsult. It will never do to quietly leave tho milter in th« hinds of thc Government, fir s'ldi a course involves ruinous delays and waste

of moins. A Harbour and River Trust is what is wanted, holli lo in uko im- provements in tho navigation and to look after tho general management of tho port. If such nn institution is nooded I in Brisbane, whore officials ran bo got at,

and ministers ¡interviewed nt any timo, how much more so in Rockhampton, whore no such facilities exist for bringing pressure to boar upon tho au'Jtoritios.

A work of this naturi) does not como

directly within tho provinco of tho Municipal Council. Wo do not disputo tho right, of that body to int» est itself in works beyond tho municipal boundary, provided the fun is nf tho m tnicipality are not spent or pledged to carry them out. Tho expenditure ol' municipal revenues is strictly c.infiticl by tho Act lo municipal purpns.'s. Tho tramway and deep water wharfage «chôme is tboreforo undoubtedly beyond the province of the Municipal Council, but the Mayor and Abformen might willi advantage bring un 1er llii> notice of the Government tho necessity for river im- provements or for the creation of a Uiver Trust. This business, however, legitimately belongs to o'.ir new Chamber of Common», and wo comm md it, to their attention. WouM it no', lu advisable to atonco Communicate with tho Chambers at lîrisb.nic an ! Maryborough, with a view to concerted action to get a Hirer and Harbour Trust Act passed in the forthcoming session of l'.irliament ? The Cor,ojrrA.ri Tunàsimuit should also, wo think bc addressed on the pn'ijcct without delay, so as to enable 1 ho Government to tnko tho matter in hand, and at tho outset to include it in lh"ir programme

Thu Chamber here ould then take measures to collect information to ascertain how trusts of tho kind aro usually constituted, and whit are thoir functions. The members of thc

district would nu doubt gladly se.-ond tho efforts of our merchants, and uso their influence with tho Government and other members of tho Legisla! ure t > get a really useful measure matured and passed into law. There arc . other questions calling for the intervention ol' our new Chamber of Commerce, but wc feel assured that this ono concerning tho establishment of a Harbour and River Trust, and the improvement of our River, is of paramount importance ; nnd its urgency would warrant tho Cjinmttteo in taking it in hand with earnestness and vigour at their first regular meeting " next Wednesday.

A rumour was current in town yesterday tîiit a vessel was ashore on an island iii the neighbourhood of Keppel Bay, un I that tho tracery (a wheatsheaf and sickle! awl spar found at Hahiagow.-tii were part of thc wreck. Wc have hoon unable to ascertain any further particulars, hut should any come to hand wc shall take the earliest opportunity of laying them before the puhlic. lt was also reported that (piantitics of hroken spars, planks, and wreckage of various kinds were still washing

ashore at Kum Park.

JULI! rumours of the discovery of traces of Leichhardt have so frequently gained currency, that there is now a prevailing disposition to regard all reports of discoveries relating tn this eminent explorer with distrust. Perhaps this fueling is carried too far, for il is quite possible that as thc interior of this country becomes known, some definite and reliable information as to Leichhardts fate may bc obtained. It appears from our telegrams published yester- day and to day, that a mau named Jinnie has arrived in liiishaue hy thc steamer boomerang -probably having taken bis passago at Towns villa or Bowen-who assorts that he has found a survivor of Leichhardts party, named Classait, and has got hold of Leichhardts diary, consisting of sixty pages. He states tint the mon of tho expedition mutinied,

wanting to return, Leichhardt insisting mi prococding, although ill. They loft, and Leichhardt died on thc fifth day after, (Hassan was away at tho time of tho ministry, in search of -water. Thc mutineers took, tho horses, hut were all subsequently killed at Eyre's Creek. It seems that on Thursday, Hume made a de- tailed statement of thc discovery of Classai! and tho fate nf Leichhardts party. Thc statement was apparently truthful, hut much doubted by thc general public. Hume, our telegram says, was unwilling to show docu- ments, pending his arrival in Sydney. This was considered a suspicious circumstance, and has helped to throw discredit on his story. Thc point that most requires explanation in our view, however, is, what has become of tho survivor, Classau, There is nothing re- markable in Hume's reluctance to show docu- ment* he may have in his possession, but ono would havu supposed that if his story wore true, the living cvideneo in thc person

of the niau (Hassan would have been forth- coming. lt seems, however, that Mr. John Uouglns is satisfied willi Hume's ioiiu fiU's, and has telegraphed to Mr. Parkes to that effect Thc question arises, who is this linnie ? There is, we are informed, a surveyor of that name, who used tn bc on the Maranoa, and who is a relative of Mr. A. C. (.rcgory, tho Surveyor-fJoncral.. lint if we remember rightly, this is the name of thc convict who, sonic eighteen mouths ago or more, whilst in prison ill New South Wales,

and aFtcr having served two or three years of his sentence, scut a written statement to Mr, Parkes, thc Premier of thc sister colony, stating that he believed he could find remains of Leichhardts party, and, in all probability, bis diary ; and that, if thc (iovenuncnt would grant him his freedom, he weald try his best to do so. Thc statement seemed plausible, and a special commission was appointed to examine thc prisoner aud test his truthful- ness. Thc Coiumissioii used every device to

ascertain if tho mau wera attempting an j impution, but thc most searching crosá cxauiinatinn failed to shake his testimony, but,

on thc contrary, seemed to confirm it. Thc .? New South \Vnlcs Government, therefore, gavcliiin hisliliurty, and provided him an outfit

for his journey. He stai cal shortly afterwards. : Supposing he is in actual possession of Leich- hardts diary, there is nothing surprising in his reluctance to show it before he lias placed

it in tlie hands of tuc (J.ivcruiucuL under whose

auspices he went out. As we have already

poiu'ed ont, thc strangest feature in thc stury i is thc absence of any explanation ns to thc present whereabouts of thc reputed survivor. Possibly thc omission is thc fault of our cor- respondent.

GLADSTONE O BS SB VS U.

PUBLISHED DAILY.

FKT.DAY, JULY 3, 1874.

MAILS for Sydney and the Australasian Colonies, por s.s. Balclutha will close at thc PostjOJfioe this (Friday) evening for registered totters at C o'clock, for book packets and news- papers at 7, and for, ordinary letters at S

o'clock.

IK thc report of Wednesday's mooting of

thc Committee of tho Rockhampton Benevolent I Society, tho expenditure of No. 1 district should bc £13 4s. Od. only, and thc total expenditure £29 12s. Cid. instead of £59 12s. Cjd. as published.

WE desire to remind our readers that the lecture on American Humour by Mr. Emile Arglos will bc delivered this (Friday) evening, in the School of Arts, Bolsovor-stroct, thc chair to be taken, at 8 o'clock. During thc address several readings from some of thc most popular humourists of thc day are pro- mised, and as thc lecturer generously proposes to give half tho proceeds in aid of tho Port Curtis District Hospital fund, -there will, no doubt, bc a full attendanoe.

AT the Police Court yesterday morning, before thc Police Magistrate, Thomas Hunter was charged with illegally obtaining a passage on board tho s.e. Balclutha from Sydney to Rockhampton. Constable John Hinch proved that thc chief officer gave the defendant into custody at two o'clock yesterday morning on the above charge, when he said-"I paid my passage in Melbourne right through to Rock- hampton, aud lost tho ticket in Sydney." Henry Bowe, chiof officer of the steamer, stated that they left Sydney on thc 27th Juno last, and the following day, while at sea, 150 milos from Sydney, thc defendant was found on board ; he said that he had paid bis passage in Melbourne, and that he only bad 30s. ou him ; thc faro from Sydney is £3 10s., and witness now asks the Bench to make an order for thc payment of that sum The defendant said in reply to the usual questions that he paid his passage te Mr. White, tho Company's agent in Mel- bourne. Mr. F. N. Beddek suggested that the defendant should telegraph to Mr. White, and thus prove thc accuracy of his state- ment. The defendaut would not accede to this; he would not pay thc expense of thc telegram and reply. Thc Court then ordered the defendant to pay the passage money, J£3 I0i., and 20s. flue, in default of immediate payment one month's imprisonment in Rockhampton Gaol. Bridget Gorman was charged with wilfully and unlaw- fully damaging a house on the 22th ultimo, to thc extent of £1 by pulling aud breaking off four weatherboards from the kitchen, the property of Andrew Cully of Rockhampton. Bridget Cully, wife of tho complainant, proved that on the evening of the day named in tho information the defendant esme to her husband's house with her daughter, and com- mitted thc offence complained of, at tho same time using very had language and threatening to take witness' life Thomas Budden, a labourer residing in Bolsover Street saw the defendant break the boards off on the occasion referred to. Wit- ness was awoke by thc noise, and saw that a little girl was with her ; it was a bright moon lightnight.and verything was distinctly visible For thc defence, Selina Gorman, the little girl spoken of by the last witness, and daughter of the defendant, was called and gave a totally different version of thc whole affair, stating stating among other matters, that Mrs. Cully first abused and then assaulted her mother. The Bench, however, considered thc case fully proved, and ordered the defendant to pay a fine of £4, together with 20s. compensation for tho property destroyed, and 4s. fid. costs of Court, bi default of immediate payment, imprisonment with hard labour in Rockhampton gaol for two calendar months,

C|c^odiíjanijíton IHiUeliu,

trrcH wnicTi » ISCORFOIITI» TUP.

GLADSTONE O B S E R V H il

PUBLISHED DA.ILY. THURSDAY. FEBRUARY 5, 1874.

THE colonisation of Non; Guinea is again to bo attempted, and a movement with that end in view is being organised in Sydney. Whatever mny bo tho result of the present eflbrt, the occupation of Ibnt rich and extensive territory by the colonists of Australia is inevitable, and its accomplishment is only a question of a fow years at most. The last expedition failed through shameful mismanagement, the vessel chartered for the purpose having foundered tn consequence nf her unseaworthy condition. It is absurd to suppose that failure under such circum- stances could long hare a deterrent effect upon the many adventurous spirilB always ou tho lookout for " fresh fields and pastures new ;" and as a matter of fact, we find at the present moment, under tho magic spell of new gold discoveries, thousands of our fellow

(colonists running tho risk of dangers grcnter than those experienced by the passengers of thc ill-fated Maria. The opening up of Cooktown and Ilia Palmer Gold-field marks au imnorlaut stop in the march of settlement to the north-

wards, and thc space intervening between tho farthest point airca ly reached and the island of New Guinea is to small, that tho occupation of tho latter hy people from the Australian Colonies may soon bo looked for in the ordinary course of

settlement.

There can bo no doubt that tho wave

of population will not be stayed in its northward progress by tho present limits of British rule. New Guinea will be occupied by

British subjects, who will not wait t

for (he sanction of the Government to

their proceedings. Captain MOEESBT ' acted wisely in taking formal possession of bis magnificent new discovery, pend-

ing tho decision of the Imperial authori- |

tíos; and wo sincerely hope tbat his action . will be ratified, and tliat at au early dato.

As bearing upon this subject, we ob- servo with satisfaction that the U.M. schooner Sandfly left Sydney for New Guinea a few days ago, and will bo fal- lowed by U.M. steamer Basilisk, accom- panied! by a steam launch, in order to complete tile coast survey of tho territory discovered by-Captain MOBESBT. It is rumoured (hat this expedition has (ho further object nf forming a naval elation on tho new territory, and thus complet- ing its annexation, but the report wants confirmation. A policy of inaction iu tbis matter by the Imperial Govern- ment would be productive of evil cousequences of thc gravest naturo, for a repetition of thc chronic state of anarchy prevailing nt Fiji mu st in (bat case take placo. Tho protection of Imperial interests and of tho commerce both of , Great Britain and tho Australian

Colonies, als:> demands tlic annexation of tho island» forming tho northern boun- dary of TorrrH Strait. In view of these weighty considerations, wo cannot soc

how tho Homo Government can hesitato

to annex thc territory in quostion.

There is a difficulty in tho way nf | tho annexation of the wholo of the j principal island of New Guinea, as tho

Du'c'i lay claim to that portion lying j westward of tho Hist parallel of j longitude. They maintain an in-

significant station on the nortli-west j coast, but it is doubtful whothcr ; that is sufficient to establish an

absolute right lo tho'country against j

a bm ii 1'nlo occupant. However, be that as it may, lhere is still hy far tho-largost portion of (lie main inland, besides thc c mtiguous islands discovered by Captain MOUKSHY, open to Ibo British Govern- ment, mid which should be secured al once. Tho claims of tho Dutch could

bn investigated at a future time, and doubtless an amicable understanding could easily bc arrivod at.

Thc mort potent coloniser for those islands would bo a rich gold-field. It is said that gold was found there by the officers of tbe Basilisk, and it is a matter of history that the Papuans wore gold trinkets and ornaments on their persons. Anothor fact of some significance is tho relative position of New Guinea to tho gold deposits of Australia, as part of it is within the longitudinal bolt which includes nearly all the important ! goldfields as yet discovered on (bis con . tinont. But gold is not necessary to I the successful seulement of Now Guinea.

According to Capt. MonEsnr and othor I authorities, there is abundance of rich . agricultural land on those islands

eminently adapted for the growth of , sugar, coffee, spices, and other tropical i productions of commercial value. Tho

natives are also intelligent, docile, and friendly-not like, the nomad raca of this country, but cultivating the soil, , and living in villages and ou (arms, in a . degree of comparative comfort.

It strikes us that this is tho country that will to tho fullest extent meet the views of tbat class of colonists who have raised sugar growing in Queensland to . tho importance of a valuable and porma 1 neat interest. Tho one difficulty they

experience is tho want of suitable labour. Tboy hare hitherto met thiB want by sending out recruiting vessels among tho islands of tho Pacific, but the abuses ¡ which have grown up in the prosecution , of this traffic, notably the kidnapping ] practices of tho Fiji plautcrs, have

brought into existence repressive regu-

lations, which are almost if not ; altogether of a prohibitory nature ; and I the members of the northern con j stituoacics, with Mr. FITZGERALD, I a large sugar-planter, at their head,

now ask for increased facilities for the introduction of Coolies. At Now Guinea this labour difficulty wo may reasonably presume would have no oxistence, as there is a residont popula- tion io every way adapted for tbe work of a plantation, and who would most willingly give their services for a rate of remuneration far below what is possible iu Queensland. AU that is wanted to prepare tho way for tho planter at New Guinea is thc establishment of autho- rity (hero for the complete security of life and property. Were this task undertaken at once by the British Government, tho rights of the natives might; bo duly protected, and conflicts such as those attendant upon tbe colonisation of New Zealand entirely averted. It is generally admitted that the cultivation or improvement of tbe soil givcB a right of possession in a sense tbat cannot be rocogaised in the roving useless aboriginal race of Australia who have done no more for their country tban tho kangaroo, and can scarcely be said to possess a superior right of ownership.

Tho inhabitants of Now Guinea are of a highor type of humanity, and fulfil the conditions which giro them an undoubted right to recognition as owners of the country they hold in actual occu- pation. They should be treated accordingly, and the right of property should be guarded with equal care in

the case of the native as in that of the European settler. The latter need not fear the rosult of fair dealing, as his superior intelligence, education, and force of character must of necessity give him the pro-cmiuenee.

MUCH has hoon said and written from time t<i time hy men interested in tho progress of I Queensland mid familiar with botany, with

reference to thc merits of thc sida refusa, lt

is declared to bc .1 valuable libre plant, and only requiring the energies of an experienced and enterprising man to make of it a valuable staple of commerce, lt is becoming very abundant in thc neighbourhood of this town in all directions. Ou the hanks of the river it may he found growing strong, and on Atholstane Hange also. Tu many paddocks it is fast becoming au intolerable nuisance, as from its hardy nature and ready propagation it is displacing the native grasses and destroy- ing tho pasturage. If any one would take thc initiative in thc matter of turning it to account be wonld bc n benefactor to his country ; or if any of our readers could furnish information through our columns for the successful pre- paration of thc material for the market, an

inducement might thereby he furnished for < making a trial I

PUBLISHED D A.ILY.

TUESDAY, FEBRUARY 3, 1874.

As adjourned mooting of the Coimnittoc of

the l'art Curtis aud Leichhardt Districts

Hospital was held yesterday afternoa» in the Court House, Kast-street, Present-Messrs. K. iL Hunter (President), J. Headrick (Vice President), T. S. Hall lt. L. Dibdin, W. Pattison, L. Sandel, E. P. Livermore, mid Dr. Macau. Thc minutes nf thc last meeting woro road and confirmed, when thc President

j said that it was with great regret he had. to

report the removal of botli auditors by death. Tile Secretary had asked him if Messrs. <». 1!. Shaw and R. L. Dibdin, two gcutlomon well-known to them all would lie permitted to audit thc accounts so as to further the business of the Institution as much ns possible. He had granted thal permission, and it wonld bo for tho Committee to express their approval or otherwUc of what had been dono. Mr. Hall moved that thc netion of thc president in appointing thc two gentlemen namoi aa auditors in tho room of Messrs. B. Brndnitzawl R. J. Robinson, bc now confirmed.

Mr. Li vcrmoreseconded, aiidsaidthatthcthaiiks I oftlicCommittccshouldbegivcntoMcssrs. Shaw and Dibilin for their kindness in coming for- ward. This was added to Mr. Hall's motion, put to thc meeting and carried unanimously. Thc Secretary laid on thc table the audited accounts for the inontliB of November and December last, showing cash in thc Bank ÜÖ9S Is. 4d., debts due by tho hospital £220 los., thus leaving n net balaiico to thc credit of thc Institution of £377 fia. 4d. Mr. Pattison explained that a considerable amount, upwards of £107 hail yet to bc collected in the town. This money had already been promised, and was only awaiting collection. Mr. Hall mored, and Mr. Dibdin seconded, that the accounts ns audited be 'passed. Carried. Thc secretary read a letter from thc lady secretary of thc Ikuovi lieut Society, asking for an instalment of £100 of thc Covcninienl grant. A long and rather acrimonious discussion ensued, which resulted in Mr. Hall moving, and Mr. Dibdin seconding, "Thattbe secretary pay over to tho Ladies' Benevolent ?Society £200 of the .amount uow due by usage, and the balance of £200 so soon as thc funds of thc Hospital will permit, and that all future grants of money received by thc tîoin mittee from the Covoriimcnt bc expended only nuder tho snjicrvisiou of the Committee through its own officers." Mr. Livermore could not agrco with the motion, but would propose ns au amendment that " thc sum of £201), out ot the £400 received on aecount "f the pauper fund bc paiil to tho Benevolent' ?Society at once, and £200 ns HUGH as thc funds of thc Hospital permit, say within three months." This was seconded by Mr. Sandel, and put to thc meeting, when thc votes being «pia!, the original motion was \*ut with thc sauie result, and thc Chairman gave bis casting vol« for the original motion, which was therefore carried. It was then suggested thal the Chairman write to tho Covenimeiit, asking whether the £400 is intended for thc Hospita!, and if KO let them clearly state whether the money is to lie sent to thc Benevolent Society, to bo distributed by them independent of thc hospital fund. A letter was read and received from Mr. I!. M. Leigh, tendering bis resignation as a member of thc committee for 1874. After a little further conversation, tho meeting separated.
