articleText:
í%J|oc%inj!t<m §uHeti»,

WITH vrutcii ts t\coKrotirr.u TUB

GLADSTONE OBSERVER.

PUBLISHED DAILY. WEDNESDAY, MAROU IS, 1874.

Tm; circular just issued by thc SECRE

TARV I-'OR l'um.ic LANDS to theCommis

sione n appointed nuder the Act of 1868, may be regarded as the first blast of the new Ministry against thc dummier. It bas not been issued hastily, but pre- pared apparently after searching inquiry

and careful délibération. Mr. STEPHENS

has visited that stronghold of dummy ism, the Darling Downs, and has no doubt satisfied himself that the evil is

one which may not only be abated, but which the Government are bound by all legal means to root out. Still, the issue of the circular is but the initial step, and if dummying is to be suppressed, it must be combated with a strong hand, and by a minister conscious of having a clear parliament-try majority at his back. The question therefore arises, whether in his designs against the dummier, Mr. STE- PHENS is likely to bc supported at least by the lower branch of the Legislature, and by the almost unanimous voice of public opinion.

To give the Government a chance of success, it is requisite that not only should their object be leg.il and proper, but that they should seek to attain it by strictly justifiable means. lt ts not enough that the evil of dummyism ad- mittedly exists, and ought if possible to be extirpated. There is a multitude of other evils from which society ought to be protected, but which it is found practically impossible to .suppress by legal means, or at any rate by means in themselves not unjustifiable. Two wrongs cannot make one right, and therefore it is just possible that dummy- ing may prove less injurious to the pub- lic than the measures adopted for its re- pression. We say may, because we are not altogether without hope that the remedy sought to be applied by the Government will prove morally unexcep- tionable and practically efficacious.

It is commonly argued that all restric- tions upon the purchase of land are in- operative-that the capitalist will always gel all he wants-and that the obstacles placed in his way are but the parent of perjury and other kinds of public de- moralisation. 'Diere is unquestionably much truth in this argument, but on examination we think it «i'll appear that restrictions upon the purchase of land, though an admitted evil, are productive of less mischief than would be created by applying the principle of absolute free trade. It is argued thal were the whole country thrown open to unlimited free selection, the supply of land would be so enormously in excess of the de- mand that speculation would have no existence. Hut the fallacy of this argu- ment is readily shown by reference to accomplished facts.

The waste lands of (he Crown derive

their value from the proximity of population, or by the speculative value they acquire as the magnets which attract population. In thc far west the present occupants, even were thc privilege of unlimited free selection accorded them, would not perhaps care to largely invest in the purchaseof theirbroad acres. Hut in the settled districts, and in the neighbourhood of towns, the

effect of unlimited free selection would be to convert hundreds of square miles of waste lands into enormous private estates-bought, not for actual occupa- tion or improvement, but simply for speculative purposes. Thus we should soon see powerful associations of capitalists buying up the whole of the settled districts at a nominal cost, and retailing them at prices admitting of splendid profits to the seller. By this means we should create a race of wealthy land sharks, continually growing richer at the expense of the actual settler, and to the manifest detriment of the country.

And even in the unsettled and remóle districts, we should soon find that un- limited free selection had deprived the public of the "eyes of the country."

Anyone acquainted with the character of »

our interior must be aware that there are few runs which might not be kept for ever sacred from intrusion by thc judicious purchase of a tend) or even a twentieth of their gross area. There is little doubt that by such means the alienation of one-tenth of the total area of the colony would practically drive the Government out of thc land market, for the area remaining would be rendered actually as well as nominally waste lands of the Crown. Wc think few persons

hold that such a result would be bene- ficial to the colony. The conclusion, therefore, is that restrictions upon the sale of Crown lands, however inadvisable in some respects, are on the whole ab- solutely necessary for the due conser- vation of the public interests.

Once admitting the necessity of restric- tions, it becomes a question for the Legislature to determine as to their nature and scope. And this determina- tion having been expressed by statutory enactment, it is obviously the duly of the Executive to assist by all reasonable means in giving it effect. In im- posing restrictions upon the sale of Crown Lands, the Parliament only expressed the dominant wishes of the community ; and the Government, as representing the majority of the legis- lature, are not justified in permitting those restrictions lo be set at nought. On the contrary, it is their clear duty to see that the intentions of the Legislature are respected, and, if a statute be found ineliicacious, to suggest amendments on the first opportunity. Judged by this rule, it must be admitted that the late Ministryexhibited an indifference towards dummyism which cannot be wholly excused, however exemplary their conduct may have been in other respects. It was probably this indiffer-

ence which induced the new House to strike the blow which led to the recent

change of Government. Rightly or wrongly, the public belief was thai if Mr. I'AI.MKK was not in league with lite dumniier, the hands of his Government were so hampered by their connections that the restrictive provisions of thc Land Act could not be enforced by their

agency.

The circular issued by Mr. STKPHKN'.S appears to lay down for the guidance of the Commissioners, rules well within thc scope of the Land Act itself. So far as we can perceive, there is no undue stringency attached to the restrictive provisions. The directions are plain

and moderate in tone. Hut their effect, if they be enforced with a firm and impartial hand, will be im- portant. lt is open to much doubt, however, whether the present MINISTKK FOR LANDS will be much mote firm and impartial than his predecessors in office. The dtimmier commands influence on both sides of the House, and his boldness and unscrupulousness has been most faithfully reflected by men ranking themselves amongst the Liberal party. Thc DAVKNI'ORTS and the TAVLORS have been held up as types of our most liberal politicians, but in their case liberal opinions have been no obstacle to their engaging in deep-laid schemes to defraud the public of its lands. It remains to be seen whether

these men will lie impartially brought to book, or whether their former services to the Liberal Parly will be held to furnish

an excuse for their recent misconduct. Of one thing Mr. STKI'HKNS may rest assured,-the slightest manifestation of partiality or weakness, either on the part of himself or his subordinates, will ensure his own defeat, and bring disgrace and discomfiture on his party.

AT tlie Police Court yesterday morning, before Messrs. Frank if. Jleddek and diaries Harden, justices, one summons case, AV. Lee e. W. Davis, for a broach nf the Stamp Act, was Rtruck out, there being no appearance of either party.

AT thc Lunatic licccption House, yesterday afternoon, before Messrs. Mosssrs. Frank N. Huddck and Charles Harden, justices, Anna Wells, a recently arrived immigrant per Southern Helle, was charged with being of unsound mind ami not fit to bc .-it large. Constable Hinch proved tho arrest at the Immigration Depot, and Dr. Salmond gave the necessary medical testimony. The Court committal the accused to thc licccption House for one month, to obtain medical treat-

ment.

THE recklessness displayed by butchers' boys while rilling on horseback is proverbial, especially ill Queensland, and their extra- ordinary escapes from death or mutilation arc equally noticeable. Yesterday afternoon ono of these youthful aspirants to the dignity of block and cleaver came to grief in William street, by being thrown violently from thc horse he was riding and dragged along tho mod a considerable distance. Ho picked himself up, however, and leaning against the side of the animal gave vent to several gasping sighs and n few, hut very few, tears. A gentleman who happened to bc near thc spot at thc time ran up and said, *' Arc yon much hurt my poor hoy V"-" No-o-not much-but my hock is oh-painful." The contortions .ind appear- ance of thc lad excited the gentleman's sym- pathy, and he at once announced his intcntiim of sending for assistance, when the Isry ap- parently thinking this au indignity replied iii Btill broken but tinner tones, " Hang that, g- ive us a log up," and rode off very little thc worse for his spill.

TUR meeting convencí in tho School of Arts last evening, for the purpose of arranging the programme and other mattel's connected with the forthcouu'ug Volunteer concert, was fairly attended, despite thc attractions of thc Loyal troupe nt thc Theatre. Tho offers of aid from volunteer musicians was most cucour.iging, and it is evident that nothing but energy on thc part of the committee is requisite to make

the entertainment a financial ag well os % musical success. Au excellent programme was prepared, and we understand that among the performers aro thc names of scver.il lady and gentlemen amateurs who have not before appeared in ltockhamptou.

Thc date of thc concert has been lixed for

Wednesday, Sth April, when His Honor thc Judge and the members of thc Dar will no doubt give their attendance. We observe that a meeting of the monitors of the Volunteer and Town Hands hast been convened for

this evening at thc drill room, aud os nu important place in thc programme has been assigned to thc band, wc have no doubt the performers will make their usually creditable appearance on thc occasion.

articleText:
Cíje|focÍj|ain}!to» Ijulletiii,

WIT« wnicu IB inconrofciTKD mr.

GLADSTONE OJiSTSUVEíl.

PUBLISHED DA.ILY".

THURSDAY. SEPTEMBER 10, 1874.

THOSE who fully comprehend the issues involved in the question of what is termed reciprocal free interchange amongst the colonies, will not be at all surprised at finding our Chamber of Commerce Committee unprepared to discuss it yesterday. It is indeed a question full of complications, and is, as Mr. PATTISON observed, really a measure of protection under the guise of free trade. It may be all very well for Chambers .of Commerce to pronounce affirmatively upon reciprocity as upon any other abstraction, but when the principle comes to be embodied in practice, difficulties of various kinds start up and embarrass the legis- lator. Perhaps the greatest of these is, that it means a relinquish- ment of revenue, which Colonial Treasurers generally can ill afford. The benefit, too, would be problematical. Possibly the South Australian Treasurer might be induced to look with a favour- able eye upon a proposal which, while involving a loss of revenue, would give the public of that colony cheap sugar. But the reciprocity proposed would not have this effect. It would simply place the Queensland sugar grower on a level with his con- temporary in the Mauritius so far as South Australia is concerned, and could not appreciably affect the price of sugar to the consumer in that colony. The wine-producer there would, in fact, get thc benefit of a market in Queensland, but at what cost to the colony of South Australia? Why, simply by loss of the amount previously realised from the sugar duty. The same effect would be produced were the TREASURER to distribute said duty among the wine growers, in proportion to the number of gallons they each manufactured, and there would be the advantage that inter- colonial complications would arise out of the transaction. In Queensland, again, the TREASURER might hand over tlie amount of duty collected on colonial

wine to our sugar-growers, and thus save,

the embarrassment usually attending fiscal diplomacy. Such a distribution of the public moneys would be unparalleled, no doubt, but if it accomplish precisely the same object as reciprocity, it would be a much simpler mode of protecting the South Australian wine-growers against their colonial competitors, and their cheap labour rivals at the Mauritius. If the South Australians desire chea]) sugar, their obviously wisest course will be to abolish the duty altogether ; for even if reciprocity with Queensland lead to the general use of Queensland sugars in pre- ference to those from the Mauritius, the selling price must not be materially reduced, or the Queensland planter would find the benefit of reciprocity mythical. In wine there is more margin for reduc- tion, and there is no doubt that were South Australian wines introduced here

free of duty, both the producer and con- sumer would derive benefit. The former would have a monopoly of the-Queens land market, while the latter would get a pure and wholesome beverage at a moderate price. Birt the expedient would be a clumsy and unsatisfactory one, .ind it certainly would be discordant to the spirit of theage, which seeks to liberate com- merce from all trammels and monopolies, and allow to the people of every portion of the globe the full benefit of its own natural advantages. If the Queensland sugar-grower cannot compete with the Mauritius planter, his wisest course is to direct his energy into some other channel, and raise some product which the soil and climate of Queensland are pre-eminently fitted for. But our belief is, that the case of our planters is not so bad as is represented, and as cheap labour is now procurable in unlimited quantity, we expect to see a continued increase in the sugar exports from this colony.

We must not bc understood to be unfavourable to the introduction of

colonial wine duty free. On the con- trary, we hold that there are reasons of public policy why the impost on all light

wines should be abolished. The almost universal use of ardent spirits is a curse to the colony, and were a sound whole- some wine procurable at a low price, we believe its use would become general, with marked benefit to the general health and social condition of the people. The State would thus lose revenue through the diminished consumption of spirituous liquors, it is true, bul the loss would be more than conterbalanccd by the gain from the quickened industry of the bread-winning portion of the community, and the consequent prosperity of all classes. _ Ardent spirits are - maddening, demoralising, and destructive of the vital energy of their votaries, while pure wine not only gladdens the heart of man, but is also promotive of his bodily health, especially in a climate whose summer heat is decidedly enervating. While, therefore, we have no faith in limited reciprocity, wc are strong advo- cates for the admission of all light sound wines duty free. There is no valid argument for remitting the duty on colonial light wines only, for if Austra- lian wine-growers cannot compete in their own'market with the European article, thc sooner wine-producing ceases to be a local industry, the better for Australia. We believe that intercolonial free-trade can only be satisfactorily realised by means of a Customs' Union, and that limited reciprocity; if tried, will prove an

utter failure.

It is announced in our columns to-day that thc ceremony ot laying thc memorial stone of the new Congregational Church, Bolsover strcet, will take place on Wednesday, tho 23rd instant. Wo understand that thc stone will ho laid by tho Rov. E. (J rillitb, ot Brisbane. Thc ceremony will be followed by a tea meet- ingin thc School of Arts, with thc usual public meeting, at which his Worship the Mayor hus kindly consented tb preside.

AN advertisement notifies that Professor Hoselmaycr intends to rc-opou at thc Theatre Royal this evening, when ho will introduce several new illusions, and, by request, the birds and mice will bc put through their little performances, thc grand cavalry ride, with eight birds dressed in uniform, to conclude tlie entertainment. Photographs of thc Professor are to bo given to every lady visitor dilling the evening. An entertainment for the benefit of thc Hospital is announced for to-morrow (Friday) evening, and as tho funds of the institution need replenishing, we hope tho benefit will bc a substantial one. The "second grand matinee" takes place on Saturday afternoon, and positively the last appearaucc of tho Professor will bc on. the Borne evening.

A CHINAMAN living on'tkc north aide met with a serious loss yesterday in a very simple manner. He was driving a horse and cart laden with firewood into town, and on coming down the incline to moot tho punt, the horse became unmanageable, and began to back thc loaded dray towards thc river. All the efforts of thc celestial to check thc backward progress of thc vehicle down the steep incline proved unavailing, so thc dray was nnloadeii, ¡md then the horse persevered in backii..g thc empty dray into thc stream until, as a last resource, thc horse was released from thc shafts and the dray left to its fate, w"aieh

continued its course until it was out of ruacli from thc punt at low water. The dray has since gone so far down that grappling i runs will be necessary for its recovery.

As one proof among many of thc c:ipahil itics of this district, we have been shown a sai nple of arrowroot grown and prepared by Mi". T. Wright, on the north side, quite equal to any yet manufactured in this colony. Thc vai ïcly from which it was prepared is maralla aritu dinanen, commonly called the white, an d it yielded welL Thc sample ia very (inc and white, and when tested by water, left- no discoloration aftersottTing, and it also thick cued well m cooking. Thc root, wc uudcrst and, after being dug and cleared was simply gr ated into water, and all tho light fibrous m Itter washed out, in several waters. Last of all! thc powder being washed through a tine sieve. When thoroughly cleansed, thc powder was exposed in the sun to dry, and after a. few days, was fit for usc The trial made is suffi- cient to show that a good marketable o rticlu of this commodity can bc produced here at a comparatively trifling cost ; and if it was grown on a large scale, aud proper appl'-ances were nvailahlc for its preparation, it would no doubt bc found romuuerativc to thc producer.

Cj}e|fücl,¡)¡unj!l<m §\\\\û\\\.

wira «inen m INCOMOHTUD TB I

GLADSTONE OBSSUVElt

PUBLISHED DAILY.

WEDNESDAY. SEPTEMBER IC, 1874.

Oem usual monthly Summary ol JICWB, for trausBvission by the English mail, will bu pub-

lished to-morrow.

Ko. I, now series, of a pamphlet entitled " Plain Words," hos just reached us. It is printed by Messrs. Thorne nml Greenwell, of Brisbane, and consists of a lecture delivered by the Bev. Mr. M'G&vin, on thc " Claims of the Papacy in 1874." Wc have been re- quested to notice the pamphlet, and have done so, but must decline to criticise it, the snbjoct teing unsuited for discussion in thc columns of a daily newspaper. .

TUE Gracie Troupe make their first appear- ance this evening in thc Theatre Royal, and judging by the programme, and the reputation of the various artistes, tho entertainment will be a great treat The gymnastic performances of Mademoiselle Gracie and Senor Gonzales are said to lie of a very sensational character, while the minstrelsy of McSBrs, Buckley and Holly has never been excelled in thia hémis- phère. Mr. and Mrs, Briggs have also under- taken to contribute their quota to tho enter- tainment, so that altogether pleasure seekers may look forward to a very agreeable evening.

Sous difficulty has bean experienced in ? getting wool for thc barque Lady Douglas,

now on the berth for London, partly in con. sequence of the season, and portly because of the indisposition to ship in any -way ont of thc regular course. We are glad to learn, how- ever, that some 200 bales were secured yester- day, and that the Captain now BCCS his way to sail with a full cargo in tho first week in November. The roads arc now in good order, and there is no appearance of any interruption to travelling at present. It may be hoped, therefore, that anticipations with regard tn the sailing of the Lady Douglas will bc full}

realised.

articleText:
Cjje If ocíi^ntnnton §uUetin,

IT (Til WHICH ll IttOOBrOIITKP TIIK

GLADSTONE! OßSflRVISR.

PUBLISHED DA.IL.Y.

MONDAY, JULY 27, 1874.

THE failure of the Land Bill, and the non-acceptance of the resolutions pro- viding for the resumption of the runs needed for settlement in the so-called " Settled Districts," leaves the Land ques- tion in a worse state than when the

session began. The attempt to legislate has shaken confidence and raised hopes ;

and the failure has not restored confi- dence, while it has naturally created much disappointment. Our coast squat tages have become almost valueless in tim eyes of capitalists, and intending selectors, who were waiting to pick out the eyes of the resumed runs, have been compelled to postpone their projects indefinitely. It remains to be seen, however, what will bc the effect of thus blocking legislation. It may be hoped that reflection will moderate extravagant opinions on both sides, and at thc re-assembling of Parliament leave ex- treme politicians in a better frame of mind than they have enjoyed during thc

recent session. The " ultras " on both sides wanted a great deal too much. Honorable members who professed to support a " Liberal " Government, wished unceremoniously to drive the Crown tenant into the " back tracks," while several ardent representatives of the grazing interest were determined to yield not one inch of their territory with- out compensation. The Government, in a crooked, clumsy way attempted to con- ciliate the two. They purposed resuming thc whole of the settled districts, whether wanted or not, and leave the unsealed districts sacredly untouched. As a plaister upon thc wound caused by their bill, they purposed also to issue new leases of the confiscated squattages, which were really to afford a better tenure titan was given by the law of 1868. Instead of placingthe interests of

the Crown tenant in the hands of a liberal Government, they would commit them to the tender mercies of the individual free selector, who would have the range of the whole country, from Point Danger to Carpentaria, and the liberty to establish his homestead wherever he thought fit. Each selector might pick out an " eye," and in establishing his isolated residence might at the same time establish a chronic quarrel between himself and the pastoral tenant whose domain he in- vaded. The result would have been the advent of good times for lawyers and poundkeepers, and prolonged and bitter agitation in the political arena. And unfortunately experience teaches that when men differ in politics differences also arise in social matters. A man whose political creed is at fault receives the cut, oblique or direct, from his ac- quaintances, and becomes the unhappy victim of social ostracism. This may not be a very deep cause of grief to the victim, but its effect is not beneficial to society at large, or productive of unanimity of opinion.

Although, therefore, the postponement of resumption, as a solitary fact, is un- doubtedly an evil, it is possibly a less evil than the Ministry proposed to inflict upon the country by their Land Bill. It must be admitted that unnecessary legis- lative changes are pernicious, and that in so far as the changes proposed by the Land Bill were unnecessary they were also undesirable. Wholesale resumption was certainly unnecessary, and as certainly its effect upon the community would have been mischievous. It is on this ground that the Legislative Council may well take their stand, and rind a defence for their otherwise indefensible conduct in throwing out both. Land Bill and Resuming Resolutions. The function of the Council is to resist rash changes, and in this- matter it must be allowed that their resistance was justified. The country wanted land thrown open for settlement, but it did not want the Ministerial Land Bil!. Had the right method been taken in the first instance, the Government might have easily pro- vided the former without agitating the community by the latter. Had resuming resolutions for actual requirements been submitted at the beginning of the session, they would certainly have been adopted by the Assembly without serious demur, and if rejected by the Council would have exhibited that body in no favour- able light. Indeed, it can hardly be

conceived that honorable members of

the Council, musty as their opinions be,

would have ventured to refuse the re-

sumption of land for actual require-

ments.

Of course the Ministerial poltcywillnow be to raise a cry against the upper House and promise to bring in a still more sweeping land bill next year. But it is unfortunate that the imbroglio is chiefly due to their own want of judgment, and that popular indignation will be divided between them and their opponents, instead of being directed in full force against the senile politicians of the Upper Chamber. The continued locking up of the lands is, however, a real public grievance, and unless some of our squatters profit by thc example set by the Messrs. ARCH KU, and voluntarily surrender such portions of their runs as may be needed to supply the bona fide demands of intending settlers, there will be a very pretty quarrel in a fewinonthshence. Sucli aquarrelcan only end in one way, and it may be hoped that Australian histor)' will not be allowed to repeat itself too strikingly in this colony. The Upper House pro- bably feel secure in their life interest scats, bul, most of tile members have attained such nu age that a few years at most will incapacitate them for further mischief. And there are still more summary ways in which anything like increasing systematic obstruction lo i reform may bc effectively dealt willi, lt

' would not bc impossible lo abolish the 1

Liglslatíve Council even without the consent of the present members. But we will hope th?.t so extreme a step will not be found necessary.
heading: The Rockhampton Bulletin, WITH WHICH IS INCORPORATED THE GLADSTONE OBSERVER. PUBLISHED DAILY. MONDAY, JULY 27, 1874.

articleText:
CijeItod^HiiiDtou bulletin,

«un wiiioir II iNcoiroBirxD ina

& li A p S TO ff fl OBSERVE Ä.

PUBLISHED DAILY.

THURSDAY, JULY 23, 1874.

RESUMING our description of the new

Insolvency Act, we find that the creditors | may, if they think fit, appoint more than

one trustee. They may also appoint a | committee of inspection, under whose ! direction thc trustee will be required' to wind up the estate of an insolvent. IJy section io2, any bailiff selling prpperty under execution to the amount of ¿S50 and upwards is required to retain the proceeds for fourteen days, and in the event of notice of the debtor's insolvency being served on him within that period, must hand over the proceeds of sale, less expenses, to the trustee in the estate. In the event of no such notice being re- ceived the proceeds will go to the execu- tion creditor. This is a valuable provision, and ought to be a protection to the insolvent,, as well as to the general body of creditors. It is next provided that in case of anv insolvent's receivina a

I salary, the court may order payment of a

reasonable portion of such salary to the trustee during insolvency. Conveyances which under the provisions of the Act I are deemed acts of insolvency are de-

clared! void, as are also improper ! voluntary settlements and fraudulent

preferences by the debtor. By section IOS a fraudulent preference is declared to. be the conveyance or assignment of property to any creditor, except for rea- sonable and sufficient consideration given at the time, within six months preceding insolvency ; and by the next section any such conveyance or assignment for valu- able consideration is held to be fraudulent, unless proved to have been made in good faith ; and, what is an important innovation, the onus of proof in such case will be on the party alleging the validity of the transaction. It is also provided that pressure by a creditor, or proof that conveyance was made only in pursuance of an antece- dent agreement, shall not protect such a transaction. By section ni, any banker, attorney, or agent of an insolvent is required to deliver all moneys, securities, or papers to the trustee, unless entitled by law to retain the same, and refusal to deliver will be treated as contempt of court. Sections 112 and 113 protect all ordinary business transactions with an insolvent before notice has been received of his insolvency ; and also any seizure under legal process where the execution was issued before the date of adjudication.

With the object of discovering an insol- vent's property, the court may summon and examine witnesses under suspicion ; and no question put to any insolvent will be deemed unlawful by reason only that the answer thereto may be incriminating. Thc court may also order any person who on examination appears to be in- debted to any insolvent, to pay over such »mount, with or without costs. Property belonging to the insolvent may be seized in any room or receptacle, which maybe broken imo for that purpose byan officer of the court, armed willi a warrant. And any person giving information leading to the discovery of concealed property will be entitled to one-tenth of its value as a reward. The trustee, under direction

from the court, may receive and open the post letters addressed to an insolvent; but this power can only be conferred for a period of three months subsequent to adjudication.

General provisions affecting the ad- ministration of estates require that the insolvent should, to thc utmost of his power, assist in the realisation of his property, and in its distribution amongst his creditors; and in thc event of neglect or failure he will, in addition to any other penalty incurred, be punishable for I contempt of court. The trustee is

required, inthe administration of property, to have regard to any directions given at a general meeting of creditors, which i will be deemed to override any directions I given by a committee of inspection. The

trustee is also required to call a meeting of the said committee at least every two months, when they may audit his accounts and determine whether any and what dividend is to be paid. He is also, while allowed discretion in the manage- ment of an estate, required to call general meetings of the creditors from time to time for the purpose of ascertaining their wishes. An appeal from any act or decision of the trustee lies to the court, who may summon general meetings of creditors and direct the registrar to preside at such meetings. The trustee may also apply to the court for advice

or direction.

f _ ' Tn dealing with an insolvent's property, the right to transfer stock or shares will bs vested absolutely in the trustee, who "mûstkëe'p pfôpêr minutes of proceedings

at creditors' meetings, and also books of I account showing all receipts and dis- bursements in the estate, and such books are to be open to inspection by any creditor, personally or by agent. By sections 132 and 133 the trustee's powers to deal with property are defined at length. He may carry on die business of an insolvent so far

as may be necessary for the beneficial winding up of the same, exercise power 1 of attorney ; sell the property of an

insolvent either by public auction or private contract, give receipts for money, and draw dividends. With the sanction of the committee of inspection, the trustee may mortgage an insolvent's property to raise money for the payment of his debts ; appoint the insolvent himself to manage the business or realise ; bring or defend any actions at law relating to the property of the insolvent1; refer a dispute to arbitration, and compromise debts and claims; divide amongst creditors, according to its estimated value, any property .which cannot be conveniently realised upon by sale ; and employ a short-hand writer to take notes at any meeting of creditors or examination under this Act. The

trustee may also accept a composition, with the sanction of a general meeting of creditors, and, after approval by the court, such composition will be binding on all the creditors. By section 136 a trustee is required to pay all moneys into a bank, and if he keep more than £50 in his hands beyond ten days, he will be subject to pay interest at the rate of twenty per cent per annum, and to dismissal without remuneration. This is another attempt to remedy a notorious abuse under the existing law, and as such must be regarded with satisfaction.

Sections 140 to 151 inclusive provide for proof of debts and distribution of assets. Unliquidated damages will not "be provable, nor will debts incurred by

the insolvent after the fact of his in- solvency has been notified. All debts must be proved before the trustee, and the following are to be deemed pre- ferential claims, viz. :-Local rates due within twelve months previous to the order of adjudication, and all wages or salary of any clerk, servant, labourer, pr workman in the employment of the insolvent not exceeding ^50 or three months' wages. All other debts proved are to be paid pari passu. Insolvency terminates apprenticeships, but th* trustee may on application transfer any indenture. No distress for rent may be

levied upon an insolvent after adjudica-1 lion, but a landlord will have a pre- ferential claim to the extent of three months' rent. Interest may also bc

allowed by the trustee, computed up to ¡ the date of adjudication. The trustee, | with the consent of creditors, may make

an allowance to an insolvent for main- J tenance or service. Under section 150 | set-offs are allowed in case of mutual j dealings between debtor and creditor, and provision is subsequently made for

tile protection of secured creditors. j

Dividends must be declared from time to lime, and if the trustee declare no , dividend for a period of si* months, he I must summon a meeting oí creditors,

and tell the reason why. Notice of dividends must be given in the Gazelle and other newspapers. No action for any dividend will lie against a trustee, but he may be ordered to pay it, with interest thereon, out of his own moneys, if tlie Court think fit. Any surplus moneys, after payment of the final dividend, is to be paid to the insolvent.

At the last examination for closing the insolvency, an adjournment may b; ordered if the insolvent's accounts are unsatisfactory, or if he have disobeyed any order of thc court. When thc whole property of the insolvent, or as much as can be realised without needlessly pro- tracting the insolvency has been realised, tlie court will mähe an order that the insolvency has closed ; and at any time after the insolvent has yjassed his last, examination, or at any earlier time after consent by a meeting of creditors, a cer- tificate of discharge may be granted ; but the court must first be satisfied (i) that thc insolvency has arisen from cir-

cumstances which the insolvent cannot justly be held responsible for: or (2) that a spi-cial resolution, expressing the opinion of the creditors to that effect lias been passed ; or (3) thal the gross amount realised in tlie estate is equal tp the total amount of debts proved. The court may also, if it think fit*!, suspend tlie certificate on other grounds. Pro-

vision is further nude for the issue of the certificate after the lapse of time, viz., at the expiration of twelve months,

with the written consent of the; majority of.creditors, or at the expiration'of two

years without such consent. And in the event of such certificate being again withheld, it may be granted with the consent of creditors at the expiration of three years. A certificate may also be granted subject to certain conditions as to the insolvent's salary or earnings. Such certificate will not release the insolvent

j from fraudulent debts, from debts due to

the Crown, or from debts arising from any offence against a statute, or iucurrcd

¡ on a bail bond. But it will bc a full discharge from all other debts. Section 176 fixes the status of an undischarged insolvent No debt provable under the insolvency may be enforced against him for a period of three years after die close of such insolvency, and if after that time he pay up the balance of twenty shillings in the pound he will bc entitled to his certificate of discharge ; and if he have not, at the expiration of titree years, obtained a certificate of discharge, the balance of debts due in insolvency will be deemed a subsisting, debt in the nature of a judgment debt, which, with the sanction of the Supreme Court, may be enforced against property of the

debtor.

The remaining sections of this Act : must be reserved for a third notice. !

articleText:
^c^ocïijainjjton bulletin,

2[wmi wiiicit IM ipicoaroitiTr,» TIIK

GLADSTONE O SS S II FER,

PUBLISHED DAILY.

FRIDAY, MARCH 13, 1874.

IT is even now contended liy many persons that wheat-growing will not pay ort tlic Darling Downs, and we are con- stantly assured thal the selectors there must take to stock-raising or eventually come to grief. The persistency with which this doctrine is laid doini has cer-

tainly obtained for it very general belief, just as in past years it was almost universally held that thc most fertile parts of Queensland would scarcely grow a cabbage. We confess therefore that a return just furnished to the Honor- able the Minister for Land« by the proprietor of the Allora steam flour mills, has overcome us with gratified surprise. It appears that thirty farmers, whose names arc specified, have cultivated an area of 300 acres in the Allora district this year, and that the gross yield of

wheat therefrom is eleven thousand five

hundred and sixty-two bushels, or at j the rate of over thirty-eight bushels to the acre. In South Australia, we observe, the average yield of the year is given as under thirteen bushels lo thc acre, and that is regarded as a good yield. If therefore a yield of thirteen bushels will pay for cultivation, the Darling Downs farmer can afford to lose two crops out of three, and still be little worse off than his South Australian contemporary. So much for thc assertion that wheat-growing in Queensland will not pay.

There is no doubt, however, that these wholesale and reckless assertions have done great injury to the agricultural interest in Queensland, not so much from the weight of authority which has attached to them, as from thc numerous failures made by settlers in this colony. A man who goes into any ordinary business without experience and without capital is seldom expected to succeed, but it has been supposed by many enthu- siasts that the man who undertakes the cultivation of the soil can hardly fail. The truth is that experience, capital, and unremitting industry are just as essential in ihn farnjor ac fra any oilier colonist, and if in thc absence of these, cultivation will not pay, it is childish to lay the blame upon thc soil or climate. Yet this is every day done by many of the most intelligent people in the colony, who would be amongst the first to ridicule such inconsequcntal reasoning if applied to any other of the affairs of life. Still, the fact is undoubted that the assertion that cultivation will not pay, has become a household word, and lias pre- vented the investment of capital in farm- ing pursuits.

In the district of Rockhampton this has notably been the case. Four years ago, when attention was being turned to sugar cultivation in Queensland, one of our oldest and most highly respected colonists delivered a lecture to prove that sugar could not be profitably grown in our district. Rockhampton, lie said, was situated in a dry bell, and the soil on our river banks was not fertile. The uninviting appear- ance of tile land adjacent lo the town attached weight lo this assumption, and hence to this day no capitalist has been imprudent enough to embark money in sugar cultivation here. It is trite that in two different parts of the district a considerable acreage of fine sugar cane was grown, bul the owners lacked ihe capital to provide llie requisite ma- chinery, and hence the cane went lo feed horses and cattle instead of sugar mills. And if in one case ihe unprecedentedly severe frost did much damage, and in the other thc late hurri- cane committed great havoc, those were accidents which might have happened anywhere, and certainly did not go to prove that the cane cannot be profitably cultivated in our district Vet capitalists hang back, and prefer encountering the inconveniences of residence in the far north, to investing their means in a part of the colony which is really, as well as nominally, in the settled districts.

Yet lhere is an unsalable demand fol- land tn the Rockhampton district, and all that is worth having is caught up im- mediately after it is thrown open for selection. Hut it is apparent}}- not «?anted for cultivation. Hain- ' farm- ing and slock raising appears to be tile height of our settlers' ambition, and tims the progress of lite district is extremely slow. Rockhampton owes its prosperity to trudie with the interior, and not to settlement in its neighbourhood, while at brisbane, Mary- borough, and Mackay, the producers of the soil are amongst the best «istomers of the! mechanic and shopkeeper, mid consequently the chief" supporters of the trading community.

Were we not convinced of the utter

fallacy of the dry belt theory as applied to our district, and of the unjust de- preciation lo which the character of its soil has been subjected, we might accept the position of a non-agricultural district without repining. Hut convinced as we are thal no part of the colony presents greater attractions lo the settler com- bining cultivation with grazing, we ? think that some concerted effort

should be made to disprove the unfavorable assertions which have operated as a drag upon the progress of our district. Had a third of the money which was lost in quartz-reefing been invested in sugar-growing, we should have found Rockhampton in a different position to-day. It is therefore just a question whether even now it would not be desirable to form a sugar-growing company, with ample capital. Any unresumed run in die district would be available for a suitable site, and with moderately good management, the enter- prise could not fail. The success of one sugar plantation would quickly lead to the formation of others, and our town and district would forge a-head with fresh impetus. With prosperous settlers in tlie neighbourhood of thc town, and a railway gradually penetrating further into the interior, the greatness of Rockhamp- ton would rest on a basis that no future dry-bell theorist could disturb.

articleText:
Ç|clocï.Îjiim|jton bulletin,

WITH tv men is i it COR roi AT RD Tim

GLADSTONE CBSSRFSn.

PUBLISHED DAILY.

TUESDAY, MARCIE 3, 1874.

Wii.YTKvr.ii success may attend the con- duct of the Harbours and Rivers de-

partment in oilier parts of the colony, there is no denying that so far as the pori of Rockhampton is concerned, its arrangements are characterised hy general bungling and inefficiency. The money spent at various limes in attempting to improve the navigation of the river has been wor.se than thrown away. The steam dredge has been lying idle for years, while the steam-lug Mary, which was originally sent here as a tender to dredge, divides lier time between towing vessels and going under repair. if wanted for any emergency she is seldom available, and if the reports of those connected with her be credited she is

rarely in a seaworthy condition. In the

meantime the loan votes for river im-

provement are being steadily frittered away, with the view, we suppose, of satisfying that rather numerous class in the community who hold thal matters cannot go wrong so long as the money is put into " circulation.'' Persons, how

ever, who take a more enlightened view of tlic subject, hold thal the amount at the disposal of the department might as well have been thrown into the river as spent upon maintaining and repairing a dredge which, judging by the past, is least injurious lo the navigation when laid up. Ami reflection upon the subject is not rendered less dis- agreeable by the knowledge that the dredge might, in skilled hands, have done important service in removing the obstructions which impede the naviga- tion of the river. It may be hoped, however, that steps will now be taken to

i make the dredge as celebrated for utility j

in the future as she has been notorious

for uselessness in the past. The depart- ment appears to admit and regret thal blunders have been made, and in its

case, wc trust, repentance will be the , first step towards radical reform.

lt is with respect to the management of thc steamer Mary, however, that we intend to enter our protest to-day. It is

natural to conclude that if thcGovcrnmcnl find it necessary to own steamships, they will keep them in a state of thorough efficiency. In these times, at any rate, our Government is not troubled with a want of means, and the public have therefore a right to demand that cheese- paring economy shall be no sufficient excuse for inefficiency. Yet the manage- ment of the steamer Mary is chavacter

I ised by extreme parsimony. She is

never placed in thorough repair, bul merely patched up for the time being. She is not even provided with an engineer, but committed to the unskilful

hands of an untrained man who acts as

engine-driver. Thc expenses of the vessel, it is said, are limited to six pounds per week, and this amount docs not

suffice for the remuneration of skilled labour. Surely the force of folly could no farther go, even were the steamer a permanent charge upon the revenue. Uut in consideration of the fact that her earnings, independent of mail carrying, have amounted to an average of over two hundred pounds a month since September last, the false economy complained of must be regarded as a crime rather than a blunder. In the event of a " blow-up," or any other fatal accident occurring through want of skilled surveillance, the public would demand that the responsibility bc placed on the right shoulders.

Tile justice of these remarks is seen in the " masterly in- activity" displayed by the authorities yesterday. On Sunday evening, the intelligence reached (own that a large vessel dismasted had been that morning driven within sight of the Haid Hills, and that she then lay at anchor in an exposed and dangerous part of the coast. The Mary had started just before the news <:aine to hand, but she should have been at Glad- stone by daylight yesterday morning, and was then within twelve hours' steam ol

the distressed vessel. A telegram might have been sent dispatching her to the rescue, and by nine or ten o'clock last night she should have been alongside the ship. The public have an undoubted right to ask why was not this done, and to receive an unequivocal answer. If il be alleged that the Mary is unseaworthy, and therefore could not be <lis|vitched tc a spot within fifty miles of the Keppel Kay pilot-station, the authorities will certainl) be held responsible for the mischief thai may ensue. If the dismasted vessc prove to be the Southern Helle, with 42c passengers on board in addition to tin seamen, the consequences of delay 111.11 be terribly serious.

There is less excuse for the conditioi of the Mary, on the ground that withii the past six months she was subjected t<

I a so-called " thorough overhaul " at the

expense of the Loan Fund. The vole of ,¿5000 for improving the navigation of the Fitzroy was misappropriated to

J the repairs of the steamer, and there being

a large unexpended balance of that fund still available, thc department cannot plead want of money as an excuse for botching their work. 'Chere is, indeed, so much of the odour of corruption about the whole business that it may be hoped the new TREASURER will make it the subject of a searching inquiry before

Parliament assembles.

After thc above was written, the plans of the Harbour Department had suffi- ciently matured to admit of their laking decisive action. As will be learnt from our news columns, arrangements were made yesterday afternoon for employing the steamer Queensland to tow in the disabled ship ; but as that steamer had not then lelt Maryborough, and will have to call at llundaberg and Gladstone, she cannot go to the relief of the ship until Wednesday. This delay might have been of little consequence, but it might also have resulted in needless loss of life and property. Urgent represen- tations were therefore' made to Captain RtiNiii.!'. yesterday afternoon, which induced him to telegraph a peremptory order to Gladstone for the Mary, s., to start immediately for the ship, it is not supposed that the steamer will be able to low the vessel into Keppel Ha)', but she may take off the possibly starving passen- gers and crew, or give such other succour as the exigency of the case may demand. There can he no doubt that this tardy step of the Harbour-master was a proper one, but the question still remains Wliy was not the Mary dispatched some six or seven hours earlier? We shall be told that Captain Ri'NW.r. had no power to act without authority from Ilrisbane, but the public will not accept that as a justification, however willing they may bc lo admit it as a colourable excuse, f In the face of it the plea is absurd. Were five hundred lives known

to be in imminent peril within fifty miles of Rockhampton, shall we be told that tile Mary could not get up steam, and go to the vessel without a departmental order from Hrisbane ? If so, the regu- lation is worse than absurd. The HARHOUR-MASTKR must have some

discretionary power, and the public reasonably demand that in all urgent cases he shall burst the bonds of red tape, and act promptly on his own responsibility. Common humanity de- mands that a public officer shall afford the earliest possible succour to ship- wrecked people, even at the risk of a subsequent departmental snubbing.

We sincerely hope that the delay complained of will not prove disastrous in this instance. If so, the public may rejoice that, without any startling loss of human life, circumstances have occurred to show thc imperative necessity of greater discretionary power being com- mitted to local hands, and of greater promptitude and /eal being displayed in

thc exercise of it.
heading: The Rockhampton Bulletin. WITH WHICH IS INCORPRORATED THE GLADSTONE OBSERVER. PUBLISHED DAILY. TUESDAY, MARCH 3, 1874.

articleText:
^egocï^amptoit bulletin,

wira willen ?. incoaroiiTi-i- TIIK

GLADSTONE OB SK RV IC R.

PUBLISHED DA.ILY".

TUESDAY, JOLY 21, 1874.

A SUPPLEMENT to the Government Gazette, of the nth instant, contain in- structions issued to the several benches of Magistrates, Clerks of Petty Sessions, and others charged with lite duty of carrying out the provisions of the Elec- tions Act of 1874. As the Act makes important changes in the mode of pre- paring tile electoral rolls, a brief descrip- tion of measure will not be without

interest

On or before the rst August the Conn of Petty Sessions of every police district is rei|iured by section 12 to appointa member of the police force to !»e a

colIectorofclector.il lists, and -'-i as ? many assistant collectors as may be requisite. Thc next clause provides for llie appointment of other than police as collectors where nci .ssary, and the next that thc police when so ! employed sliall be entitled to no addi

donal remuneration. It is now the 21st

j July, and the instructions to appoint I collectors have but just reached here.

In the more remote parts of the colony, the probability is that the ist of August

will arrive before thc instructions come to band, so that the ro!!s ii) sucli places will not be legally prepared under the new Act. This may be of little conse- quence, but it might prove inconvenient did Mr. MACALISTER deem it expedient to appeal to the country ; for were several electorates unprovided with new rolls, the GOVERNOR would be furnished with

a potent argument against granting a dis- solution when an important portion of the constituent body would be disfranchised through official tardiness in bringing the new law into operation. In the Central districts, however, the Mitchell is the only electorate in which it may be found impracticable to comply with the require- ments of the Act in this respect.

The collectors having made a declara- tion to ensure faithful performance of the duties imposed upon them, will start on their journeys through the various electorates, and before the 31st August must prepare alphabetical lists of all persons qualified to vote within their respective districts. These lists are to

show in the usual form where each elector

resides, what is his qualification, and where his property is situate or how his claim arises. This information, be it observed, is to be supplied by the collector, and it will easily be understood how want of fidelity or care on Iiis part may be thc means of disfranchising qualified persons, and of enfranchising those who have no claim to vote. It is true that any persons omitted by the collector may send in his claim to enrolment, in writing, at any time before the 10th October, but the fear is, that the Government having undertaken the duty of collecting the names, no one will think it necessary to

ascertain whether his name has been placed on the list or not. It is apparent, therefore, that tlte business will need closely watching, for, unfortunately, the police, although disqualified from voting, have sometimes very strong political predilections. Such persons, the " in- structions" state, the Courts should carefully abstain from appointing as col- lectors ; but the greatest care that may possibly be exercised will form but a poor guarantee to the public. We

believe the collection of electors'names in

this manner will be found liable to great abuse, and that without some organisa- tion in the populous electorates a great many qualified persons will be missed by the collectors, and find themselves dis-1 franchised at election times. However, thc new system is now the law of the land, and it will be the duty of every good citizen to aid in making it as

effective as possible. I

The lists once prepared must be

handed to the respective clerks of petty j sessions, and be by them exhibited during the last fourteen days of Sep- tember. During the succeeding ten

days, any person named in such list may , forward a written objection against any other person, but it must be accompanied by a deposit of five shillings, which on the order of the revision court, may be appropriated to the payment of costs in the event of the objection not being sustained. The court may also order the payment of any further sum by way of costs, and levy for the amount by the ordinary process.

The revision courts must be held be- tween the i st and 21 st days of November,

and due notice of them must be given j in the local newspapers or otherwise ' made public. The proceedings at such ? courts do not materially differ from those

under the late Act. All names on the I lists, not objected to, must be retained, and in thc case of applications in writing from individual claimants, " the declara- ¡ " rion contained in the notice of claim " is prima .facie evidence of the qualifi " cation claimed, and in the absence of " any valid notified objection, entitles " the claimant to be inserted in the " lists." This is a decided improvement on tlie old law, which left it to the discretion of the revision court either to receive or reject an application.

The qualifications of electors are thus briefly set out in the " Instructions ":

(1.) Residence in the district for thc sis

montas immediately preceding the making out of thc electoral list.

(2.) Possession, for thc like period, of a

freehold estate, situate in the district, and worth £100 above all encum- brances.

(3.) Occupation, for a like period, of any

house, warehouse, counting-house, office, shop, or other building, situate in thc district, of thc clear annual valuo of £10.

(4.) Possession of a leasehold estate, situate

in thc district, of the annual value of £10, held upon a lease having not less thau eighteen months to run after thc timo of making out the list.

(5.) Possession of a leasehold estate, so

situate, and of thc annual value of £10, of which possession hos been held for at least eighteen months immediately preceding the making out thc list.

(G. ) Thc holding for six months previous to

making out tho list, a license from the (lovcrnmciit to depasture lands within

the district.

No aboriginal native of China, or of the South Soa Islands, or of Australia, ni-of India, should bc inserted in any list, unless he holds a free- hold qualilicatiou, that is, unless he holds No. 2 of thc qualifications abovc-mcutiouol.

A freehold estate is .111 estate held for the life of the holder, or for the lifo of another person, or any greater catite : where the estate is held for a term of years, or for any period less than tho Ufo of thc holder, or less than, the life of another person, the estate is not

freehold.

Where property of tho character described1 in qualifications 2, 3, 4, 5, 0 above-mentioned, is jointly owned, occupied, or held by moro

than ono person, each person should he entered ! on thc list as entitled to vote in respect of the \ property, if thc value of his individual interest ; separately considered equals thc limit of value, j

Thc following persons are disqualified from licing electors, and their names, therefore, : should not be inserted in any list :

(1.) Persons of unsound mind.

(2.) Persona in receipt of aid from any

charitable institution.

(3.) Persons attainted or convicted of treason,

felony, or other infamous crime, in any part of Her Majesty's dominions who have not received a free or conditional pardon, or undergone his sentence.

Tm: names of thc magistrates ou thc rostcr f.x attendance nt the Police Oourt this morn- ing are Dr. Salmond and Mr. M. S. Rundle, 1 J.'si*.

PUBLISHED DAILY.

FRIDAY, AUGUST 28, 1874.

AT tho Police Court yesterday, the only business disposed of was the constituting Mads Eshcnseu a British subject, by the oath and

forms of naturalisation.

IN our notice of the series of special religious services in yesterday's issue wc omitted to mention thc last, which is to bo held in St. Paul's Church of England, on Monday fortnight, September 15, at half-past seven o'clock.

AT thc Lunatic Roccption House, yesterday, before tho Polico Magistrate and Mr. V. Ñ. Bcddck, J. P., Helen Carroll was charged with being of unsound mind and unfit to bc at large. Ou thc evidence of Dr. Salmond, who had been called upon by tho Rev. Dcau Murlay to ex- amine her, she was committed to the Lunatic Reception House for one month, for medical caro and treatment, the Doctor stating that in all probability the mouth would be sufficient, as, from thc history of thc case, drinking to excess was tho apparent causo of lunacy.

THE Courier's correspondents report thc following movements of stock:-From Banana, under date 8th August, wo are informed of the departure of the Mantuan Downs sheep for New England. Both shearing and lambing

commence this month all round Banana. 7000 ewes and wethers, Messrs. Mackay and Devereux's, from Huntly Downs, Peak Downs, passed St. George on thc 13th instant ; they travel by Walgett, New South Wales, and are for sale, condition fair; Mr. W. C. Brown in charge. From thc Kennedy it is re- ported that thirty bulls, bred by Mr. Beard- more, of Cressbrook, bave been sold here at au average of £23 10a. per bead. Messrs. Hay- lock, Clarke, and Wilson, were thc purchasers, thc former taking thc greater number. Messrs. Barker's cattle, I hear, left Exmoor yesterday for Carpentaria Downs. They arc still in charge of Mr. E. Favenc, and have been much benefited by their stoppage there.

Cbc Eocïïi^amiitoîi Bulletin

WITH WHICH If lIVOftrOKlTKD TfTK

O LID S TO FE O USER. VE R.

PUBLISHED DAILY.

MONDAY, MARCH Ni, 1874.

Tim Rockhampton Separation move- ment has proved an unquestionable benefit to thc country, by compelling a fair adjustment of thc representative powerof thc colony, and by securing some approach to an impartial distribution of the public expenditure. It may be hoped that the new agitation threatened by the extreme northern members will have a similarly beneficial effect, by com- pelling a decentralisation of the Public Works and Land departments. Already the attention of many southern politicians has heen directed to this matter, and several of the best informed among them are known to be advo-

cates of the system of entrusting purely local matters of administration to thc management of the people them- selves. As yet, howeve1;, there is no

well-defined idea as lo the form Mecen-;

tralisation should lake, bul ¡Ls advocates may feel gratified at the admission that some change of system must ere long bc made. In another column will be found portions of a leading article cut from our last files of the Brisbane Courier, a jour- nal which may now with some justice claim to represent the opinions of our most enlightened and thoughtful public men. Our contemporary's observations are of a general character, and though excellent of their kind, do not give much assistance to the practical legislator, who must, we suppose, be left to solve the problem in his own way.

THE members nf tlio famous "Loyal troujio," arrivotl hist night hy thc Queensland, s., and announce a (irHt performance at thc Theatre Iluyul to-morrow evening.

Mi;. Aw lliiitro ,Sri;vi;N*s, of Robson's Troupe, informs us that the wire is stretched in its position in thu Cremorne Gardens, and hchaswalkcdacrossit. Thcarrangciiioiitsmade for thc day's entertainment arc first-class, a good programme of sports and prizes being in preparation, and our old friend, Dan Briggs, is to superintend tho refreshment depart-

ment.

IN vating tho Civil Service Estimates a few «lays ago, tho members of the Legislative Assembly at Sydney indulged in au acriinonous discussion with regard to two appointments made by the Treasurer from thc public outside, passing over thc claims of men who had been long in thc service. Thc Treasurer was very hard pressed hy various speakers, and «lid not improve matters hy saying thc vacancies could not be lilied up with competent officers from thc ranks of civil servants. Ultimately Mr.

Parkes came to the rescue of his hon. colleague, j observing that "ho (Mr. Parkes) for one, did not subscribe thu doctrine that gentlemen in thc public service were not to expect pro- motion ; nor did he on thc other hand, sub- scribe the doctrino, that they were to receive promotion in every case in priority. Thc rule was a sound one, that when any situation in thc public service was to ho filled, those who

stood next in thc service should have it, if I they were thoroughly competent to perform thc duties. (Hear, hear.) He held that it would take away every reason for good con- duct, if the gentlemen in thc public service could not look forward with a tolerable amount of conlideucc to promotion, if their efficient service justified the promotion. But that mle was not to bc applied in any unreasoning haphazard way, hut in view of tho public interest,

If it was found necessary, in thc interest of thc public, to take sonic stranger and appoint him over thc hcails of a dozen men, it ought to bc done. In this instance thc question was whether thc linties performed hy the person who had been appointed could have been per- formed hy auy olliccr already in thc depart- ment. He thought tlic Treasurer was thc best judge of that. Ile Avas not personally aware of thc appointments until he heard them brought forward this evening. But in all that had been said, ho had. failed to see any pre- sumable grounds for mistrusting the decision of the Treasurer. If thc Miuistcr was to have thu confidence of thc Pariiamcnt.it all, he waa certainly to bc trusted to do what was right iu i k cose of this kiud."

articleText:
WITH WHICH IS ÎBCOEPOliTKD TUF,

GLADSTONE O BS ERVE II.

PUBLISHED DAILY".

TUIWUAY, FHHIIUAKY 17, 1874.

! MK. l.iu.r.v's .ippoiiilmcnl lo the

Acling-Judgeship will excite lillie sur-: prise. Tile illness of Mr. Justice LUT-j wenn, .'ind llie accumulating arrears of legal work, rendered some immediate provision necessary lo prevent an aggravation of the law's ordinary delays. And as, independent of thc declining health of thc senior judge, the necessity of further additions lo tho Hench was generally recognised, we may not only anticipate that Mr. LILI.KV'S temporary appointment is hut a step towards a permanent judgeship, bul also presume that at least one other appointment of a similar nature will soon follow. A third judge has been talked of for months past, and the general impression is that

the selection would have been made long ago but for the circumstance thal the judge-designate was pledged to the country to finish his political career by completing some "further public labours." The recent action of party politics has indefinitely postponed the fulfilment of this pledge, and we cannot blame Mr. LILLEY if he has at length concluded that the exigency of the public service eleases him from thc obligation. His path of duty, we think, is distinctly marked, and if we regret the delegation of educational reform to other " trusty hands," regret is tempered by thc belief that what the public loses in one way by the change, it is likely to be fully reimbursed in the other. The truth seems to be that Mr. LILLEY had occu- pied the position of a leading politician ?while lacking sonic of its more important qualifications, and thal in consequence thc public will suffer no appreciable loss by his withdrawal from the Legislature. On the other hand, his accession to the Supreme Court Hench may be expected to confer some important benefits upou thc country. On the whole, therefore, bis elevation must be deemed a matter to bc regarded with satisfaction by the public.

The new appointment is fortunately in harmony willi political traditions. In the mother country, elevation to the Judicial Bench has been ever regarded as the well-earned reward of lengthened public services ; and the Legislature has consequently attracted thc most powerful and cultivated intellects lo be found in Die ranks of the legal profession. As a politician Mr. LILLEY has had a lengthened career, and if he has failed to attain the highest success as a public man, it cannot be denied that he has I done yeoman service to the State. A I legal education is perhaps nol advan-

tageous to a man aiming lo become a leading politician. Habitual indulgence in hair-splitting may sharpen the intel- lect, but it can hardly tend to strengthen tlie force of conviction, or lo foster decision of character. An old writer says

" I know you lawyers can with cose

Twist your wonls ami moaniuga aa yon

please ;

That language hy your skill uinrlv pliant Will bond to favour every client ; That 'tis thc foo directs thu sense

To make out either side's pretence. "

No one who has watched our parlia- mentary debates can have failed to per- ceive the frequent special pleading of (he legal members. There has been no fee to direct the sense, il is true, bul there has been anger, personal dislike, and ambition. And il is no serious dispa- ragement to Mr. Lru.t'v to observe that his skill in making language pliant has often excited doubts of his perfect sin- cerity. His earnestness appears lo be worn like a garment, his indignation is invariably tempered by à smile, ami his most persuasive pleading excites doubt as to whether the speaker t's quite con- vinced of the justice of his cause. In him, therefore, the firmness indispensable to a leader has often borne the aspect of caprice and obstinacy, and hence he found it impracticable to drag his intel- ligent followers into what were, even lo himself, unfathomed depths. No leader of an Opposition ever had a better chance of success dian Mr. Lt LI .LY when, willi a majority al his back, he first con- fronted the PAI.MLR administration ; and no leader ever owed his failure lo a series of more egregious blunders than did Mr. I.ti.t.KYou that oc<xiston. And when failure compelled abdication, a recriminatory speech converted the defeat of his followers into a discreditable tout, lt is but just to add, however, that his demeanour since that remarkable mistake has been unexceptionable, and that his political career terminated in a laudable and successful attempt to re-c.nile the scattered fragments of his party, and to form a Liberal administration under the leadership of his formet rival, lt is true that his self-abnegation was assisted by the knowledge that he was about to be called to a higher sphere of duly. Dut

Iiis conduct was raised above suspicion by the circumstance that it was his poli- tical opponents who first cleared for him an avenue to the judicial bench. Thc ermine was freely at his disposal before the PALM ¡cu Ministry succumbed, and, had Mr. MAÇAI.ISI'KR failed to grasp the reins of power, his elevation would have in no way been endangered. His ap- pointment will therefore secure the stamp of public approval, and »vc are persuaded the universal hope is that Mr. Justice Lu.i.KV will long adorn the high and honoured position to which he has been

called.

For the now vacant seat in the Assem- bly there are already two candidates. Both belong to the legal profession, and one-Mr. GARRICK-hasjircviouslyoccu pied a seat in our Legislature. With Mr. I.II.LHV'S careel'before them, it is not lo be wondered at that the members of the bar are anxious lo step into his shoes, or that the profession look upon the Valley electorate as their lawful prey. Il is difficult, however, lo understand how any doubt can exist as to thc result of tile contest should no other candidates take the field. Mr. BLAKK is a deter- mined opponent of the LII.I.F.V scheme of education, while il may be fairly pre-

sumed that Mr. GARRICK'S are thc

" trusty hands " which are to carry the revised bill through thc dangerous pas- sages of parliamentary conflict. Under these circumstances il is devoutly to be wished that Afr. BLAKK may only add another to his list of defeats. He is the unscrupulous emissary of denomination alism, and we have no doubt the intelli- gent electors of the Valley will so regard

him.
