articleText:
Cíic IJocMjatnplûu bulletin,

IV I TH WHICtt IS IKCOftrOKlTHI THC.

Qi, ADS TONE 0 HS IC RV Eil.

PUBLISHED DAJLY".

SATURDAY, AUG DST 22, 1874.

Tins morning our excellent Go visit NOR resumes his tour, and bids us a last fare- well. As he told us on Thursday, this is his third and final visit. It would be

idle were we lo pretend any very ardent personal attachment to his EXCELLENCY. He has been but three years in the colony. He has been amongst us but lluee times. And Iiis acquaintanceship, even willi most of our leading citizens, has been necessarily slight Warm affection is a product of slow growth, and one essential to its existence is personal contact. That, in the case of the MARQUIS OF NORMANDY and tile people of Rockhampton, circumstances have prevented, and personally they only know him as a comparatively new arrival in the colony, and an occasional and distin- guished visitor, whose exalted official posilion forbids intimacy, and willi whom familiarity is impossible. His EXCEL- LENCY'S noble ancestry, his reputa- tion as an English politician, Iiis individual worth, and Iiis discreet bearing on all public and private occasions have, however, placed him very high in thc esteem of the colonists, and therefore Iiis premature departure has been heard of with general regret. The proverb tells us thal good people arc scarce, and, even in the recollection of the nollie MARQUIS' predecessors, we cannot but feel that among future Governors we may never meet his like again.

But it is as thc representative of our most gracious SOVEREIGN that His EXCELLENCY has the greatest claim upon our regard. It is in the departure of an experienced, impartial, and strictly con si itutional governor that we shall sustain the greatest deprivation. It can never bc forgotten that when his EXCELLENCY landed in the colony our political affairs were in a slate of chaos ; that legisla- tion was impossible through the viru- lence of contending politicians; that north was arrayed against south ; and that a dismemberment of thc colony appeared at the time inevitable. At the metro-

polis, our chief centre of population, the Ministry of the day were intensely unpopular ; and consequently if thc GOVERNOR was not called upon lo dis- trust the counsel of Iiis constitutional

advisers, he could not accept it without incurring heavy responsibilities. The circumstances were peculiarly trying, and when the newly arrived GOVERNOR found parly feeling run so strong that the citizens of Brisbane refused lo join the Government of the colony in a loyal demonstration, the effect must have been most chilling. The fact that the munici- pal authorities pulled down the triumphal arches erected by the Government was, however, one of the least discouraging symptoms. A far more ominous circum- stance was the leaguing together of cx Ministers of the Crown and aspirants to tile Supreme Court Bench in a factious alliance to maintain the repre- sentative chamber of the Legislature in

a condition of dead-lock. If these

energetic measures of obstruction did not assume the appearance of sedition rather than legitimate political agitation, it must be conceded that to an English politician just arriving from the birth- place of modern constitutional govern- ment, the distinction between sedition and legitimate party action must have seemed to be very finely drawn. The occasion was a very anxious one, and the new GOVERNOR must have felt that no ordinary dangers and pitfalls beset his path.

A less experienced politician might have been tempted to arbitrate between the contending factions, and to trust that by his interference the combatants would, if they coulds not entirely cease hostilities, be at least induced to " fight fair." Bul Governor NORMANDY, by his action, evinced a thorough appre- ciation of the evil of meddle- someness. He started with thc assump- tion that the people of Queensland were living under representative institutions, and that all the grievances complained of must be redressed by constitutional means, and by such alone. He there- fore remained an apparently listless and unimpassioned spectator of the struggle. He let matters take their course, until appealed to by a parry who, while ad- mitting themselves the minority in thc Legislature, declared that they were thc representatives °f lne majority outside. As such representatives they addressed his EXCELLENCY by a written memo- randum, declaring their want of con- fidence in his constitutional advisers. Here was a dilemma out of which a less capable Governor than Lord NORMANDY would have found extrication difficult. Dut he treated the appeal with at least assumed indifference. Iii thc first place he, as Ht:u MAJESTY'S representative, knew nothing of thc Parliamentary few who rcpresenlcd the outside majority ; ami, secondly, he never yet knew a Ministry to enjoy the confidence of thc Opposition. This reply was quaintly pul, bul in such a way as no longer to admit of argument, lt turned the famous " key lo the position," and pul the Ministry of the day in full com- mand of the parliamentary fortress, lt removed the drag-chain from the wheels of the slate coach, and permitted its veteran driver to again direct it in the path of progress. ll is trite thal attempts at obstruction were afterwards renewed, but " the representatives of the people outside" found themselves divided and utterly incapable of main- taining the conflict. Their SAMSON was shorn of his locks, and he himself received intimation that he no longer enjoyed the confidence of his ona followers. Thus the Opposition soon cnmibled away, and the members of our representative chamber were taught a wholesome lesson. There is not

likely to be a dead-lock again, at any rate between opposing par- lies in the same House; and it may be also hoped that no such misfortune will ever occur between the two chambers. That differences of a serious character will arise there is only lo much reason to dread, but it may be hoped that there is enough patriotism among our public men to prevent a repetition in any form of the evils arising from so unjustifiable a departure from constitutional practice.

In thus referring to the conflicts of the

past, we have no desire to rekindle old * animosities. But in simple justice to our j departing GOVERNOR, we are bound to contrast'"thc peace and contentment of the present with the hostilities and violent party feeling of former years. His EX- CELLENCY, immediately after taking the oaths of office, was called upon to act entirely upon his own discretion. There was not a man in the colony to whom he could look for advice. There was the recommendation of his responsible ad- visers, no doubt, but it became his duty to decide whether they were, as alleged, mere usurpers of power, and deserving of ignominious dismissal. The current of public opinion in thc southern part of the colony had already pronounced in the affirmative, and the Press were almost unanimous abettors of the " Liberal Opposition." His EXCELLENCY'S de- cision proved correct, but in the then attitude of parties he must have watched its effect will) deep anxiety. Now every- one admits the propriety of the course taken, for " nothing succeeds like success." But, it is a fact, nevertheless, that at thc lime alluded lo there were

confident predictions of his EXCEL- LENCY'S early recall. Instead, he has been rewarded with promotion, and never was reward more justly earned.

The public of the colony owe a debt of gratitude to the Marquis of NOR- MANDY, and we are glad to observe that even in thc metropolis this conviction is rapidly gaining ground, and that his EXCELLENCY, if not quite a popular Governor, is one almost universally respected and esteemed. In Rock- hampton he has always been highly appreciated, and the reception given on this his farewell visit cannot have been otherwise than gratifying. His EXCEL- LENCY departs this morning willi tho best wishes of all classes amongst us. That he may have a long and prosperous career is, we are persuaded, the heartfelt desire of thousands of residents in this part of the colony.

THE visit of the PREMIER to Rock-

hampton can liardly fail to &e productive of good. He came here as the head of the Government, il is true, bul also as the leader pf a political party which has been uniformly unfriendly towards the

central and northern districts of the

colony ; and tile honorable gentleman was personally unpopular,-so much sa, indeed, that at one time rudeness was deemed necessary lo vindicate thc con- sistency of the town, and to mark the resentment felt for past injuries. Hut, happily, on reconsideration, more worthy counsels prevailed, and it was deter- mined to entertain our Ministerial visitor with becoming cordiality. This deter- mination once arrived at, our leading

citizens treated Mr. MACALISTER as

their guest, and a stranger would have found it difficult to discern even a trace of party feeling in their deport- ment On the other hand, it is due to the PREMIER to say that he also waived personal and political differences, and accepted the attentions of his entertainers with perfect good feeling. Thus a truce was not only declared, but possibly the foundation of a better understanding in future was laid. If Mr. MACALISTER has not felt called upon to confess penitence for past neglect, our citizens have equally avoided committing them- selves to any ratification of the Ministerial policy, past, present, or future. There is the mutual understand- ing that we shall agree to differ, and thal we shall give support to any Administra- tion which shows itself capable and desirous of meting out equal justice to all parts of the colony. Still there is reason to believe that Mr. MACALISTER has been gratified with the progress of the town and the energy of ¡ls inhabilan ts ; and probably, among other facts, he has discovered that wc are not undeserving of some attention from he Government. He has found that

_ a community we are characterised by singular unanimity in public matters, and that we are not unacquainted with the duties and privileges appertaining to citizens of a free and prosperous country. He has not been bored by money begging deputations, and he tells us that

such as did wait upon him have departed ; "perfectly satisfied." Perhaps we may infer that the satisfaction is mutual, although it has not transpired that our guest has made a single promise beyond the perfectly safe one thal all matters laid before him shall receive " careful consideration." Our hope is, however, thal a renewed personal acquaintance with the town, its prospects and its wants, will enable Mr. MACALISTER lo judge of the reasonableness or otherwise of fuñiré applications. We are not likely hereafter to bc told, at any rate, that Rockhampton has fallen to thc position of a third or fourth rate town, or that it has been pampered by unjusti- fiable government expenditure. Mr. MACALISTER has failed to discern thc evidence of that extravagant outlay which his party declare has been lavished upon our district, for the very simple reason

that no such evidence exists. Thc ex-

penditure which figures so largely in official returns has been upon thc Northern Railway, and thc Government have «Teated a valuable asset from which the Treasury will soon derive a large revenue. I n other respects the town and district, even in the palmy days when the late Government were in power, has fired but scant ly.

lt is unnecessary, however, to occupy sp« in further discussing this subject lo-d;iy. The public here, we believe, are quite willing to Jet byegones be byegoncs, but if they exhibit a disposition

to 'doubt the sincerity of Ministerial J

promises, not even Mr. MACALISTER can i justly blame their scepticism. Wc will ; hope, in conclusion, that the future con- ; duct of the Government will be such as ; to justify their prolonged existence, in which case we can promise that they with not meet with hostility or un- generous criticism from thc people of Rockhampton.

Tm; best thanks of the public of Rockhampton are due to the MAYOR and aldermen and other gentlemen asso- ciated in the GOVERNOR'S Reception Committee, for thc admirable manner in which the duties imposed upon them were carried out. There may possibly have been some slight incompleteness in the arrangements, but on the whole the pro- ceedings of the week have reflected great credit upon the community. The labours of thc Committee haye been arduous a7)d unintennitting, and they are entitled to distinct public recognition. Everyone who has the true interests of the town at heart must feel grateful and proud thal wc have representative men amongst ns cai>able of uniting cordially and effectively in promoting the public weal.
heading: The Rockhampton Bulletin. WITH WHICH IS INCORPORATION GLADSTONE OBSERVER. PUBLISHED DAILY. SATURDAY, AUGUST 22, 1874.

articleText:
Cj5e$(ociijj!unpl(m §ulíetiu,

WITH «I11CU lb 1KCDRT0XLTKU TUB

GLADS TO NE OBSERVER.

PUBLISHED DAILY".

SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 5, 1874.

Tm-: prospectus of the "Northern Steamboat Company" is now before the public. Tlie designation of the Company is somewhat less pretentious than was at first suggested, but the change, wc think, will generally be deemed an improvement In fact, the effort is and professes to be a modest one. It does not contemplate taking the colony by storm, or provoking active opposition from the A.S.N. Company. It seeks to provide steam- boats for a trade which that Company does not deem worth cultivating, and consequently no feeling of antagonism ought to be created when the little vessels of the new Company make their appearance in our waters. There is no desire, we believe, on the part of the promoters to take up an aggressive attitude towards the A.S.N. Company. It is held that the want of means of

shipping cargo to the northern ports is a grievous injury to the mercantile com- munity here. So far as steam communi- cation is concerned, our merchants are absolutely cut off from all the ports north of Bowen, and to restore that com- munication is the primary object of the Northern Steamboat Company. It is, therefore, simply a defensive movement, and as such ought not to provoke hostility. .

It is unnecessary for us to occupy space to-day in pointing out the advantages the proposed Company is likely to confer, both upon Rockhampton and the ports farther north. The pro- spectus will be found to supply con- clusive arguments on that matter ; indeed, no business man ought to to need instruction on a subject in winch he is so deeply interested. But others amongst us have also an impor- tant indirect interest in the question of steam communication with the north. The more the trade of Rockhampton expands, thc greater will be thc value of its warehouses, shops, and business sites. If, therefore, our property-holders per- ceive their true interests, they will not only wish success to the movement to establish the new company, but also take care that their names appear on the list of shareholders. The capital needed is not great, and if all join, the amount required from each shareholder will not press heavily on any. Of course, we assume that all engaged in trade will do their best, and not expect out- siders to do everything for them. The gentlemen present at yesterday's meeting did not shirk their responsi- bilities in this matter, at any rate, and we hope those traders who were not in attendance, will show their sympathy with the movement in a practical shape.

We have, however, no intention to make an ad miscricordiam appeal on behalf of the new Company. If well managed, it can hardly fail to prove a financial success, and we think that, on glancing at fhe names on the provisional board, the most fastidious person might select some half-dozen directors whose

j presence is a tolerably good guarantee

for effective management. The necessity for the formation of a company at all, vre take it, is found in the circumstance t'tiat the placing of a merchant's name on the share list gives him a direct personal interest in assisting to provide cargo for the Company's boats ; and if, as we hope, the business men of all the northern ports can be induced to join in

the venture, the Northern Steamboat

Company cannot fail to be a complete

success.

THE lion. thc Premier, tho Courier under- stands, denied himself the delights of tho hall at Townsville, given to celebrate His Excel- lency's visit, and set out adventurously to visit Charters Towers and thc adjoining gold-fields. So much zeal is worthy of record, and in fu ture Mr. Macalister will be able to speak wi th inore authority concerning our northern gold-fields.

'TIIE "(iracio Anglo-American Oompany of Minstrels and fiyninasts" arrived by the Ti nonee from tho north on Tuesday. Eight nf the company arrived from India in thc Flint anire, and, owing to thc accident to that vessel, have since been improving their time at thc northern ports. They have recently lieen joined by Messrs. Holley and Weston, formerly of Hussey's Troupe, which performed in Rockhampton three or four years ago. The new company intended to perform hero next ?week, but Professor Hasclmaycr having secured both thc Theatre and the School of A Tts, is for tho present master of thc situa- tion. Two entertainments "running" atouo ti me, however, would not lie profitable tn the pu<rforiners in either, ami therefore thc < íracic Troupe will not sustain much loss by post- poning their first appearance until Monday

week.

PUBLÍSHEED DAILY*.

SATURO AV, AUG CST 29, 1874.

THE movement to provide additional steamship accommodation for our northern coasting trade gives fair promise of success. At first sight it may seem presumptuous for a small community like ours to attempt the establishment of a local steam navigation company. Bris- bane, the capital of the colony, recently made a similar attempt and failed, it is true ; but the causes of failure are manifold and various, and when fairly looked at do not supply ground for despairing of a more satisfactory result

here.

In the first place it was proposed to purchase four suitable steamboats, specially constructed for the trade, and furnished with compound engines and all the latest improvements. In the nature of things this would have caused great delay, and two years would have elapsed before the Company could have been in the position to commence operations. Two years is a long time to look forward to in this colony, and the merchants who saw their goods shut out by every steamer naturally felt dis- couraged by the proposal. " In two years hence," they argued, "circumstances may have altogether changed, and what shall wc do in thc meantime ? Unless some- thing be done immediately, Sydney and Melbourne will grasp at our expanding northern trade, will know their customers, and will have formed such connexions as it will bc difficult to sunder in favour ol new competitors, even though they hai! from the capital of the colony. It ii not relief two years hence that we seek but relief now. If the proposed com pany is to do us any good at all, it mus be done immediately." The force of thii reasoning was at once seen, and th« provisional directors found it necessary to announce their intention to charte! boats, in order to commence business a once. That would have been a ven sensible determination, had it no unfortunately proved impracticable Only two vessels were to be procured and neither was suitable for the trade One was disliked by passengers as slow and she drew too much water for severa of the northern ports with which it wa desired to trade. The other was not de ficient in speed, but she was objection able as a great coal-eater, and i employed to go as far north as Cooktown would have had no storage capacity fo cargo. These boats, therefore, toidi not be availed of with any reasonabl

prospect of success, and the new com- pany could not afford to damage their prestige by starting an inefficient andunre tnunerative interim service. The proposal to begin with chartered boats consequently fell through. This result only showed the futility of the movement, and aroused the suspicion that the promot.-rs of the company had launched their project without first connting its cost The pro- moters struggled on for a time, but the scheme really broke down when it was found impossible to charterboats.

There were, however, other causes of non-success. The A.S.N. Company, with the true instinct of self-preservation, made prodigious efforts to conciliate the Brisbane merchants. They offered to run steamers fortnightly from Brisbane to Cooktown, and to make Brisbane one of the termini, if the Government would only give them a reasonable subsidy for mail conveyance. Here was a sub- stantial advantage, and the metropolitan merchants, who are wise in their genera- tion, influenced the Government in favour of the proposal. They reasoned that a local steam navigation company might be a very good thing two years hence, but a fortnightlyservice with commodious boats to Cooktown was a much better

thing now. The Company's offer was consequently accepted by the Govern- ment, and the promoters of the Northern Steam Navigation Company no doubt accepted their defeat with resignation. They had got less than they asked, but far more than they had hoped, for facilities for northern trade had been

provided for them at the public expense, and they could henceforward ship by the mail boats, or take advantage of any stray opportunity that might offer, without the slightest risk of a depre- ciated share list. And when the A.S.N.

Company conferred the additional boon j of placing the Black Swan regularly

on the line between Brisbane and

Mackay, it was naturally felt that every concession that could be reasonably, sought had been made.

To the merchants of Rockhampton,

in a different light. They discovered in them a design to rob them of their northern trade, and to alienate them from customers who would certainly have given them a slight preference. To the northern people it was imma- terial whether their goods came from Brisbane or Rockhampton. Their desire was the cheapest market. But there were collateral considerations in favour of

Brisbane. It was the larger market, and

it was the seat of Government. These two considerations reconciled them to

the change, and induced them to approve of the public money being devoted to subsidising vessels to pass our port. The new contract consequently gave satis- faction, both to north and south, and noone complained except the "discon- tented people of the Great Central Division."

It is plain that we cannot look to the Government for any complete redress of our - grievance in this respect, and it therefore becomes a question whether our traders shall sit contentedly down while business drifts away from them. Of course-if, after due consideration, no- thing can be done, we must accept the inevitable. But it does really appear as though fortune were about to befriend us in an unexpected manner. Two of our local firms have, in fact, already taken steps to meet the requirements of the port, and it is some- what remarkable that each, acting inde- pendently of the other, lias arranged for placing upon our river a new steam-

boat of about one hundred tons burden. The Messrs. THOMSON have procured theirs from England, and she (the Norse- man) is expected to arrive in about a

month. She is fitted with compound engines, steam winch, etc., and was built, we understand, specially for this port. Messrs. HUNTER and Co.'s steamer is being built in Sydney, and ?will be equipped similarly to the Norse- man. These vessels will be both good sea boats, and while possessing consider- able power, will be small consumers of coal. They will be quite equal to the trip to Cooktown and back, and being worked at little more expense than a schooner, will be able to carry cargo at moderate rates of freight. Being of light draught, they will run into Broad sound, Mackay, and Ross' Creek at Townsville with great facility. They will, it is believed, navigate the placid waters inside the Barrier Reef with regu- larity, and make quicker trips than the Tinonee. They are not intended to carry passengers, it is true, but will probably afford accommodation quite equal to that in the steerage ofjthe A.S.N. Co.'s vessels. The question then arises, Is there trade for these two boats in the event of their being put on? We have made inquiries amongst those who ought to know, and the reply is, yes. The Tinonee, it is

argued, is often obliged to shut out ; goods, although her rates of freight are

prohibitory, and although she seldom : goes beyond Mackay. Transhipments

from southern steamers are ol course .

provided for first, and the local merchant ! has not only to contend against high freights, but also to take the chance of getting his goods away. This is a most humiliating position, and it must be positively destructive to trade.

We are assured that were regular communication established between Rockhampton and the northern ports, at moderate rates of freight, a good trade

could at once be done. In the matter of

flour and Tasmanian produce,for example, our traders can do business just as -well as Brisbane or Sydney. We import from Adelaide and Hobart Town, and can re-export on just as good terms as the Sydney or Brisbane people, and .we have the important advantage of being geographically within half the distance of Brisbane, a consideration of great im- portance in dealing with perishable goods. Again, there is a good trade to be done with Cooktown, in live

j stock. No port in Queensland is so j favourably situated as Rockhampton j for exporting fat sheep, and the ' Cooktown people will not always be

content with beef. Already, consider- able numbers of both sheep and horses have been shipped here for the north, and business of this nature has only been limited by the want of proper means of conveyance. In general merchandise, too, lhere is a trade to be done, as is proven by the large shipments made and cargo shut out by the Tinonee. These are facts, which are worth bushels of mere arguments-such as that " it is im- possible for Rockhampton merchants to compete with Brisbane and Sydney." They have done so in the past despite exorbitant freights, and the uncertainly and inadequacy of means of communi- cation. And that they will do so in the future, when direct importations from England enable them to compete in price with the southern merchants, no one who looks at the facts impartially

can doubt.

In conclusion, we repeat that an opportunity now offers to the business men of Rockhampton which it is of the highest importance they should take advantage of. They can, by concerted action, provide at least a temporary service with the northern ports, and so lay the foundation of a trade whicli must ere long assume important dimensions. The owners of the steamboats proposed to be employed are themselves deeply interested in the matter, and may be expected to join heartily in the venture. The risk need not be great at first, and the trade once estab- lished on a remunerative footing, there will be no difficulty in raising the capital necessary to secure first-class vessels. If all join, failure is impossible, and we shall have the proud satisfac- tion of showing how much may be accomplished by a small community whem it is resolved to unite as one man to promote the common weal.

SERMONS on behalf of the Wesleyan Mis- sionary Society will be preached to-morrow (Sunday), in the Kent-street Wesleyan Church, in the morning, at 11, by the Rev. F. T. Brentnall, and in the evening, at 7.15, by the Rev. H. Woodhouse ; and at the Allenstown

Wesleyan, Church, same hours, in the morning by the Rev. H. Woodhouse and in the evening by the Rev. F. T. Brentnall. Collections in aid of missionary work will be taken after

each service.

STATE of the Hospital for the week ending August 28,1874:-Admitted during the week -2 males and 3 females ; discharged-3 maleB and 1 female ; died daring the week-1 male (Charles Ncwsam) ; remaining in hospital 26 males and 6 females ; total, 32; 1 patient in special ward. ViBiting Committee for tho month of September: Messrs.H. Schmidt and A. Feez. Visiting Surgeon : Dr.

Salmond.

WE aro pleased to notice that the horse, saddle, and bridle, the property of Mr. James Smith, which was taken from thc inside of the School of Arts enclosure, has been recovered Senior Sergeant Graham hearing of the horse, dispatched a constable in search of it, who found it, and also thc saddle and bridle, in the neighbourhood of Lion Creek. As the parson who illegally used the horse is known to tho police, the matter will in all probability be investigated at the Police Court.

ONB of the steerago passengers by the Lord Ashley s.s., which sailed yesterday from this port, was a prisoner named Robert Harrington, who was arrested in Rockhampton on a charge of forging and uttering, and is now remanded to Cooktown. This prisoner, it will be remembered, was brought up on remand on the 6th iustant, charged with forging and uttering a cheque for £30, purporting to be signed by Mr. Thomas Hamilton, late Police Magistrate at Cooktown. Also, a man named Harry Downing alias "Soldier Harry" was forwarded to St. Lawrence on a charge of horse-stealing.

ERRATA.-In our report of the Municipal meeting of Inst Thursday, with reference to the letter from Mr. Jager, seeking indemnity for thc loss of a draught marc, which met its

death in conBoauonco of the oncninf? of a drain

for wator-pipes through hia paddock, wo should hare stated that, in reply, Mr. Jagar was to be informod that the contractor, by the terms of his contract, had assumed thc en-

tire responsibility for accidents of gio kind referred to. In the paragraph referring to tho letter from the Oas 'Company, it is inadvert- ently stated that the' Council would erect the lamps ; for Council read Oat Company.

AT tho last Jnecfcingof tho Brisbane Chamber of Commerce, the chairman drew attention to the BDiall amount of interest shown hy many of the members iu the affaira of tho Chamber, there being frequently a great difficulty in getting a quorum at the ordinary meetings. There could bo no doubt as to the valncof such an institution, hut it wasaqucstion whether it was worth carrying it on iu tho face of such apathy. Mr. Perry, who said be should much regret the doing away with tho Chamber, thought the matter might be reme- died by holding the monthly meetings of the members generally instead of committee men only, and gave notice of a motion to that effect. Mr. Fenwick thought tho short at- tendance arose not from apathy, but from the knowledge that no irapirtant lousiness was in question. Ko doubt if such were the case a full attendance could bc relied on. The fore-

going is from thc Telegraph, and it is con finned {hy tho Conner's report. Our metro- politan friends appear to bo apathetic in every public movement which has not for its chief object the fleecing of thc public Treasury.

TnLEn KArmo communication between Hoek hamptou and Keppel Say has now been inter rupted for nearly three wecke, and both steamers and sailing vessels have been popping in upon us uuawares, os in tho olden time. Tho linc repairer has been out on repeated expeditious, aud not finding any break in tho wires, couclndcs that the Haw is in the short bit of cable laid across the Narrows. Accord- ingly an electrician (Mr. Sharkú) has been despatched from Briabaiio by the Lady Bowen, e., to examine the cable, and if wrong to put it right. Thc line between here and thc hay was, wc understand, badly constructed in tho first instance, and is frequently " down," to thc serious inconvenience ot the public It may be hoped, therefore, that steps will now be taken by thc department to repair or reconstruct tho line, and thus gire tho public something like certainty of communication. The correspondent of a southern paper intimated tho other day thc ii> tontion of the authorities to construct .1 lino from Keppel Bay to Gladstone, which perhaps is a good idea. Thc distance is not great, anti, if not too expensive, thc advantage of a double

line would be considerable. .Some anxiety is felt about thc ship Suffolk, now 101 days ont with immigrants, and tho interruption of 1 communication with tho liiy is therefore pir ' ticularly provoking.

GLADS TO NTS OBSERVER. \

PUBLISHED DAILY. TU KS DAY, FEBRUARY Hi, 1874.

i IN view of thc debasement which

surrounds municipal government in the metropolitan city of Queensland, the people of Rockhampton have just cause for pride and thankfulness. Years ago a Little J'eddlington spirit permeated all public matters at Brisbane, and now that the eily bas in many respects outgrown its early weaknesses, the old taint still

adheres to its civic institutions. The

City Council is a bear-garden, the public streets arc disgracefully kepi, and the character of the Corporation is a reproach to the citizens. No wonder lli.il in such circumstances all hope of restoring the reputation of the Council has been abandoned, or that relief is sought through the intervention of Parliament, and the reincorporation of the city under a special Act.

il is in no spirit of exultation that we write thus of the metropolitan Counc il. On the contrary, we observe its degrada- tion with genuine reg.et. Thc example so set cannot but have a deteriorating effect upon municipal institutions in otherparlsofQueensl.md. and tend tobring the beneficent principle of self-govern- ment, upon the healthy development of which thefulureprosperity of thecolony is largely dependent, into haired and con- tempt. \Vhen, as occurred at the recent election of mayor al Brisbane, one alderman was permittee! lo make a bur- lesque of the proceedings by a disorderly

motion to the effect that another alder-

man be appointedchaplain to the Council, and when a disappointed candidate for

the chair was allowed lo instill the MAYOR elect with impunity, it is im- possible not lo feel that in a measure the whole colony is disgraced by sucb pro- ceedings. Had a proper feeling existed amongst thc aldermen, such irregularities

would not have been tolerated for a moment, and such men as Messrs. GRAYSON and BII.I.KIT would have dis- covered thal the taproom and not the council chamber was their proper sphere

of action.

.Much might be done to redeem the civic reputation of Brisbane, were greater public spirit displayed by the citizens. lint politics alone seem capable of exciting the people of the metropolis to energetic action. They are ever ready to hold an indignation meeting to denounce a " sipialting government," or abuse a representative 'who bas dared to vole against the popular wish, but the discreditable conduct of aldermen is always deemed beneath notice. Il is naught that the city rivals Cologne for the variety and pungency of its slinks, or that lhere is not a well-kept gutter within the whole civic boundary, lt is liol in such matters that thc metropolitan nose scents corrup- tion, bul in the circumstance that Conservative politicians have dared

to exert an influence on the

legislation of the country. lt

would be far more creditable lo our

Brisbane friends if, without neglecting to display an enlightened interest in the po- litical affairs of the colony, they would reserve their vials of oratorical «Tath for the heads of their civic functionaries, whose ill conduct and incapacity threaten to not only make shipwreck of municipal government, but also en- danger the health and lives of the

citizens.

Of course il would be unbecoming to the metropolitans to follow (he example of the second (own in the colony in any maller, and especially so in dealing with their public institutions. Yet we may he permitted lo suggest lhai a leaf or two might be taken out of our book willi great advantage 1o the ciii/ens of Bris- bane. If, for instance, the present me- tropolitan aldermen could be induced by the pressure of public opinion to resign in a body, it is very unlikely (hal an entirely new Council' would not prove a vast improvement on any Corporation thal Brisbane has yet been blessed willi. New blood cimwi he introduced with advantage where there has been a loo free admixture of had blood, and hence the nou-vecupei alive effect of the ordi- nary annual elections. But once stall willi a clean sheet, and the names at- tached lo it would be found lo represent men not only of purer blood, but also of vasily improved intellectual and moral perceptions and capacities.

ll appears, however, thal a bill for the Incorporation of thc City of Brisbane has already been prepared, and will be

submitted to Parliament during next session. What the general character of this measure is has not yet transpired. ' Hut it contemplates one alteration which can hardly fail to prove beneficial. It provides that the MA VOR shall be elected by the general body of ratepayers, instead of by the aldermen from among themselves. After the recent display al Brisbane, it is evidently time that some change of the kind were made ; and in Rockhampton circumstances have occurred which indicate that even here thc present mode of electing the MAVOR sometimes furnishes an occasion for undignified intrigues and ill-concealed jealousies. The question therefore arises -Wily is a special bill of incorporation necessary for thc metropolis ? and why- not extend the advantages of reform to municipalities generally ? This inquiry, it may be presumed, will be pertinently suggested in thc Legislature when thc Brisbane Incorporation Hill comes under consideration, and it will have to be conclusively answered before the measure is permitted to become law.

In several other respects the municipal laws of thc colony are in need of amendment. This was fully acknow- ledged by the late ( jovernment, whose intention il was to introduce an amend-

ing and consolidating measure on the first good opportunity. Hut for sonic years past the redistribution question, and the factious obstruction offered to the late Government, prevented legislation on

so comparatively trifling a matter as muni- j cipal reform. Happily the redistribution

question is now disposed of for a time, j and factious obstruction is a thing of the ¡last It may therefore be hoped that, despite the declared urgency of land legislation, and the two sets of Estimates requiring lobe dealt with next

session, il may be found practicable to j secure consideration for a new Munici- j polities Hill, and legislation on other j important subjects of domestic reform, j

'Chere is just one point on which ; observation wan-ants us in pointing out a widely-spread error. The practice in this colony has been to require purely honorary service in the Mayoral chair.

This we believe to be one cause of the general inefficiency of municipal govern-

ment in the colony. A Mayor's duties ; are onerous and constant. The honour | attached lo the office is certainly a trifling compensation, but docs r.ot out- weigh the discomfott and anxiety encountered by its occupant. To

attract amable men of high standing in | the community, some other compensa- tion must bc provided, and that, we believe, would be supplied by an animal vote lo defray the expenses incidental to the chair. Payment for services ren- dered is not desired, but it is too much

to expect a man to incur great labour j and responsibility, and also set himself up as a target for philanthropic

ladies and audacious male collectors, lt is a Mayor's special privilege to head all subscription lists, and as the ultimate "allie of such documents is de-

pendent upon the figures set against the first autograph, His WORSHIP'S liberality must be stimulated lo the requisite pitch

by an irresistible artillery of words. The j most obdurate of Mayors never closed j his purse, or failed to surrender al cbs- 1 cretion to the lady collector, when

" With blandished parlej's, feminine assaults, Tongue batteries, she surceased not."

Hence, if the ratepayers of the colony |

would make their civic chairs attractive, | the example set by Rockhampton in this respect must be generally followed, liven mayoral honours may be purchased at too great a cost. As was once quaintly observed, " Fame is a revenue payable only to our ghosts."

A J:KSI»I;XT of Taroom, Br. Tjonis Hon. Hinger, ¡1 native of liermauy, died suddenly ut IMby on Tuesday last from disease of tim heart, lie hail stilfcrcd for some time past from that distressing complaint, ami hail gima on a visit to Dalby to spend .1 fow weeks, in the IMHO of alleviating lu's ctuid'tion, when In; was overtaken by death. Dr. Henninge!'was a resilient nf Taroom fur a nuinhur nf years prior to his death, ami was helli in high esti- mation hythe inhabitants of the town cul

district, nuil wa* universa"y respeetcil by ! those who had the pleasure oí hisacuuiiiitaticc. We regret to state that he leaves a w Mow and four children totally unprovided for.

A MIN uamoil Michael Burlie, a labourer, was adniittod into the hospital yesterday lifter, nunn with his light font badly crushed. It appears that thc unfortunate fellow, who was employed oil thc railway extension, some distance beyond Westwood, was at work i'l a cutting, when a bank of earth suddenly gave way and fell upon him, a large «tone .striking him'III tho foot, inflicting a very sori'ius wound. Ile was immediately extricated and forwarded to tuwu by thc train, the injured limb being roughly 1 minni up with a few bandages ¡ind some pieces of cloth. He is not expected to be again lit for work for Rome time to como.

Tm: friends of Mr. Wi"',nn Hopkins, sta- tioner, will have been pleased tn rem! in last Saturday's Bnflcfitt thoiiilieial assignee's repot ¿ in thc matter nf Mr. Hopkins' insolvent csUtv. lt appears thal despite tho forccil sale of thu stock in one lot at auction, and the summary collection »ifdelit-sby the ollicial assignee, thc estate has yielded witlc'i a hundred pennis nf thc liabilities. This proves that when 11011m-eil upon Mr. Hopkin* hal really a eoiui,lura!i'.. surplus of assets, and tint lie w.n a v'etim t 1 the excessive powers .sometimes exercised hy sharp creditors by virtue or seeret lii"s ul" sale. Mr. Hopkins has now recoiiiuc'ir-cd business, and will no doubt retain the ofen- sivo connection he hail acquired l».y several j'cars of industry .-cid attention t j 1rs cus-

tomers.

Tm: prospectus "f Hie Cooli omi lTr,:th1 appears i'l mir column . to-day. A "< if.s naine

implies, tho new jouiii:' wdl'lie pul il isl, ed at

Cooktown, 011 thc làil.avmir Uiver, the millet <>f thc Palmer gnld lii ld. The propiielor ;s Mr. W. II. |" Hailey, who hus had long experience "i thc newspaper business in Kock - hampton, ,u"l ¡ms proved himself a man nf energy ami industry. Thc printing p'aul, wo understand, is entirely new, having just boen purchase,! in Sydney, lt in already nt il" destination, and there is little doubt thal tli-3 lU-i'tibl will make its appearance at the adver- tised time-carly in April. Thc now journal may be expected to have a considerable circu- lation on thc northern gold-lields.

GLADSTONE OBSERVER.

PUBLISHED DAILY. WEDNESDAY. FEBRUARY 25, 1874.

THE meeting convened by the MAYOR for this afternoon should attract a good attendance of our business men. As yet the project of a new Queensland Steam Navigation Company is in the initial stage, and the plans of its pro- moters have not been made known probably have not been laid. Thc meet- ing at Brisbane appears to have been prompted by the palpable want of steamboat accommodation between the various Queensland porLs, and especially between Brisbane and the new settle- ments on the northern coast. It is reported that one thousand lons of mer- chandize are lying at Brisbane awaiting transit northwards, and that the want of steam conveyance is seriously crippling the trade of thc metropolis. The A. S. N. Company secure freightage at Sydney for all their available vessels, and Brisbane merchants consequently find their goods shut out. It would be unreasonable to expect a Sydney steam- ship company to cultivate the trade of Brisbane at the expense of their own port, and if a sudden expansion through thc Palmer rush makes their fleet unequal to the demands upon it, they are bound to give a preference to the interests of their own shareholders. The circum- stance that several large sailing vessels arc loading at Sydney for

I the Endeavour River goes to prove

the insufficiency of steam conveyance ; and the probabilityis that thc movemcntsof thc southern merchants are scarcely less hampered than arc those of their con- temporaries at Brisbane. The A. S. N. Company are not to be blamed for their inability to cope with thc increased trade. It could not have been foreseen or provided against without entering upon thc region of speculative ship- building. Twelve months ago the Company's fleet was equal to .ill ordinary requirements of the trade. If many of their steamers were old, while nearly all frere insatiable coal-caters, they were gradually remodelling and converting them into good economical vessels of very respectable speed, even in these/lays of rapid steaming. The late accident to the James Paterson occurred at an un- fortunate time, and has greatly compli- cated the Company's arrangements. So that, if our merchants find trade brought nearly to a deadlock through insufficiency of means of transit, no blame is attach- able to anyone in particular. The simple truth appears to be that more coasting steamers must be procured, and tile question lo bc solved now is whether the Queensland trading community shall patiently await thc movements of the A. S.N. Com] ¡any, or pul their own

shoulders to the wheel.

The greatest difficulty in thc way of establishing a second Queensland Steam Navigation Company is thc lamentable failure which resulted from the opera- tions of the first. The gauntlet was thrown down to " Old Monopoly " twelve years ago, and the Queenslanders trusting to their government subsidy were confident of an easy victory. The warfare was spirited and long-continued, and although the older Company came triumphantly out of the struggle, another such victor)' would have been ruinous. Before thc collapse of the Queenslander.1;,

A. S. N. Company's stock had receded far below par, and insolvency loomed in the distance. The turning-point was gained when the Queensland boats were purchased al a low figure, and began to run under the Austral- asian flag. Since that time the Com- pany's affairs have been steadily im- proving; but even now, after several years' command of the Queensland trade, it has barely recovered the losses incurred in crushing the rival company.

That thc operations of steamship com- panies are not necessarily conducted at a loss is shown, by the brokers' ((nota- tions of steam stocks. The A. S. N. Company's shares realise par, but the Hunter River Company-its successful competitor-is in a much better position, for its £10 shares are quoted at ¿£13 10s. The capital of the latter cornpany is only .£55,000, and it has been for many years a dividend-paying con- cern, despite thc severest competition of the old Company in time past. The Clarence River Company made heavy losses rill lately, and its £10 shares fell to forty shillings ; but better times have dawned upon that Company also. At thc proprietors' meeting, held on the 9th instant, thc net profits of the half year were shown to have been .£2733, out of total gross earnings of ,£12,570. Ten per cent dividend was then dcclaed, and .£1500 carried to reserve fund.

These facts go to prove that there is room for a new company in Queensland, and that with good management il would soon become a dividend-paying concern. If formed now its object would be to undertake business which the A. S. N. Company finds itself unable to do, and therefore it possibly might escape the uncompromising opposition manifested towards the late Queensland Company. Rivalry of course there would be, but even thc Directors of the A.S.N. Company must admit the healthfulness of competition in trade, and experience has probably taught them the folly of cut-throat opposition. There would be abundant scope for both companies, and there is no good reason why their proceedings should not be distinguished by honourable rivalry, such as for years past has marked the compe- tition of the A. S. N. and Hunter River Companies.

It is very unlikely that any important business will, be transacted at to-day's meeting. Hs object principally is to obtain an expression of public opinion in reference to the projected company. That obtained, further steps must be deferred until the plans and proposals of thc promoters in Brisbane are made

known.

PUBLISHED DAILY".

FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 0, 1874.

THB Clermont, Copperfield ami Lilyvale maila (lao at Rockhampton on Wednesday, orrivecHjy yesterday's train. Mr. l'eunycuick at Gainsford has forwarded a memo to tbe Postmaster ot Rockhampton stating that thc up mail to Clermont, which left Rockhampton on Tuesday morning, arrived at Gainsford a day late, and will not return to Gainsford till Saturday evening. It will therefore bc sent with tho Springsure miils, and will reach Rockhampton on Monday evening i ii"toad of

Saturday, thc contract time. I Wc learn from Mr. Graham Macdonald that a snip's yard drifted ashore on thc coast at his

station, Balnagowan, two days after thc recent J heavy gale. It is about thirty feet long, sud has ropes attached, also two chains, one block, ?nd portions of a sail torn into shreds. And on Sunday some tracery in wood, bealing the emblem of a wheat-sheaf and sickle, washed ashore only a short distance from Mr. Mac- donald's house. After making inquiries, we

are inclined to think that t!u yard is the fore- : yard of a steamer. It did not come from tho Landsborough, os the spars of that ship were painted buff colour, whilst this one is black ; and supposing tho Landsborough to bc wrecked, thc drifting fragments from her course would not be likely to reach the mainland. We cannot identify tho wheat-sheaf tracing but possibly some of our readers may be able to throw light upon tho subject. These fragments do not necessarily signify that a wreck baa taken place, as a vessel might lose spars and even masts, and yet get safely into port. Wo find that they are not from thc Countess Belmore, as although that schooner lost her foroyard aud a portion of her bulwarks, the yard was subsequently recovered, and she had no tracery resembling that washed ashore. However, thc probabilities nf a wreck or two having taken place near this part of thc coast are very strong, ami thc Government arc inourring a grave responsibility in delaying to tend out a vessel of some sort to remove doubts relative to tho matter,

WITH WHICH IB inOOftFOfclTKD TIIK

GLADSTONE OBSERVER.

PUBLISHED DAJLY. WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 12, 1874.

THE appointment of the Royal Com- mission to inquire into and report upon the Education question is now an accom- plished fact. To its personnel objection cannot fairly bc taken. Amongst its members are included such advanced secularists as Mr. Justice LILLEV, the Hon. S. W. GRIFFITH, and Mr. JOHN DOUGLAS on the one hand, while repre- senting the so-called religious side of the question are such staunch denomi nationalists as the Hon. W. H. WALSH

and Dr. O'DOHEKTY. Of Dr. PREN- I TICE'S opinions on the question we know nothing ; and we eau little more than ¡ guess at thc views of Messrs. HOCKINGS | and MF.IN. The presumption is, how- j ever, that, looking at the Commission as j a whole, what die secularists may be I

supposed to lack in zeal is more than compensated by numbers. On the sec- j tarian side, Mr. WALSH is a host in himself, while for gentle smooth

running inflexibility, Dr. O'DOHERTV . is without an equal amongst our j public men. When we say, how- ever, thal the secular members lack zeal, we perhaps do them some injustice Mr. LIIXF.V, for his reputation's sake, is bound to manifest earnestness, and it is not to be supposed that Mr. GRIFFITH'S

elevation to the Attorney-Generalship will slacken his hold upon the principles in which he was nurtured, and which he so recently as last session gave proof of his fidelity to. Mr. HARLIN, as a culti- vated mart, and one practically and technically conversant with the educa- tional wants of our youth, may, as Secretary to the Commission, be expected to render it valuable aid. So that, on the whole, thc appointments may bc deemed to supply guarantees for an impartial and comprehensive inquiry.

One of the chief duties of the Com- mission, wc apprehend, will be to ascer- tain the true comparative values of what are respectively known as the national and the denominational systems. The members will, it maybe presumed, inquire into the working of the vested schools in this colony, and let the public know whether in points of efficiency and economy those institutions are sucli as the public are entitled to expect. The non-vested schools will receive attention, and it will bc shown whether these institutions impart, ai alleged by their advocates, an education equal to that given in the vested schools and at a much less cost. We shall alsr leam whether clerical influence succeed; in attracting to these schools childrer who would otherwise grow up in ignor ance. And finally, we shall also lean whether the scandals prevalent will regard to such schools have any founda

tion in fact. The Board iias issued a strict mandate against teachers in non vested schools givingreligious instruction, yet it is broadly declared that such in- struction is still imparted, and that lesson-books arc still used which have

an unmistakeably proselyting tendency. These imputations are either true or false, and it will, we presume, be the duty of the Commission to set all doubts at rest with respect to them. If true, no further proof will be required of the viciousness of the system, as one sup- ported by the public moneys, for it is monstrous that in State - endowed schools parents should incur the risk of having their children taught doctrines which they believe to be essentially per- nicious and soul-destroying.

Another important question for the Commission to pronounce upon is how to prevent the abuses which have crept into our grammar school system, and which have given to our secondary schools the character of class institu- tions. Knotty points will also arise in connection with the proposed extension of free education to the higher schools, and with the establishment of the contemplated university. There is a wide divergence of opinion as to the

propriety ot free education irom top to bottom." It seems to be now

universally admitted that essential elementary instruction must bc imparted absolutely free of cost, but the balance of opinion appears to be in favour of making a charge for secondary education, and providing for the wants of genius in humble life by the granting of liberal scholarships. Mr. LILLEY, as is well known, advocates gratuitous education from the infant school to thc university, and we confess to much sympathy with that principle. Its uniform application and simplicity are important considera- tions in its favour. On the other hand, the imposition of fees for the more advanced instruction is beset with innumerable complications, and cal- culated to foster class jealousies. The standard for the free schools could not be fixed without much heart-burning. Most people admit that educa- tion now-a-days must comprise some- thing beyond the three Rs, and it would be hopeless to recommend that free instruction should be contracted within such limits ; and, if it be deter- mined that elementary education of all kinds shall be imparted free of cost, the standard will embrace studies which to a large proportion of scholars must be

deemed non-essentials. We are at a

loss to discover any satisfactory point at

which the State shall draw the line between free and paid education, and it is not very probable that the Royal Com- mission will succeed in finding it.

There is one very important branch of the question, however, on which good may be anticipated from the labours of

the Commission. It has been with j the existing Board of Education an j insoluble problem how to procure j a supply of trained and skilful teachers, -and the consequence is that many of our public schools are lament- ably deficient in teaching power. It is, we think, less a question of number than of quality, for the percentage of incom- petent teachers is generally believed to be unduly great. Surely there must be some practicable means of grappling with this difficulty. Our present educa- tional system is costly enough, in ail con- science, but without competent teachers we can only expect the minimum of instruction with the maximum of expense. The remedy will probably be found in better training schools for one thing, and in the offering of prize appointments for another. Possibly our school teachers are not as a body much under-paid ; but theirs is a hopeless calling. They appear to have no chance of rising beyond the

monotonous level of head-master of one

of the larger schools, a position which, after all, is barely worth attaining. Were there a few well-paid appointments open to men of unusual industry and talent, !

a better class of men would be found in

the ranks of our school teachers, and the I whole tone of our educational system would be raised. But without such an attraction thc walk of life trodden by the school teacher will be availed of only by youths of inferior intellectual power; and parents who find their sons not equal to the strain of one of the higher professions, will fall back upon school teaching as a pursuit in which mediocrity forms no insuperable barrier to success within its own narrow sphere.

The Commission, it may be antici- pated, will not confine its attention to Queensland, but extend its inquiries to the other colonies, to Europe, and America. In Victoria, alone, is a wide field for iu ! vestigation,and it lias the advantagcof not

being inconvenientlvdistant. There is one

thing to be borne in mind, however. The question of education, throughout the civilised world, is in a transition state, the duty of the Government instructing tlie people being but a modem doctrine. Wc must not therefore too lavishly follow precedent in the matter, but endeavour to take advantage of the experience of other countries, and resolve upon founding an educational system cal- culated to place our youth in the van of intellectual progress.

THC want of more frequent steam com- munication between Rockhampton and the northern ports has induced a number of gentlemen interested to convene a meeting for Tuesday nest, the object being to arrange for chartering or purchasing a suitable steamer for the northern trade. Wc gladly notice this determination on the part of our trading community to help themselves, for tiiat there is business to be done if means of quick transit be provided, no one acquainted with the circumstances can doubt. The local agent of thc A.S.N. Company have for years reported that the Tinonee, s.s., is inadequate to the wants of the trade, and have urged the putting on of another steamer. And that, we have every reason to believe, would have been done had not the Government stepped in and subsidised the Company's steamboats lo give our

port the go-by. The geographical posi- tion of Rockhampton, however, gives our merchants advantages in carrying on the northern trade that Brisbane does not possess, and there is not the slightest doubt that if a suitable steamer be put on she will pay well, and mate-

rially help in developing the trade of our : port. Because Brisbane has failed in !

the late attempt to get up a local steam ! navigation company it by no means ; follows that, in beginning on a more modest scale, we should fail also. We have found means to carry on our Municipal Council, oar School of Arts, and our Hospital, in a most successful manner, while the Brisbane people have most notoriously failed in maintaining similar institutions - the metropolitan council being overwhelmed in debt, the school of arts bereft of its buildings, and the hospital necessarily taken over by the Government. We do not make these remarks for the purpose of self glorification, but to inspire confidence and encourage our community to culti- vate that spirit of self-reliance which, combined with united action, has been hitherto the secret of success. We hope this matter of steam communication will be taken up with animation, in which case the truth of the adage that " Heaven helps those who help themselves," will be speedily exemplified.

GLADSTONE Olí SERVER.

PUBLISHED DAJLY.

_ . _. . ,_ " . <t>

THURSDAY, MARCH ffli, 1874.

FROM clause 42, the remainder of thc new Gold-fields Bill relates almost

entirely to the Administration of Justice. It is provided that the GOVERNOR may establish on any gold-field a warden's court, presided over by .1 warden alone, or by a warden and assessors ; to be a court of record, and to have jurisdiction in all actions, disputes, and questions relating to mining ; provided that in any money demand the amount sought to be recovered shall not exceed one hundred

pounds. Every warden sitting alone is empowered lo hear all cases of complaint for breach of thc regulations, and inflict the specified fines and forfeitures ; and on gold-fields where no warden's court has been proclaimed, the GOVERNOR may appoint some justice of the peace to exercise all the powers and authorities of a warden, and to determine, when sitting alone, all cases ordinarily adjudi- cated upon by justices in petty sessions.

Thc appointment of assessors is pro- vided for in clause 51. A list of not less than fifty persons is to be made out by the warden from thc jurors' book of the district court held on the gold-field ; and

where no district court shall have been established the list is to be made out

from the population of the neighbour- hood, all persons liable to serve .os assessors being necessarily holders of miner's rights. It will be lawful for either of tho parties to a case lo require that it be heard before the warden and three assessors, provided that before any

assessors be summoned the sum of one

pound ten shillings shall have been paid to thc warden, such amount to be equally divided amongst the assessors. It is also provided that a similar sum be paid for each adjournment. Either party may challenge two assessors without assigning cause, and any further number on as- signing cause, the truth of which will be inquired into by thc warden. Assessors will be liable to a penalty of ¿£5 for non- attendance, and before sitting each of

them will bc sworn. The assessors will hear a case with the assistance of thc

warden, and the decision of a majority of them will.be binding. Mut if, after two hours' deliberation a majority cannot agree, then the warden himself shall de- cide the complaint.

Under clauses 58 to 79 inclusive, a variety of special powers are given to the warden. He may order an inspec- tion to be made of any land, on applica- tion by either parly, before the hearing of a case ; cause a survey to be made ; seize any gold, and any earth or quartz containing gold, thal may be in dispule ; authorise entry on an adjacent claim by a person who his previously made a declaration of secrcsy before the warden ; grant injunctions on sufficient notice having been given of the intention to apply for them ; appoint a manager when necessary to carry on works that may he in dispute ; grant injunctions for seven days without notice ; and order the deposit of gold in dispute.

Under clause C9, no complaint shall bc dismissed by any warden because of informality, but such complaint or sum- mons shall be amended Ivy thc warden " so that the subject matter in dispute " shall plainly appear, and the warden " shall proceed to adjudicate according " lo the rights of parlies," unless the defendant shall have been deceived or misled by an informal summons. A new trial may be granted, cither before the warden alone, or before the warden and three assessors as before provided. Power is also given to the warden 1» reserve any question, in the form of a special case for the opinion of the district court judge, any order or verdict of the mining court being suspended luean i time.

Clause 74 provides that in any pro ceeding before a warden's court for Un recovery of land, reservoir, etc., tin court sball be authorised to fix boun dories, order any sum in tho nature o nestle profits, whether exceeding £io< or not, to bc paid to the complainant i he bc so entitled; cause the complainan lo be put into possession of any gold land, or reservoir, and (if necessary order any buildings, fixtures, or chattels to be removed. Thc five succcedini clauses specify the duties of the wardci when a proceeding is as to the right ti divert water, or in respect of ai encroachment, of money due on a con tract, or in respect of a partnership Clause 79 requires all constables anc peace officers, within their jurisdictions to assist tile warden in carrying out hil

duties.

Clauses 80 to 92 inclusive, provide fo appeals from the warden and assessors t< the district court ; but if on the hcarin; of an appeal questions of law be raised a further appeal 011 those points shall Iii to the Supreme Court, in thc shape of ; special case set out by the judge of tin district court. The judge will also haw power to submit tn a special case for th< Supreme Court, any points of law raisec by himself. This provision appears t£ open tlie door to endless litigation, foi the wealthy appellant may always raisi points of law which will admit of inter minable argument in the Supreme Court It will bi: open to litigants, however before the hearing of a case, to agree lc accept the decision of the warden's cour as final, in which case no appeal will lie And in cases where the subject-matter o the dispute does not appear tu the couti to exceed twenty pounds, the appellam will not be entitled to the cost of hu appeal although he succeeds, unless ir the opinion of the court the issue: directly or indirectly involved exceed twenty pounds, or there are specia circumstances which entitle thc appellan to costs. Appeals may be heard by tin judge alone, or by thc judge and three assessors, who arc to be selected fron thc district court jurors. Under clausi 91 the jurisdiction of district courts ii enlarged for gold-fields, and the judge will also have an equitable jurisdictior to thc extent possessed by thc primar) judge in equity. . By clause 92, nc district court will have jurisdiction to ti) any mining case, in debt or on contract in which thc amount claimed does noi exceed twenty-five pounds.

Under the head of " Miscellaneou; Provisions," are included clauses 93 ti 108-(not 107, as stated in yesterday'; issue). Clause 93 authorises any Dis tiict or Supreme Court judge to dis charge an applicant from custody whe may bc imprisoned under any wanant o commitment under the Act," providec that it sball not bc lawful for such judge to inquire into the merits of the original order on which the commitment wa; founded. The three succeeding; clause! provide for thc recovery of court-fees in a summary manner before any warden, and for the taxation of attorneys* hills ol costs and counsels' fees. Clause 95 imposes two months' imprisonment or £ fine of ten pounds for contempt of cout i Clause 98 specifies that every share ot interest in a claim, or land occupied foi business or residence, shall be deemed in law a chattel interest. Thc five succeed

ing clauses provide penalties for forging a miner's right, for breach of the regula- tions, for extortion, and for assault on warden. Thc holding of any interest by a warden in any gold claim is made a misdemeanour, for which the offender will be liable to fine and imprisonment, or both, in the discretion of a court. A similar penalty is imposed if any warden shall knowingly adjudicate in any matter in which lie has a iwcuniary interest. This penalty should effectually extirpate what is alleged lo he a frequent abuse on our gold-fields at the present lime.

Clause 104 provides for interpleader cases. Thc next clause imposes a penalty of ten pounds upon witnesses who do not appear after thc tender of their ex- penses has been made. The next clause provides that no proceedings under this Act shall be removable into the Supreme Court, except as hereinbefore provided (in the form of a special case, drawn by a district court judge, on points of law). The two remaining clauses empower the GovEiiNou-iN-Couiccii. to make regula- tions, which may be for the whole colony or any particular part thereof, and which when published in the ffaietie will have

the force of law.

The new bill, if passed, will provide the miners with chea]) law, al any rate ; but if il encourage a litigious spirit it will not be an unmixed benefit. Hut, as " Commissioners' law" is played out, and thc mining interest has assumed the cha- racter of a permanent industry, it is only just to provide lliose engaged in it with the means of legal redress. One merit of the new bill is that il will not apparently bc very expensive in working. The warden will merely replace the commissioner, and the only additional officer required will be a registrar for each warden's court. The district courts will of neces- sity be multiplied, which will involve the appointment of another judge and crown-prosecutor for the northern dis- tricts. Hut those appointments will he necessary whether thc new Gold-fields bill ho passed or no. On the whole the bill appears lo be simple and compre- hensive, and calculated to remedy many of thc defects of the law as at present existing. Hut, after all, so much is de- pendent upon the regulations to be founded upon the new Act, that it is impossible to forecast its success or failure, ¡lending their publication.

Urn Melbourne tclcgr.nn tn-day states tbat Hennessy aud Martell refuse to secure ordere for their brandies. Tliis ilctormiuation ap- pears to have been anticipated by the Mel- bourne merchants, judging by thc following telegram which appeared iii thc Brisbane Cottrter eight days ago :-c* Very large sales of brandies have been made equal to SGO quarter casks. Hcnuossy's is quoted at Os. 3d. to Os, 4íi¡. for bulk ; MarteH's, Ss. Sd. Small par- cels of HcnncsHy's ISIi'.t liavc been placed at , 10s. CiL Far case of the same brand 2Ss. has "bocnrcfuBcd."

O T*.l D S TO NE O tiSRRVBU

PUBLISHED D/VtLV. WEDNESDAY, SEPTEMBER 2, 1874.

ABOUT one-third of the inhabitants of the colony reside within the boundaries of the seventeen municipalities estab- lished in the various towns. Of the 47,450 persons so brought under the influence of local self-government, the municipality of Brisbane is estimated to contain 15,000, Rockhampton and Mary- borough each 5500, Ipswich 4821, Toowoomba 3200, Warwick 3000, Copperfield and Dalby 2000 each, Mackay 1200, Townsville 800, Bowen 700, and thc remaining six still smaller numbers. The return which furnishes these figures, however, although officiai, contains internal evidence of inaccuracy, for in an adjoining column the number of dwellings in each municipality is also given. Tested by these, the population of the respective towns will present a very different appearance. The return, we presume, is compiled from municipal records, which should give the number of dwellings with exactness, but the stated population is evidently the merest guess-work. If, therefore, we make an estimate of the population by multiplying the number of dwellings by four and a-half-assuming that to be the average number of persons living in each house-we ought to arrive at a pretty accurate conception of the actual population of each municipality some twelve months ago. Allowances, oi course, must be made for empty dwell- ings in towns in a state of decadence, but only two or three in the list come undei that head. Again, thc population even thus ascertained will not give a true con- ception of the population of the towns named, owing to the varying sizes of the different municipalities. For example, the municipality of Brisbane contains only 2183.acres, which indicates thal although South Brisbane is included with- in the civic boundaries, the environs ol North Brisbane must be excluded. Geo- graphically again, Maryborough, with 25,000 acres, is nearly twelve times as large as the metropolitan municipality, while Rockhampton, with 15,000 acres, does not include that part ol the town situated on the north side. The ap- pended table will assist the reader in testing the official return", but we cannot claim that either column represents the actual population :

r.itlmalcd Ksttmmod IVi|iiil«tlor, Dwellings. l'oimlHiiun. mi; ciel . " dwolliiic Allora ... 120 500 540 Bowen ... 225 700 1,012 Brisbane ... 3,083 15,002 13,873 Clermont ... 125 400 502 Copperfield... 490 2,000 2,205 Dalby ... 350 2,000 1,575 Drayton ... 147 900 . «Ol Gayndah ... 171 509 709 Gladstone ... 101 427 408 Ipswich ... 1,180 4,821 5,310 Mackay ... 237 1,200 J,! «li Maryborough 820 5,500 3,090 llocUnunptou 1,100 5,500 4,950 Roma ... 140 1,001) G30 Toowoomba... 770 3,200 3,400 Townsville ... 304 800 1,380 Warwick ... 497 3,000 2,230

We confess that an examinador of this table leads to thc conclusion that for comparative pur poses the figures are quite unreliable It will be recollected, for instance, thai by the census ol 1871, the municipalitj

of Rockhampton was shown to contain 1138 dwellings and a population 01" 5064. Since then dozens of houses have been erected, and yet the return now before us states the number of dwellings at 1100, and the population at 5500, the latter exactly the same as Maryborough ; while, curiously enough, the dwellings within the municipality of Maryborough are estimated to number only 820. According to the census of 1871, Mary- borough contained 733dwellingsand3542 persons. How the figures in the return are arrived at we are at a loss to discover, but it looks as though some ambitious alderman had set down the population of Maryborough as 5500, in-order to make that town appear equal to Rockhampton. Bowen, again, accord- ing to thc census of 1871, contained 188 houses and 715 persons. Since that time the town has certainly not been progressing, yet the return just issued states the dwellings at 225-an increase of 37 ; and the population at 700-a decrease of 15. Other instances might be given to prove that the return, so far as population is concerned, is absolutely valueless.

The difficulties of corporations in the formation of streets is indicated by the total mileage within each municipality. In Brisbane there are only 47 miles of streets, while in Ipswich there are 33, in Maryborough 74, and in Rockhampton 76. And as in Rockhampton our streets are half a chain broader than in the other towns named, their formation and repair will form a heavy permanent charge upon the municipal funds. It must not bc forgotten, however, that our streets are nearly level, and that we have close at hand an abundant supply of the very best road metal.

Another table contained in the return shows the financial position of the various municipalties, with their receipts and expenditure. Thc total estimated value of all rateable properly in the colony slightly exceeds three and a-Iialf millions sterling. On this the total amount of rates levied last year was ^16,476. The cash assets of the various municipalties on the date of balancing amounted to .£11,171, while the liabilities and loans reached the

respectable total of ¿£58,852. The total receipts for last year were slightly under .¿55,000, but less titan one-fourtli of this was realised from rates, theGovern mcnt contributing ¿£19,000, and the re- ceipts from other sources, presumably from tolls and dues, being ¿£2 2,000. The rates collected at Brisbane amounted TO J£5348; at Ipswich, .£1000; at Maryborough, ,£761 ; at Rockhampton, ^1741 ; at Toowoomba, 1182; at Mackay, .£510 ; and at Townsville, jCil3- The total receipts for the year from all sources were : By Brisbane, 13,364 ; by Ipswich, .£1407 ; by Mary- borough, ,£10,144; by Rockhampton, .¿6970 : by Toowoomba, 5739 ; by Mackay, .£2712; and by Townsville, ,£1877. These figures indicate that ip regard to population and municipal im- portance Rockhampton still maintains the position of the second town in the colony. It need hardly bc mentioned that of the ,£10,144 received by the Municipal Council of Maryborough last year, the greater portion was on loan account, but how much the return does not clearly show. The rates collected form the best criterion of thc importance of a municipality, and in that respect Rockhampton is far in advance of any other provincial town.
