articleText:
Cí)e §ocíi§!iinj)ton bulletin,

WITH WHICH IS itNCORFOKATKD THK

OL i D STONE OH HER lrR ff.

I

PUBLISKÏÏD DA.rr_.Y~.

MOXDAY, FlCliiiUAUY 23, 1S74.

UNÍIKR tlio head of " Northern Views, liy n Northern Man," n series of articles is now bein;; published in the Brisbane Courier. After the opening remark that a rebound from the Conservative policy of Mr. PALM KU and his colleagues was a natural result of un extension of the representation, the writer, in number one, goes on lo say thal a third party are in process of formation, who may by ingenuity and coalition wield a force very much disproportioned to the num- ber of votes they may record. This party, we are next told, is composed of thc representatives of the vast territory lying to the north of Cape Palmerston. A sketch of the history and character of the country embraced in ibis description follows. The writer attempts lo show that in its pastoral areas, its mineral resources, and its agricultural industry, the north contains the germs of future prosperity and greatness. The

second paper " notes with surprise the ' " appearance, unaccompanied by com- ' " ment or explanation, of a published " memorandum lo the Honorable the " COLONIAL SKCRKTARV, and signed by " three of the representatives of the " northern electorales." The writer admits lite publication to be a certain discourtesy to the high official to whom the document was addressed, and holds that " it displays a want of tact thus to " parade a political programme having " for its object a vital alteration in the " Constitution." livtV after making this admission, he says " the deed having been done, its consequences must be accepted," especially as " there are one " or two resultant advantages accruing " which lo somecxtentcompensale for the " primary indiscretion." The writer next proceeds to give his " views " on the document in a manner which leads to the conclusion that he is one of the famous " triumvirate," and is, in fact, its self consliluted mouth piece for the time being. Il is this last consideration which induces us to make " Northern Views " the subject of an editorial notice.

The whole of the second paper is devoted lo an apology for the memo- randum, and an argument upon its first demand-payment of members, and the abrogation of that clause in the Consti- tution Act which compels representatives on accepting olliee to seek re-election by their constituents. The arguments in favour of these changes, although not new, are marshalled willi fair ability, and if not adopted by the new Ministry, will find many supporters in members repre- senting southern and central con- stituencies. There is nothing dis- tinctively northern in this part of the programme, and therefore it does nol demand further notice here. It is not until we get lo the third paper that the peculiar idiosyncrasies of a " Northern Man " are shadowed forth. Mis argu- ments in favour of financial separation are just a recapitulation of those which have been suited, iterated, and reiterated 'in these columns for years past in advo- cating financial as a prelude lo territorial separation, bul the writer carefully omits to common! upon the objec- tionable and illogical feature of this part of tho northern programme. His reasoning may go lo prove tho necessity of decentralisation, bul we tail to lind in il a single valid argument in favour of financial separation al Cape Palmerston, with a view to the ultim ito removal of tho capital. Such lop sided legislation will certainly nut lind favour with the present Parliament, however stoutly en- forced hythe " ingenuity and coah'jion'' of the newly formed party.

The chango of <¿ipil.il is no new remedy for the grievances of Northern Queensland, but we hav e always failed to perceive the force of the arguments used in its favour. It is scarcely rea- sonable to ask that the grievances of tho small minority in the North shall be re- dressed at the expense of the overwhelm- ing majority in tho South, lt would be a great convenience la the three northern members lo attend a Parliament al lïowoii. but it would homme an intolera- ble grievance with the thirty-nine other members lo be compelled to reside for half tho year in thal remólo place, liven the load representatives of the

Central districts^in which we include Rockhampton, Blackall, Port Curtis, and the five inland electorates of 'which Rockhampton is the port-would find it much more inconvenient and less

agreeable to perform their legislative

ditties at Bowen than at Brisbane. And in lite matter of administration

the proposed change of capital is equally objectionable. Except that thc extreme North may now be cntitjed to another member on thc ground of recent accessions of population, the present distribution of the representation is fail to all parts of the colony. Therefore, just as Brisbane is the most convenient point for the majority in the matter of legislation, it must also be deemed the most convenient in that of administra- tion. Thc arguments against a change of capital lo Howen apply in an inferior degree to Gladstone ami Maryborough ; and on thc whole lhere can be no doubt that Brisbane is the most convenient capital site for the bulk of the popula- tion. In consulting the greatest good of the greatest number, therefore, we shall be obliged to leave the scat of govern- ment for tlie present undisturbed. The time will come, however, and is probably not very far distant, when the conditions will be altogether changed. In a few years it may be expected that Brisbane

«ill cease to be the most convenient

capital for thc majority of thc population, but then if all parts of the colony be fairly represented the required change will be easily made by a vole of the majority in the Legislative Assembly.

When the numerical balance of members is in favour of the North, thc Souih will lind it no longer practicable to retain the «?al of government at lirisbane. For these reasons we conclude that this part

of the northern programme lays down a ! course of action thal is neither just nor politic at the present juncture.

The alternative-territorial separation at Cape Palmerston-is an entirely diffe- rent matter ; bul it will be found equally repugnant to the groat majority of members in the new Assembly. If in

the central districts wc look forward to

the lime when the seat of government shall be removed to a ¿nore convenient position, we can hardly be expected to assent lo a policy which would .preclude all hope of our ever securing the desired change. Our demand in years past was for Separation at Dawes' Range, and for a new colony whose constitution should form a guarantee against the centralisa-

tion of which the northern members

complain. Rightly or wrongly, the petitioners, prayed for the initial establish- ment of provincial institutions. And now that the Imperial Government have refused even to consider the prayer of our petition, our hope is that the rapid How of population northward will be the most certain remedy for existing griev- ances, and the best security for future justice.

We have thus been insensibly led into

the consideration of a " Northern Man's" fourth paper, which we regret lo say is the most injudicious of the series, and is calculated lo rendel' nugatory the " resultant advantages " expected to accrue from the premature publication of the triumvirate programme. After a flippant and disingenuous reference to the Separation movement which originated in former years at Rockhamp- ton, the «Titer says " some fresh excite " ment turned up, and the agitation died " away ;" again, that Mr. FVIT.,

" having obtained half a million of " money for his constituents, dropped " thc question of Separation ;" and, finally, that

*"Tno price of dropping Separation was half a million, but what a wretched view must be entertained of both buyer and seller.

"A very trite proverb tells us, if our own experience fails, that thc love of money glows with possession. Thc venality of a con- stituency once bought is ever assured. Its iulluciieu is a question of valuation, ami there- fore not to be relied upon.

"Separation at Dawes' Hange is desired neither by tho North nor Hockhamptoii. Thc latter is well coûtent to remain an integral part of the colony ; thc former do not wish to include Hockhamptoii, because by ,so doing they would have to embark in a second struggle .to prevent Hockhamptoii from repeating thc evil they now suffer from so far as regards thc position of thc capital."

This gratuitous insult is offered by a

?writer who tells us of the formation of a

third party, whose ingenuity and coalition are to accomplish great things for the

Northern districts. It is difficult here to acquit him of wilful and deliberate misrepresentation, but we are willing to believe that " in ignorance he did it," and that he is still anxious to back up I the ingenuity of the Northern members with the influence of those representing j the Central constituencies. lint unless

the triumvirate display more tact in the legislature than they have in their cxtra ollicial deliverances, it is clear that co- operation with them will be impracticable, and that »lad in garments of Tooley-street manufacture, they will take up their quarters in thal

Cave of- Adullam which Mr. WALSH

formerly occupied with such unenviable distinction, and with so little advantage

lo his constituents.

The reasons why Rockhampton abandoned the Separation movement have been repeatedly slated, and ought to be well known. Firstly, Separation was only urged ;ts a means to an cud - thal end being justice. Secondly, as soon as thc petition was sent home, ami Mr. AKCHKK appointed to lay it "at the fool of the Throne," the local Parlia- ment passed a measure giving substantial guarantees of future justice-we refer

lo the Electoral Districts Arl

of iS/2, which gave lo the country north of Dawes' Range five ailiiition.il representatives, and twelve vciles in a House of forty-two members. Thirdly, the legislature ful- filled a previously disregarded pledge by voling a sum for our railway extension ; and fourthly. Earl KiMiucRl.r.v informed

Mr. ARCHKR that he could not recom- mend Ili.u MAJKSTV to consider our petition until an expression of opinion upon il had been obtained from the Queensland Legislature or Govemmenl. Surely these circumstances fully justified a discontinuance of the separation agitation. Indeed, had it bcea con

linued, the epithets applied to 1

the leaders of thc movement by our southern opponents would not have ? been altogether undeserved. Having

started with tile Announcement that

justice and not Separation was our pri- mary aim, we could not reasonably per- sist after justice was conceded.

With regard lo thc "half-million of money" which appears to be the stumb- ling-block of the northern members, we can only repeat that this part of the colony is prepared to take the full re- sponsibility of that expenditure ; and we have no doubt that the representatives of the constituencies benefiting by the railway will join cordially with thc nor- thern members in passing a measure for equitably re adjusting the loan burdens of the colony. It may also be hoped that the members for the central districts

mil, despite the vagaries of the triumvi- rate, unite heartily with it in demanding

a full share of administrative attention

and expenditure for the "vast territory lying to the north of Cape Palmerston."
heading: The Rockhampton Bulletin, WITH WHICH IS INCORPORATED THE GLADSTONE OBSERVER. PUBLISHED DAILY. MONDAY, FEBRUARY 23, 1874.

articleText:
Cf§c'§ocït|iimjitoi\ bulletin, I

WITH wmcn ts iRconroaiTKD mr. j

GLADSTONE onSKRl'RH.

PUBLISHED DA.ILY".

WEDNESDAY, Al'KIL 2», 1874.

ONE of thc measures which are expected to ensure temporary popularity to the present Ministry is thc " Land Frauds Enquiry Bill of 1874," which was read a first time in the Legislative Assembly on the 15th instant. As may be pre- sumed, it is the long-promised measure which is to compel the dummiers of the Darling Downs to disgorge their ill-gotten principalities. At first sight the bill appears to create a new and inquisitorial tribunal, which ought to bc wholly un- necessary if the Government and the existing law courts did their strict duty. But this both arc said to bc unable to do, and hence the necessity to create a special court, to be presided over by an official created for that purpose, and designated the "Judicial Commis- sioner." This functionary's appointment is to be for a term not exceeding three years, and a " reasonable salary" is to bc paid to him from the Consolidated Revenue. Thus, whatever the effect of the bill, it will certainly provide a snug billet, at a fat salary, for some favoured vrotegé of the powers that be. The bill seems to make no provision for a renewal of the appointment, from which it may be concluded that Mr. STEPHENS expects within three years to extirpate the whole dummy fraternity, in which wc hope he »rill not be so unfortunate as to be dis- appointed.

The Judicial Commissioner will hold inquiries, in open Court, in any of the following cases :

Where any person ia charger! with having obtained a lease of, or possession of Grown land, or any certificate or other document by any violation of, fraud upon, or evasion of any of thc provisions of thc "Agricultural Ueserves Act ot 18G3," ortho " Leasing Act oí lSlili"

or the "Crown Linds Alienation Act of 18GS" or "The Homestead Arcas Act of 1872."

Whore auy person who has obtained any lease, certificate, or other document, not being a deed of grant under the groat seal of tho colony, under any of tho said Acts, is charged with having done or omitted to do anything the doing or omission of which would under tho said Acts or any of them take away or deprive him of the right to such lcaso, certifi- cate, or other document.

Thc GOVERNOR in Council is to ap- point by proclamation the times and i places for holding said enquiries, and the

SECRETARY FOR PUIILIC LANDS is alone

! to be empowered to make charges under

the bill. The charge so made is to briefly set forth thc facts on which the Minister intends to rely, and it is to be signed both by him and the Judicial Commissioner. A copy of the charge is to be served upon the alleged offender, who must lodge a sworn defence in writing at the oflice of the Judicial Commissioner at Brisbane within ten days after service. Appended to the form of charge is a notification that in default of a written defence being lodged as re- quired, tile Commissioner will proceed to hold the enquiry ex part*. The Commissioner may, however, at his dis- cretion, allow a defence to be put in at any time before the final decision. Service may be made either personally, or al the delinquent's usual place of abode ; and in the event of service personally or at his residence being impracticable, it is provided that the charge may be made through the Government Qazctt-c and two Brisbane newspapers. One would have thought the local newspapers the most suitable vehicles, but the author of the Bill, we suppose, must be credited with superior intelligence upon that point.

Thc Commissioner is to be endowed with all the powers and authorities of Judges of the Supreme Court, for com- pelling the attendance of witnesses, the production of deeds and documents, and so on; and any witness refusing to answer any question, give evidence, pro- duce documents, or make any disclosure relating to such inquiry, is to be liable to twelve months' imprisonment, and a fine not exceeding j£iooo. Thc evi- dence taken at such inquiries, however, is not to bc receivable in any court ol

criminal jurisdiction. The Com- missioner is empowered to permit amendments in thc charge or de- fence, and may, at his discretion, award costs to either party. All wit- nesses are lo be examined on oath, and the Commissioner is lo be guided by equity and good conscience without regard to legal forms and ceremonies. Tlie statements contained in the charge are also lo be taken as prima jac'w. proof " of the facts in such charge stated, and " the burthen of proof in all cases shall " lie upon the person charged." This looks very much like an adaptation from the Frencli criminal law, and it is not likely to be sanctioned in the Legislature

without some acrimonious debate and

personal recrimination.

Clause 2i is hardly less offensive, as placing the defendant entirely at thc mercy of a possibly biased official. It

runs thus :»

21. If unou any inquiry tho Commissioner aimil he satisfied that thc lease or possession

of any lam!, or the certificate, or other docu- ment referred to in any charge, lias been ob- tained by the person charged, by any violation of fraud upon, or evasion of, any of the provi- sions of thc said Acts, or that the right to any lease, certificate, or other document as afore- said, has been lost or forfeited by means of any such act or omissiou, as in the fourth sec-

tion hereinbefore mentioned, the Cummis sionur shall, by order under his hand and seal, declare such lease to bc forfeited, and such land to be vacant Crown lands, subject to tho Acts in force relating to Crown lands, or such loaso certificate or other document to be void ami of no effect.

The next clause empowers the Com-

missioner to issue lu's warrant to the Sheriff to deliver possession of the land so declared to be vacant to thc persons appointed in such warrant to receive the same ; and by the next following clause the charge, defence, and decision of the Commissioner are to be lodged in and become records of the Supreme Court.

Subsequent clauses provide for appeals j to the GovEKNOR-in-Council ; and for the j

protection of bona fide transfers for valu- able consideration, even though the lands may have originally been acquired by violation of, fraud upon, or evasion of the law,-though it is enacted that no such breach, fraud, or evasion shall be taken to bc waived by lapse of time, acceptance of rent, or notice of such breach, fraud, or evasion. It is also provided that all the powere of thc Government under the existing Acts and regulations are to be preserved without

abridgement or interference. It is also 1 provided that rules may be made by the Commissioner, to be approved by the GovF.RNOR-in-Council, for carrying ont the provisions of the new statute.

That in the event of this bill becoming law a remedy will bc provided against the evil of dummying may perhaps be admitted. Hut there is too much reason to fear that the "Judicial Commissioner" will be selected because of the sound- ness of his opinions upon the land question; that inquiries may be so ordered as to vex and worry political opponents ; and that, while the law may hamper the great monopolist, it may also become a means of oppressing the struggling settler who in the hope of improving his condition of life has perhaps unconsciously violated some provision of the land laws. It may be admitted that the intentions of the present MINISTER FOR LANDS are good, but his new law must be one for both

rich and poor alike, and although the Minister alone can set the machinery in motion, the public will not tolerate its partial administration. If applied at all, its provisions must be brought to bear upon all classes of offenders, and it therefore becomes a question whether thc benefit it is likely to confer will not be more than balanced by the general harrassment and uncertainty of tenure which it will carry in its train. Were the inquiries conducted personally by the Minister, there would be direct responsibility to Parliament, but the Commissioner will be an irresponsible functionary, and against his decision there will be practically no appeal. The fact that all inquiries are to be held in open court is the only guarantee of strict justice afforded by the bill, but even that is insufficient where the judge is the servant of the plaintiff. It would be rash to venture an opinion as to the probability of the measure becoming law, but it is tolerably certain that its course through both Houses will be contested inch by inch.

Upon their success in passing this Frauds j

Hill and the Land Sales Bill the fate of

the Ministry unmjslakeably hangs, and

no one who has watched the course of

land legislation in the colonies would be surprised at an appeal to the country

being necessary to solve the knotty j questions suggested by these twin

measures.

Wr. understand tLat the Police Magistrate j has written to thc authorities, at tho instiga- j tion ot th« Health Oflieer. drawing their j attention to thc dilapidated condition of thc weatherboard shod, dignified in these Franco English times by the expression-morgue. The fences enclosing tho structure arc very much ont of repair, and the building itself, in

its present stato especially, is a positive dis- j grace to the town. !

Tur. sale of general merchandise in thc estate of tho late Mr. H. .1. Robinson com- mences this looming at thc stores of Messrs. J. Palmer and Co., iu KiUroy-strcet. The stock to bo disposed of is larger and moro valuable than was ever submitted to public competition on any picvions oeeasion in Rock- hampton, thc catalogue numbering 117Ü lots. Thc salo is to be "entirely without reserve," and will, of necessity occupy a long time. Luuohcou will be provided, at one o'clock for j thc accommodation of persons in attendance.

THK body of Thomas Lawlor, ono of the persons who was drowned in thc Fitzroy cally ou Sunday last, by thc accidental upsetting of a boat, was fouud yesterday morning floating in tbe river some distance below thc steam dredge by a man named Archibald M'Millan.

With the assistance of Samuel Reilly, mate of thc schooner Flirt, he succeeded in bringing thc l»dy to thc wharf, where it was handed over to thc care of the police who conveyed it to thc morgue. During thu morning it was viewed by thc witnesses amt identified. A magisterial inquiry was huid iu the afternoon at the Court-house, before Mr. V. TH. UeiMek, a report of which will bo seen in another ' column.

articleText:
Cjje ^ocïî|anijîto« bulletin,

WITH Willen fa l«CORPOt*TKD THF.

GLADSTONE O BUB EV EB.

PUBLISHED D A-ILiV.

SATURDAY, MAY 23, 1874.

THE anniversary tea meeting of the Grace- mere Church will bo held on Wednesday evening next, the 27th instant. A public meeting will he held after toa, and a special train will bo provided for tho convenience of

visitors.

AT the Police Court yesterday morning, be- fore the Police Magistrate, one drunkard was discharged with a caution, and an inmate of the Lunatic Reception House named Christian- sen, was discharged to the care of his friends upon the evidence of Dr. Salmond. The Police Magistrate and Mr. Frank N. Beddck were the sitting magistrates iu the latter case.

IT would seem from our parliamentary telegrams, that thc Denominationalists in the House of Assembly last night, in committee on thc non-vested Schools Abolition Bill made, as it was expected they would do, a very obstinate stand against the passing of thc bill, and succeeded in extorting a compromise to the effect that aid to present non-vested schools shall not cease in December 1870, but in June, 1880, thus enabling them to continue their drafts on the public Treasury in support of religions sectarianism for a period of three years and a-half longer than thc time proposed in thc original bill. Wc think that tho time allowed by Mr. Griffith was amply sufficient, and tho further extension conceded in com-

mittee is simply preposterous. It is perfectly clear that tho question was mainly influenced by political considerations, and was not

decided on its merits.

THERE was an excellent attendance at the

Theatre Royal last night, thc reserved and front scats being nearly all occupied, while thc body of thc houBo was comfortably filled. The bill of tho previous evening was repeated -Lord Lytton's play of tho "Lady of Lyona " forming the first part of thc enter- tainment. We have said that Miss Gougen* heim's conception of tho character of Pauline Deschappelles, thc proud but loving woman, is perfect, and her rendering of thc author's Ircautiful and impassioned language a masterly specimen of oloeution, and her efforts last night confirmed this opinion. The manage- ment have rc-openol the William-street entrance to thc reserved and front scats

aud have made them very comfortable by the addition of carpeting and other minor improvements. To-night, thc popular comedy of " Who killel Cock Robin " will be per- formed, with Miss Gmigcnhcim as Satanella. Thc Scotch drama of "Cramond Brig" is also announced, in which two newly arrived actresses-tho Misses Wilson-will take part, whilo Mr. Thomson will personate Jock

Howieson.

COLONIAL.

GEORGETOWN. .

Tuesday. -

ONE thousand ounces of gold llave been lodged in the Bank during the week.

All kinds oí provisions arc plentiful, except- ing beef.

. Twelve primula have been offered for bullocks iand refused, their owners preferring to drive

articleText:
THE ROCKHAMPTON BULLETIN

WITH WHICH IS INCORPORATED THE

GLADSTONE OBSERVER

PUBLISHED DAILY

SATURDAY, APRIL, 4, 1874

TELEGRAPHIC DESPATCHES.

COLONIAL.

COOKTOWN.

VIA TOWNSVILLE, Thursday, 9:30 a.m.

The following vessels are now in port :- The Boomerang, Wonga Wonga, Arakoon, and Bunyip, steamers ; the Young Australian, Currambene, Kishon, and Southern Cross, schooners ; and numerous small craft besides. All of them brought horses and passengers.

The news from the diggings is very dis- couraging. There is no food to be had.

Heavy rains have fallen again the last few days.

The horse market is very low, owing to large

arrivals.

Flour is easier for the present, but there is no quantity in stock. In a few days again present stocks will be absorbed. Great com- plaints are made against the merchants in the south for not sending more provisions

The brig Minora is on a reef. The Boome- rang, s.s., will call to render assistance.

Mulligan's prospecting party will leave to-day for the new ground which has been discovered thirty miles higher up the Palmer from the present workings. They are confi- dent of finding good payable gold.

Great numbers are leaving Cooktown for

the Palmer.

A local hospital is about to be established, eighty pounds were collected for it in one night.

Great dissatisfaction is expressed here at the delay of the land sale.

Fresh meat is more plentiful now, the butchers lowored their prices to-day. Beef is ten-pence per pound, and mutton is plenti- ful, such as it is, at one shilling.

Mr. F.J. W. Beardmore has started business here as shipping agent, and is doing well.

Mr. Henriques has built the first wharf.

Mr. Fountain, the engineer, is here, for the purpose of erecting government wharves.

The Cooktown Herald is much appreciated, although small.

There is to be a meeting to-night to petition the government for a municipality. The Surveyor's plans will go down by the Wonga Wonga, s.s.

The steamers Boomerang and Victoria leave for the south to-day.

Great dissatisfaction is expressed at the irregular communication with Rockhampton, nothing having reached us from that port since

the Leichhardt.

We have received Rockhampton papers to March 13, and Sydney papers to March 18.

The weather is very cool ; the average temperature last month was eighty degrees. The nights and mornings are very cool, and there is an entire absence of mosquitoes.

Friday.

Vessels are arriving here daily with large

numbers of horses and passengers, but no cargo.

There is a great dearth of provisions, and famine prices prevail.

There has been no bread here for the last fortnight. The last shipment of flour arrived

by the Henry Albert, cutter. It is selling at Townsville prices nominal.

There are 3000 people here who are are half

starved, and great misery will arise if the rush is not stopped.

The telegram from Brisbane in the S. M. Herald of March eighteenth issue is incorrect. No such quantity has arrived. Twenty thousand ounces gives a great margin for all the gold purchased in Cooktown.

There are plenty of men on the ground at present to test the field.

Sickness and privations, extensively prevail. Robberies on an extensive scale are per- petrated every night by a gang of Sydney scoundrels. They stupify their victims with

chloroform.

A line quartz reef has been discovered at the Palmer, splendid specimens from which are now on view at the Australian Joint Stock

Bank.

Great complaints are made against the Government for not making a dray road.

There is a splendid opening here for horse and bullock teams, but especially the latter.

The Victoria, s.s.takes 3000 ounces of gold.

For timber and general provisions there is a great demand, and merchants cannot go wrong, in particular we mention there is a splendid market for flour, which is selling at forty pounds per ton.

The rate of packing for the Palmer is two shillings per pound.

(r!)c||o(í{(j¡itnp(oit bulletin,

ff I Til ITU ICU li IKCORrOKiTP.I) THU

GL A OS TO NW OBSKIiriCR.

PUBLISH!ED DAILY.

FRIDAY, JULY 10, 1874.

NEVER was any measure subjected to snell rough handling in the Queensland Parliament, as the Land Bill of Mr. STEPHENS. In the first place, members

had to be assured before taking it in | hand, that they might alter it to please their fancy, save the provision for the re- sumption of the ten years' leases in the Settled Districts. The House certainly used the liberty thus given with great freedom, and patched and cobbled the bill almost clause by clause before they could make up their minds to let it pass. However, it did in a manner pass thc Lower House ; but only to undergo even rougher treatment in the Council.' On Wednesday, the Council were in committee on the bill, and made "numerous amendments," not sparing intact the one vital provision which Mr. STEPHENS had so carefully guarded in the Commons. For we leam that an amendment was made in the

ninth clause, which provided for the resumption of the leased halves, stipu- lating that by way of compensation for the cancellation of leases, the lessee shall be permitted to select one-tenth of thc land resumed. The.Hcusc seems to have shirked the direct responsibility of rejecting the bill altogether by making

an amendment which the Government cannot accept. The bill in its emasculated slate has been referred back to thc Assembly, where it was last night under discussion, and we learn that the principal amendments made by the Upper House were being rejected. The upshot of all this will surely be that the

Crown Lands Sale Bill will meet with a j similar fate to that which overtook its

kindred measure, the Land Frauds \ Bill, at an earlier period of the session. And so the Land policy of the present Government will pass'away to be no more seen.-At least we fervently hope

so.

THE report of the Chief Inspector of Distilleries for the year ending 31st Mardi, 1873, indicates that sugar grow- ing continues to progress, and gives promise of soon becoming one of our most jmportanl industries. The quantity of rum distilled during the year was 164,413 gallons, just half of which was manufactured in the Maryborough district. At Mackay, where the produce of sugar was 325z tons, only 49,000 gallons of rum was distilled, while at Maryborough thc yield of sugar was only 2196, though the rum produced was 83,000 gallons. The Inspector says thc contrasl is remarkable, and attempts to account for it by the luxuriant growth of cane in the rich scrub soil of

me Maryborough district and thc more extended use of the vacuum pa» on thc Mackay plantations. No distilling has yet taken place in the districts lo thc north of Mackay, but it is expected that tliey before long will be included amongst the licensed distilling districts. The yield of sugar has increased from (>zG(> tons in 1872-3 to 7987 tons in 1873-4. Thc greatest increase is sh omi al Mackay, but proportionately Cardwell, which produced only 38 tons in 1S72, and 290 in 1873-4, shows thc greatest progress. The Chief Inspector

anticipates that the coming season will ? show a total of to,ooo tons, worth, at j £:¡ per ton all round, £250,000. This displays a rate of progress which must bc highly gratifying, seeing that in 1868 the total yield of sugar was only 619

tons. Il may be hoped thal some of1

our landowners will take steps to intro-

duce the cultivation and manufacture of sugar into the Rockhampton district, now that the famous dry-belt bugbear has been exploded. That this valuable product may be profitably grown here no one acquainted with its cultivation in otherparts of the colony appears to doubt. Had half the money been invested in sugar that we have squandered in quartz our district would be in a much more prosperous condition than it is at pre-

sent,

i ' "
